If enye man wole wite whi y make þis book and oþire Where the reasons for writing in English may be found. bokis in þe comoun peplis langage, turne he into þe v first chapitris of þe book clepid 'afore crier' and into þe first prolog of þe book clepid 'cristen religioun', and þere he mai see þerof þe causis, See Gairdner's monograph on the Reule, pp. 18-20: 'It is principally to rebuke the presumption of two sorts of people. One of these foolishly hold only to the use of the Bible in their mother tongue, especially the New Testament, and "daren all other books" written in Latin or in the common tongue "to be writun into waast; and not only into waast but into marryng and cumbryng of Cristen mennes wittis". They think other studies at schools a deceit into which men are led by the Fiend . . . . Another sort, besides studying the Bible, especially the New Testament, in their mother tongue, approve the reading of other books in English, and recommend, as far as they dare for fear of their prelates, unsavoury books in their mother tongue as noble, worthy and profitable for Christian men's learning, though some of them teach untruly and perilously the matters taken in hand. But this book, the Donet, and the others above named, ought to make them ashamed', &c. whiche, as y trust, ben of god and of eche man allowable and preisable.

The e is underdotted to denote dele∣tion. ben receiued in grete fauour, for þe good and profitable trouþis whiche ben in hem, þouȝ manye defautis be þerwiþ founde in hem, for to noon it is ȝouun forto knowe al. for þis and for alle oþir goddis ȝiftis, to him be preising and þanking, honour and glory, his plesaunt
seruice to him fulfilling and paiyng of al his peple, treuly, dewly, deuoutly and fully. amen. for þis ... amen. These exact words occur at the end of the Prologue to the Reule; cf. Gairdner's monograph, p. 28.

And, for as moche as ouer long it were me to declare now Pecock has made 'a litil book to be a declara∣tive' of the extent to which it is advisable to learn and pub∣lish truths imperfectly understood. and heere how hard it is to knowe treuþis in þis lijf, and how litil surete is in þe knowing of trouþis in þis lijf, and ȝitt þat neuerþeles bettir it is a man leerne hem so þan to lack al, and bettir it is a man forto write and teche what and how he kan fynde into profityng þan forto le∣ve alle suche þingis vnwritun and vntauȝt, ffor ellis manye ful profitable bokis And of the extent to which it is permissible to hold various opinions at various times. schulde we into þese daies haue lackid; And for as moche as whanne in a mater MS. amater. ben dyuers opyniouns, and mowe be mo opyniouns, it is honest ynouȝ a man MS. aman. to speke and write aftir oon of þo opyniouns, and an oþire tyme to vttre þe Because it would take too long to explain every time the exact way in which one's words should be taken; oþire opinioun; And also for as moche as ouer long it were forto parfitli denounce and notifie vndir what entent y seie and write al what y haue, or schal seie or write, and how y wole and entende þat it be take of þe heerers and reders; And also for as moche as neuere man ȝitt wroote enye notable book whiche couþe so suerli sett his wordis þat noon in∣pugnacioun and because objections are certain to be made against any teaching; couþe be made þere aȝens, as in a litil tretice y so lenger teche; þerfore y haue made a litil book to be a declarative See Notes. of þese pointis and of mo, aȝens envie and therefore the 'litil book to be a declarative' has been made. detraccioun and malice, whiche perauenture myȝt rise into summe heerers or reders being moche redier forto suche writingis lette and distroie þan forto enye suche bi her owne laboure fynde, make and multiplie into good occupacioun for cristen lay men, þat þei bi reeding þerinne disseuere hem silf þe more fro þe worlde and þe fleisch, and þe nyȝer and þe oftir and þe sweetlier knytte hem and couple hem to god and to his wel willingis, as forto be a bilowe MS. abilowe. to blowe and puffe vp þe fier of deuocioun in her soule, into banysching aweie þe coolde of vndeuocioun and of vncharite, whiche coolde is modir of moche myslyuing, as þe contrarye heet is modir of moche good lyuing.

'þe donet of cristen religioun' and 'þe book of cristen Pecock will not be responsible for books circu∣lated against his wish, until they have received his final correc∣tions. religioun' and oþire suche of doctrine and of officiyng whiche,
bifore þe deuyce and setting of þis present book, ben runne abrood and copied aȝens my wil and myn entent, as y haue openli prechid at poulis, and þat bi vncurtesie and vndis∣crecioun of freendis, into whos singuler siȝt y lousid þo writingis to go, and forto not haue go ferþir into tyme þei were bettir examyned of me and approvid of my lordis and fadris of þe churche, y wole to be as noon of myn; but in as | moche as in me is, y wole þei be rendrid vp aȝen, and bettir formes of þe same be to hem deliuered, whanne dewe deliueraunce þerof schal be made.

Bettir am not y þan was holy seynt Gregory (wolde god Even Saint Gregory made errors, and had detractors. y were a quartir so good) whiche, not wiþstonding hise holy ententis and hise kunnyng, founde so moche mys disposid men forto lette and diffame and distroie his bokis þan forto make a quartir so moche of writing into chering of cristen soulis, þat he wolde not þat eny of his bokis schulde be publischid bifore his deeþ, as it is write in his lijf. ȝhe, and aftir his deeþ, summe of þis bokis were bi suche now seide men brent, and mo schulde of hise bokis be brend, if help of god had not be prouidid. and ȝit y wote weel þat, if bisy and sutil inpugnaciouns schulden be made aȝens hise bokis, or aȝens austyns, or eny oþire holy seintis bokis, scant ynouȝ oon leef schulde stonde vnprovid or colowrabily vnrebukid. But what were þis panne? forto prouoke þat no writing were had, or rad, or occupied into goostli feeding and edifiyng of cristen soulis? A symple and a litil leerned man in carpentrie kanne, and may fynde a defaute in a kingis palice made to þe kingis worschip and eese, whiche is not able to make a pore coote for MS. cootefor. þe eese and þe chering of a begger. þus moche herof as now. more is seide in þe litil book bifore spokun i. e. the 'declarative'; see above, p. 6..

Siþen seint Jerom had manye detractouris and inpugners Also Saint Jerome. of hise writingis, as he him silf witnessiþ, what merveyle is if y so haue? And siþen ful manye famose doctouris wri∣tingis On the other hand, many writers are revered for their merits, notwith∣standing their occasional errors. ben had in greet deynte and in greet profite in þe chirche of god, and ben wel and profitabli suffrid to be red and occupied, not wiþstonding þat, here and þere among, þei
fallen fro it þat myȝt be bettir seid, and whiche þei myȝten Why should it not be so with Pecock? not at þe fulle comprehende, what merveile were it þouȝ it so falle by me, whiche entende not forto euen me to hem, but forto be a profitable procutoure to lay men, into whoos leerning and ediflyng, as to me semeþ, ouer litil writing into þis tyme | haþ be deuysid?

Alle inpugners whiche laboren bi gile and wijle to make May God amend the ways of envious detractors! her inpugnacioun seme good bifore þe multitude of lay men, and at temperal lordis eeris, and at multitude of clerkis not scolid in dyuynite, or not profundeli endewid in dyuynite, how euer it be of her degree in scole, or state in þee chirche, and alle þo whiche bi detraccioun and diffame, pride, sturdy herte and envie, sp[e]ken MS. spoken. and writen in stide of clergie, god amende for charite.
Here eendith þe prolog of þis book. And here bigynniþ þe first chapitre of þis present book.

DIV3.HEAD: [ie chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, what is a man? The definition of a MAN.
Sone, a man is a quick body, y-made of a resonable soule and a fleischly body.
ffadir, what is a resonable soule?

Sone, a resonable soule is þilk soule which, ouer þat it The definition of a reasonable SOUL. It works, not only by (1) FIVE OUT∣WARD BODILY WITS, and (2) FIVE INWARD BODILY WITS, but also by (3) REASON, and (4) FREE WILL. worchiþ bi v outward bodily wittis wiþ her appetitis or lustys, bi v inward bodili wittis with her appetitis or lustys in þe body, it haþ in it silf resoun and fre wil, with whiche þe hool man resonyþ and fre williþ in him silf and in his soule.
ffadir, was þe soule of a man eer þan it was couplyd to þe The soul is made at the same time as the body. same mannys body? For fuller teaching, see Folewer, Pt. I, chap. iv.
Nai, sone, eche soule is made in þe body in þe same poynt and pricke of tyme in whiche it is couplid and joinyd to þe body. and þis is trewe boþe of mennys soulis and of beestys soulis.
ffadir, schal þe soule of a man dye and come to nouȝt, The soul of a man shall never die. whanne þat we seen þilk man daie? For fuller teaching, see Folewer, Pt. I, chap. iv.

Nai, sone, þe soule of man schal neuere deie. But whanne
þe soule of man is departid from þe body, þanne þe man deieþ. but þe soule so departid from þe body abidiþ in him silf, riȝt as an aungel is in him silf wiþoute body, where god wole þat þilk soule be. And it schal eft soone in þe eende of þis worlde be couplyd aȝen to þe body, forto dwelle so euere to gidere in ioye or in peyne, as þe man in þis lijf schal deserue.
ffadir, schal þe soule of a beest abyde and be departid The soul of a beast dies when the beast dies. from þe body, whanne þe beest | dieþ? Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chap. iv.
Nai, sone, eche beestis soule dieþ and comeþ to nouȝt, whanne þe beest dieþ.
ffadir, whiche ben þe v outward bodili wittis? Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chap. v. The FIVE OUT∣WARD BODILY WITS enumerated.
Sone, þese ben þei: Seyng, heering, Smelling, Taasting and touching.
ffadir, whiche ben þe v inward bodili wittis? Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chap. vi. The FIVE IN∣WARD BODILY WITS. enumerated.
Sone, þese ben þei: Comoun witt, ymaginacioun, ffantasye, Estimacioun and mynde.
ffadir, what is þe office MS. officie; the second i underdotted. of þe v outward bodili wittis? The office of the five outward bodily wits described.

Sone, it is forto knowe bodili þingis in her presence, and whilis þei ben in kynde. As it is forto se þingis present to þe siȝt, heere þe sown present to þe After þe, MS. has h, crossed through. eeris, touche hardnesse, neischnes, heet, or coold present to þe touche, and so forþe of oþire.
ffadir, what is þe office of inward bodili wittis? Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chap. vi, and see Donet, Notes to p. 10. The office of the five inward bodily wits described.

Sone, it is forto knowe alle þe same bodily þingis þouȝ þei ben absent, and þouȝ þei ben not in kynde; riȝt as y knowe now my fadir, or his schap, figure and colour, not withstonding he is deed; and as y knowe now a beest, or his schap, figure and colour, which y siȝe at rome, whanne y was þere; and so of oþire þingis knowable bi outward wittis.
ffadir, what is þe office of comoun witt in specialle? The office of COMMON WIT described.

Sone, it perceyueth alle suche þingis in her absence whiche mowe be knowun of outwarde wittis in her oonli presence. And he perceiueþ and knowiþ alle suche bodili þingis of
whiche eche may be perceiued of dyuers outward wittis, as The 'Common Sensibles': motion, rest, size, number, and figure. ben þese v: mouing, reste, greetnes, noumbre and figure. And also he iugith and deemeþ bitwix þo þinges, whiche þingis noon oon outward witt may knowe, and þerfore noo oon outward witt may iuge and deeme bitwix hem: as ben whitnes and swetenes, hardnes and sowrnes, and so of oþire diuersitees. ffor siþen siȝt may not knowe and perceiue boþe to gider whitnes and swetenes, he mai not discrive and juge þe diuersite bitwix hem. And siþen touche mai not knowe and perceyue to gider boþe hardnes and sourenes, He mai not discryue and iuge þe diuersite bitwix hardnes and sourenes. And þerfore it was necessarie to haue oon witt which myȝt so bitwixe | hem iuge and discrive, and of hem knowe þe difference and þe diuersitee. which oon witt is þe now seid commune witt.
ffadir, what is þe office of þe ymaginacioun? The office of IMAGINATION described.

Sone, it is al þe same whiche is seid of commune witt, and for to kepe in store alle þe same now seid knowingis wiþ her fundamentis, whiche ben callid 'similitudis', 'liknessis', or 'ymagis' of þingis, þat þei falle not soon aweie.
ffadir, what is þe office of þe fantasie? The office of FANTASY described.

Sone, it is forto forge and compowne, or to MS. orto. sette to gedir in seemyng, þingis whiche ben not to gedir, and whiche maken not oon þing in kynde: As if a man feyn a beest to be made of an horsis heed and of a kowys body and of a lyouns taile, and so forþ MS. soforþ. of oþire masis whiche bifallen in dreemys, whilis a man slepiþ. ffor in tyme of sleep a mannys MS. amannys. inward bodily wittis ben breemest and to wirche rediest, and her worchingis ben to be perceyued sunnest.
ffadir, what is þe office of estimacioun? The office of ESTIMATION described.

Sone, it is forto perceiue accordaunt þingis or discordaunt þingis, to kynde freendeful or odiose, þouȝ þei mowe not be perceyued bi outward bodili wittis: as herbi þe lombe knowiþ and fleeþ naturali þe malice and enemyte of þe wolfe; And þe swalow bildiþ in þis curiose manere, whiche is moost profitable maner to her kynde, her nest; And þe
bees knowen þat þis maner of gouernaunce to chese hem a king is to hem good; and so forþ of oþir lijk.
ffadir, what is þe office of MS. of þe: þe underdotted. mynde? The office of MIND described.

Sone, it is to kepe in in over-written in MS. store alle þe forseid knowingis wiþ her groundis, þat þei liȝtli not aweie slyde, and þerwiþ forto worche alle þe same now rehercid inward worchingis of þe oþire seid inward bodily wittis, wiþ þe seid sure keping.
ffadir, in what placis of mannys body ben þese v inward The five inward bodily wits are in the head. bodili wittis? Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chap. vii.
Sone, þei ben in a mannys heed.
ffadir, what wise? The positions of the five inward bodily wits described.

Sone, commune witt is placid in þe forhede. ymaginacioun is in a selle next aftir MS. aftirward; ward being crossed through and underdotted. folewing, toward þe myddis of þe heed. þanne next is placid ffan∣tasie, in þe myddis of þe heed. And nexte to him is sett estimacioun, toward þe hindre eende of þe heed. And mynde is sette in þe nolle bihinde. And eche of þese han to hem her propre chaumbres in þe brayn, or propre cellis or placis, as philosophris seyn.

The v outward wittis ben in diuers parties of a mannys The positions of the five outward wits described. body. ffor siȝt is in þe iȝen, heering in þe eeris, smelling is in þe nose, taastyng is in þe mouþe, touching in þe nett of sinowis wouun, as it were, þoruȝ al þe fleisch of þe body.

ffadir, haþ oonly man alle þese now seid outward and Has man alone these outward and inward wits and their appetites? inward worchyngis of bodili wittis, wiþ her appetitis to desire what is bi enye of hem perceiuid to be plesaunt and lusty, or for to refuse and loþe what is bi eny of hem perceyuid to be displesaunt and vnlusti?

Nai, sone, not oonli man haþ alle þese now seid outward Most beasts have the five outward bodily wits, and the five inward bodily wits, with their workings and appetites. and inward bodili wittis, wiþ her seid worchingis and wiþ her seid appetitis; but also alle þe same han manyefoold beestis, and wel nyȝe alle parfit beestis whiche mowe hem silf parfitly helpe and move from oon place into anoþir. For Moving, see Folewer, Pt. I, chap. vii.

ffadir, wherynne MS. wherynne ″dooþ a man ′þan, with marks of transposition. þan dooþ a man MS. wherynne ″dooþ a man ′þan, with marks of transposition. and his soule passe alle beestis and her soulis?

Certis, sone, in þis: þat a man and his soule han resoun Boasts have neither Reason nor Free Will, therein differing from man. and fre wil, fforwhi neuere neiþir of þese ij powers is had of beestis of her soulis. In the Folewer, Pt. I, chap. viii, it is admitted that the higher animals can probably reason to a certain extent.

ffadir, what is resoun, and what is his office? The office of REASON de∣scribed. (1) The name 'Reason' (or 'Understand∣ing') may be applied to the power which enables man to perceive spiritual substances and properties, to judge be∣tween good and bad, &c.

Sone, resoun is a power, with whiche power mowe be knowe vnbodili þingis, goostli or spiritual þingis, wheþir þei ben substauncis, as ben aungels and soulis, or þei ben to oþire substauncis accidentis or fallyngis, as ben powers, pro∣purtees and worchingis of aungels and of soulis, And also manye oþir vnbodili propurtees of bodili þingis, whiche neiþir þe outward, neiþir þe inward bodili wittis afore MS. a fore. seid mowe perceyue and knowe, as ben hefte and liȝtnes of bodies, fadirho∣de and sonehode, of persoones to gider husbondhode and wijfhode, and oþire manye suche; And also wiþ which power may be dryue oute and founden in arguyng and concluding what is trewe, what is fals, what is good, and what is bad, and what is more good, and what is more bad, and what is cheseable, and what is refuseable, and which ben meenys to haue þe good and fle þe yuel. And þis same now seid power of oure soule whiche is now clepid 'resoun', is also ful ofte clepid 'vndirstonding', so þat resoun and vndirstonding is al oon.

In anoþir maner 'resoun' is oft takun for þe worchingis (2) The name 'Reason' may be applied to the works done by the said power—to proofs, argu∣ments, &c. and þe doingis of þe resoun now bifore in þe first manere takun: as ben argumentis, profis, skilis and euidencis, which resoun, in þe first maner takun, fyndiþ, conceiueþ and formeþ. and in þis maner 'resoun' is takun in commune speche, whanne we seien þus: 'þis is a good resoun', 'þilk is a feble resoun', 'þis resoun is nouȝt', 'I prove þis to be trewe, or to be fals, bi þis resoun', and so forþ of manye oþire like spechis. FREE WILL and its office de∣scribed. (1) The name 'Free Will' may be applied to the power which wills, refuses, com∣mands, &c., according to the judgement of Reason.
ffadir, what is fre wil, and whiche is his office?

Sone, fre wil is a power, MS. apower. wiþ whiche may freely be lovyd and chosen þat þing whiche resoun knowith and demeþ to be good; And wiþ whiche may freely be hatid and refusid þat þing whiche resoun knowiþ and deemeþ to be bad, or vngood; And whiche mai commaunde to alle oþire witti
and moving powers of þe soule and to alle membris of þe body þat þei passe forþ into her such witty and moving propir wirchingis in maner as þe wil hem to wirche comaundiþ.

And in lijk maner as now bifore it is seid þat dedis of (2) Or the name 'Free Will' may be applied to the works done by this power. resoun ben clepid 'resouns', so dedis of þe wil ben oft tymes clepid 'willis', As whanne men wolen seie þus: 'þis is my wil þat þou go forþ', and so forþ of oþire herto like.

In þese ij seid powers, resoun and wil, and in her now A man should be governed principally by Reason and Free Will. seid worchingis, a man passiþ beestis. And for | þese ij powers, a mannys soule is a resonable and a fre chesing soule, and þerfore bi þese ij powers ouȝte euery man be principaly gouerned: þat is to seie, euer to loue, hate, chese, refuse, and commaunde to oþire sensual and moving powers of þe soule and to membris of þe body forto do and suffre, aftir þe doom of resoun, and neuere to loue, hate, chese, refuse, commawnde to oþire powers or parties forto do or suffre, aȝens þe doom of resoun. and so folewiþ ferþir þat, how oft and whanne euere a man avisingli and chesingli loueþ or hatiþ, chesiþ or refusiþ, doiþ or suffriþ, aȝens þe doom of resoun, so ofte and þanne he lyueþ beestly and not manly, neiþir as it is according a man to lyue; and þerfore in þat he synneþ aȝens þe lawe of his ouerer and worþier kynde.

ffadir, in what place of a mannys body ben sett resoun Reason and Free Will shall abide with the soul per∣petually, be∣cause they are of the substance of the soul, not of the substance of the body. and fre wil?

Certis, sone, in no place of mannys body fyxli or assigna∣bili; ffor þei ben in þe substaunce of þe soule, whiche soule is ouer al, þoruȝ al mannys body; and þerfore þei ben where euer þe soule be, and so in noon oon place of þe body stedely; and þerfore þei abiden wiþ þe soule and in þe soule perpetualy, þouȝ þe soule be departid from þe body, and þouȝ þe soule eftsoon schal be cowplyd aȝen to þe body, riȝt as resoun and wil ben euer perpetuali in an aungel, þouȝ he haue no body. But þe afore seid witty powers, þat But the five outward and five inward wits shall die with the body, be∣cause they are inextricably connected with the body. is to seie, þe v outward wittis with her v appetitis, and þe v inward wittis wiþ her v appetitis, schulen not abide with a mannes soule whanne he schal be departid from þe body; but þei schulen vanysche aweie and come into nouȝt See Notes.; and þat bi cause þei ben not placid or sitting in þe soule, but þei
ben placid and sitting in diuerse parties of þe body, so þat ech of þe seid x wittis haþ his propre partie of þe body assigned to him; þouȝ þe touche, wiþ his appetite, haþ þe largist partie, for welnyȝ, except þe boonys, he haþ al þe body.

And where euere enye of þese seid x wittys sittiþ in þe The Wits have their corre∣sponding 'appetites'. Free Will is the proper 'appe∣tite' of the Reason. body, þere wiþ him, þoruȝ þe same partie of þe bodi, sittiþ wiþ him his propre | to him assigned appetite. And riȝt as eche of þe seid x wittis haþ his propre appetite, so þe wil is þe propre appetite of þe resoun, and þei abiden to gider in þe soule departid from þe body.

Profis of þe trouþis whiche ben rehercid schortly here in Proofs of these truths will be found in the Folewer, Pt. I, chaps. iii-viii. þis present first chapitre, þou maist se, sone, if þou wolte, in þe first partie of 'þe folewer to þe donet', from þe bigynnyng of þe [iiij] MS. iij. chapitre þere into þe eende of þe viij chapitre þere, with answers to certeyn argumentis and obiecciouns whiche mowe be made aȝens þe treuþis tretid schortly here in þis present first chapitre.

DIV3.HEAD: [ije chapitre].
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, into what purpos and eend was man made? Man was created to govern him∣self in this life according to Reason, or according to Faith allowable by Reason, so that he may obtain ever∣lasting ligr. Certis, sone, forto reule his wil and his outward and inward wittis, wiþ her appetitis, his doyngis and suffringis and movingis in gouernaunce of doable þingis, aftir þe doom of resoun, or of feiþ allowable bi resoun, The work of Reason and Free Will in controlling the sensual appetites of man is fully explained in the Folewer, Pt. I, chap. ix. whilis he lyviþ in þis lijf; þat aftir þe deeþ of þis lijf, he be reysid aȝen into bodily lijf, forto lyue in body and soule to gedir euerlastyng, in ioye and blis, afore þe presence of god.

ffadir, y haue herd summe seie þat a man owith to lyue in What difference is there between a man's living (1) morally virtuously, (2) according to the law of God, (3) according to the doom of Reason or of Faith? þis world moraly vertuosely; And summe men y haue herd seie þat a man in þis world owȝt to lyue aftir þe lawe of god; and now ȝe seien þat he owiþ to lyue and reule his bodily wittis and her appetitis and his wil and alle hise bodili movingis in doable þingis aftir þe doom of resoun or of feiþ. what difference or diuersite is þere bitwix þese iij maners of seiyngis?

Sone, bitwix þese iij MS. iij maners of; maners of being crossed through. speches is no diuersite or dif∣ference; There is no difference be∣tween these three things. but of hem iij is oon meenyng, oon accorde and oon sentence. ffor whi moral vertuose dede, and dede of doable gouernaunce reulid bi resoun or feiþ, And þe lawe or seruice of god ȝouun to man ben al oon, as it is provid in þe book clepid 'þe iust apprising of holi scripture'. Wherfore al oon and þe same it is forto lyue moraly vertuosely, and forto gouerne oure dedis of | doable þingis aftir resoun or feiþ, and forto lyue aftir þe lawe of god and seruice to god. but þanne ferþir, þou must vndirstonde þat amonge þese Some moral virtues are commandments of Reason or Faith. dedis whiche ben reulid bi doom of resoun or feiþ, summe ben iugid and deemyd of resoun or of feiþ nedis to be doon, and þerfore resoun or feiþ werneþ hem to be left vndoon, or her contraries to be doon. And þese ben þe 'commaunde∣mentis' of resoun or of feiþ. Summe oþire ben iugid and Other moral virtues are counsels of Reason or of Faith. deemed of resoun or of feiþ to be doable, or worþi to be doon, as for good, and þat þei mowe be left vndoon, and þat oþire dedis not stonding wiþ hem, or þat her contraries mowe, as it were, lijk weel in styd of hem be doon. And alle þat ben of þis soort ben 'counseilis' of resoun or of feiþ: As ben, in Such as Chastity, Voluntary Poverty and Obedience. sum caas of circumstauncis, chastite; forsaking of wyne and alle vinose drinkis, forsaking of fleische, forsaking o[f] MS. or. richesse in plente, forsaking of lordschip in propurtee; obedience to summe approvid reule, and suche oþire; of whiche counseilis is seid and writun bi processe in þe ije partie of þis present book, Chap. xix. and in 'þe reule of cristen religioun', in þe ije partie, þe vij tretie, and in þe book clepid 'þe iust apprising of holy scripture', þe first partie, þe xvj and xvij trouþis; notwiþstonding þat, in summe caas In some cir∣cumstances the counsels become commandments. of circumstauncis, þese same now rehercid vertuose dedis or counseilis ben comaundementis of resoun and of lawe of kinde and of god, as it is tauȝt in þe first parti of 'cristen religioun', þe iije treti, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre.

And ferþir þus: siþen, as it is proued in þe book clepid The command∣ments and counsels of Reason or Faith are the laws of God. 'þe iust apprising of holi scripture', al þat resoun and feiþ comaunden, god comaundiþ, and aȝenwardis al þat god comaundiþ, resoun or feiþ comaundiþ; folewiþ þat goddis
comaundementis and comaundementis of resoun and of feiþ ben al oon. And siþen al þat resoun and feiþ counseilen, god counseiliþ, and aȝenward al þat god counseiliþ, resoun or feiþ counseiliþ; folewith þat goddis counseilis and þe counseilis of resoun and of feiþ ben al oon. and þanne ferþir | þus: siþen þe lawe of god ȝouun to man is not ellis þan goddis comaundementis and goddis counseilis; it folewiþ þat [þe commaundementis and co[u]nseilis of resoun and of feiþ and þe lawe of god ben al oon. and siþen] þe . . . siþen, addition from the top of the page in MS.; the u of co[u]nseilis being omitted. þe comaunde∣mentis And the com∣mandments and counsels of Reason or Faith are the moral virtues. and counseilis of resoun and of feiþ and moral vertues, wiþ her dedis, ben al oon, as schal be open bi þe first partie of 'þe folewer' Chaps. xv-xvii; also the end of chap. xxvii. to þis book, and in þe book clepid 'þe iust apprising of holi scripture'; it folewiþ þat moral vertues, And the moral virtues are the laws of God. wiþ her dedis, and þe seid lawe of god ben al oon and þe same.

ffadir, þe iiije manere of seiyng þere is: þat manys al and Is it true to assert (1) that love (or charity) to∣wards God, ourselves, and our neighbour is the whole duty of Man; or (2) that love towards God alone is the whole duty of Man? hool boond in þis lijf is forto kepe charite, or forto lyue aftir charite. And þis charite summe men clepen a 'þrefold loue', þat is to seie, loue to god aboue al þing, loue to a man him silf, and loue to his neiȝbore as to him silf. And ȝit þe ve seiyng is: þat forto kepe þe first of þese iij loues is sufficient seruice to god, ȝhe, and is al þe hool boond of man whiche he is bounde to kepe and fulfille in þis lijf. Wheþir þese maners of seiyng ben trewe or no, y wolde leerne.

Certis, sone, neiþir þe iiije, neiþir þe ve of þese seiyngis It is not true to assert that love towards God alone, or love towards God, our neighbour, and ourselves, comprises all the moral virtuous deeds. may be vndirstonde þus: þat þe first of hem iij, or þe al iij to gedir, or her euen to hem comoun gendre is naturali or morali alle moral vertuose dedis whiche a man is bounde to kepe, and wiþ whiche he is bound to serue god; neiþir þat þei iij to gider, or he[r] MS. he. next gendre, or þat enye of hem iij conteineþ, comprehendiþ, or closiþ withynne him, as his spicis, alle moral vertuose dedis whiche to haue a man is bounde in þis lijf. ffor al þis is vntrewe, as schal be provid openli and Where this is proved. vnaȝenseiabili in þe secunde part of þis present book, þe xiij chapitre, And in 'þe book of feiþ, hope, and charite' See Notes.

But it must be vndirstonde namelich in oon manere þus: It is true that if a man love God, he will strive to fulfil all other moral virtuous deeds. þat þilk first seid loue, bi strengþe of him silf, inclineþ, bowiþ, moveþ and stiriþ a man forto seche astir, leerne and take þe knowing of alle oþire moral vertuose dedis, and forto kepe and perfoorme hem in worching, to whiche oþire moral vertuose dedis a man is bounde bi þe MS. biþe. wil of god. ȝhe, and þilk first loue and þe | ije and iije seid loues to gider, or her next comoun gendre, doiþ þe same. But ȝitt, neuere þe But these other moral virtuous deeds are not included in love. latter, þe oþire moral v[er]tuose dedis ben not in nature enye oon of hem. And a man muste nedis knowe and haue þe oþire moral vertuose dedis wiþ þe seid loue, And ellis he And they also are necessary to God's service. schal not serue god, as to serue god he is bounde.

Also þe first of þilk iij loues is þe hardist parti to be To love God is the hardest commandment, and the easier loves towards ourselves and our neighbour naturally follow. fulfillid in goddis lawe; and þerfore it is sikir þat who euer fulfilliþ þe first of hem, whiche is hardir to fulfille þan þe tweien oþire, he schal fulfille þe ij oþire; and who euere fulfille þese iij loues, he schal fulfille al þe remenaunt of goddis lawe. And in þis vndirstonding may wel be take MS. betake. If a man fulfils these three loves, he will naturally fulfil the rest of God's law. þe wordis of crist, whanne he seid þat 'in þo seid loues al lawe and prophecies hangen' Matt. xxii. 40. For fuller discussion of this point, see Pt. II, chap. xiii.; And what Johan in his epistil seiþ: 'he þat loueþ not his neiȝbore whom he seeþ, It is in this sense that Christ and St. John meant that all moral virtues may be said to depend on love. how may he loue god whom he seeþ not?' 1 John iv. 20.

Thus moche, sone, here, as for the iiije and ve maners of spechis to gider. And so lijk good it is forto holde þe first manere, or secunde, or þridde, or fourþe maner of seiyngis bifore tretid in þis present chapitre, þouȝ not lijk cleer it is sorto holde eche of hem.

fferþirmore, in more special as to þe iiije manere of speche, The term 'charity' is more general than is the term 'moral virtue', because 'moral virtue' applies only to the habit, while 'charity' in∣cludes the habit of love and the actual loves engendering and following the habit. sone, þou schalt vndirstonde þat 'charite' in his seid generalte is more general þan is 'moral vertu'. fforwhi no þing is 'moral vertu' saue what is an habyt, or a disposicioun toward þe same habit in þe wil. For full discussion of what constitutes a moral virtue, see Folewer, Pt. I, chap. x. and to al þilk habyt 'charite' is general, and to actual louys goyng bifore into gendring of habitual loue, and to actual loues folewing aftir þe same habitual loue: and ȝitt noon of þilk actual loues is
'moral vertu', for noon of hem is an habit. and þerfore 'charite' is more general þan is 'moral vertu'.

Also 'moral vertu' and 'habitual loue' or 'habitual 'Moral virtue' and 'habitual love' (or 'habitual charity') are one and the same. charite' ben al oon; fforwhi ech 'moral vertu' is 'habitual loue', as schal appere in 'þe folewer to þe donet', in þe eend of þe ije partie Chap. viii.; and eche 'habitual loue' is 'habitual As is proved in the Folewer, Pt. II, chap. viii. charite'; wherfore 'moral vertu' and 'habitual loue' or 'habi∣tual charite' ben oon. And þerfore oon and þe same diuisioun or particioun is of 'habitual charite' into hise spicis, and of 'moral vertu' into hise spicis; and alle Therefore the kinds of 'moral virtue' and of 'habitual charity' are the same. þe same spicis or specialis ben of þe oon and of þe oþire.

Also 'moral vertuose þing' is comoun and general to moral vertu, whiche is habit or his disposicioun, and to The term 'moral virtuous thing' is common to moral virtue and to moral virtuous deeds going before and after the moral virtue. moral dedis goyng bifore þe habit into his gen∣dring, and to moral dedis goiyng aftir þe same habit into whiche þe same habyt inclyneþ. And so 'moral vertuose dede' and 'moral charitative dede' ben oon; ffor whi dedis goyng bifore þe habit of charite or of moral vertu, and dedis Therefore a 'moral virtuous deed' and a 'morally good deed' and a 'moral charita∣tive deed' are the same. going aftir þe habit of charite or of moral vertu ben 'chari∣tative dedis' and 'moral vertuose dedis' and 'morali good dedis', þouȝ þei ben not 'habitual charite', neiþir 'moral vertu', for as moche as þei ben not habit or habitis. And eche of þese dedis is a dede longyng to habitual charite and to moral vertu, whiche is an habit; and þerfore eche of þilk dedis is a dede of charite and of moral vertu; and so 'charitative dede' and 'moral vertuose dede' ben oon.

þerfore it is not oon forto seie 'charite', as it is next But 'charity' and 'charitative deed' (or 'moral virtuous deed') are not the same. general comoun to þe seid iij loues or charitees, and forto seie 'charitatyue dede' or 'moral vertuose dede'; neiþir oon it is forto seie 'moral vertu' and forto seie 'moral vertuose dede' or 'charitative dede'; fforwhi manye outward chari∣tatyue And 'moral virtue' and 'moral virtuous deed', (or 'charitative deed') are not the same. dedis and manye outward moral vertuose dedis ben, whiche ben not charite, neiþir charitees naturali, formali or moraly, and manye outward charitative dedis and many outward moral vertuose dedis ben, whiche ben not moral vertu, neiþir moral vertues naturali, formali or morali. Neuerþeles, into alle þese now seid dedis boþe charite and
moral vertu inclynen, moven, speden, dryven and maken hem to be doon.

And so 'charyte' nameþ boþe habitual loue and actual The meaning of 'charity', 'moral virtue', 'moral virtuous deed', and 'morally good thing' recapitulated. loue; 'moral vertu' namyþ oonli habit or his disposicioun into him, but not eny dede inward or outward; 'moral vertuose dede' or 'morali good | dede' nameþ þe dedis goyng bifore þe habit and þe dedis comyng aftir þe habit, and þat wheþir þei ben inward or outward; 'moraly good þing' namyþ þe habit whiche is 'moral vertu', and also þe dedis goyng bifore him and þe dedis goyng aftir him, and þat wheþir þei ben inward or outward dedis.

Eche moral vertu whiche haþ outward dedis bi whom he Every moral virtue which has outward deeds, has the same name for the virtue and for the outward deeds, e. g. 'righteousness', 'obedience'. may be gendrid, or haþ outward dedis into whiche he in∣clyneþ or moueþ, haþ oon and þe same name comoun to him and to eche of þilk dedis: as riȝtwisnes', 'obedience', and so forþ of eche oþire vertu or poynt in þe foure tablis. þe first poynt of þe secunde table, þe first poynt of þe þridde But ghostly love or charity has no such outward deed. Therefore the name 'charity' is restricted to the habit and inward deeds. table, and þe first poynt of þe fourþe table han noon suche outward dedis; and þerfore þis name 'loue' or 'charite' namyth þo habitis and her dedis whiche ben inward and not outward. See Donet, Pt. II, chap. xiii.

ffadir, if al be trewe what bifore in þis present chapitre ȝe Hence it should follow that the clear, sufficient, full, and com∣pendious teach∣ing of moral virtues and moral virtuous deeds, or of deeds com∣manded and counselled by Reason or Faith, is the same thing as the clear, sufficient, full, and com∣pendious teach∣ing of God's commandments and counsels. han tauȝt, þanne folewiþ þat where euere and how euere be maad moost cleer teching of moral vertues and of moral vertuose dedis, or of dedis comaundid and counseilid of resoun or of feiþ, þere and so is maad moost cleer teching of goddis comaundementis and counseilis and of his lawe ȝouun to a man bi whiche man ouȝte serve to him; And where euere and how euere is maad moost sufficient and moost ful teching of moral vertues and of moral vertuose dedis, or of dedis comaun∣did and counseilid of resoun and feiþ, þere and so is made moost sufficient and moost ful teching of goddis comaundementis and counseilis and of his seid lawe and seruice; And where euere and how euere be maad moost according or moost compendiose gadering to gider, þat is to seie, moost schort profitable gadering to gider, of moral vertues and of moral
vertuose dedis, or of dedis commaundid and counseilid of resoun or of feiþ, þere and so is maad moost conuenient or according or moost compendiose to gider gadering of goddis commaundementis and counseilis and of his seid lawe and seruice.
Sone, al þis y graunte, | for al þis dryuing and concluding This does so follow. may no man avoide.

ffadir, þanne ferþir þus: Siþen in þe tablis of moyses, at Therefore, since the tables of Moses do not treat clearly, sufficiently, fully, and compendiously all moral virtues and all moral virtuous deeds; it follows they do not treat clearly, suffi∣ciently, fully, and com∣pendiously all God's command∣ments and counsels. þe leest to seie, ben not tauȝt moost cleerli, moost sufficientli and moost compendioseli alle moral vertues and alle moral vertuose dedis, or dedis commaundid and counseilid in doom of resoun and of feiþ; and more myȝt be seid þat not verrili, sufficientli, or fully ben alle moral vertues and alle moral vertuose dedis, or alle goddis comaundementis and counseilis, tauȝt in þo ij tablis, as may be seen bi processe in þis same book in þe ije partye; it folewith of þe leest seiyng þat in þe tablis of moyses ben not moost cleerly, moost fully, or sufficientli, and moost compendiosely tauȝt goddis com∣maundementis, hise counseilis, his lawe and his seruice. but it folewiþ þat, how fer þilk tablis ben from þe cleer, sufficient, ful MS. sufficientful. and compendiose treting of moral vertues and of moral vertuose dedis, tauȝt bi crist and hise apostlis, and conteyned scateringly here and þere in þe newe testament and in moral philosophie, and gaderid to gider bi doctouris and oþire clerkis into bokis and treticis of moral vertues, clenly þerupon foormed and writen, so fer ben þo tablis from þe cleer, sufficient, ful and compendiose teching and treting of þe commaundementis and counseilis of god.

Sone, al þis y must nedis graunte, boþe for þe proof nowe This does so follow. Fuller proof may be seen in the Donet, Pt. II, chaps. iv-ix. made, and for largir proof in þe secunde partie of þis same book, fro þe begynnyng of þe iiije chapitre into þe eende of þe ixe chapitre. And ȝitt more þanne þis folewiþ of þe oþire bifore my seiyng, whiche y wole not conclude and dryue oute here, but in þe ije partie of þis present book. Chaps. iii, vi-ix.

And þerfore moche wondir myȝt a a overwritten in MS. wel leerned clerk haue vpon þe greet, ouer long woned rudenes of newe doctouris
and of her now folewers, whiche, withoute enye nede, and The attempt to reduce all the commandments of God to the ten command∣ments of Moses is a stumbling∣block to the people. withoute enye resoun, and wiþoute þe peplis profite, ȝhe, aȝens nede, aȝens resoun, and aȝens þe profite of þe peple, cleeven to moyses tablis so ouer tendirly, and as for al hool and sufficient commaunde∣mentis of god displaien hem so bisily. And, as y trowe, þis is oon cause whi MS. whiche; che being underdotted. goddis comaunde∣mentis ben kunned so sengli After so, the MS, has sens, crossed through. and so simpli; bi cause alle vertues and alle moral vertuose dedis comaundid mowe not in þilk x wordis of moyses tablis be seen so soon and so cleerly, by gadering and reduccioun made into hem so fer fet and so straungeli, and bi logging of alle moral vertues and of alle moral vertuose dedis in hem in so narow a place so streitly and vnaccordingly.

DIV3.HEAD: [iije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, what processe is þanne to be maad forto knowe THE FOURTH MATTER: GOD'S LAWS. How can moral virtues, i. e. the laws of God, be ade∣quately classi∣fied? and teche and noumbre cleerly and sufficiently, and þerwiþ al compendiosely, þat is to seie, schortly, profitably, alle moral vertues comaundid bi resoun or feiþ, or counseilid bi resoun or feiþ, and so in þat alle goddis comaundementis and alle goddis counseilis?

Soþeli, sone, þis processe may be made, as schal be schewid All moral virtuous deeds, or all the com∣mandments of God, may be considered under three heads: Our duty towards God, our duty towards our∣selves, and our duty towards our neighbour. in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe first trety, and in 'þe prouoker'. Eche moral dede comaundid or counseilid of resoun or of feiþ, And þerfore eche moral vertuose dede comaundid or counseilid of god, we owen to do immediatly, or at þe next, anentis god, anentis vs silf, or anentis oure neiȝbours. And ferþirmore, as is schewid in þe book clepid 'þe prouoker', toward þe eend, and bettir in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', eche suche dede to be doon bi comaunde∣ment or counseile of resoun or of feiþ for him silf, anentis The seven points of our duty to∣wards God. god immediatly or at þe next, is forto lyue to god goostly, obediently, riȝtwisly, mekely, trewly, benyngneli, or largely, And bi dedis herto seruyng meenaly; ech suche dede to be The eight points of our duty to∣wards ourselves. doon bi comaundement or counseil of resoun or feiþ anentis vs silf at þe next, is forto lyve toward vs silf goostly, fleischely, worldly, clenly, honestly, paciently, douȝtily, or largely, and bi dedis þerto perteynyng meenaly; Eche suche
dede to be doon bi comaundement or counseil of resoun or The eight points of our duty towards our neighbour. of feiþ anentis oure neiȝbore at þe nexte, is forto lyue toward him goostly, attendauntly, riȝtfully, mekely, | accordingli, Treuly, Benyngneli, or largely, and bi dedis helping to þese menali.

wherfore folewith þat alle moral dedis according to resoun Thus these twenty-three points and their corresponding meenal virtues include all moral virtues towards God, ourselves, and our neighbour. and to feiþ, and þerfore alle moral vertues commaundid or counseilid bi resoun or feiþ, and alle comau[n]dementis n omitted in MS. or counseilis of god ben conteyned in þese now seid xxiij poyntis, with herto hem helping meenal moral vertues. whiche xxiij poyntis ben named in an oþir maner þus: To god goostlines, obedience, riȝtwisnes, mekenes, treuþe, benyngnite, larges, and meenal worching into eny of hem; To us silf goostlyhode, fleischlihode, worldlihode, clennes, honeste, pacience, douȝtynes, larges, and meenal worching into eny of hem; To oure neiȝboris goostlihode, attendaunce, riȝt∣wisnes, mekenes, accordingnes, treuþe, benyngnite, larges, and meenal gouernaunce into eny of hem.

ffadir, it apperith wel bi ȝoure now afore goyng proces Hence the vir∣tues of God's moral law may be divided under three heads: (1) Our duty towards God: vij points. (2) Our duty to∣wards ourselves: viij points. (3) Our duty towards our neighbour: viij points. þat þe poyntis or vertues of goddis moral lawe ben soortid into iij parcellis, bi þis þat summe of hem ben oure gouer∣nauncis anentis god at þe next, a[n]d n omitted in MS. summe anentis vs silf at þe next, And summe anentis oure neiȝboris at þe next; and þat þe first of þo parcellis conteyneth vij poyntis, þe ij conteynyth viij poyntis, and þe iije viij poyntis.
Sone, þou seist sooþ, and þese iij parcellis or soortis mowe wel be clepid þre 'tablis' of goddis moral lawe. These three classes may be called the three 'tables' of God's law.

And for as moche as eche moral meenal vertu See Folewer, Pt. I, chap. xxvii: 'þer is oon goodnes which is fynal principal and eend to oþire goodnessis . . . and þer is meenal goodnes into þis now seid fynal goodnes, þat is to seie, a goodnes beyng meene ledyng into þe seid moral and honest goodnes.' or eche moral meenal vertuose dede into enye of þese now rehercid moral vertues or moral vertuose or moral vertuose dedis, in þat þat he is a There is really no need to make a separate table for meenal moral virtues, since they are in∣dissolubly con∣nected with their corre∣sponding eendal moral virtues. meenal vertu or a meenal vertuose dede to an oþir anentis his eendal vertu or eendal vertuose dede, See Folewer, Pt. I, chap. xxvii: 'þer is oon goodnes which is fynal principal and eend to oþire goodnessis . . . and þer is meenal goodnes into þis now seid fynal goodnes, þat is to seie, a goodnes beyng meene ledyng into þe seid moral and honest goodnes.' is in þe same moral gendre or moral kynde or poynt in whiche is þe eendal to whom he is meene, and þat for as moche as oon and þe same or euen lijk principal moral goodenes muste nedis be
in þe [meenal] MS. eendal. dede helping into hem, as schal be open in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe first treti, þerfore it needith not þat to eny meenal vertu be sette for him silf a seueral place diuerse fro | þe place of þe eendal vertu to whom he seruyþ in eny table of moral gendris of vertues .

and, for lijk skile, siþen alle þe same or alle even lijk The executive deeds of willing and nilling are in the same points and in the same Table as their inward deeds of willing and nilling. moral goodnes is in þe inward dede of willing or nylling and in þe dede whiche is bi it comaundid to be as execusioun þerof, eche such executive dede of willing good to eny persoon and of nylling yuel to eny persoon is in þat, and as for þat, in þe same table and in þe same poynt in whiche is þe inward willing or nylling of whiche he is þe execucioun or þe executive dede.

ffadir, is þis now seid soorting or parcelling of tablis þe Is this classifi∣cation under three tables the best? best and profitablist þat may be assigned into þe forþ teching of goddis moral lawis and seruycis?

Sone, þei ben sufficient. neuerþeles it is bettir and more It is clearer to make a separate table for the meenal moral virtues. profitable þat meenal vertu, takun as it were in general, as it were bi him silf, be departid and braunchid ferþir into his membris forto make þerof oon table as bi [him] Omitted in MS. silf, þanne þat noon such braunching þerof be made. for ellis þe teching of meenal vertu were ouer derk and, as it were, ouer general and ouer confuse and ouer schort and scant into þe leernyng of cristen men; namelyche siþen manye of hise membris ben named famosely bi solempne names, as schal appere aftir bi names of vertues in þe iiije table, whiche schal be made þe first table.

And aȝenward, if meenal moral vertu in general schulde Three tables of meenal moral virtues, corre∣sponding to the three tables of eendal moral virtues, might be made. But that would be too cumbersome. be braunchid oute into his spicis, þanne, siþen þe same kindes or gendris of meenal vertues of þe first dede, soort, or parcel, or table, serueþ into vertues of þe ije and of þe iije seid soortis and parcellis or tablis, as is now here bifore seid, and as schal be seen whanne þei schulen be namyd, herof wolde folewe þat þries of þe same meenal vertues and of her braunches and spicis, and vndir hir same names, mencioun schulde be made in þe soorting, tabling, and parcelling of goddis moral lawis; fforwhi oonys in þe first seid soort or parcel, and eftsoone in þe ije seid soort and parcel, and þe
iije tyme in þe iije seid soort and parcel. And forto þus do and procede in displaiyng goddis | moral lawis wolde be ouer longe and tediose and vnlusty to þe heerers and leerners, and it wolde be ouer vncraftiose and vnformal to þe techers.

And þerfore, sone, it semeþ to me as moche bettir for to One table of meenal moral virtues is sufficient. gadre to gider bi hem silf þe meenal poyntis of þe iij soortis or tablis, and name hem in her gendre, or general kynde, þus, 'meenal moral vertu'; and þanne departe and braunche meenal moral vertu into his spicis, and of his braunching into spicis make oon oþire table, soort, and parcel bi him The table of meenal moral virtues shall be called the 'First', because means precede ends. silf, and sette him bifore þe oþire iij rehercid tablis, bi cause þat meenys han a dewe ordre forto go bifore þe þingis into whiche þei ben meenys. Neuerþeles, þe ful, hool out braunching of meenal moral vertu into his spicis, making þe hool first table, schal not be sette here, but so moche þerof oonly, how moche is of bihoueful nede to be tauȝt and leerned.

and so, at þis tyme, forto sette oute and expresse goddis moral lawis, as it is sufficient into cristen mennys necessarye leernyng, þe first table of goddis lawe schal conteyne þese viij The eight meenal moral virtues of the FIRST TABLE rehearsed. poyntis of meenal vertu: þat is to seie, forto gouerne vs leernyngly, preisyngly, dispreisingly, preiyngly, þankingly, worschipingly, disworschipingly, and sacramentingly.

And þat þe ije, iije and iiije tablis conteyne eendal vertues þus: þat þe ije table conteyne þese vij poyntis: þat is to seie, The seven eendal moral virtues towards God of the SECOND TABLE rehearsed. forto lyue and gouerne vs anentis god at þe next, goostly, obediently, riȝtwisly, mekely, treuly, benyngneli, and largeli.

And þat þe iije table conteyne þese vij poyntis: þat is to seie, forto lyue and gouerne vs silf anentis vs silf at þe next, The eight eendal moral virtues towards our∣selves of the THIRD TABLE rehearsed. goostly, fleischely, worldly, clenly, honestly, paciently, douȝtili, and largely.

and þat þe iiije table conteyne þese viij poyntis: þat is The eight eendal moral virtues towards our neighbour of the FOURTH TABLE rehearsed. to seie, forto lyue and governe us anentis oure neiȝboris at þe next, Goostly, attendauntly, riȝtfully, mekely, accordingli, treuly, benyngnely and largely. The Four Tables are fully set out for reference in the Summary of Contents for Pt. I, chaps. iv-ix.

ffadir, here a man myȝt wondre vpon ȝoure disposing of Will not the justice of this classification under Four Tables be challenged? tablis, in lasse þan ȝe schulen | cleer ȝoure silf; fforwhi ȝe
assignen and disposen, at þe fewist, iij tablis forto conteyne alle moral eendal vertues, ȝhe, and þerwiþ her meenal vertues and her executive vertues, in þat, and as for þat, þat þei ben meenes or execuciouns to eendal vertues, and so forto conteyne alle moral vertues; and ȝitt crist, as it wole seme, Christ con∣sidered only two tables: Our duty towards God, and our duty towards our neighbour. was contentid wiþ ij tablis, fforwhi he seiþ þus, mathew, xxij chapitre vv. 37-40.: 'þou schalt loue þi lord god aboue al þing, and þi neiȝbore as þi silf; in þese ij lovys (þat is to seie, loue to god and loue to neiȝbore) hangiþ al þe lawe and profecie.' Whiche ij lovis, as it semeþ, maken oonly þe first and þe iije tablis of oure So MS.; probably an error for ȝoure. eendal vertues, or ellis þe ije and þe iiije tablis in noumbre of ȝoure alle tablis. ȝhe, and St. Paul con∣sidered only one table: Our love towards our neighbour. seynt poule, as it seemeþ, was content wiþ oon table; for he seiþ as, Romans, 13e chapitre, v. 8. þat 'who ever loueþ his neiȝbore fulfilleþ al þe lawe of god.' and þis is, as it seemeþ, [þe iije table] Omitted in MS. of ȝoure eendal moral vertues, and is þe iiije of ȝoure alle tablis. Wherfore a man myȝt argue þat neiþir crist, neiþir þe apostle powle sawe so fer as þei schulde haue seen in assignyng tablis of goddis moral lawe; or þat ȝe seen þerynne ouer fer, or ferþir þanne þei sawen.

Sone, for answer herto, y seie þat, if þe wordis of crist But the two tables of Christ come to the same thing as Pecock's Four Tables. and of seint poule, in þe placis now allegid, be wel con∣siderid, it wole be knowe þat euereiþir of hem in her þo wordis puttiden alle þe same tablis whiche y putte here; fforwhi, whanne crist seid þat 'a man schulde loue god aboue al þing, and his neiȝbore as him silf', crist þerynne seiþ pleynly ynouȝ þat a man schulde loue him silf, wiþ þis, þat he schulde loue god and loue his neiȝbore, ffor ellis he myȝte not loue his neiȝbore as him silf', but if he bifore and eer loued him silf. Wherfore crist spake þere of þre moral loues in general, Of whiche a man schulde haue oon to god, anoþire to him silf, and þe iije to his neiȝbore. And, siþen þe iij tablis whiche y assigne for al eendal moral vertues ben noon oþir þan þese same iij general moral | lovis, conteynyng in sum maner wiþ hem alle dedis beyng meenys to hem and alle dedis being execuciouns of hem, it folewiþ þat crist in þo his wordis puttid þe iij tablis whiche y here
putte of eendal vertues; ȝhe, and he þerwiþ and þerynne puttid þe table whiche y here putte of meenal vertues.

And, in lijk maner, if we weie wel þe allegid wordis of And the one table of St. Paul comes to the same thing as Pecock's Four Tables. Seynt poul, no wise man wole seie but þat, whanne he þere spake of moral loue in general whiche a man ouȝte haue to his neiȝbore, he meenyd of þilk moral loue in general bi whiche a man schulde loue moraly his neiȝbore as him silf, ȝhe, and for god; and ellis þilke loue were not to a cristen man vertuose, neiþir a poynt of cristis lawe, as schal appere in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun' in latyn. And if poul vndirstode so of a mannys loue to his neiȝbore, certis, þerynne poul vndirstode iij moral louys in general: oon of a man to god, siþen a man may not loue his neiȝbore for god, but if he bifore and eer loue god; an oþir loue of man to him silf, siþen a man mai not loue MS. loue himsilf; himsilf being crossed through and underdotted. his neiȝbore as him silf, but if he bifore and eer loue him silf; And þe iije loue of a man to his neiȝbore. And, siþen þese iij general moral lovis, holding wiþ hem her meenys and her execuciouns, as þei ouȝte so holde, ben not ellis þan þe iij bifore seid tablis of eendal vertues, ȝhe, not ellis þan þe iiij bifore seid tablis, as it is open bi proces here bifore made, folewiþ wel þat poul puttiþ alle þe tablis of goddis moral lawe whiche y here putte.

ffadir, forsoþ me þinkith ȝe assoilen sufficiently my doute. How is it that Christ speaks of two loves, and Pecock of three? but, fadir, how is it trewe þat þilk loues bi whiche a man loueþ god aboue al þing, MS. alþing. and his neiȝbore as him silf, ben two lovis aftir þe speche of crist now bifore allegid, and ȝe noumbren here þe same lovis for iij lovis?

Sone, whanne ij general þingis ben noumbrid as for tweyn, One love men∣tioned by Christ, viz. to love one's neighbour as oneself, is really two. if oon of þo ij generalys be departid into two spicis of him, þan we mowe make noumbre of ij, or of iij, at oure owne lust. and so þilk | same lovis whiche crist clepid 'two' mowe be clepid 'iij', and euereiþir cleping is trewe ynouȝ.

DIV3.HEAD: [iiije chapitre] Chapter numbered 4 in margin.
DIV3.P:
[F]Adir,
Cf. henceforward Poore Mennis Myr∣rour, fols. 5a, l. 4, to the end of 13b. At fol. 5a, l. 4, the correspondence with the Donet starts.
For the Prologue and first part of Chapter I of the P.M.M. (fols. 3a to 5a, l. 4), and for the abbreviated account of Doughtiness (fols. 30a, l. 7, to 31a, l. 18), see Appendix to Donet.
For description of the MS. of the P.M.M., for points not noted in collation, and for Table of Correspondences between P.M.M. and Donet, see Appendix to Donet. what is P.M.M. inserts it. forto lyue leernyngly, as it is þe first The FIRST TABLE. poynt of þe first table? To live leernyngly is to learn the SEVEN MATTERS.

Sone, it is forto wille, chese, and be bisie forto knowe, leerne, and kunne and þanne aftir forto remembre P.M.M. inserts þese vij þingis or maters. alle þo trouþis whos kunnyng and remembring schulen be meenys to vs forto governe vs in dedis of oure wil aftir resoun or P.M.M., of for or; the or misplaced, and used for and, l. 8. feiþ, anentis god immediatly, anentis vs silf immediatly, and anentis oure neiȝboris immediatly. And, siþen P.M.M. omits siþen. alle þo The SEVEN MATTERS re∣hearsed. trouþis mowe be comprehendid and conteyned in þese vij maters, þat is to seie: what god is in him silf, whiche ben hise benefetis, whiche ben hise punyschingis, whiche is his moral lawe and seruice commaundid and counseilid to be doon and to be fulfillid of vs, whiche ben oure natural wrecchidnessis, whiche ben oure wickidnessis, and whiche ben remedies aȝens hem boþe; þerfore P.M.M. omits þerfore . . . maters. forto lyue leernyngly, as it is þe first poynt of þe first table, it is for to wille, chese, and be bisy to leerne, kunne, and knowe þese now last rehercid vij maters. P.M.M. omits þerfore . . . maters.

ffadir, whi noumbre ȝe þese vij þingis, or maters, more Why are these said SEVEN MATTERS so specially important? They com∣prise all that is necessary for a man to know in order that he may live goostly and win heaven. þanne oþire?

Certis, sone, y P.M.M. omits y . . . cause. haue now seid þe cause, P.M.M. omits y . . . cause. for in þese vij ben conteyned cleerly, fully, and compendiosely al þat euer P.M.M. omits euer. is necessary a man MS. aman; P.M.M. aman. to knowe forto be a good cristen, goostly lyuer MS. "lyuer 'goostly, with the marks of transposition; P.M.M., goostli lyuer.; Namelyche if a man forȝete not þat alle creaturis made of god, except peynes of helle, In P.M.M., of hell is a correction on the margin. ben hise benefitis ȝouun
to man. And if he knowe þese vij, him neediþ knowe P.M.M., to knowe. no ferþir to wynne heuen; ffor þei schulen sufficiently reule h[i]m MS. hem; P.M.M., hym. in kunnyng P.M.M. omits in kunnyng. þoruȝ al contemplative lijf and al actif lijf, as is pleinly schewid in þe prolog of þe book In P.M.M., of þe book is a correction on the margin. callid 'þe reule of cristen religioun'.
ffadir, where may a man leerne þese seid vij maters? Where these SEVEN MATTERS may be learnt.

Soþeli, sone, in þe holy bible MS. "bible 'holy, with the marks of transposition; P.M.M., holi bible., made of þe oolde testament and of þe newe, þei mowe be knowen In P.M.M. be knowen is a correction on the margin. | sumwhat, but not cleerly, neiþir fully, as it is provid in þe book clepid 'þe iust apprising of holy scripture', 'Bokes made by Bysshope pecock' in margin, and the titles underlined in the text. and in 'þe afore crier', and P.M.M. omits: and in þe prouoker and in þe represser. in 'þe prouoker', and in 'þe represser' P.M.M. omits: and in þe prouoker and in þe represser., also P.M.M., and. in doctouris writingis, þei mowen be leerned sumwhat and scateringly. but in þe book callid 'þe reule of cristen religioun', wiþ þe book 'filling þe iiij tablis', wiþ a fewe mo in 'þe prouoker' and in 'þe fore crier' to þis present book noumbrid and namyd, þei mowe be knowun ordinatly, cleerly, and boþe largely and compendiosely, how moche is nedeful and spedeful, nameliche at þe first, into cristen mennys holy and good lyuyng.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue anentis god P.M.M. omits anentis god. preisingly, as it To live preis∣ingly is to declare God's goodness by inward [or out∣ward] speech. is þe secunde poynt of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto, at sum whilis, whanne oþire grettir seruicis of god, þat P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. is to seie, fynal That is, eendal services, as explained in the Second Table, Pt. I, chap. v. seruycis of god, P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. schulen not þerbi be lettid, and whanne a man MS. aman. in his semyng haþ nede forto be kyndelyd and quykened into goostly freendful P.M.M. omits goostly freendful. loue toward god or toward him silf, a man forto P.M.M. omits a man forto. preise god in him silf, or in his seyntis, or in his benefetis, and in his oþire werkis; þat is to seie, forto declare or witnesse, bi
inward [or outward] Omitted in MS., but should probably read inward or outward. The point is not very clear. Cf. the varying evidence of pp. 30, 32, 33. The corresponding passage of the P.M.M., fol. 6b, reads: inward speche or outward speche. speche, sum excellence or worþines or goodnes of god in him silf, or in his worchingis, or in hise seintis, or in enye of hise creaturis.
ffadir, wherto availith suche preising? The benefits arising from such praising: (1) Love towards God and oneself.

Sone, it availith principaly for to gendre and contynue and to kepe in þe preiser greet frendful, goostly welwilling and loue anentis god and anentis a man MS. aman. him silf, and alle her purtenauncis aftir in þe [xxiije] Space left in MS., and in P.M.M., for reference to chapter; the reference is to chap. xxiii of Pt. II. chapitre of þis book rehercid, and for noon oþire P.M.M. inserts eend. principally; for god neediþ noon of oure preisingis, neiþir as for him silf he is in oure preising amendid, betterid, cherid, or delitid. Neuerþeles, (2) Separation from the flesh and the world. þe vse of þis office, whiche is preising, may availe forto holde vp þe preisers consideracioun, mynde, and affeccioun wiþ god, þat it falle not doun vpon worldly and fleischli þingis, and þanne folewingli to not be amys occupied in hem bi occasioun or entirmetyng wiþ hem. But, certis, þis effect or availe | of This second benefit arises from the first. preising is includid and conteyned in þe oþire bifore seid effect and availe of preising; fforwhi how moche oonly is þe freendful, goostly welwilling and loue whiche we han to god and to vs silf, so myche and þerbi is þe cleeving and oonyng whiche we han to god, and þe departing of oure loue fro þe fleisch and þe worlde. and þerfore þis secunde effect and availe is born and conteyned in þe first. And bi þis now afore MS. a fore; P.M.M., bifore. seid of preising to god, may be knowe what is forto lyue preisingly anentis aungelis and men, and wherto it availiþ.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue dispreisingly, as P.M.M. substitutes: as it is þe iije point. it is a vertu P.M.M. substitutes: as it is þe iije point. To live dis∣preisingly is to denounce a fault, either of oneself or of another, by inward or out∣ward speech. of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto, at sum while, whanne resoun iugiþ it to be doon, and whanne bettir seruice of god, þat P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. is to seie, final See above, p. 28, note 12. seruice to god, P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. schal not þerbi be lettid, a man to
dispreise him silf or sum oþire creature: þat is to seie, forto declare, denounce, or witnesse, bi inward speche or outward speche, Cf. above, p. 29, note 1. sum vnworþines or vnnobilte, lack, defaute, wrecchidnes, or vice, trespas, or synne, of him silf or of sum oþire creature, for þis entent: þat he him silf, or þe oþir So that this fault may be amended. creature, be þerbi brouȝt into mekenes, or into þe depper mekenes, or into sorowe for his synne, or into removing, MS. re removing, the first re occurring at the end of a line; P.M.M., remouyng. wiþdrawing, or lassyng of P.M.M. omits of. ouer moche fleischly or worldly loue had vpon him silf or vpon sum oþire creature, or into warnes and good disposicioun wherbi pryde, or suche seid ouer moche loue, schulen be lettid forto arise.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue anentis god preiyngli, as it is To live preiyngli is to ask God anything, by inward or out∣ward speech, for our own or our neighbour's benefit. þe fourþe poynt and vertu of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto, at sum whilis, whanne oþire profitabler seruicis of god, þat P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. is to seie, fynal See above, p. 28, note 12. seruicis of god, P.M.M. omits þat . . . god. schulen not þerbi be lettid, and whanne a man in his seemyng haþ nede to quyk him silf in þe seid loves, and namelich in moral desiris (whiche here P.M.M. omits here. y clepe 'louys' or 'willingis' P.M.M., wilnyngis.) vpon goodis to come and to be had, a P.M.M. omits a man forto. man forto P.M.M. omits a man forto. aske of god, bi inward speche in resoun oonly, or þerwiþ bi outward speche in tunge, or bi oþire outward sygne, countenaunce, or dede occupiyng þe stide of | outwarde speche, enye þing þat is to oure bihoue or to oure neiȝboris bihoue, in goddis seruice: as is forȝeuenes of synne, grace to forbere synne, As we do in the Paternoster. grace to worche and suffre vertuosely, and so forþ of alle oþire poyntys whiche ben includid in þe preier y-callid in latyn 'Pater noster', in þe maner P.M.M. inserts of. as þilk preier, 'Pater noster', is expowned in þe first parti of þe book y-callid 'þe reule P.M.M., þeule, and cross in margin. of cristen reigioun'.
ffadir, wherto availith preier maad to god? The benefits of prayer re∣hearsed.

Sone, it availith principaly to gendre, and contynue, and kepe in him whiche preie[þ] MS. preier; P.M.M., preieþ., þe now seid desires toward
god forto haue alle necessaries for him whiche preieþ, and for oþire, into goddis seruice. ffor god neediþ not to be certified, or be tauȝt, or be remembrid what þingis ben to vs necessarye; Neiþir he mai be moved, or charmed, or chaungyd, bi craft of wordis and askingis, neiþir bi inpor∣tune or noysum multitude of askingis, as men mowe. And, þerfore, al þe good of oure preiyng whiche Omitted in P.M.M. is brouȝt forþ in vs silf P.M.M. inserts which here. is now seid: þat is to seie, greet desijr born vpon þe þing desirid of vs and askid of god, whiche desire god moche apprisith, moche allowith, heeriþ, grauntiþ, and rewardiþ. Cf. below, p. 46. Neuerþeles, bisidis þis availe, preier availeþ into þe same oþire good into whiche now afore is seid preis∣ing to availe, þouȝ þis P.M.M., þese ij arailes. secunde availe P.M.M., þese ij arailes. of preier be includid and conteynyd in his seid first availe. Bi þis now bifore seid of P.M.M. omits of. preier to god, may be knowe esili what is P.M.M. inserts it. forto lyue anentis creaturis preiyngli, and wherto it availith.

ffadir, what is it for to lyue þankingly to god, P.M.M. omits to god. as it is þe To live þank∣ingly is to acknowledge God's benefits by inward or outward speech. ve poynt and vertu of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto, at sum whilis, whanne oþire profitabler seruycis of god schulen not þerbi be lettid, and whanne a man in his semyng haþ nede to quyke him silf in þe seid lovis to god and to him silf, and nameliche in moral desiris (whiche y clepe here P.M.M. omits here. 'loves' or 'willingis' P.M.M., wilnyngis.) vpon goodis to come and to be had, seie and P.M.M. omits: and be aknowe. be aknowe P.M.M. omits: and be aknowe. to god, bi inward speche in resoun oonly, or þerwiþ bi outward speche in tunge, or bi oþire outward signe, countenaunce, or dede P.M.M. runs: or dede þat he wole in sum maner, and then the parallelism continues. occupiyng þe stide of speche, þat | he haþ receyuid benefete or benefetis of god, and þat he haþ cause forto in sum maner P.M.M. runs: or dede þat he wole in sum maner, and then the parallelism continues. of vndirstonding aȝen quyte god fully, or sumwhat, in seruice for þoo P.M.M. substitutes certeyne. benefetis doon of god, and receiued into þe seier, or into sum oþire persoon whom he loueþ.
ffadir, wherto availiþ þanking made to god? The benefits of such thanking.

Sone, forto quyke a man þe feruentlier and þe hertlier to performe and fulfille sum seruicis to god whiche he seiþ generaly, or specialy, in þilk þanking him forto do to god. and so þanking serviþ into gendring, nurisching, and encresing of moral desiris forto do seruicis of god and to god, wiþ þe oþire availes wherto preising and P.M.M. omits and. preiyng serven.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue anentis god worschipingly To live wor∣schipingly is to declare God's excellence by other means than by inward or outward speech. or honouringly, as it is þe vje poynt of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto at sum whilis, whanne oþire fynal P.M.M. omits fynal. See above, p. 28, note 12. seruycis of god, aftir doom of resoun more profitable to be doon, schulen not þerbi be lettid, and whanne a man in his semyng [ha]þ MS. wiþ: P.M.M., haþ. nede to make bisynes forto gendre freendful, goostly loue toward god or toward him silf, worschipe or honoure god, þat is to seie, declare or witnesse bi dede, as of bowing or louȝing vs silf ynneforþ P.M.M., wiþinforþ. in þe vndirstonding, or in þe ymaginacioun, or ellis bi signe, countenaunce, or dede withoutforþ, dyuers P.M.M. omits dyuers . . . word. from outward word, P.M.M. omits dyuers . . . word. sum excellence, or worþines, or goodnes of god, being in him silf, or beyng in hise worchingis, wrouȝt bi him into hise seintis, or into enye of hise creaturis.
ffadir, wherto availiþ enye such worschiping? The benefits of worshipping, and the differ∣ence between praising and worshipping.

Sone, it availiþ to þe same effect to whiche availiþ preising; fforwhi From foot of page in P.M.M.; omission mark in text. bitwixe preising From foot of page in P.M.M.; omission mark in text. and worschiping is noon oþire difference saue þat preising is made bi outward speche, and worschiping is made bi oþir outward signe, countenaunce, or dede. Cf. above, p. 29, note 1. And herbi may liȝtli be knowe what is forto lyue anentis aungels and men worschipingly, and wherto it availith.

ffadir, what is P.M.M. inserts it. forto lyue disworschipingli, as it is þe vij To live dis∣worschipingli is to denounce a fault, either our own, or another's, by other means than by inward or outward speech. vertu of þe first table?

Sone, it is forto, at | sum while, whanne resoun in iþ it it overwritten in MS. to be doon, and whanne bettir See above, p. 28, note 12. seruice of god schal not þerbi be lettid, a man to disworschip him silf or sum oþire creature P.M.M., creaturis.; þat is to seie, forto declare, denounce, or witnesse, withinne forþ or wiþoute forþ, bi sum signe or tokun diuerse fro inward and outward speche Cf. above, p. 29, note 1. P.M.M. reads fro outward speche only. of P.M.M., or. word, sum vnworþines or vnnobilte, lacke, defaute, or P.M.M. omits or. wrecchidnes, or vice, trespace, or synne, of him silf or of þe oþire creature, for þis entent: þat he him silf, or þe oþire creature, be þerbi So that this fault may be amended brouȝt into mekenes, or into þe P.M.M. omits þe. depper mekenes, or into sorewe for his synne, or into removing, wiþdrawing, or lassing MS. orlassing. of ouer myche fleischly or worldli loue had vpon him silf or vpon sum oþir creature, or into warnes and good disposicioun þat pryde, or þis seid ouer moche loue, not arise; as whanne a man MS. aman. weriþ sak clooþ, or puttiþ askis vpon his heed, or gooþ bare foot and in symple and pore araye, or beriþ in his hond sum pore, vnworþi sticke or staf, or makiþ such þingis be sette nyȝe aboute him.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue P.M.M. inserts anentis god. sacramentaly, as P.M.M. omits as . . . table. it is þe To live sacra∣mentaly is to receive Christ's sacraments duly. viij membre of þe first table? P.M.M. omits as . . . table.
Sone, it is forto receyue cristis P.M.M., his. sacramentis, þat is to seie, baptym and oþire, dewly.
ffadir, how receyuiþ a man baptym dewly? What is meant by receiving Baptism duly.

Certis, sone, if he be of sufficient age age overwritten in MS. and of sufficient vndirstonding whanne he it receiviþ, he must be repentaunt for alle hise mysdedis afore don, and he must be in ful wil and purpos, wiþ al bisines, to forbere mysdedis in tyme from þens aftir to come; he must aske forȝeuenes of mys∣dedis passid, and grace forto P.M.M., to. forbere mysdedis and to fulfille vertues in P.M.M. omits in . . . come. tyme to come P.M.M. omits in . . . come., in þilk ful and hool bileeue whiche is tauȝt bi crist and his apostlis—of whiche
bileeue þe articles ben tauȝt largeli in þe book y-callid 'þe Where the arti∣cles of Christian belief may be found. reule of cristen religioun', and more schortely þei schulen be For schulen be, the P.M.M. substitutes ben. rehercid in P.M.M. reads: in þe donet, þe parti, þe chapitre, spaces being left for the references. þis same book, in þe first chapitre of þe ije partie P.M.M. reads: in þe donet, þe *arti, þe chapitre, spaces being left for the references., and ben also sett forþ in a ful compendiose maner in þe book clepid 'þe prouoker of cristen peple'; | And he must remembre him silf vpon þe eende and P.M.M. inserts þe. entent for whiche baptyme was ordeyned, and conforme him to þe same entent and purpos. And if he þat schal be baptizid be not of sufficient age, or not of sufficient witt and discre∣cioun, whanne P.M.M. omits whanne . . . baptym. he receiviþ baptym, P.M.M. omits whanne . . . baptym. þanne he is excusid from þis þat is now seid into tyme he come into sufficient discrecioun to perfoorme what is now P.M.M., ″nowe ″is, the oblique dashes denoting transposition. seid.
ffadir, into what entent and purpos ordeyned god baptyme The purpose for which Baptism was ordained. to be receivid?

Soþeli, sone, þat þe receyver, in it receiving, schulde make a couenaunt wiþ god to kepe al þat is now afore MS. a fore. seid; and þat he schulde in þis wise remembre him þat crist, bi meryt of his blood scheding, waschiþ his synnes awaie, as þe watir waischiþ, at þilk tyme, his body; And þat he owith to be dede and biried from al his oold mys lyuyng, and to arise into a new MS. anew. lyuyng, as his body is biried in þe watir, and arisiþ vp from þe watir, and as crist lay deed in þe sepulcre, and arose into a newe lijf from þe sepulcre. and for þat baptym schulde be a signe MS. assigne; cross under first s. and a remembratife tokene P.M.M. reads: tokene of þese now seid conceitis. of þis now seid couenaunt, and also of þis now seid conceitis P.M.M. reads: tokene of þese now seid conceitis., þerfore was baptym ordeyned, as may be takun of seint poul, Romans, vje Space left for reference in P.M.M. chapitre.
ffadir, how receiviþ a man þe eukarist dewli? What is meant by receiving the Eucharist duly.

Sone, if he be of sufficient age and of sufficient witt and discrecioun whanne he it receiviþ, he must take þe eukarist, not as oþire comoun or vsual meete and drynk, as diden men
of corinthe in poulis daies, ia corinthies, xje chapitre; and he muste be in charite, þat is to seie, in dewe loue toward god and his neiȝboris, and be in wil to contynue þerynne, and be sory for alle defautis þer aȝens afore doon; and he muste remembre him silf vpon þe entent and purpos for whiche þis sacrament was ordeyned, and he muste co[n]forme MS. comforme; P.M.M., cōforme. him þerto. and if þe receiver be not of so sufficient age and discrecioun as is now P.M.M., now is. seid, he is, as for þanne, into tyme he come into sufficient discrecioun, ful excusid of þis charge.
ffadir, to what purpos, entent, and eende ordeined god The purpose for which the Eucharist was ordained. þe eukarist | to be receivid and hauntid?

Soþeli, sone, for þat þe receyver, in þe eukarist receiving, schulde ofte remembre him silf þerbi vpon cristis holy lijf and passioun, and vpon his benefetis and his lawe, and folewingly schulde take and make a sad purpos to god P.M.M. inserts: þouȝ without newe bond and couenaunt. þat he wole be oon to god and to his neiȝbore in charite, and in keping vertues and þe lijf whiche crist kepte and tauȝte in erþe; riȝt as þilk signes whiche he eetiþ and drinkiþ ben made, or seemen to be made, oon to him, or ioynyd to him, in his bodili substaunce. And forto make ofte þis remem∣braunce and oft þis purpos, was ordeynyd þe eukarist ofte to be eten and drunken, as to be P.M.M. inserts ofte. of þis seid P.M.M. omits seid. purpos a remem∣brauncyng tokene, or signe of witnesse þerof, as may be takun, luke, þe xxij Space left for reference in P.M.M. chapitre, and Ia corinthies, xje chapitre. And, In the margin of the P.M.M., by the side of the following passage, is written in a much larger, sixteenth-century hand: 'Transsubstantiation not knowe'. Pecock was accused of heresy on this point. See Babington's Introd. to Rep., pp. xlii, footnote 1, and lxxii, footnote 1. þerfore, if enye man receiveþ P.M.M., receyue. þis sacrament of eukarist, or þe sacrament of baptym, wiþ contrarye entent þan it signifieþ and bitokeneþ to be takun and vsid fore, he is in þilk receiving fals and double and scornyng to P.M.M. omits to. god, And þerfore he must needis greuousely P.M.M., in þat greuoseli. in þat P.M.M., in þat greuoseli. do synne.
P.M.M. substitutes: More of sacra∣mentis maye be seen in þe book of sacra∣mentis. No more of sacramentis here, bi cause þat of þese and of oþire sacramentis large doctryne is ȝouun in 'þe book of sacramentis', and in oþire bokis to h[i]m MS. hem. vndir seruyng P.M.M. substitutes: More of sacra∣mentis maye be seen in þe book of sacra∣mentis..

DIV3.HEAD: [ve chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Adir Cf. henceforward P.M.M., ije chapitre, fol. 14a to 14b (end)., how manye moral vertues, comaundis or coun∣seilis, THE SECOND TABLE. ben of þe ije table?
Sone, vij. There are seven moral virtues in the SECOND TABLE.
ffadir, whiche vij?

Sone, anentis god goostlynes, P.M.M. reads loue, and names larges next. obedience, riȝtwisnes, meke∣nes, The moral vir∣tues of the SECOND TABLE rehearsed. treuþe, benyngnite, and and, overwritten. larges larges comes second in the list in the P.M.M. .

ffadir, what is P.M.M. inserts it. forto lyve anentis god goostly
P.M.M., louyngli.
The Point is lettered a in red in margin of the P.M.M. to denote its being the First Point of the Second Table according to the reckoning of the P.M.M. (fol. 14a). The other Points are similarly lettered in the margin of the P.M.M. as a guide, the Points not being treated in the same order as that given in the list (fol. 14a). See Appendix for Table of Correspondences between P.M.M. and Donet., as it is To live to God goostly is to will to God what is not in our power to make Him have, or lack. þe first poynt of þe ij table?

Sone, it is forto wille P.M.M., wilne. to god al his good, whiche is not This goostlihode is one species of our friendly love towards God. in a P.M.M. omits a. creaturis power for to make him haue, or not haue, and lacke: as ben his myȝt, his wisdom, his loue, his mageste, and suche oþire. þis goostlihode P.M.M., loue. is oon spice P.M.M., speche, with the h under∣dotted to denote deletion. of þe al, hool, freendful welwilling and loue whiche we owen to god. P.M.M. inserts: as is open bi þe book clepid þe sufficience of þe iiij tablis. and þis spice of freendly loue toward god, as wel as oþire spicis of freendly loue toward god, we schulen haue and paie to god aboue al freendly loues to creaturis, and of al oure herte, of al oure soule, | and of alle oure strengþis. and how al þis is to be vndirstonde is sumwhat tauȝt in þe ije partie of 'þe P.M.M. omits þe moore book of. It is not clear whether this 'moore book of cristen religioun' is the Reule or a still larger work. In Donet, p. 15, l. 27, a second part of the Reule is referred to. See Introd., Section I, A. moore book of P.M.M. omits þe moore book of. It is not clear whether this 'moore book of cristen religioun' is the Reule or a still larger work. In Donet, p. 15, l. 27, a second part of the Reule is referred to. See Introd., Section I, A. cristen religioun', þe iije trety,
