and and . . . charite omitted in P.M.M. in 'þe book of feiþ, hope and charite and . . . charite omitted in P.M.M.,' and in þe book 'filling þe iiij tablis'.

purtenauncis to þis now seid freendful, welwilling loue, in The passions pertaining to our love to∣wards God: þe vndirstonding þerupon ȝouun in þe first partie of 'cristen religioun', þe iije trety, þe [ ] Space left in MS. and in P.M.M. for reference. chapitre, ben þese viij P.M.M., vij; reuþ being omitted. in (1) Eight in the sensual appe∣tites and the heart. þe sensual appetitis and in þe herte: þat is to seie, passional love, hate, desijr, drede, gladnes, sorynes, reuþ, P.M.M., vij; reuþ being omitted. schame, and P.M.M. substitutes: and þese vij; rouþe being omitted. oþir lijk viij P.M.M. substitutes: and þese vij; rouþe being omitted. passiouns vndir þe same names in þe (2) The corre∣sponding eight in the Will. ouerer appetite or wil: þat is to seie, passional love, hate, desijr, drede, gladnes, sorynes, rouþe P.M.M. substitutes: and þese vij; rouþe being omitted., and schame.

Of P.M.M. omits Of passional drede . . . seruyle drede. passional drede ben ij maners: oon whiche is drede The distinction between 'son∣like' dread and 'servile' dread. forto offend god and to lese his love, whiche is callid 'soneli drede'; Anoþir is drede forto falle into peyne or punysching, whiche is callid 'boond drede', or 'seruyle drede'. P.M.M. omits Of passional drede . . . seruyle drede. More P.M.M. reads: More of þe passiouns schal be seid aftir in þe iij parti of þe donet; this may therefore be the same thing as the Folewer. See Introd. to Donet, Section III; Folewer, Pt. I, chaps. xviii-xx. of þese passiouns schal be seid aftir in 'þe folewer to þe donet'. P.M.M. reads: More of þe passiouns schal be seid aftir in þe iij parti of þe donet; this may therefore be the same thing as the Folewer. See Introd. to Donet, Section III; Folewer, Pt. I, chaps. xviii-xx.

ffadir, what is forto lyue anentis god obediently? This Point is taken in the P.M.M. after largeness, righteousness, and meek∣ness, fols. 17b, l. 5, to 18a, l. 19, and is lettered c in red in the margin of the P.M.M. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8. To live to God obediently is to keep His com∣mandments and counsels.

Sone, it is forto obeie and kepe hise lawis of kynde assignyd to vs, summe bi his commaundement, and summe bi his counseiling; and forto obeie to alle hise voluntarie assignementis and positive ordinauncis, and to receyve hem and fulfille hem, as fer forþe MS. ferforþe. as we knowen his wil to be þat we so schulde do, bi witnessing of his holi scripture, as ben þese: forto P.M.M. omits forto . . . and. loue god moost of alle, and oure neiȝbore These com∣mandments and counsels re∣hearsed. as vs silf; and P.M.M. omits forto . . . and. forto allowe, receyue, and honoure þe P.M.M. runs: his new preesthode bi hym. newe preesthode P.M.M. runs: his new preesthode bi hym. sette forþ in his churche of þe newe lawe; and forto heere þe preestys þerof, and to receyve goddis loore and sacramentis of hem; and forto obeie to hem, as P.M.M. omits as. whanne
euer þei iustly for oure open defautis putten vs P.M.M. inserts denouncingli. oute of cristen, or saued mennys comuning On erasure in MS., P.M.M. simply mennys soorte. or felawschip P.M.M. simply mennys soorte.; and forto be receivid aȝen P.M.M. inserts denouncingli. bi hem into cristen mennys felawschip P.M.M. simply mennys soorte. and comunyng P.M.M. simply mennys soorte. whanne we leeuen þe same defautis; and for to be bi hem P.M.M. inserts at þe leeste denoun∣cyngli. of oure synnes assoilid whanne we schryven vs to hem | of þe same synnes, and P.M.M. omits: and . . . oþire. so of oþire P.M.M. omits: and . . . oþire.; And in lijk maner to alle P.M.M. inserts oþire. goddis voluntarye posityve assignementis ordeined P.M.M. omits ordeined . . . oþire. al redy, and to alle oþire, P.M.M. omits ordeined . . . oþire. in caas þat he enye suche wole make, ordeyne, schewe, or reule; þouȝ P.M.M. omits þouȝ...consideracioun. it so be þat þe kepingis of þe same counseilis of god and of lawe of kinde be in oþire tablis bi and aftir sum oþir consider∣acioun. P.M.M. omits þouȝ...consideracioun.

how cristen preesthode, with hise officis, P.M.M., office. in his sum maner Where teaching on the Christian priesthood may be found. is of lawe P.M.M. inserts here: of kynde and in his sum oþir maner is of lawe. of feiþ, is tauȝt and declarid sumwhat in þe first partie of 'cristen religioun', þe [iij] Spaces in MS. and P.M.M.; reference supplied from Gairdner's monograph, pp. 48-9. trety, þe [xvj] Spaces in MS. and P.M.M.; reference supplied from Gairdner's monograph, pp. 48-9. chapitre, and more P.M.M. runs: And more þerof schal appere in þe boke of sacramentis and in þe boke of preesthode. in þe first partie of 'þe iust apprising of holy scripture', and in 'þe book of preesthode'. P.M.M. runs: And more þerof schal appere in þe boke of sacramentis and in þe boke of preesthode.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue anentis god riȝtfulli, or To live to God riȝtfulli or justly, is: (1) To perform our promises made to God, whether thereto is set oath or vow, or no. iustly? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 16a to 17a, l. 2. This Point of riȝtwisenes is lettered d in red in the margin of the P.M.M. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8.

Sone, it stondiþ in two maners: Oon is, whanne euere and P.M.M., or. how of[te] MS. of; P.M.M., ofte. euere we wolen, or schulen to god make couenaunte or boond of biheest, bi worde, or bi oþire signe or dede occupiyng þe stide of worde, vpon eny þing to be of vs doon, or left vndoon, in tyme to come, to P.M.M. omits to . . . free. whiche we weren bifore free P.M.M. omits to . . . free., þat we perfoorme þilke boond and couenaunt, bi cause þat bi þilke boond growiþ to god a riȝt MS. ariȝt. forto cleyme þilk dede bihestid in boond and couenaunt,
and P.M.M. omits: and ... promys. also ellis we schulde breke oure promys P.M.M. omits: and ... promys., and þat wheþir to þilk boond made, ooþ or vowe be ioyned and sett, or no; so þat þe mater and dede bihiȝt in boond to god be honest and profitable into goddis seruyce, alle þingis seen, and for alle tymes considerid; And so þat it be seen, in doom of avisid resoun, profitable or needful þat we sette to such ooþ or vowe to þe seid biheestis in to þis eend, þat we be þe more, and þe ofter, and þe spedelier MS. spededelier; P.M.M., spedilier. remembrid and stirid to perfoorme þo P.M.M, þe. biheestis; þouȝ, þouȝ ... god omitted in P.M.M. See Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix. aftir sum oþir skile Such deeds of promise may also be classified under Truth, the Fifth Point of the Second Table. and consideracioun, alle suche dedis ben in þe v poynt of þis same secunde table, whiche is trovþe to god. þouȝ ... god omitted in P.M.M. See Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix.

Anoþir P.M.M., And oþir. maner of riȝtwisnes to god is þat we so bere vs anentis alle hise creaturis þat we in no maner trete, vse, or (2) To use His goods and His creatures ac∣cording to His commands. demeene enye of hise goodis, or enye of hise crea∣turis, aȝens his wil: þat is to seie, in oþir wise þan he haþ ordeined hem of vs to be tretid, vsid, and demeenyd; and þat is into releef of oure nede, and into oure necessarye sportyng, and suche oþire vsis helping, þat þerbi oþire notable seruycis of god schulen be þe bettir doon, alle tymes considerid; fforwhi it is open þat in suche maner of iustnes and riȝtwisnes we ouȝte bere vs iustly anentis oure neiȝboris, And þerfore moche raþir þus iustly anentis god, and ellis we doon to god wrong.

ffadir, what is P.M.M. inserts it. forto P.M.M., to. lyve anentis god mekely? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 17a, l.2, to 17b, l.5. The Point of mekenes is lettered e in red in the margin of the P.M.M. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8. To live to God mekely is to abase ourselves, and venerate Him.

Sone, it is forto louȝe vs silf vndir god in conceyt, in wil, in countenaunce, worde, tokene, and werk, and to hiȝe god fer above vs in alle þese seid maners as oure [hiȝest] MS. biheest; P.M.M., hiȝest, which makes much better sense. and souereynest lord; And þat we forbere to attempte or assaie Also to forbear from tempting God to work unnecessary miracles on our behalf. goddis myȝt, wijsdom, or wil, þat he schulde do or worche for vs sum werk aboue kynde, bi miracle, wiþout nede, or wiþoute sure reuelacioun þat we schulden assaie him so to
do; whiche attemptyng wolde falle in caas þat we wolde take vpon vs, wiþoute nede, and wiþoute sure reuelacioun from god þat we schulde so take vpon vs, sum werk passing oure power of kynd; or if we wolde purpos sum eende, and ȝitt we wolde leve of to take meenys being in oure power of kinde toward þe same eende, withoute sure reuelacioun þat we schulde so leue, and we wolde waite MS. awaite; the first a underdotted. aftir þat god schulde sende vs helpe þerto aboue kynde.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fol. 18a, l. 19, to 19a, l. 2. The Point is lettered f in red in the margin of the P.M.M. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8. what is it forto lyue anentis god trewly, nameliche P.M.M. omits nameliche. To live to God trewly is to be absolutely true in affirming, denying, and performing, whether thereto be set oath or vow, or no. wiþoute such boond as is spokun of in þe iij P.M.M.,ij, as the Points are differently arranged. poynt of þis ije table?

Sone, it is, as ofte as we wolen, or schulen to god afferme or denye, bi worde or bi signe, countenaunce, or dede occu∣piyng þe stide of worde, enye þing present, passid, or to MS. orto. come, P.M.M. inserts bi vs or bi eny oþir doer. þat we þerinne afferme and denye treuly: þat is to seie, as it is, was, or P.M.M., and. schal be; and þat wheþir we to þilk affermyngis or deneiyngis sette ooþ or vow, or neiþir ooþ, neiþir vow; And so þat we lien not to god | vpon þingis present or passid, as cayn dide, genesis, iiij v. 9. Space for reference in P.M.M. chapitre, seiyng to god þus: 'y wote not, lord', whanne god askid of him: 'Where is þi broþir abel?' neiþir we absteyne fro þe perfoormyng of oure dede to come, whiche we han affermyd vs to do, wiþoute P.M.M. omits wiþoute ... purpos. promysse, in oonly purpos, P.M.M. omits wiþoute ... purpos. but if iust cause rise forto h[i]m MS. hem; P.M.M., hym. forbere, And so þat þerupon we not lie.

ffadir, what is it forto lyue anentis god benyngnely? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fol. 19a, l. 2 to l. 14. Lettered g in red in margin of P.M.M. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8. To live to God benyngnely is to accept his punishments meekly, without grumbling.

Sone, it is forto forbere worde, countenaunce, and werk which schulde tempte god into disturblaunce of his quyetenes and reste wiþynne forþe, if he were þerto movable, and into
it chaungeable, as man is. And so herbi folewingly we P.M.M., he. muste forbere blasphemyng, chiding, and reuyling, mowyng, scornyng, and suche oþire toward god, for eny of his chastis∣ingis sent to vs, or suffrid falle to vs. P.M.M. here concludes this section: And þus myche as for þe vij vertues or comaundementis of þe secunde table; as the Donet (ll.15-16) after treating largenes.

ffadir, what is it P.M.M. omits it. forto lyue anentis god largely? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fol. 15b. The Point is lettered b in black in the margin. See Donet, p. 36, footnote 8. To live to God largely is to voluntarily give to God what He does not exact, such as wilful poverty and chastity done to God immediately.

Sone, it is forto ȝolde, ȝeue, or paie to god what we ben not bounde forto ȝolde, ȝeue, or do to him; as ben dedis of pure counseile and of plenteuosenes, and not of comaunde∣ment, neiþir of dette. Suche dedis ben wilful pouerte and chastite, in þilk skile and consideracioun in whiche þei ben ȝulde and ȝouen to god immediatly; þouȝ þe same pouerte The same poverty and chastity if done to oneself immediately, belong to the Third Table. and chastite, in skile and consideracioun in whiche þei ben chosun of a man to be his immediat good disposiciouns, þouȝ into god fynaly þei ben in þe iije table.
and þus moche as for þe vij vertues or comaundementis of þe ije table.
[vje chapitre] Chapter numbered 6 in margin. THE THIRD TABLE.

[F]Adir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., iije chapitre, fols. 19a, l. 15, to 20a, l. 6. how manye vertues, or comaundementis and There are eight virtues in the THIRD TABLE. counseilis in general, ben of þe iije table?
Sone, viij. P.M.M., v; ffleischlihode, worldlihode, and largenes being omitted.
ffadir, whiche viij? P.M.M., v; ffleischlihode, worldlihode, and largenes being omitted. The eight moral virtues of the THIRD TABLE rehearsed.

Sone, to vs silfward P.M.M., silward. goostlihode, P.M.M., loue. ffleischlihode, These three Points are omitted in P.M.M. worldli∣hode, These three Points are omitted in P.M.M. Clennesse, honeste, pacience, P.M.M. here inserts and. douȝtines, and largenes.These three Points are omitted in P.M.M. Or ellis þus: ffor to lyue toward vs silf, as P.M.M., as ... deemeþ omitted. resoun or feiþ deemeþ, P.M.M., as ... deemeþ omitted. goostly, P.M.M., louyngli. fleischly, P.M.M. omits fleischly, worldly, largeli. worldly, P.M.M. omits fleischly, worldly, largeli. clenly, honestly, pacientli, P.M.M. here inserts and. douȝtily, and largeli. P.M.M. omits fleischly, worldly, largeli.

ffadir, what is þe goostlihode P.M.M., loue. of a man anentis him silf, To live to one∣self goostly is to will to oneself heavenly goods and re∣wards, not in man's power to give, or take away. as it is þe first poynt of þe iij table?

Sone, it is a willing P.M.M., wilnyng. bi whiche a man williþ P.M.M., wilneþ. to him | silf þo goodis whiche is not in eny creaturis kyndeli power forto ȝeue to him or putte to him, or take aweie from him: as ben oure blisful P.M.M., blesful. rewardis to be had in heuene, and goddis fre P.M.M. inserts stiring. gracis þidirward helping here in erþe. Certis, P.M.M. omits Certis ... him silf. þis This goostlihode is a species of love towards oneself. goostlihode is not but a spice, or a remembre, of þe al, hool, welwilling love whiche a man ouȝte forto haue anentis him silf. P.M.M. omits Certis ... him silf.

ffadir, how moche ouȝte a man loue him silf wiþ þilk A man should love himself goostly less than God, and more than any other creature. goostlihode P.M.M., loue. whiche is þe first poynt of þis present MS. present f; f being crossed through obliquely. iije table?

Sone, wiþ þilk loue he schal loue him silf lasse þan god, and more þan enye P.M.M. omits enye. oþir creature. What þis loue is, and what is loue of frendschip, and what is loue of concupiscence, and how a man haþ not loue of freendschip saue to god, and A man's goostly love is only for God, himself, and other reasonable creatures. to him silf, and to oþire reasonable creaturis, is P.M.M. runs: is tauȝt in þe iij þarti of þe donet, chapitre and in þe filling of þe iiij tablis, þe ije parti, þe chapitre, spaces being left for the references. This 'iij parti of þe donet' may be the same thing as the Folewer. See Introd. to the Donet, Section III. See p. 36, footnote 14. tauȝt in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe first trety, and in 'þe book of feiþ, hope, and charite', and in þe ije partie of 'þe grettir book of cristen religioun'. P.M.M. runs: is tauȝt in þe iij parti of þe donet, chapitre and in þe filling of þe iiij tablis, þe ije parti, þe chapitre, spaces being left for the references. This 'iij parti of þe donet' may be the same thing as the Folewer. See Introd. to the Donet, Section III. See p. 36, footnote 14.

ffadir, what is fleischlihode, as it is þe ije poynt of þe iije To live to one∣self fleischely is to desire, seek after, get, have, and keep the goods of the flesh as Reason commands, or allows. table? P.M.M. omits Point of fleischlihode.

Sone, it is forto wille, seche aftir, gete, haue, and kepe goodis of þe fleisch in maner and mesure and in oþire circumstauncis wiþ þe whiche resoun comaundiþ or allowiþ hem to be souȝte aftir, gete, haue, and holde: as ben wijf, children, mete, drynk, helþe, strengþe, and suche oþire þingis openli knowun to alle men forto long immediatly to
þe fleisch. and alle þese seching, getyng, havyng, and Such seeking after, getting, having, and keeping are 'executions' of the desiring or willing to have such fleshly goods; and so are in the same Table as the willing. keping, wiþ manye fold dyuers werkis, ben execuciouns of þe willing to haue þe same fleischly goodis, And þerfore þei ben in þe same moral kynde and table in whiche is þe willing to haue þe same fleischli goodis.

ffadir, what is worldlihode, P.M.M. omits the Point of worldlihode. as it is þe iije poynt of þe iije table? To live to one∣self worldly is to desire, seek after, get, have, and keep worldly goods as Reason com∣mands or allows.

Sone, it is for to wille, seche aftir, gete, and haue, and holde worldli goodis, aftir rehercid in þe vertu of honeste, in maner and mesure and in oþire circumstauncis as resoun comaundiþ or allowiþ. And, siþen bi what euer meenys or dedis þis seching, getyng, and holding ben not but execu∣ciouns Such seeking after, getting, having, and keeping are 'executions' of the desiring or willing to have such worldly goods; and so are in the same Table as the willing. of þe seid willing into þe | same worldli goodis; þerfore þe dedis bi whiche þese seching, getyng, and holding be made and doon, ben in þe same moral kynde of vertu, and in þe same table, in whiche is þe willing, þouȝ þei ben fer distaunt in natural kynde fro þe seid willing.

ffadir, þouȝ y ouȝte not bere ȝou an honde þat ȝe putten Are not fleischli∣hode and worldlihode usually termed 'vices'? vicis into þe iije table in stide of vertues, þat is to seie, fleischlihode and worldlihode, ȝitt, certis, vndir þo same names in whiche ȝe clepen þe ije and iije vertues of þe iije table, oþire men clepen 'vicis', and how men wolen allowe ȝoure þeryn clepyng, y wote not.

Sone, truste þou to me, or ellis trust þou to resoun, þat Fleischlihode and worldlihode are vices only in so far as they are practised in excess, or practised other∣wise against the doom of Reason. þer is no fleischlihode or worldlihode [a] MS. or. vice, saue for þat he is vnmesurable, or in sum oþire wise aȝens þe doom of resoun. And, siþen not eche fleischlihode and eche worldli∣hode is vice, but it muste nedis be þat as eche fleischlihode and eche worldlihode whiche ben vnresonable ben vicis, so eche fleischlihode and eche worldlihode whiche ben resonable, þat They are virtues in so far as they are reasonable. is to seie, according to doom of resoun, ben vertues. And 'Fleischlihode' and 'worldli∣hode' are general terms covering both the virtue and the vice. þerfore folewiþ þat þese names 'fleischlihode' and 'worldli∣hode' ben general and indifferent as wel to vertues as to vicis. And so, if for þis generalte and indifference, oþire men mowe clepe vicis bi þo names, so wel may y for þe
same generalte and indifference clepe vertues bi þo same names; Nameliche siþen noon oþire special and propre names ben sette to þo vertues. þerfore who euere wole chalenge my now bifore vsid namyngis of þe ije and iije membre in þe iije table, lete him assigne to me specyal according names to þo ij membris, whiche he may not seie nay but þat þei ben vertues, for þat þei accorden to doom of resoun; and y wole anoon forbere and absteyne me fro þe seid maners of calling. It is the thing, not the name, that signifies. And eer he can so to me assigne, y can not bettir counseil to me and to him for pees and accorde þan forto remembre it what oon writiþ in sentence þus: 'Whilis men accorden in þe þing and in þe treuþe in it silf, stryue þei not aboute wor∣dis and namyng of þe same þing'; Nameliche herfore for þat alle wordis mowe signifie as men at her owne lust wole haue hem to to overwritten in MS. signifie, and specialy in nede, whanne þere is not so greet plente of names but þat þer is lack of propre names to summe propre þingis, as it is in þis present purpos.

ffadir, what if it lijk to men forto clepe þe ije and þe iije Should not the virtues be termed 'reson∣able fleischli∣hode' and 'resonable worldlihode', to prevent mis∣understanding? pointis of þe iije table vndir þese names: 'resonable fleischli∣hode' and 'resonable worldlihode'? it semeþ, fadir, þat þese namyngis schulden wel notifie þat þilk fleischlihode and þilk worldlihode of whiche ȝe meenen in þese ije and iije pointis, ben moral vertues and not moral vicis.

Sone, if þis cleping whiche þou now assignest may do eese This is not necessary, but quite per∣missible, if it will help igno∣rant men. to symple persoonys for her sympilte, whiche ben strongli movid oft bi sown of worde more þan bi þe trouþe of þe þing in it silf, y am wel plesid þat þese ije and iije pointis of þe iije table be þus clepid 'resonable fleischlihode' and 'resonable worldlihode'. but ȝitt, certis, sone, siþen it is so, þat þis resonabilnesse is includid in eche moral vertue, and is nedisli and essenciali requirid to eche dede, if þilk dede schulde be a moral vertuose dede, it is not nede, but raþir vayne, forto expresse resonablenesse in þe namyng of eny moral vertu, if we bere oure consideracioun to þe þing as it is in it silf. Neuerþeles, mennys eesis which mow stonde wiþoute yuel þerof comyng, y wole raþir fauoure þan lette. And, þerfore, take who so wole þe namyngis for whiche, sone, þou pledist.

ffadir, perauenture to manye men it wole seeme þat þe ije Are not reson∣able fleischlihode and resonable worldlihode the same as clennes and honeste? point, which is resonable fleischlihode, is al oon wiþ þe iiije point, whiche is clennes; And þat þe iije point, whiche is resonable worldlihode, is al oon and þe same wiþ þe ve point, whiche is honeste, in lasse þan ȝe, fadir, putte here sum difference bitwix hem.

Sone, sufficient difference is sette bitwix hem where eche Resonable fleischlihode is not the same thing as clennes, for resonable fleischlihode is concerned with the reasonable seeking after, getting, having, and keeping of fleshly goods; clennes with the reasonable use of them. of hem in his owne place is discryvid; fforwhi resonable fleischlihode is in þe resonable | sechyng aftir, getyng, having, and holding of fleischly goodis, as mete, drynk, and oþire; And clennes is in þe resonable vsing of þo same goodis, whanne and aftir þat þei ben resonabili gete and had. and open it is þat a man may folewe þe doom of resoun in seching aftir, in getyng, having, and holding mete and drynk in quantite and qualite of hem, and ȝitt, whanne he schal vse hem, he may do aȝens doom of resoun, for he may ete ouer moche and drynk ouer moche at oonys of hem. and herbi eche man may wite þat resonable fleischlihode is not þe same vertu whiche is clennes, siþen a man may have þe oon whilis he lackiþ þe oþire, ȝhe, whilis he haþ vice con∣trarie to þe oþire.

In lijk maner, bi resonable worldlihode we ben reulid And, for a similar reason, resonable worldlihode is not the same thing as honeste. forto in resonable maner seche aftir, gete, and haue worldli goodis; and bi honeste we ben reulid forto resonabili vse hem aftir þei ben gete and had. And it may be so, þat a man MS. aman. folewith doom of resoun in getyng hem, and þerfore haþ resonable worldlihode vpon hem, and ȝitt he folewiþ not þe doom of resoun in vsing hem; for peraventure he ouer moche vsiþ hem, and þerfore haþ not honeste vpon hem, but haþ þe vice whiche is contrarie to honeste. and þerfore it is open ynouȝ þat resonable worldlihode and honeste ben not oon and þe same vertu, siþen þe oon of hem may be had whilis þe oþire is not had. And if þei weren al oon, certis, whanne euer þe oon of hem were had, þe oþire were also þan had. And þis is y-nouȝ, sone, to þin entent.
ffadir, wherto seruen þo gracis of whiche ȝe han now Man needs God's grace: spoke? See above, p. 42, l. 7. This section is omitted in P.M.M.

Sone, wiþoute grace no man may eny good dede do (1) to obtain reward in heaven. deservingli for to have for it eny rewarde of blys of heuene, and withoute grace no man may be preseruyd or defendid (2) to be pre∣served from various dangers, fro myschauncis and myscheefis whiche bi kinde wollen ofte falle: bi fier, bi watir, bi enemyte of men or of spiritis, and bi oure owne worching, stonding, or walking in perilose placis, where ben perels of deeþ, and ȝitt to vs vnknowun, and so of oþire maners; and | aȝens whiche, whanne and if þei falle, no man MS. noman may lette for þe while but god; and god no man MS. noman so helpiþ in such a caas saue whom as þerto he haþ in a specyal grace. Also, wiþoute grace no man MS. noman may have (3) to obtain forgiveness of sin. forȝeuenes of his synne bifore doon, how euer moche contri∣cioun and confessioun and oþire dedis he worche forto have þerof forȝeuenes. And ȝitt noon grace is bouȝte of god; but God's grace is freely given. eche grace is frely ȝouun of god, and ellis grace were no grace.

ffadir, whiche ben þoo dedis bi whiche a man stirith and Rehearsal of the moral vir∣tuous deeds by which a man may obtain God's grace: (1) Willing and desiring to have such grace. (2) Moral vir∣tuous deeds done for God. prouokith god into ȝeving of þe seid grace, or gracis, to him?

Sone, bisi willing and desiring made to god forto haue hem is oon meene into grace, or into þe first and þe secunde now seid effectis. And also ech moral vertuose dede doon for god, and in grace bifore hadde, is meene into þe sam[e] MS. sam. effectis, and into encrecing and into multipliyng of suche gracis. Certis, MS. Certis "bi 'asking, with the marks of transposition. asking bi MS. Certis "bi 'asking, with the marks of transposition. inward or outward speche, þat is to seie, preier made to god, availiþ not þerto, but oonly in how moche it availiþ into making, contynuyng, or encresing þis seid willing and desiring withinforþe in þe asker, as it is sumwhat bifore (3) Penitence for sin. [seid] Omitted in MS. in þe fourþe chapitre. See above, pp. 30-31. Also specialy, into ȝeuing of grace into þis effect þat þerbi wijt of synne bifore doon schal be forȝouun and doon aweie, contricioun, confessioun, purpos forto not oftir synne, desiring and willing and preier, tendre perfoormyng and keping of goddis lawe, bi so moche þe bettir þat þer aȝens was doon trespace, and oþire mo aftir in þe xviij chapitre to be rehercid, ben prouocative meenys. and þe hool agregate of þese meenys for þe iije, or þe last now rehercid grace, is clepid 'penaunce', or, more propirly,
'penitence' or 'forþenking', taking þilk name of þe formest dede among þo prouocatyve meenys, whiche is contricioun, þat is to seie, a willing of a man whiche haþ synned þat he hadde neuer synned. So þat þis penitence is not ellis þan a spice of þis goostliho∣od, and is an execucioun of a willing to haue þe seid grace whiche schulde sche[u]e The MS. clearly reads schene, an unknown word; perhaps an error for scheue. See Notes. oute from him wijt of his synne bifore of him doon. Also, into getyng of (4) Friendship with good men. grace fro god to a man him silf, into eche maner of effect of grace, availiþ ful moche if þe same man putte him silf into þe special and dere freendschip of anoþir man moche lovid of god, and make þat þe seid oþire holi man accepte him into his dere freendschip. Certis, in such caas, þe seid holy mannys freendschip anentis god schal deserue ful greet gracis to þis man, þouȝ þis same holy man preie not to god þerfore, as herof doctryne is had in 'þe more book of cristen religioun', þe first partie, þe secunde tretice.
ffadir, what is clennes? Cf henceforward P M.M., fols. 20a, l. 6, to 23a, 1. 12. To live to one∣self clenly is to obey Reason in (1) nurysching, (2) gendring.
Sone, it is forto kepe and fulfille þe doom of resoun in vse P.M.M. substitutes dedis. of nurysching and in vse P.M.M. substitutes dedis. of gendring, for goddis sake fynaly or eendly.
ffadir, what is clennes in vse P.M.M. substitutes dedis. of nurisching? (1) Clennes in nurysching is of two degrees:

Sone, clennes in nurisching is ech gouernaunce doon bi doom of resoun in vse of P.M.M. omits vse of. nurisching, or aboute vse in P.M.M. omits vse in. nurisching. and of þis clennes or gouernaunce ben ij degrees: Oon is mesurable and temperat taking and vsing of mete (a) Sobriety, which is a commandment. and drynk, slepe, housing, cloþing, laboure, rest, eir, delec∣taciouns; vse of oure inward and outwarde sensitive wittis, and vse of her appetitis and þe P.M.M. omits þe. delectaciouns; þe vse of oure resoun, mynde and wil; and vse of oure bodili goyng, moving, ligging, resting and sitting, gesture, lauȝyng, speking and countenauncyng, in maner, mesure, quantite and tyme, and in oþire circumstauncis, as P.M.M. omits as profit or. profit or P.M.M. omits as profit or. as nede askith to P.M.M. omits to þe fleisch. þe fleisch P.M.M. omits to þe fleisch., for goddis sake, and for his seruice þe
bettir to be doon, and not for oure volupte. And þis degree of clennes in nurisching may wel be clepid 'sobirte'.

Anoþir degree of cleene norisching is to forbere sumwhat (b) Abstinencè or fasting, which is a counsel. of þese now bifore seid þingis, wiþ vow or wiþoute vow, more þan resoun biddiþ or commaundiþ to be forborn, and þerfore sumwhat more þan is bi þe now bifore goyng degree to be forborn; And ȝitt, forto so forbere, into sum eend | and effect to be þerbi geten, resoun wel allowiþ and preisiþ, for as moche as resoun deemeþ þilk forbering to be a profitable meene into sum g[r]ettir MS. gettir; P.M.M., grettir. good þan to whiche good þe first bifore sette degree of cleene norisching mai be meene. And þis degree of clennes in norisching, or of cleene norisching, may wel be clepid 'abstinence' or 'fastyng'; þouȝ P.M.M. omits þouȝ ... him silf. Cf. Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix. it so be Clennes as a counsel is included under largenes to oneself. þat, bi and aftir sum special consideraciouns whiche mowe be had vpon maners, degrees and circumstauncis of sum clennessis, alle þo clennessis which so ben vndir counseil and oute of precept, as so and suche, ben in þe viij point of þis iije table, whiche is largenes of a man to him silf. P.M.M. omits þouȝ ... him silf. Cf. Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix.
ffadir ffadir, an addition from the margin in P.M.M., what is clennes of gendring? (2) Clennes in gendring is of three degrees:

Sone, clennes anentis dedis of gendring is ech gouernaunce doon and lad bi doom of resoun anentis vsis P.M.M., deedis. of gendring. and of þis clennes or gouernaunce ben iij degrees: Oon is (a) Temperance, which is a commandment. a man to knowe fleischli a womman not oute of wedlok, and þanne wiþ office and entent to gete a childe, if god wole it graunte; or ellis to paie þe dede of P.M.M., for. wery and perilose luste of his feere, whanne she P.M.M., he or she. or he P.M.M., he or she. askiþ þe fleischli dede to be doon, for drede of her falle into avoutrie, P.M.M., fornicacioun. or into worse; And in þese ij caasis is clennes from P.M.M., fro. al synne in þe paier, as is comounli holden; Or ellis, in þe iij caase, forto satisfie his owne wery and perilose birþen of lust, and not for his owne desirid and willid P.M.M. omits: and willid. voluptuose lust, neiþir for such of his feer voluptuose willid lust. And þanne in such an asker is clennes from P.M.M., fro. deedly synne, but not from P.M.M., fro. venial synne, as is comounly holden; þouȝ in þis caase be no synne in þe
paier, as is now afore seid. Neuerþelees P.M.M. (fols. 21b, l. 13, to 22a, l. 6) substitutes: Neuerþeles to summen it semeþ ful probable þat pure clennes from al synne may be oonli in þe first case now rehercid, þat is to seie, whanne persoons in matrimonye couplid delyne to gedir vndir hope of child bigeten and for þilk eend, and ellis þei wolden not so to gedir deele; and þat in ech of þe oþir casis seid deling to gedre in matrimonye is synful, þouȝ in sum of hem be more synne þan in summe, as is open to resoun þat it so schuld be. And þis degre of clennes anentis gendryug may be clepid 'temperaunce'., moche þing may be seid colourabili aȝens þis iije caase, as schal appere in 'þe book of cristen religioun', þe first partie, þe iije tretice. þerfore no more MS. nomore. of þis mater here, but þat þis degree of clennes anentis gendring mai be clepid 'temperaunce'. P.M.M. (fols. 21b, l. 13, to 22a, l. 6) substitutes: Neuerþeles to summen it semeþ ful probable þat pure clennes from al synne may be oonli in þe first case now rehercid, þat is to seie, whanne persoons in matrimonye couplid delyne to gedir vndir hope of child bigeten and for þilk eend, and ellis þei wolden not so to gedir deele; and þat in ech of þe oþir casis seid deling to gedre in matrimonye is synful, þouȝ in sum of hem be more synne þan in summe, as is open to resoun þat it so schuld be. And þis degre of clennes anentis gendryng may be clepid 'temperaunce'.

þe ije degree of clennes anentis gendring is to forbere, wiþ (b) Continence, which is a counsel. vowe or wiþoute vowe, dedis of gendring, sumwhat | more, or moche more, þan resoun biddiþ or comaundiþ to be for∣born, And þerfore sumwhat more, or moche more, þan is bi þe now next bifore goyng degree to be forborn; þouȝ resoun forto so moche forbere, into sum eende and effecte to be þerbi getun, weel allowiþ and preisiþ, for as moche as resoun deemeþ þis forseid more forbering to be a profitable meene into sum grettir good þan to which good þe former degree of clennes anentis gendring may be meene. And þis degree of clennes anentis gendring may wel be clepid 'contynence'.

þe iije degree of clennes anentis dedis of gendring is for∣bering (c) Chastity, which is a counsel. vttirly for euer, in vowe or wiþoute vowe, dedis of gendring, vndir þis entent, þat þerbi sum greet goostli goode be geten, which good, wiþoute þe now seid vttirly forbering, schulde not be geten, And which good, so bi þis now seid vttirly forbering geten, is grettir good þan is þe good which, wiþoute þe P.M.M., þis. now seid vttirly forberyng, and wiþ P.M.M., without. enye of þe oþire now bifore goyng forberyng P.M.M., forberigis [sic]., schulde be getun; And þerfore [resoun] Omitted in MS.; P.M.M., resoun. wel allowiþ and deemeþ þis vttirly forbering to be mowe do. And þis iije degree is comounly clepid Continence and chastity are sometimes included under largenes towards oneself; sometimes under largenes towards God; 'chastite'; þouȝ P.M.M. omits þouȝ ... table. See Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix. þe ije and iije degree, aftir sum oþir skile and consideracioun, ben in þe viij poynt of þis iije table, and, aftir sum oþire skile and consideracioun, þei mowe be in þe vije poynt of þe ije table, and, aftir sum oþir consider∣acioun
of promys maad to god forto kepe hem, þei mowe be sometimes under riȝt∣wisnes towards God. in þe iije poynt of þe ij table. P.M.M. omits þouȝ ... table. See Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ix.

and, siþen to a P.M.M., þe. capiteyn of a castel, to whom longiþ þe The proper use of our inward and outward sensi∣tive wits, &c., so that they do not lead us unto Vnclennes, is included under Clennes. saaf gardyng of þe ynner warde, longiþ forto se P.M.M. inserts to. þe saaf gard of þe vttir P.M.M., vtterer. warde and of þe gatis, and awaite to alle vttir P.M.M., vtterer. þingis which schulen P.M.M., schuld. make perel into þe wynnyng of þe castel; þerfore to boþe clennes of norysching and to clennes of gendring longiþ þe vse of oure inwarde and outwarde sensitive wittis and vse of her appetitis and delectaciouns, þe vse of oure resoun, mynde and wil, and vse of oure bodely goyng, moving, resting, sitting, gesture, lauȝing, speking and countenau[n]cyng, MS. omits contraction mark for n: P.M.M., countenauncyng. in | maner, mesure, quantite and tyme, and in oþire circumstauncis, as þei putten not vs in perelle to falle into þe now seid vnclennes of gendring and P.M.M. omits: and of norisching. of norisching. P.M.M. omits: and of norisching.

DIV3.HEAD: [vije chapitre]. Numbered 7 chapitre in margin.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 23a, l. 12, to 29a, l. 13. what is þe vertu of honeste? To live to one∣self honestly is to obey Reason (1) in use of worldly goods; (2) in one's actions.

Sone, Sone, in P.M.M. a correction from margin. it [is] Omitted in MS.; P.M.M., is. forto kepe and fulfille þe doom of resoun anentis vse of P.M.M. omits vse of. worldly goodis to vs silf ward, and anentis þe moving, P.M.M. inserts and after movyng. gesture, and countenaunce, and setting of oure body. And so it stondiþ in two maners, or ij spicis: Oon is (1) Honeste in use of worldly goods. mesurable and resonable vsing P.M.M. inserts geting, treting, and louyng, which is contrary to the teaching of the Donet, p. 45, where honeste is differentiated from resonable worldlihode. of worldly goodis, which ben þese: ricches, þat is to seie, money, and al þat may be bouȝt and soolde for money, apparels or araies, meyne, dignitees, officis, worschipis, preisyngis, fauouris, fames, fredom and liberte of wil, ioies, sportis, myrþis, pleies, lauȝingis, kyn, children, not P.M.M. omits not considerid . . . worldlynes. considerid to be vsid for nede and profite to þe fleisch, but into anoþir eende of worldlynes, P.M.M. omits not considerid . . . worldlynes. for goddis
sake and his seruice P.M.M., seruices; and þerbi omitted. þerbi P.M.M., seruices; and þerbi omitted. þe bettir to be doon. Which Honeste in use of worldly goods is of different degrees: (a) Moderation, or measure. now seid honeste men and wommen maken to haue dyuers maners and degrees: fforwhi sum man MS. summan. vsiþ P.M.M. runs: sum man desiriþ, sechiþ aftir and takiþ þe now bifore, &c., which is contrary to the teaching of the Donet, p. 45. See p. 50, footnote 13. þe bifore P.M.M. runs: sum man desiriþ, sechiþ aftir and takiþ þe now bifore, &c., which is contrary to the teaching of the Donet, p. 45. See p. 50, footnote 13. rekened kyndis of worldly godis into his propre lordschip, withoute eny refuse of her multitude or quantite, forto vse hem, not into his owne lust or plesaunce oonly, neiþir principaly, but into þe seruice and plesaunce of god bi vse of hem to be doon. And þis first degree of honeste may wel be clepid 'mesure'. And sum man vsiþ P.M.M. runs: sum man desiriþ, sechiþ aftir and takiþ, &c. See note above. into his propre (b) Wilful poverty, which is of four degrees; one being greatest wilful poverty. civil lordschip sum kyndis of þe P.M.M., þo. now seid godis, and forberiþ vse of P.M.M. omits vse of. sum oþire kyndis of hem, and þat wiþ vowe or wiþoute vowe; or ellis he takiþ into vse P.M.M. omits into vse. alle kyndis of hem, but not in so greet habundaunce eny of hem as resoun wole wel suffre hem to be mowe take; And þat for he wolde be þerbi þe abiler into doyng of sum notable grettir goostli MS. goostlihode; the hode crossed through. goode þan he can do wiþoute þe now seid maner of forbering. Sum man MS. summan. forberiþ þe propre cyuyl lordschip of summe now P.M.M., now "seid "bifore, the oblique dashes denoting transposition. bifore seid P.M.M., now "seid "bifore, the oblique dashes denoting transposition. worldly goodis, þat is to seie, of worldli richessis, and þat wiþ vowe | or wiþoute vowe; And he kepiþ þe cyuyl lordschip in comoun with summe neiȝboris, or felawis, vpon þe same worldli ricchessis, how euer moche he and his seid felawis mowe come to bi noon weernyng of resoun, And þat wheþir þo ricchessis ben movable or vnmouable; Neuer∣þeles, herwiþ he takiþ no more MS. nomore. to be spent vpon his owne persoone þan natural nede or goostly nede, bi riȝt doom of resoun, askiþ to be aboute his persoon spendid. Sum man MS. summan. forberiþ þe propre cyuyl lordschip of alle ricchessis, and al cyuyl lordschip in comoun wiþ oþire felawis, vpon vnmouable ricchessis oonli, and þat wiþ vowe, or wiþoute vowe; And he kepiþ þe cyuyl lordschip in comoun wiþ summe oþire neiȝboris, or felewis, vpon mouable worldli richessis, how moche euer, wiþoute wernyng of resoun, he and his seid
felawis mowe come to; Neuerþeles, herwiþ he takiþ no more to be spended vpon his owne persoone þan natural nede or goostly nede, bi riȝt doom of resoun, consentiþ and grauntiþ to be aboute his persoone spendid. And eche of þese next bifore rehercid iij degrees of forberyngis, or forsakingis, is clepid 'wilful pouerte', þouȝ oon of hem be grettir pouerte þan is anoþire of hem. Sum man forberiþ al P.M.M. inserts ciuil. lordschip in his owne propurte, and in comoun wiþ oþire felewis, haue∣able, wiþoute weernyng of resoun, vpon worldli ricchessis mouable and vnmouable, And þat wiþ þerto vowe, or with∣oute vowe. and he holdiþ him content with þe bare vse of hem toward him silf in a streit sufficience as to his kynde and his natureward, and with þe mynystracioun and dis∣pensing of þo ricchessis to be made aboute oþire felawis and oþire ferþir neiȝboris in her nede bodili and goostli, And þat in oon of þe first bifore going maners touchid of honeste, þat is to seie, in receiving into mynistracioun as manye ricchessis as he may come to bi not weernyng of resoun, or ellis in receyuing oonly a certeyn quantite, and in | a certeyn mesure, of worldli ricchessis to be dispensid bi him, and in forberyng to take moche more MS. mochemore. of hem offrid to him, or whiche myȝt be geten or takun of him wiþoute weernyng of resoun. and þis degree of honeste may weel be clepid 'grettist wilful P.M.M. omits wilful. pouerte', or 'hiȝest wilful P.M.M. omits wilful. pouerte'.

Also, þouȝ þe vse of freedom and liberte of wil, doon and (c) Obedience of one man to another, where liberty may be inadvisable. made as resoun deemeþ it to be doon and hauntid, is vertuose and allowable, meritorye and rewardable, of god, and makiþ þe first P.M.M. substitutes lowist. vertuose degree in vse of wil, which degree may wel be clepid 'fredom', or 'liberte'; ȝitt P.M.M. inserts for as myche as. such now seid fredom and liberte of wil is an occasioun into moral yuel, and is, as it were, a letting fro sum greet moral good, which ellis myȝt be geten, or þe bettir be geten, in maner lijk to þe maners in which þe iij bifore seid vertues, sobirte, temper∣aunce, and mesure, or ellis þe maters wherupon þo vertues goon, mowe be occasiouns of moral yuel, and mowe be let∣tyngis from grettir moral good þan is bi hem likeli to be
geten. And ȝitt, siþen P.M.M. omits siþen. no man may caste from him vttirly alle hise fre willingis and nyllingis into anoþir mannys willing and reuling; þerfore sum man MS. summan. so moche forsakiþ his owne wil, and so moche puttiþ his wil vndir anoþir mannys wil, wiþ vowe or wiþoute vowe, þat what euer þing not aȝens comaundement of P.M.M. omits comaundement of. resoun and goddis lawe þe oþir man to him biddiþ, he wole do; þouȝ to alle oþire dedis whiche þe oþire man wole P.M.M. omits wole. not, or schal not, him bidde, he wole be fre to do as him silf wole.

And, for as moche as ech man is freel and passionable, This obedience of one man to another often reduces itself to obedience to some recog∣nized rule. and þerfore troubleable and derkeable and temptable in his resoun, as ech oþir man is, and þerbi ouer greet perel it seemeþ to summe men for to so fully as is P.M.M., now is. now P.M.M., now is. rehercid submytte hem to anoþir mannys witt and wil, And namelich, in lijk wise, to þe wil of þe successouris of þe same oþire man, which euer þei schulen be; þerfore sum man MS. summan. submyttiþ and puttiþ, wiþ vowe or wiþoute vowe, his wil vndir anoþir manys wil | so fer oonli as þe oþir man biddiþ him to do eny dede comaundid bi sum certey[n] MS. certey; P.M.M., certeyn. reule writen and approvid auisidli bi P.M.M. omits bi ... biddiþ, running a risidli [sic] or eny dede, &c. þe chirche, and chosen of þis same man, or whanne euer þe oþir seid man biddiþ P.M.M. omits bi ... biddiþ, running a risidli [sic] or eny dede, &c. eny dede so nyȝ and so moche longyng to þe seide reule þat, wiþoute þilk dede, þe estate P.M.M., state. of þe seide reule myȝt not have his countenaunce P.M.M., continuaunce. in good prosperite. And þis forberyng or forsaking of fre∣dom [of] Omitted in MS.; P.M.M., of. wil is clepid 'obedience'. þus moche as for þe first pryncipal bifore spoken honeste.

þe ije principal bifore spokun honeste is a mesurable and P.M.M. inserts a. resonable beryng of vs silf in oure maner of going, sitting, (2) Honeste of action. ligging, resting, and in oure maner of mouyng þe heed, þe hond, or eny oþir parti of oure body, and in oure lauȝing, pleiyng, speking and bourding, and also in countenauncyng, þat it be not ouer sad and heuy, neiþir ouer liȝt and wanton. Also, for skile like to it which is now bifore seid in þe vertu
of clennes, y seie now þat to þe vertu of honeste longiþ þe The proper use of our inward and outward sensi∣tive wits, *c., so that they do not lead us into Inhoneste, is included under Honeste. vse of oure inward and outward sensitive wittis, and þe vse of her appetitis and delectaciouns, þe vse of oure resoun, mynde and wil, and þe vse of oure bodily goyng, movyng, gesture, lauȝing, speking and countenauncyng, in maner, mesure, quantite, tyme, and in oþir circumstauncis, as þei putten not vs into perel of eny P.M.M. inserts of. þese ij now seid inhonestees.

And, þouȝ it so be þat vowis and ooþis mowe at sum The danger of taking an oath or vow without due considera∣tion. while, and of summe persoonys, be weel made vpon summe gouernauncis or dedis to be kept, ȝitt y counseil ful eernestly and hertily euery man and womman forto be wel waar and long avisid what avowis P.M.M., vow and. or P.M.M., vow and. ooþis he make, ȝhe, and wiþ counseil of hem þat han experience how men han doon wiþ vowis and ooþis; and þat he take proof and assaie of a gouernaunce þoruȝ a notable tyme, how he may bere it, eer þan he vowe it; And nameli þat he not make manye vowis or ooþis; for, certis, ful ofte it haþ be bi surist assaie proued þat what haþ seemed in þe resoun of wise men to haue bi liȝt | and esy forto be contynued, haþ be riȝt vnesy to con∣tynue, And þat for certeyn circumstauncis which han fallen in þerto bi tyme in contynuaunce, which circumstauncis couþe not be seen, or be þouȝt vpon, bifore, and for oþire dyuers causis. þerfore wolde god þat þe batail and þe perel, ȝhe, and þe falle of summe persoonys myȝte be instruccioun and informacioun, warnyng and gastnes, to oþire. And ȝitt nede is þat wommen take hede to þis what is now seid more þan men. Also, at sum tyme and oft, þouȝ a reule approvid and allowid of þe churche, or a gouernaunce, of such seid forberyngis or forsakingis, considerid wiþoute þerof þe assaie, ȝhe, and taken þoruȝ a notable tyme into assaie, of a persoone, seeme to þe consid[er]er, MS consider, with the contraction sign for er omitted; P.M.M., considerer. or þe assaier, and to oþire con∣siderers and iugers, to be to þe persoone riȝt euen, meete, or proporcionable, and according for euer, ȝhe, and þouȝ to þe cheser þerof it haþ seemed him to haue þerto swete calling of god, and, as it were, þerto strong drawing, ȝitt it haþ be seen, or P.M.M. omits or ... likely. it was ful likely P.M.M. omits or ... likely. aftirward bi lengir assaie and
experience, þat þilk reule haþ not be so for euer to þe same persoone even, mete, or proporcionable and according; but it P.M.M. omits it. haþ be grettir occasioun to him into wors moral yuel þan if he had not take vpon him P.M.M. omits him. suche seid reule or gouernaunce of forberingis, and P.M.M. omits and. at þe leest, it haþ lettid him from greet notable good, which bi him myȝt and schulde haue be P.M.M. omits be. doon. wherfore myche nede is to be had in þis caas greet special grace of god to reule a man aȝens al sutel and sliȝe tempta∣ciouns stiring and tising, þat a man take to him a birþen vneven or vnaccordyng to his freelnes, or vnaccording to sum special and notable in him vnablenes, P.M.M., abilnes. or to MS. orto. but but ... iije point of þe ij table omitted in P.M.M. See Folewer, Part II, chap. ix. ȝitt it is to be feelid here, þat alle þo maners of Honeste, as a counsel, is included under largenes towards oneself; or under largenes towards God; or under riȝtwisnes towards God. honeste which ben counseilis and not preceptis, considerid and takun as counseilis, ben | in þe viije point of þis iije table. And if þei be ȝouun immediatli to god, þan, in þilk skile, þei ben in þe vij poynt of þe ije table. And if þei haue promysse made to god sette þerto, þanne, as in þilk consideracioun, þei ben in þe iije poynt of þe ij table. but ... iije point of þe ij table omitted in P.M.M. Whi þe v P.M.M. iije, the Points being differ∣ently arranged. DIV3.HEAD: [viije chapitre].
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, what is pacience? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 29a, l. 14, to 30a, l. 6. To live to one∣self paciently is to suffer adver∣sity without grumbling.

Sone, it is forto holde and kepe [þe wil] MS. wel; P.M.M., þe wil. in a softnes and in pees and reste, withoute disturblaunce and grucching, whanne enye maner of greefys fallen or P.M.M. substitutes and. comen; and þat and þat erased in P.M.M., and cross in margin. wheþir þese greefis comen fro god immediatli, or fro þe feende, or fro oure fleisch, or fro P.M.M., from. þe worlde: as fro wijf, children, kyn, straungers, seruauntis, freendis, or enemyes, hem willing or not willing.
ffadir, P.M.M. omits ffadir, sone, ffadir, sone. in how manye casis ouȝte þis pacience be had? There are two cases of Pacience: (1) in suffering adversity, (2) in remedying or preventing adversity.
Certis, sone, P.M.M. omits ffadir, sone, ffadir, sone. in two.
ffadir, P.M.M. omits ffadir, sone, ffadir, sone. in Omitted in P.M.M. whiche two?

Sone, P.M.M. omits ffadir, sone, ffadir, sone. oon is whilis þese seid greefis ben fallen and vpon a man hangyng, or abiding MS. a biding.; And þe oþire case is whilis a man is aboute hem aweie doyng or remediyng, or ellis, þat þei not falle, he be preserving and defending.

In At this point there is an omission in the P.M.M.: In þe first . . . þus. (See Donet, p. 57, l. 6.) The P.M.M. resumes with: þat is to sey. (Cf. Donet, p. 57, l. 6.) þe first of þese ij casis, a man schal bere him silf þus: ffirst, þat he be aknowe MS a knowe. alle þo greefis to bifalle him bi þe prouidence of god, as it is provid wel in 'þe more book of cristen religioun', þe secunde parti, as it is forto purge him for hise synnes; and forto kepe him in mekenes, þat he falle not into pryde, which god ful moche among alle synnes hatiþ and punyschiþ; also forto holde him in sadde and holsum consideraciouns and þouȝtis, þat he wandre not in hise þouȝtis aboute waaste and veyn þingis, and þerbi falle into manye foold synnys; also þat he deserve grettir grace and grettir glory; | and also for manye oþire greet profitis vpon which rennyþ þe preciose litil book made of 'þe xij avauntagis of tribulacioun'. See Notes. And þerfore þis man schal þanke god ful hertely for þese grevauncis and peynys falling
so to him, as for greet and louyngful benefetis of god; þouȝ he be in wil and purpos forto wirche into remediyng of hem, in þe maner to be tauȝt now next vpon þe secunde caas of pacyence.

In þe ije caas of pacience bifore seid, a man schal bere (2) Pacience in remedying or preventing adversity. him þus At this point there is an omission in the P.M.M.: In þe first . . . þus. (See Donet, p. 57, l. 6.) The P.M.M. resumes with: þat is to sey. (Cf. Donet, p. 57, l. 6.): þat Here the P.M.M. resumes. is to seie, in þo whilis þat a man be aboute to remedie and to leie a side hise greefis, or þe P.M.M. substitutes þo. whilis þat he settiþ defense wherbi þei schulen not come, he so in his remediyng and defending wirch and do, bi sobirte and softnes, mesure and obedience of spirit, wiþoute grucchyng or disturblaunce, but raþir with þankingis; and þat he so wirche and do bi leeful meenys of kynde, of craft, or of grace, and bi leeful vse of þis P.M.M. has the common pl. þese. Babington (Glossary to Rep.) and Schmidt (Studies, § 36) do not note the pl. þis; but cf. again Donet, 7/18, 34/25. now seid leeful meenys, as þat goddis seruice be not þerbi þe more lettid, neiþir in þilk wircher, neiþir in noon oþire, and þat no man MS. noman. þerbi P.M.M., "þerbi "no man, with the marks of transposition. be wrongid, and þat no man MS. noman. þerbi be made to synne.

ffadir, what is douȝtines? For the abbreviated account of Dough∣tiness in the P.M.M., see Appendix. After Doughtiness, the P.M.M. treats the seven parts of a state. See below, pp. 74-5. To live douȝtily is to perform laborious and painful deeds in God's service.

Sone, it is forto kepe and folewe þe doom of resoun in taking and bering and continuyng excellent P.M.M. omits excellent. labouris and excellent P.M.M. omits excellent. peynful dedis for þe P.M.M. omits þe ... of. seruice and lawe of P.M.M. omits þe ... of. god fynali or eendli.
ffadir, in how manye maners of laboriose or peynful dedis The five labours of Douȝtines: stondiþ douȝtines?
Sone, in v. P.M.M., iiij. From this point, for the account of Doughtiness, see Appendix only.
In which v?

Sone, MS. Soone. oon is in chesing raþir and more to do þe parfiter (1) Choice of the more difficult virtuous work, or the greater degree of a difficult virtue, rather than the less. vertuose werk þan þe lasse, whanne euereiþir of hem boþe is excellentli hard, And þei mowe not boþe be doon and be performyd to gider; And also forto in lijk maner chese and do þe parfiter degree of a vertu excellently hard, raþir þan
þe lasse parfite degree of þe same vertu; siþen in euereiþir of þese choisis and in her execuciouns lijþ excellent diffi∣cultee and peyne, which is oon of þe cheef circumstauncys of douȝtines.

þe ije maner is in re∣moving excellentli hard occasiouns (2) Removal of occasions towards sin, provided that such removal is not com∣manded or forbidden by Reason. and perels, which, as we han wel aspied bifore, ben woned drawe bi delectaciouns vs silf or oþire men into vice; and þese we excluden þat þerfore we go þe surelier into vertues. Neuerþeles, so, and and: overwritten in MS. in þilk maner, we must exclude þat resoun weernyþ not þilk excluding; þouȝ þo occasiouns ben not such þat forto avoide and exclude hem is comaunde∣ment.

þe iije maner is in removing excellent lettis of vertu, which (3) Removal of hindrances towards virtue coming from within, which removal is a counsel only. bi peyn fro wiþinforþ to vs wiþdrawen fro vertu, if þo lettis mowe be removid; or ellis in not sparyng forto worche þe vertu, þouȝ þo peynes, difficultees, or labouris, stonden in for þilk same while, beyng aboute forto lette þe vertu be doon, so neuer þe latter þat doom of resoun forto so do þe Or practice, if Reason approves, of the virtue so hindered. pretence vertu lette not; And þat þouȝ forto exclude and remove þilk lettis falliþ not vndir maundement, but vndir counseil oonli.

þe fourþe maner is in aȝens fiȝting and removing excellent (4) Removal of hindrances towards virtue coming from without, or practice of the virtue so hindered. lettis of vertu, which fro withoute forþ, bi þretenyngis of peynes or of damagis, ben aboute to lette, if þo lettis mowe be removid and excludid, And, if þei mowe not be removid, þan forto spare not forto do þe vertu, and be redi to vndir go and receyue þe peynes or damages þretened, so and if þat forto so remove, doom of resoun not aȝens seiþ and aȝens stondith; bi which doom resoun owith in þis iiije case, as wel as in þe bifore going ije and iije casis, weie wel and knowe riȝtli whiche of þe ij yuelis is þe grettir, þat þe lasse yuel be take and receivid forto lacke þe grettir.

þe ve is forto perseuere and contynue alweie, or ellis (5) Continuance in, or more frequent prac∣tice of, a diffi∣cult virtue; provided that this continu∣ance, or more frequent prac∣tice, is a coun∣sel, not a commandment. lengir, in a vertuose werk, or forto oftir do it in dyuerse whilis þan comaundement is, So þat þerynne ligge excellent hardnes or difficultee, and so þat resoun be not þeraȝens, and þouȝ þilk lenger contynuaunce, or þilk oftir hauntyng, be not of comaundement, but of fredom and counseil oonly.

oute of þe declaracioun made vpon þese v maners of douȝti∣nes Three truths arising from consideration of the five labours of Douȝtines. folewen þese iij trouþis: Oon is þat douȝtines haþ fo[r] MS. fo. oon of of repeated in MS. | his princypal circumstauncis vpon which he falliþ, excellent difficultee or hardnes or peyne, which aboute stondiþ moral vertu; þouȝ he haue for his mater þe principal (1) Difficulty is one of the chief circumstances of Douȝtines. mater of þilk vertu, which euer þilk vertu be, and in which table þilk vertu be, þouȝ ech oþir vertu haþ difficulte as for his circumstaunce as wel.

Þe ije trouþe is, þat þouȝ douȝtines bi sum skile and con∣sideracioun (2) Douȝtines is connected with every moral virtue, inasmuch as every moral virtue is difficult. be a a overwritten in MS. moral vertu of þe iije table, disposing a man anentis him silf immediatli and principali forto vndir go excellent difficultees, and þat for as moche as þe princypal circumstaunce of douȝtines is wiþinne þe worcher, and not wiþoutforþ, which is þe seid difficultee; ȝitt douȝtines is aboute alle maters of vertues in ech oþire table wherynne ben excellent difficultees or hardnessis. And so douȝtines is not formali oon specialist moral vertu; but it conteyniþ an aggregat of manye moral vertues beyng in dyuers tablis, of which vertues summe vndir summe oþire circumstauncis ben of counseil oonly. And whi þis douȝtines is putte into þe Where the reason why Douȝtines is placed in the Third Table may be seen. iije table, and whi he is so gaderid and spokun among moral vertues, causis ben ȝouun in 'þe folewer to þe donet', in þe ije parti, þe vije and ixe chapitris.

Þe iije trouþe is þis: whanne euer a difficultee risiþ MS. risiþ wiþinforþ, fro, with the marks of transposition. fro (3) A man may perform any virtuous deed by Douȝtines, even if it means his bodily death, provided Reason con∣sents thereto. wiþinforþ MS. risiþ "wiþinforþ, fro, with the marks of transposition. or fro wiþouteforþ to þe purposer forto worche eny vertuose dede, he may wel ynouȝe do his purpos and entent bi vertu of douȝtines, þouȝ þilk difficultee be to him of greet damage and peyne þat it bringiþ forþ to him bodily deeþ, if doom of resoun bidde, or at þe leest counseil or allowe þilke chaunge to be doon and take, þat þe bodili deeþ be receyuid raþir þan lette þilke vertu be vndoon; And, if doom of resoun allowe not þilk chaunge, þat þan þe purposid dede may not be doon riȝtli bi douȝtines. Certis, forto knowe and witte whanne and how resoun schal deeme oon good to ouerpeise and weye þe oþir good, and oon yuel to ouerpeise and weye þe oþir yuel, helpiþ moche what y
haue write | in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe first tretice.

ffadir, what is for to lyue largely anentis vs silf im∣mediatli? Largenes is not included in the Third Table in the P.M.M. To live to one∣self largely is to give, or do, to oneself good things, which neither God nor Reason commands.

Sone, it is for to ȝeue or to MS. orto. do to vs silf goodis which we ben not bounde bi god or bi resoun forto so hem ȝeue or to MS. orto. do to vs silf, and þat of what euer maner of goodis þo be, So þat god or resoun wel allowe þat we so ȝeue or do þo goodis to vs silf.

And so, as it is seid bifore, bi and aftir dyuers skilis and Largenes may be included under other Points of the Third Table. consideraciouns, moral vertues mowe be in dyuers tablis, and in dyuers pointis of oon and of þe same table; and in special, now to seie, summe vertues which now ben in þis viije point of þe iij table, ben in oþire pointis of þe same iij table. and þat þis is noon inconuenient, y declare and schewe in 'þe folewer' to þis 'donet', in þe ije parti, þe [ix] Space left for reference in MS. chapitre. þerfore, sone, se what is tauȝt þere. And þus moche as for vertues of þe iije table.

DIV3.HEAD: [ixe chapitre]. 9 chapitre in margin. THE FOURTH TABLE
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 31b, l. 14, to 32a, 1. 15. how manye vertues, or comaundementis and There are eight moral virtues in the Fourth Table. counseilis in general, ben of þe iije table?
Sone, viij.
Which viij? These virtues rehearsed.

Sone, toward oure neiȝboris goostlibode, P.M.M., loue. Attendaunce, largenes comes second in the list in the P.M.M. riȝtwisnes, mekenes, accordyngnes, P.M.M., accordignes [sic]. treuþe, P.M.M. inserts and. benyngnite (or myldnes) and largenes. largenes comes second in the list in the P.M.M. Or ellis þus: forto lyue toward oure neiȝboris goostly, P.M.M., lovyngli. attendauntly, largeli comes second in the list in P.M.M. riȝtfully, mekeli, accordingli, treuli, benyngnely (or myldeli) and largeli. largeli comes second in the list in P.M.M.
ffadir, what is oure goostlihode P.M.M., loue. towarde oure neiȝbore, as To live to our neighbour goostly is to it is þe first poynt in þe iiije table?

Sone, it is oure willing P.M.M., wilnyng. bi whiche we williþ P.M.M., willen, which is perhaps the right reading here, as Pecock's regular ending is -en. See p. 77, note 5. to him goodis which, forto to him ȝeve, or forto MS. orforto. to to omitted in P.M.M. him sette, and forto fro P.M.M., from. h[i]m MS. hem; P.M.M., him hem. take, is not in a creaturis power: as ben his blisful rewardis to be had in hevene, and goddis gracis freely helping him þidirward, in þe maners tauȝt in þe ije parti of 'cristen religioun', þe iije trety. Here the P.M.M. closes the treatment of this Point, and treats Largenes. See below, pp. 66-7. þis goostlihode of a man This goostlihods is a species of our love to∣wards our neighbour. anentis his neiȝbore is a spice, or a membre, of þe al hool general freendli love which a man ouȝte have to his neiȝbore.

ffadir, in which | vsis may y execute profitabli toward This goostly love to our neighbour may be executed by praying for God's grace towards him, and by ac∣cepting him as a friend. my neiȝbore þis seide goostlihode, or goostly freendli willing, born toward him?

Sone, in asking and preiyng þat þi neiȝbore haue grace into ech of þe seid effectis of grace rehercid bifore in þe vj chapitre, where it is spokun of goostlihode of a man anentis him silf; and also bi þis, þat þou takist and acceptist him into þi specyal freendschip and felawschip, fforwhi þerbi and þerfore god wole þe more grace ȝeue to him, as to þi freend, for þi sake: þat is to seie, for þe loue which god haþ to þee, deservid bi þi vertuose dedis of þe iiij tablis doon for goddis sake, As herof long doctryne is ȝouun in 'þe more book of cristen religioun', þe first parti, þe ij trety.

ffadir, what is þe vertu of attendaunce? Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 32b, l. 19, to 33b, l. 1. To live to our neighbour attendauntly is to bear our∣selves rightly towards our inferiors and superiors.

Sone, it is þe fulfilling of þe lawe P.M.M. here inserts charge. Cf. lawe, charge and boond below, Donet, ll. 25-6. and boonde of ouerte toward vndirlingis, or of subieccioun toward ouerers. Or ellis þus: attendaunce is to fulfille þe lawe, charge and boond bi which a souereyn is bounden to his vndirlingis, or bi which þe vndirlingis ben bounden to her souereyns.
ffadir, how manye maners P.M.M. inserts of ouerers. ben þere ouer her vndirlingis? THE SEVEN RELATIONSHIPS OF SUPERIORS TOWARDS INFERIORS rehearsed.
Sone, vij.
Which vij?

The fadir and P.M.M. inserts þe. modir ouer þe P.M.M., her. childe, þe In P.M.M. þe husband ouer his wijf, is an addition from foot of page; mark of omission after child in text. hu[s]bonde MS. hubbonde; P.M.M., husbonde. ouer his wijf, In P.M.M. þe husband ouer his wijf, is an addition from foot of page; mark of omission after child in text. þe scole maistir ouer his scolers, þe crafty man ouer his appre[n]tise, Contraction mark for n omitted in MS. þe hirer ouer his hired laborer, þe P.M.M., þe ... legi omitted at this point, but inserted after to him boond, with marks of omission showing the passage should follow aprentise above. curate ouer his parischen, And þe king ouer his legi. P.M.M., þe ... legi omitted at this point, but inserted after to him boond, with marks of omission showing the passage should follow aprentise above. Bitwix þe freeman and his boond man, it neediþ not to P.M.M. omits to. make eny oþire maner of combinacioun save which is seid to be bitwix þe prince and his legi; for þilk two maners ben not different, saue bi more and lasse oonly, And it may be þat alle legies of a prince ben to him boond. P.M.M., þe ... legi omitted at this point, but inserted after to him boond, with marks of omission showing the passage should follow aprentise above.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 33b, l. 1, to 35b, l. 13. what is forto lyue anentis oure neiȝboris iustli or There are two ways of living riȝtwisli to our neighbour: (1) To perform our promises made to him, whether there∣to is set oath or vow, or no. riȝtwisli?

Sone, it is doon in two maners: Oon is, whanne euer and how oft euer, we wolen, or schulen, to oure neiȝbore make couenaunt or boond of biheest, bi worde or bi oþir signe or dede occupiyng þe stide of worde, vpon eny dede or þing to be of vs doon, or to be of vs left vndon, in tyme to come, | þat we perfoorme þilk boonde and couenaunt, bi cause þat bi bi overwritten in MS., and omission mark in text. þilk boonde þere growiþ to oure neiȝbore a riȝt MS. ariȝt. of claym vpon oure dede so bihestid to him in boond and couenaunt, and þat wheþir to þilk boond be sette ooþe or vowe, or no; Here there is an omission in the P.M.M., which runs straight on: Anoþir maner of riȝtwisnes; see Donet, p. 63, l. 8. And also ellis we schulde breke oure promys or oure coue∣naunt, which is not to be doon.

Also, sone, here it is to witte þat doom of resoun allowiþ The circum∣stances in which Reason allows, or does not allow, oaths or vows to be set to promises. not ooþ or vowe to be sett vnto eny promys made to god or to man, but if resoun iuge þat þe mater of þilk promys, þat is to seie, but if þe dede promisid, be honeste and profitable to be doon anentis him to whom it is promysid; and but if resoun iuge bifore þat, bi þilk ooþ or vowe sette to þe dede promysid, þe promyser schal be þe more remembrid, movid,
and stirid forto perfoorme þe dede promysid. And, þerfore, whanne euer ooþe or vowe is sette to a promys made to god or to man, lackyng eny of þese now seid circumstaunces, þouȝ þe promys be fulfillid and perfoormed, ȝitt þilk setting to of ooþ or vowe is not allowid of resoun, and and þerfore . . . resoun is repeated in the MS. þerfore þe making of þilk promys, vndir and wiþ such ooþ or vow, is not allowid of resoun. and þerfore . . . resoun is repeated in the MS.

bi þe first membre is excludid al wilful covenaunt breking; By the first kind of riȝt∣wisnes, we are forbidden to break any covenant, e. g. that of marriage. And so bi þis iustnes be excludid oure envie and wraþþe Thus riȝtwisnes towards our neighbour ex∣cludes wrath and envy. anentis oure neiȝboris, ffor as moche as enuye to oure neiȝbore is not ellis þan a willing MS. awilling. þat oure neiȝbore lack hise sum certeyn goodis which resoun deemeþ him owe to haue, or a nylling þat he haue hem, lest þerbi oure glory be takun aweie or be lassid afore men; And wraþe to oure neiȝbore is not ellis þan a willing þat oure neiȝbore haue sum yuel contrarye to sum of þe now seid godis, for þat, as to vs seemeþ, he trespasith, doiþ yuel, or displesith to vs. so þat envie and wraþþe ben habitis P.M.M. omits habitis . . . her. or disposiciouns or her P.M.M. omits habitis . . . her. dedis of þe wil, and so bi In P.M.M. a half-faded be follows. willyngis or nyllingis or outwarde dedis comaundid bi hem; þouȝ comounly, whilis a man haþ enuye or wraþþe, he schal haue pey∣nes and movingis in his body and folewingli in his soule; which peynes and movingis ben not þe envie, neiþir þe wraþþe, bi cause þat, as ech moral vertu is a P.M.M. omits disposicioun . . . his. disposicioun or habit or his P.M.M. omits disposicioun . . . his. dede of þe fre wil, so ech moral vice must nedis be a disposicioun P.M.M. omits disposicioun . . . or. or habit or P.M.M. omits disposicioun . . . or. dede of þe fre wil oonli, as schal appere in 'þe folewer to þe donet'.

After this, the P.M.M. inserts: In like maner it is to be seid of slouȝ[þ] or þe vice which is contrarie to douȝtines.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 35b, l. 13, to 36a, l. 3. what is mekenes As to position of Meekness, &c., in the Four Tables, see Folewer, Pt. II, chap. ii. to be had anentis oure neiȝboris? To live towards our neighbour mekely is to make ourselves out no better than we are, or not so good as we are.

Sone, it is a bering of vs silf wiþynneforþ and withoute∣forþ toward oure neiȝboris euen as we ben, or lasse þan we ben, in reward of hem in doom of resoun; which beryng risiþ bi cause of oure having in godis of kynde, of fortune, of craft, of maners, or of grace, more þan þei han, or even wiþ hem, or lasse þan þei han. Wherfore P.M.M. omits Wherfore ... laboure. pride is þe vice bi The contrary vice is pride. which a man, in his owne reputacioun, and in willing þer to answering, settiþ him silf hiȝer þan he is worþi anentis hise neiȝboris, and þat for sum good which he haþ receyuid of god or of kynde or of man, or which he haþ gete bi his owne kunnyng or laboure. P.M.M. omits Wherfore ... laboure.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 36a, l. 3 to l. 11. what is it P.M.M. omits it. forto lyue accordingli, as it is þe v P.M.M., vje, the Points being differ∣ently arranged. To live to our neighbour accordingli is to consent to laws made for the common profit. poynt of the iiij table?

Sone, it is forto consent to neiȝboris into þe making, keping and vsing of reulis, ordynauncis and lawis to be made, such as resoun wel deemeþ to strecche into þe comoun availe bodili or goostli, P.M.M. runs: gostli and þerwith into þe avail, &c. namelich if þerwiþ þei schulen come into þe availe P.M.M. runs: gostli and þerwith into þe avail, &c. of þe consenter, and not into P.M.M. inserts his. disauayle.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 36a, l. 11, to 36b, l. 2. what is trouþe, or forto MS. orforto. lyue treuli anentis oure To live to our neighbour treuli is to affirm or deny absolutely truly by word or deed, whether there∣to be set oath or vow, or no. neiȝboris?

Sone, it is, as ofte as we wolen, or schulen, to oure neiȝboris afferme or denye, bi worde, or bi signe or dede occupiyng þe stide of worde, þat þe mater so affermed or denyed bi treuþe, P.M.M. substitutes trewe. namelich In P.M.M. namelich ... trowen is omitted. as we trowen, In P.M.M. namelich ... trowen is omitted. and þat wheþir þe mater so affermed or denyed bi present, passid, or to MS. orto. come, oure owne dede or anoþir creaturis dede, and þat
wheþir þer to be sette eny ooþ, or no, eny vowe, or no Here the P.M.M. passes straight to Benignity; cf. below, p. 66, ll. 20-29.; ffor ellis we schulden make lesing wiþoute ooþ or vowe, or ellis wiþ ooþ or vowe, and neuer neiþir of þese resoun wole allowe.

| Also, sone, it is to witte þat resoun allowiþ not ooþ or The circum∣stances in which Reason allows oath or vow to be set to an affirming or denying. vowe to be sette to eny affermyng or denying made to man, not beyng enye promys, þouȝ þilk affermyng or denying be trewe, but if resoun se and iuge bifore þat þe dede of of overwritten in MS., and mark of omission in text. affermyng or denying be honest and profitable to be doon; And but if resoun iuge bifore þat þe affermer or denyer schal be þe more trowid, or schal not ellis be trowid, whanne honeste and profite asken þat he þerynne be þe more trowid, or ellis be trowid, to afferme or denye as trouþe is. And þerfore alle such affermyngis or denyingis, circumstanciatid wiþ setting to of ooþ or vowe, whanne þe dede of affermyng or denying is not honest and profitable, and whanne nede or profit askiþ not þat þe affermer or denyer be þe more bileuyd or be bileeuyd, resoun not allowiþ, but iugiþ to be ydil and veyn, and þerfore to be not doon.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fol. 36b, l. 2 to l. 13. what is benyngnyte to oure neiȝbore P.M.M., neiȝboris.? To live to our neighbour benyngnely is to behave towards him temperately in word and deed.

Sone, it is a mesuryng, reuling, temperyng and demening of oure speche, countenaunce, gesture and dede toward oure neiȝbore f[ro] fro, a correction from margin; MS. for; P.M.M., fro. boistousenes, rudenes, þat at þe leest oure neiȝbore be not þerbi temptid or movid into P.M.M. omits into ... or. vnrestful pas∣siouns or into vnpacience, or P.M.M. omits into ... or. forto breke vp his loue from P.M.M., fro. vs, and forto wil P.M.M., wilne. and wirche to vs yuel and harme. and so bi benyngnite ben excludid al vnresonable P.M.M. omits vnresonable. angry reprov∣ing, scornyng, P.M.M. omits scornyng. chiding, rebuking, in worde, and al vnreson∣able vengeaunce, cruelnes, and rygour in dede.
ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 32a, l. 15, to 32b, l. 18. what is largenes? To live to our neighbour largely is to relieve his need.
Sone, it is a P.M.M. substitutes to releeue. willing forto releeue P.M.M. substitutes to releeue. oure neiȝboris lak and nede bi oure habundaunce and plente.
ffadir, in how manye maners may þis largenes be doon? There are two kinds of largenes:

Certis, sone, in two maners: fforwhi we mowe releeue oure neiȝboris bodili lak and nede bi oure bodili habundaunce (1) Relief of bodily need. and plente; and also we mowe releeue oure neiȝboris goostli (2) Relief of ghostly need. lak and nede bi oure goostli habundaunce and plente, ouer P.M.M. omits ouer ... resoun. þat we be þerto bounde bi precept of god or of resoun. P.M.M. omits ouer ... resoun.

Ensaumple of þe first maner P.M.M. omits maner. is þis: feding, cloþing, Examples of bodily relief, including the SEVEN BODILY WORKS OF MERCY. helyng, herborewyng, MS. heerborewyng, with the first e underdotted. visiting in | bodili maner, glading and chering, oute of prisoun quytyng, biriyng, worldly goodis ȝeuing or leenyng, worldly dettis forȝeving, and eche of þese now seid maners to oþire men of power for þe pore procuryng.

Ensaumple of þe ij maner is þis: teching, counseiling, Examples of ghostly relief, including the SEVEN GHOSTLY WORKS OF MERCY. exortyng, preiyng, good exaumpling, to good putting and dryuing, trespacis and giltis forȝeving, into goostlihode coun∣fortyng and glading, chastisyng, or iustli bi love punysching, and þat suche dedis be doon bi oþire men of power pro∣curyng.

DIV3.P: [F]Adir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 36b, l. 13, to 37a, l. 9. is þis chalengeable, þat ȝe setten riȝtwisnes to The term riȝt∣wisnes is common to all the virtues of the Fourth Table, and is applicable to the virtue contrary to both wrath and envy. be comune, vndir oon name comprehending and conteynyng þe vertu contrarye to In P.M.M., to ... contrarie is an addition from foot of page; omission mark in text after the former contrarie. wraþþe and þe vertu contrarye In P.M.M., to ... contrarie is an addition from foot of page; omission mark in text after the former contrarie. to envie?

Sone, nay, MS. may, with the first stroke crossed through and underdotted. þis is not chalengeable, more þan it is chalenge∣able to treters of cardynal vertues in þat þat P.M.M. omits second þat. þei setten temperaunce, as it is a cardynal vertu, vndir oon name to be comune, in comprehending and conteynyng sobirnes contrarye to glotenye, and P.M.M. inserts þat. contynence or chastite contrarye to lec∣cherye, and honeste contrarye to veyn glory and to covetie; And in lijk maner to sette riȝtwisnes, as it is a cardinal vertu, to be comune vndir oon name to alle þe vertues of þe iiije table.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 37a, l. 9, to 37b, l. 9. which is þe difference bitwix pacience and benyng∣nyte? The difference between patience and benignity: Patience en∣sures a man's personal peace; benignity our neighbour's peace.

Certis, sone, pacience disposiþ and settiþ a mannys spirit to be in a restfulnes as in him silf, wiþoute biholding or eny moving toward eny oþire outward þing; And benyngnite settiþ a mannys outward bering in speche, countenaunce, dede occupiyng þe steede of worde, in such a foorme and maner þat it not brekiþ, but kepiþ, of spirit þe restfulnes of hise neiȝboris, or of sum oþire outward þing. And so pacience repressiþ disturblaunce which schulde make vnrest and vnpees in a mannys owne spirit, which disturblaunce and vnrest myȝt be wiþoute eny moving into P.M.M., in. greef toward eny oþir þing, And benyngnite repressiþ þe cause | in a mannys beryng which schuld be a moving to vnese, and disturble sum oþir outward þing.

ffadir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 37b, l. 9, to 38a, l. 17. aȝens which of þese poyntis of þe iiij table trespasiþ Usury violates the command∣ment of riȝt∣wisnes towards our neighbour. the Third Point of the Fourth Table. an vsurer?

Sone, siþen bi lawe of kinde, of resoun, and of charite, riȝt as ech man which haþ superflue goodis more þan is nede to occupie, ouȝte frely ȝeue of þilk superflue godis to his neiȝbore suffring nede, if þilk neiȝbore schal not be of power to aȝenquyte; so ech such habundaunt man in goodis is bounden bi þe same lawe of open resoun, of kynde, and of charite, forto frely leene of his superflue goodis to his nedi neiȝbore, if of þilk neiȝbore it is hopid þat he schal mowe aȝen paie or aȝen quyte it. And, siþen in vseri þe leener, bi manassing þat he wole not ellis leene, driviþ and com∣pelliþ þe borewer to assent forto paie a summe of his owne good bisidis þe summe borewid, and þat for þe borewyng or þe leenyng, which is not resonable cause to so compelle, for it is aȝens lawe of kynde, of resoun, and of charite, as is now openli seid; þerfore such a leener, so dryving þe borewer, tretiþ þe borewers good aȝens þe borewers fre resonable wil; and þerfore þe leener trespasiþ aȝens P.M.M. runs: aȝens þe first seid membre of þe iiije point callid riȝtwisnes, the Points being differently arranged. It then runs: Also, sone, such an vserer, leener, being habundaunt of his superflue goodis to leene, trespaciþ aȝens þe ije point, which is callid largenes, for as mych as bi þe seid lawe of resoun, which is to a man lawe of kinde, he is bounde to leene freli to þe nedi being of power to aȝen paie; riȝt as, if he be habundaunt in superflue goodis to ȝeue, he is bi þe same lawe bounde to freli ȝeue bi almes to þe nedi being out of power to aȝen paie, and ellis he trespaciþ aȝens largenes. And so an vserer trespaciþ boþ aȝens þe ije point and aȝens þe iiije point of þe iiije table (fols. 38a, l. 17, to 38b, l. 12). þe seid secunde membre of þe iij poynt, callid 'riȝtwisnes', of þe iiije table. Sone, siþen a symonier presumeþ and takiþ vpon him forto sille þe þing which is oonly goddis þing, and which þing no creature may have or possesse as for his owne, forto P.M.M. omits forto . . . wole. do þerwiþ what he wole, P.M. omits forto . . . wole. bi cause þilk þing is a goostly and a spiritual þing; þerfore such a symonier trespasiþ to god, for as moche as he tretiþ goddis propre good and þing aȝens riȝt, P.M.M., inserts aȝens goddis leeue and. aȝens god∣dys licence.
