DIV3.P: [F]Adir, Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 39b, l. 18, to 41a, l. 12. of ech of þese vij maners rehercid bifore in þe THE SEVEN RELATIONSHIPS OF ATTEN∣DAUNCE OF SUPERIORS TOWARDS INFERIORS: [ix] ix, a correction from the margin: MS. viij, marked as error; P.M.M., next. chapitre, in þe vertu of attendaunce, y preie ȝou þat ȝe seie forþ alle P.M.M. runs: alle þe charges openli and fulli. Certis, sone, summe of þese maners I schat declare heere, and þe remenaunt mowe be seen in þe first parti of þe donet in to cristen religioun, in þe vje [sic, but xje & xije in the copy now printed] chapitre. Cf. p. 71, note 8., or manye, of þo chargys or purtenauncis openli.

Certis, sone, wiþ þe grace of god, so schal y. P.M.M. runs: alle þe charges openli and fulli. Certis, sone, summe of þese maners I schal declare heere, and þe remenaunt mowe be seen in þe first parti of þe donet in to cristen religioun, in þe vje [sic, but xje & xije in the copy now printed] chapitre. The first attendaunce, whiche is to be of þe fadir and (1) The parents towards their child. modir toward þe childe withynne his mannys age, haþ þese poyntis: bodili nurischyng; bodili save wardyng, with al her necessary P.M.M., "purtenauncis "necessarie, with the marks denoting transposition. purtenauncis P.M.M., "purtenauncis "necessarie, with the marks denoting transposition.; into vertues h[i]m MS. hem; P.M.M., him. leding and customyng; him chastising and punyschyng; oure bileeue and goddis lawe him teching, or forto MS. orforto. be tauȝt of oþire ordeyning; comaunding, if þei wole, þat þe childe helpe hem in bodili laboring wiþ hem, as he canne | and may.

The ije attendaunce, which þe husbonde man Omitted in P.M.M. may make (2) The husband towards his wife. to his wijf, haþe þe same now seide poyntis of þe fadir toward þe childe; also vsing his wijf, if he wole, into childe bigetyng, and for [e]esing MS. cesing; P.M.M., eesing. of his vnsuffrable fleischli freelte; Also paiyng to his wijf fleischli dette, if sche aske it, for childe bigetyng, or for her fleischli nede remediyng; getyng worldli goodis for boþe P.M.M. inserts her lijflode. and for her childrens lijflode; comaunding In P.M.M., comaunding . . . like is an addition from foot of page. Mark of omission in text after lijflode. to her, if him lijk, In P.M.M., comaunding . . . like is an addition from foot of page. Mark of omission in text after lijflode. forto receyue his fleischly comunyng, whanne he wole haue it for childe bigetyng, or for verry nede of his fleisch releuing; comaunding to hir, if him lijk, forto nurisch þe childe and kepe it; to kepe þe husbondes house and goodis; to diȝt mete and drynk; to serue him and hise meyne þerwiþ; to chere and counforte þe husbonde aftir his labouris; to helpe þe husbonde forto gete her boþe lijflode and her children lijflode as fer as oþire chargis now [rehercid] MS. resoun; P.M.M., rehercid. and resoun wolen suffre; to not ȝeue or spende goodis of þe husbondys getyng in waast, or withoute her nede, aȝens his benyuolence.

Þe iij Omitted in P.M.M. attendaunce MS. attendaunce is; the is being crossed through and underdotted. of a scole maystir towarde his scoler (3) The school∣master towards his scholar. haþ þese poyntis: teching treuly, fully, diligently, þe doctryne of his scole, and in not wilili P.M.M. omits wilili. receyuyng for his laboure more þan he deseruiþ.

þe attendaunce of a crafty man vpon his apprentise haþ þese (4) The crafts∣man towards his apprentice, and parties: perfoormyng treuly, fully and diligently þe coue∣naunt made bitwixe hem, and in seiyng þat þe couenaunt made be resonable, wiþoute bigiling, fraude, extorcioun, or (5) The hirer towards his hired labourer. (See p. 78.) ouer moche rewarde or seruice for teching of his craft taking.

þe 
The P.M.M. omits discussion of the duty of prelates and princes, and runs: þe gouernaunce of a prelate which he ouȝte to haue anentis his parisschens, and þe gouernaunce and þe attendaunce of a prince which he ouȝte to haue anentis his peple and suggetis, þou maiste se in þe donet of cristen religioun, in þe ije partie, in þe vje and vije chapitris (P.M.M., fol. 41a, l. 13 to l. 19). In the copy of the Donet now printed these subjects are dealt with in the First Part, chaps. xi and xii.

The P.M.M. next deals with þe child in his ȝongþe, &c. Cf. below, pp. 76-7. gouernaunce of a prelate, wherbi he myȝt be worþili (6) The prelate towards his parishioners. attendaunt vpon hise peple, conteynyþ þese poyntis:


prechyng and teching goddis lawe, which is made of oure MS. oure neiȝboris feiþ; neiȝboris being crossed through. The prelate's duties com∣prise: feiþ MS. oure neiȝboris feiȝ; neiȝboris being crossed through. conteynyd in holi scripture, and of moral resoun, which is callid 'lawe of kynde'—þis teching he schal make openly (a) Preaching and teaching. in pulpyt, if he wole, and priuely in comunicacioun wiþ persoonys desiring and asking to be tauȝt—counseiling whanne  nede is, And þerto re∣medies  schewing, answeris ȝeuyng to doutis arising aȝens oure feiþ and þe lawe of kynde;
exaumpling vertuose dedis, namelich þat he do no þing aȝens (b) Setting a good example. þi lawe, lorde, in knowing of þe peple;
good and deuoute exorting, and from yuel þe peple dreedfully (c) Exhorting and warning. gastyng;
þi sacramentis mynystring; (d) Administer∣ing the Sacra∣ments.
how hise parischens lyven toward þ lawe enqueryng; of her defautis hem vndirnymyng; (e) Inquiring into the spiritual state of his people, and rebuking their faults.

rebellis, heretikis and obstynatis aȝens þi lawe punyschyng, or hem bi þe pope or þe prynce to be punyschid procuring; for his peple oft and deuoutly preiyng; (f) Punishing, or procuring the punishment of, heretics and obstinate sinners.

hem whiche he knowiþ certeinly be obstynat synners and brekers of goddis lawe to denounce auctoritatively, þat is to seie, bi assignement of god made to him þerto, þat þe synners ben bounden of god and of his riȝt doom to be dampned, (g) Praying for his people. also to be oute of þe soorte of sauable soulis, bi as moch as (h) Denouncing obstinate sinners. may be known aftir þe maner and qualite of her gouernauncis in which þei ben as for þilk tyme ynne, þat is to seie, if þei schulen be dampned;

Also hem whiche he knowiþ certeinly to be repentauncers (i) Absolving the repentant. for her synnes and to be ful turners to god, aftir foorme y-sette aftir in þe [xviije] MS. xiij; the v being probably unintentionally omitted. chapitre of þis first party, to denounce auctoritatively, þat is to seie, bi assignement of god made þer to MS. þerto. a preest, þat alle þo ben lowsid and assoilid of god and of his greet mercy;

Also alle þo which he knowiþ certeinly to be kepers of goddis lawe, bi filling of vertues and fleing vicis, to denounce (j) Assuring the virtuous of everlasting life. auctoritatively, þat is to seie, bi þe assignement to him made of god þerto, þat þo riȝtful lyvers ben of þe soort of savid men, if þei in such good lyving die;

To princys and to þe comunalte, how þei schulen ordeyn and (k) Assisting the prince and his people to rule and live according to God's law. reule alle þe parties of þe comunalte, þat þei not reule ne ordeyne aȝens goddis lawe, but alweie wiþ goddis lawe, assistence and counseil and informacioun and exortacioun ȝeuing;

making and ordeyning, wiþ consent of þe peple which (l) Framing, with consent of the people, laws for the better fulfilling of their duty towards God. schulden hem | kepe, lawis, ordinauncis, resonable, holsum and profitable, leding into goddis more plesaunce and his seruice þe bettir or more sureli to be doon, if þe peple which schulde hem kepe, ȝeue þerto her assent, bi hem silf, or bi her attorneys and procutouris; which maners of resonable posi∣tive Laws, for ex∣ample, as to the places and times of worship. lawis ben þese: as is forto ordeyne certeyn placis and tymes where and whanne peple schal come to gider forto attende to þi lawe leernyng, remembring, teching, and þerynne to gedir talking, and make to þee, lorde, to gidere preiyng and preising, bisidis oþire tymes and places which ech persoone may chese at his owne wil and at his owne leiser, to þe same goostli labouris bi hem silf, or wiþ oþire felawschip, so þat it be not aȝens þe doom of resoun; And And laws as to the manner and times of fasting. also as is forto assigne certeyn tymes for fastyng and þe maner of fastyng; And also as is forto refreyne and werne and aȝenstonde alle vnskilfulle nouelries, alle wantoun deuo∣ciouns, And laws against new and heretical doctrines. of þe peple, which deuociouns and new fyndingis wolden lette and appeire þe more cleer, more pure and more sure leernyng and keping of goddis lawe; and so forþ MS. soforþ. of manye oþire holsum ordinauncis to be made, so þat þilk lawis and ordinauncis ben not to manye for choking and letting mennys wittis to leerne and kunne parfitli þe lawe of scripture and lawe of kynde, for þe greet attendaunce which must nedis be ȝouun to so greet a multitude of lawis positive.

Also to þe attendaunce of a prelate it longiþ þat þese now (m) Performing these duties gratuitously. seid officis he freeli ministre, and þe werkis of þe same officis freeli ȝeue and forþ doo, withoute saale or chaunge or eny bargeyning as price for þe werke or for þe office receyuing.

also his good gouernaunce stondiþ in forbering al maner of (n) Abstaining from fleshly and worldly fleischli and worldli vsis, entirmetyngis and solicitudis,
wherbi he schulde be lettid from dewe and diligent atten∣daunce pleasures and power, which would hinder his work. and execucioun of alle þese now rehercid dedis, except | whanne and where nede of his bodili kynde and þe more forþeryng of goddis seruice for oþire tymes it askiþ, As ben þese now folewing: ouer oft wyne and vynose drynkis vsing; In worldly maner domynacioun or princehode bering, but if nede for reule of þi peple it aske; worldli officis and rekenyngis in courte or oute of courte keping; ouer poor and vnsufficient endewing or sustynaunce, mouable or vn∣mouable, receyuing; his endower or his sustynaunce wiþ ouer greet chargys and solicitudis of reparyng, defending, ingardyng, encresyng, maynteyning, and suche oþire, in his owne persoone, to bere taking. 'Take' here seems used in the sense of 'make', 'forbearing (p. 73, 1. 36). . . to make his endower or his sustenance bear'. Cf. Rep., p. 156: At whiche men mowe lawȝe and take bourde, and Babington's glossary note under Take.

DIV3.HEAD: [xije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [T]He gouernaunce and þe attendaunce of a prince Omitted in P.M.M. See p. 71, note 8. (7) The prince towards his people. The prince's duties com∣prise: towarde his peple conteynyth þese poyntis folewing: þat is to seie,

seyng þat as manye parties or degrees or statys as ben (a) Proper pro∣vision for the seven kinds of labour necessary in Church and State. necessarye to þe nede and profite of þe comounte, be ordeyned and stablid to be and abide, as ben þese vij
The following seven points are num∣bered in the MS., in the same hand, ie to vij.e
The P.M.M. deals with these seven states in connexion with Doughtiness (after the account given in Donet, Appendix), fols. 31a, 1. 18, to 31b, l. 14: ffadir, for as myche as in þe first maner of douȝtines ȝe made mencioun of vij parties whiche maken a comounalte ful, hool and sufficient to him silf, I preie ȝow seie ȝe whiche ben þilk vij parties. Sone, þei ben þese : þe first is, &c.:

The first, P.M.M. inserts is. erþetiliers, wiþ MS. wiþ beestys multipliyng repeated. P.M.M. substitutes: with purtenauncis, as bringing forþ of beestis and oþire. beestys multipliyng MS. wiþ bestys multipliyng repeated. P.M.M. substitutes : with purtenauncis, as bringing forþ of beestis and oþire. The ije, P.M.M. inserts is. craftys men; The iije, P.M.M. inserts is. merchauntys; The iiije, P.M.M. inserts is. mynistris P.M.M. substitutes : laborers or mynystris. or seruauntis or laborers P.M.M. substitutes : laborers or mynystris. The ve, P.M.M. inserts is. leerid P.M.M. has : þe ve is scolers or leerned men; boþe . . . moral kunnyng being omitted. men or scolers, boþe of natural kunnyng and of moral kunnyng P.M.M. has : þe ve is scolers or leerned men; boþe . . . moral kunnyng. being omitted. The vje, P.M.M. inserts is. prelatis, or curatis, wiþ The P.M.M. runs : with oþire to hem subseruyng, or to hem perteynyng. And þe vije is þe hiȝ prince, with his vndir∣neþe him dukis and officeris. And þus myche as for vertues of þe iije table. Then it goes on to virtues of the Fourth Table. See above, pp. 60 ff. vndir hem helpers, as louȝer
preestis and oþire ordrid men, and wiþ religiouse persoonys profityng forto be able, if god so graunte, to be takun into state of prelacye or curacye; The vije, þe prynce wiþ hise helpers vndir him, as dukis, and oþire officers The P.M.M. runs : with oþire to hem subseruyng, or to hem perteynyng. And þe vije is þe hiȝ prince, with his vndir∣neþe him dukis and officeris. And þus myche as for vertues of þe iije table. Then it goes on to virtues of the Fourth Table. See above, pp. 60 ff.;

and þat al waastful and vnprofitable parties, statis, degrees, (b) Abolition of all offices and crafts harmful to the State. offices, or craftis, to þe hool comounte be lettid to be, or þat þei be removid, if þei happe to be;

seyng also þat eche of þese vij parties haue suche persoonys (c) Proper pro∣vision of fit labourers in the seven kinds of labour necessary in Church and State. as ben able and sufficiently disposid to þe vse and exercise of þilk partie; And þanne þat þilk partie haue so manye suche persoonys as is nede and profite for þilk parties | con∣tynuyng into þe comoun profite, and no mo;

seyng also þat þilk parties which ben not ordeyned to (d) Proper pro∣vision of sus∣tenance for scholars and priests. laboure into wynnyng her lijflode and al maner necessaries, bi cause þei ben ordeyned to laboure in spirit for þe comoun profite, as ben scolers and preestys and gouerners, þat þei haue of þe oþire parties her sufficient fynding or endewing, movable or vnmouable, as is moost expedient to her officis trewli, dewli executing for þe comoun profite, for goddis sake and his seruice, finali or endeli;

making, and ordeyning to be made, lawis, wiþ comoun assent (e) Framing just laws, with the people's consent, and governing according to them. of his peple, for reule of alle his lege men, not oonli in con∣tractis and couenauntis aboute propirte and þerto purte∣nauncis, or in keping pees, but also in alle oþire maner of gouernauncis longing to þe comoun profite, and to goddis vertuose lawe keping, as fer as vndir mannys witt and power it may falle to fynde, knowe and ordeyne; wiþ which lawis he schal gouerne and reule, or procure to be gouerned and reulid, hise peple, and not aȝens þese lawis to do;

seyng þat boþe he and eche state or degree vndir hise prince∣hode (f) Governing according to the laws of Reason and Faith, as taught by the priest. lyue as þei ouȝte bi resoun and bi feiþ, and bi lawis þerupon maad to þe comune and to ech oþeris helpe, forþering and profite, wiþoute synne and trespace aȝens þe lawe of kynde and lawe of oure feiþ, which lawe of oure feiþ prestys schulen to him and to his comunalte bi holi scripture treuli
and sufficientli ministre, And þe prince schal it deuouteli leerne, kepe and defende;

punysching alle trespasers aȝens þese poyntis now seide, and (g) Punishing justly all who trespass against the laws of Reason and Faith. þat bi bodili peyne or bi her worldly goodis, which punysch∣ingis schulen be taxid in qualite and quantite bi lawis þerupon maad with þe comunaltees assent; not willing and not desiring þe punysching and þe peynes of his peple made to hem in her ricchesse or in her bodies, saue oonly for nede of her amendement, and for her good lyuing and gouernaunce, and for þat entent oonly doyng;

| defending alle hise legy men bi his strengþe, lawe and (h) Defending his people from all harm and wrong. auctorite, from alle wrongys in her personys and in her goodis, And so to defende eche man in his riȝt, and specialy to defende goddis riȝt, þat is to seie, þe trewe cowrs of goddis lawe, whanne euer he be to enye of þese After þese, the MS. has requyred, crossed through. bi enye man requyred, or whanne euer he may þerof haue sure knowing; seyng þat alle hise debutees and officers execute diligently (i) Seeing that his ministers properly per∣form their duties. and treuly and freely, in his name and in his stide, for his helpe, her officis to hem assigned, and þat for þe comoun profite, into goddis plesaunce;

holding him content wiþ his propre endewing; noon taxe or (j) Demanding from his people only just tax and service. talage or tribute of hise peple, withoute nede or profite of þe comounte, and not wiþoute þe comounte assent, asking and taking; not taking eny personal service of his peple aȝens her wil, ferþir or more þan his lawe resonable, afore made bi consent of his peple, taxiþ, lymytiþ and assignith;

neiþir þat he lette his peple to consente, to ordeyne, to do, (k) Allowing just liberty to his people, especially in spiritual things. to go, to passe, to ȝeue, to suffre, aftir resoun and aftir her wil, Namelich goostly purposis into þi plesaunce or seruyce, lorde god, in lasse þan þerbi arise damage to þe comoun profite, suche as ouȝte in doom of resoun raþir to be eschewid þan þe same good dedis or purposis of hise peple ouȝte to be fulfillid.

The childe Cf. henceforward P.M.M., fols. 41a, l. 19, to 43a, 1. 5. in his ȝongþe is bounde anentis his fadir and THE CORRE∣SPONDING RELA∣TIONSHIPS modir to reuerence hem and P.M.M. inserts to. obeie to hem in alle poyntis
afore MS. a fore. rehercid in þe attendaunce of fadir and modir to þe TOWARDS SUPERIORS. (1) The child towards his parents. childe. In P.M.M. runs: þe child in his age of manhode. his age of manhode, þe childe P.M.M. runs: þe child in his age of manhode. is bounde to reuerence fadir and modir, and to helpe and releue þe febilnes, þe pouerte, wrongis suffring, þe vnkunnyng, and P.M.M. omits: and amende. amende P.M.M. omits: and amende. þe mys lyuing of hem, if þei falle into such nede.

Chargys of þe wijf toward þe P.M.M. substitutes her, but the word is half erased. husbonde stondiþ Stondiþ here, and below, p. 78, l. 17, is perhaps to be regarded as a singular verb, and chargis as a collective noun, taking either a singular or plural verb. Cf. the P.M.M., fol. 41b, ll. 17-18, Charges of þe apprentise to his maistir is, where the Donet has ben (p. 77, l. 13). The -iþ, -eþ plural of the pres. ind. is rare, though not unknown, in Pecock. In the Represser I do not remember an instance; Babing∣ton's glossary: 'aȝenstondith, pl. 7', must be wrong, for the subject is 'God'. The Donet once has williþ, p. 61, l. 1, where the P.M.M. reads willen. The P.M.M. has stiriþ and enclineþ where the Donet reads stiren and inclynen, p. 95, l. 24. in (2) The wife towards her husband. reuerence to him doing; in obeisaunce to alle hise comaunde∣mentis afore | touchid paiyng; in releuing and helping his febilnes, sijknes, vnkunnyng, pouerte, aduersite and myslyu∣ing, as moche as sche may P.M.M., can and may. and can P.M.M., can and may. wiþ resonable and discreet circumstauncis, and namely wiþ wise counseil þer∣upon of oþire wise men asking, if þei falle.

Chargys of þe apprentyse to his maistir The third relationship, the scholar towards his schoolmaster, is omitted both in Donet and in P.M.M. ben P.M.M. substitutes is. Cf. above, footnote 5. forto obeie (4) The appren∣tice towards his master. The third relationship, the scholar towards his schoolmaster, is omitted both in Donet and in P.M.M. and fulfille anentis his maistir what he bihiȝte forto do and fulfille anentis his maistir bi þe couenaunt of his apprentise∣hode, wheþir þe P.M.M., þo. werkis ben werkis of his craft, or eny oþire werkis for þe maistris profite. Neuerþeles, wheþir þe ap∣prentise wole sufficientli leerne, or no, þe craft which his maistir is redy and willy to teche him, he may chese, wiþoute eny wrong þerbi to come fro him toward his maistir, in lasse þan þerbi sum wynnyng, profite, or avauntage, schulde growe bi couenaunte of þe apprentisehode toward his maistir; for into so moche leernyng and worching into þe maistris profite, into how moche and which þe couenaunt of þe apprentise∣hode dryueþ, þe apprentise is bounde, and no ferþir; ffor whi ech man may lefully renounce and forsake what is for
his owne oonly avauntage, worschip, or fauoure, to be of him doon.

How þe hirer owȝte haue him anentis þe P.M.M., his. hired laborer, (5) The hired labourer towards the hirer. and how þe hyrid laborer ouȝte bere him anentis his hyrer, may be open bi what is tauȝte in þe combynacioun or knytting of a crafty man and his apprentyse, See above, p. 71. þat is to seie, þat euer eiþir of hem kepe his party of þe couenaunt bitwixe hem maad.

Cf. below, p. 83, l. 28.; ech man must nedis haue me excusid if y schulde reherce hem fully; and as, y weene, no vertu of goddis lawe can be assigned which is not euidentli and openly conteyned vndir oon of þe seide xxxj vertues, ȝhe, and so conteyned vndir oon of þilk xxxj vertu vertues þat þe name of þilk oon is uerified vpon þe oþire vertu assigned to be con∣teyned vndir it, And þerfore þe names of þese xxxj vertues, if þei be had wel and parfitly in mynde, schu∣len bring into remembraunce of him þat so haþ hem in mynde, y dare weel seie, alle goddis commaundementis and alle moral vertues of his lawe, as openli and as sufficiently as so litil a noumbre of xxxj names may do (which noumbre y holde to be in a goode meene, not ouer greet, leest it schulde be ouer chargeose to þe mynde, neiþir ouer litil, leest it schulde be
ouer derk to bring into remembraunce alle goddis com∣maundementis and lawis)—And, if al þis be trewe, it folewiþ No change for the better can be made in these Four Tables. þat þis foorme of teching goddis commaundementis and lawis, fro þe bigynning of þe iij chapitre hidirto, nediþ not to be chaungid or amendid; namelich so moche as nede This cannot be said of the tables so far drawn up by other writers. dryuith summe oþire mennys foormes teching goddis com∣maundementis and lawis, to be blamyd, inprovid, chaungid and amendid, And þat boþe for insufficience and for þe vntrowþe in her teching; þouȝ god forbede y schulde oþire wise feele, but þat an oþire foorme may bi oþire men be founde as sufficient and as weel and as openly in anoþir maner teching goddis commaundementis, as þis present seide foorme, bi me sette forþ, dooþ; Neuerþeles, y weene forto fynde enye straunge foorme fro þis present foorme, and to þe seide purpos, schal be no nede. And forto make good what y haue now seide, þat oþire mennys foormes, taking vpon hem forto teche and trete goddis commaundementis and lawis, ben insufficient and inconuenient to þilk purpos, schal be schewid in a tretice þerfore speciali to be made, whos name schal be þis, 'þe inprouing of mennys insufficient foormes.'

And þouȝ þese wordis, and manye mo whiche y write in Pecock does not mean to boast, or to despise other men's work; but merely to further the knowledge of God's com∣mandments. þis present book and in summe oþire bokis, mow be takun as for wordis of veyn glorye or of pryde and of presumpcioun vpon my silf, and as wordis of indignacioun or envye as anentis oþire men and her writingis, lord god, þou knowist þat y seie hem not, neiþir write hem, vndir þilk corrupcioun, and y beseche þat y neuer so do. And, lorde, þou knowist þat | for ȝele to þi trouþe and to þi trewe seruice, y seie hem with schame and wiþ drede, lest y schal for hem be amys deemed, In lasse þanne what y now seie here for myn excuse be þerfro a defence and a coueryng.

Certis, if poul ouȝt not be deemed a veyn MS. aveyn. avaunter of St. Paul is not blamed for praising his own teaching, and for de∣nouncing other men's imperfect teaching. him silf, and of oþire mennys teching a proude despiser, for it þat he wroot and seid of him silf and of oþire mennys teching, ija corinthies, xje chapitre, from þe myddis into þe eende of þilk chapitre, and þoruȝ oute al þe first and ije

And so, sone, þouȝ y be synful and ful of defautis and ser from þe euenesse to seint poul, ȝit to alle þe reders and to alle þe heerers of al what y haue writun or schal write, my conscience reproueþ me not forto seie what poul seide of him silf, ija corinthies, ve chapitre, vv. 12-14. þus: 'We commende not vs silf eftsoon to ȝou; but we ȝeuen to ȝou occasioun to haue glorie for vs, þat ȝe haue to hem þat glorien in þe face and not in þe herte. for ouþer we bi mynde passen to god, ouþer we ben sobir to ȝou. sorsoþe, þe charite of crist dryuith vs.' þat is to seie, in pleyner maner þus: 'I entende not to commende my silf, as for my silf, in eny wordis which y schal write or seie; but y ȝeue an occasioun and a cause þat ȝe considre and knowe ȝou to haue sumwhat wherbi ȝe mowe aȝen stonde vnsufficient teching trouþe, and to aȝenstonde þe te∣chers of vnsufficient and of vntrouþe, And to knowe cleerli necessary trouþis. And among my writingis, if in eny placis of hem y passe þe capacite of ȝoure vndirstonding for þe tyme in which ȝe schulen at þe first rede hem or heere hem, be it to þe preising of god þat his trouþis ben so hiȝe þat þei ben at þe first heering so harde to ȝoure vndirstonding; And if in oþire placis of my writingis, y be so sobre þat þei ben anoon takeable of ȝoure vndirstonding, be it to ȝoure profite, for in boþe þese seide maners for to write, as y hope, þe charite of god me forþ dryueþ.'

And þerfore þe fadir is not þe sone, neiþir þe fadir is þe holi goost, neiþir þe sone is þe fadir or þe holi goost. and alle þese bringyngis forþ ben doon withynne þe (3) But one Substance. same substaunce, withynne þe same beyng, and in þe same godhede. Benefetis of god vndir graciose, þat is to seie, louȝer þan I. Under∣gracious bene∣fits: His creation of the world and of all creatures; ben P.M.M. omits ben. benefetis of grace, ben þese: his making of aungels and of men, of heuenes elementis, and of alle her contentis in so manye diuers kyndis; his keping of alle þo same, þat His keeping of the same; þei falle not into nouȝt; His gouernyng of alle þe P.M.M., þo. same, and of alle þe newingis, P.M.M., new þingis. chaungis, chauncis and effectis which His government of the same; fallen in eny of þe same, and þat, aftir P.M.M. omits aftir . . . alle. sum opynioun, alle P.M.M. omits aftir . . . alle. bi him silf immediatli (þat is to seie, in P.M.M. omits in . . . worching. þilk worching P.M.M. omits in . . . worching. withoute eny P.M.M. omits eny. meene of eny oþir creature), or ellis, P.M.M. runs: or ellis of sum inmediatli [sic] and of oþir sum mediatli. aftir sum oþir opinioun, summe immediatli and oþire summe mediatli P.M.M. runs: or ellis of sum inmediatli [sic] and of oþir sum mediatli. (þat is to seie, bi meene of oþire crea∣turis), but
ȝitt euermore þoruȝ his power, witing and willing princi∣pali; his ȝift to vs of oure boþe body and of P.M.M. omits of. oure resonable His gift to man of a body and a reasonable soul; soule, wiþ alle her kyndeli goodis; His ȝift into oure seruice of heuenli bodies, as ben planetis and sterris, wiþ her large speeris; Also his ȝift of elementis, wiþ her contentis, and so His gift to man of all the heavenly bodies, the elements, and the lower creatures; folewingli his ȝift to vs of alle creaturis louȝer in kynde þan man is; His ȝift to vs of goddis y-gete or maad bi labour of oure natural witt and wil, and of oþire powers of þe soule His gift to man of all goods made by man's own skill; subseruing or vndirseruing to oure witt and to oure wil: which goodis ben sciencis, craftys, housis, cloþis, ricchessis, worschipis, dignitees, officis, fauouris and fames; His ȝifte His gift to man of relatives and friends. of alle oure b[r]iþeren MS. biþeren; P.M.M., briþeren. and sistren P.M.M. inserts: and neiȝboris. in mankynde into oure helpe and into oure counforte.

Graciose benefetis of god ben þese: his ordinaunce þat II. Gracious benefits: His ordinance that all things, except our sins, should be for our spiritual advantage; alle þingis which ben ȝouun to vs, or schulen in eny maner bifalle to P.M.M. omits to. vs, excepte oure owne P.M.M. omits owne. synne, schulen turne P.M.M. inserts vs. into oure goostli good and profite, if we so wole, and not lette, bi oure inpacience and oure aȝens grucching; his ordinaunce þat man, aftir his synne, schulde be restorid into P.M.M., to. saluacioun, His ordinance that man, in spite of his sins, should be saved; þouȝ aungel synnyd and was left vnrestorid; His ordinaunce þat aungels schulde be to vs attendaunt and defendaunt, and þat grace wiþynneforþ schulde move vs and stirre vs His ordinance that angels should serve and defend us; and that His grace should incline us to good, and turn us from evil; into good, and also move vs and drawe vs from yuel; His ordinaunce þat oure restoring and redempcioun schulde be maad bi þe incarnacioun and þe holi lijf and peyneful passioun, resurrexioun, ascencioun and to þe doom aȝen comyng of þe His ordinance that Christ should redeem us, in the man∣ner rehearsed in the Creed; secunde persoone in trinyte, þat is to seie, þe sone of þe fadir in trinite; In which ordinaunce þe seide ij persoone took fleisch and blood, and bicam verry man, conceivid and born of maide mary, he being in oon persoone verry god and verry man, y-callid 'Jesus'
MS. Jhc, as also P.M.M.
It is a question whether to extend such abbreviated forms of the name 'Jesus'—'Jhc', 'Jhs', &c.—as Jesus, when the h is taken to represent the Greek eta, or with the Latin h, when the extended form would be printed Jhesus. The form given in the text seems to me more logical. For a discussion of the point see Prou's Manuel de paléographie, Paris, 3rd ed., 1910, pp. 115-17, and Traube's Nomina Sacra, Munich, 1907.
The c of Jhc represents, of course, the Greek sigma.; In which manhode and fleischli
body so takun, he suffrid peynful passioun and hard | deeþ vndir pounce pylate, bi departing of his soule from his P.M.M., þe. body, but euer wiþoute eny hurte to his godhede; which body also laie deed in þe sepulcre, The Descent into Hell is omitted here, and in the corresponding passage in the P.M.M. This omission from the articles of our belief was one of the accusations brought against Pecock. Cf. Book of Faith, pp. 304-5, for reason for omission. and was aȝen quykened in þe iije daie to lijf bi aȝen coupling of þe bodi to þe soule; And so Jesus roos þe iije daie from deeþ to lijf, in body and in soule, neuer eftsoones to deie; And in þe same body and soule, he boþe to gedir, god and man, þe fourtiþe daie aftir his resurrexioun stied vp into heuene, setting him silf on þe riȝt half of þe fadir, from whens he is eftsoones to come in þe same manhode, forto deeme þe quyke and deed; whanne þat alle men which P.M.M. inserts þat. euer lyueden in erþe schulen rise in body and soule to lijf; And alle þo whiche han lyued vertuosely in keping goddis lawe schulen entre, body and soule to gider, into perpetual heuene blisse; And alle þoo whiche han broke goddis lawe bi deedly synne, and haue not þerof be amendid in þis lijf, schulen be þrouȝe, body and His ordinance of the Church on earth, and of its sacra∣ments; soule to gider, into perpetuel peyne of helle; his ordinaunce þat he wolde haue a chirche here in erþe, vndir his chirche whiche he haþ in heuene; in whiche chirche here in erþe he haþ sette sacramentis, as baptym and eukarist, whos availis and dewe receitis ben afore in þe iiije P.M.M. substitutes: first chapitre of þis litil extract. chapitre of þis first His ordinance that forgiveness of sins is gained by repentance; party P.M.M. substitutes: first chapitre of þis litil extract. declarid; His ordinaunce þat forȝeuenes of synnes y-doon aftir tyme of baptym may be hadde bi repentaunce and ful aȝen turnyng to god, y-made in oon hede P.M.M., ooned. of cristis feiþ and cristis holi churche, þoruȝ maners whiche ben tauȝt aftir in þis first P.M.M. substitutes: litil extract, þe laste chapitre. party, in þe xviij chapitre P.M.M. substitutes: litil extract, þe laste chapitre. toward þe eende; His ordinaunce þat cristis holi lijf and passioun His ordinance that Christ's life and pas∣sion procured for us forgive∣ness of sins, provided we repent; deseruid to vs grace to gete forȝeuenes of synnes, P.M.M., synne. if we take and perfoorme þe remedies whiche ben resonabli ordeyned þerfore; Also þat it deseruid to vs grace or power to aȝen∣stonde
synne, grace to make aȝen restoring or in P.M.M. omits in sum maner. sum And procured for us also grace to with∣stand sin, to make amends for sin, and to deserve heaven; maner P.M.M. omits in sum maner. satisfaccioun for synne, grace to deserue perpetuel mede bi vertuose werkis; | which gracis or powers weren loste bi Adamys P.M.M., adam. synne, and þei weren vnrecouerable to be hadde, or to be geten, or aftirwarde to be kepte bi mannys owne power; His ordinaunce þat peynes and wrecchidnessis His ordinance that our 'wretched∣nesses' should be for our good; into whiche we ben falle, bi occasioun of adamys synne, be maad for oure bettir; His ordinaunc[e] MS. ordinauncis, clearly through anticipation of gracis; P.M.M., ordinaunce. þat gracis afore ȝouun ben encresid and multiplied, if we obeie to þe inwarde moving of þo gracis, and putten hem not aback; His ordi∣naunce His ordinance that grace should increase in us, if we obey the inward promptings of that grace; þat þe lijf and passioun of his sone, Jesus, oure sauiour, which lijf and passioun were doon and suffrid for vs, schulde be passing holy and passing peynful, as may be seen bi articlis which mowe be markid from þe bigynnyng His ordinance that Christ's life and passion should be supremely holy and painful; into þe eende of þe P.M.M. omits þe. iiij eu[a]ngelistis, MS. eungelistis; P.M.M., euange∣listis. and sumwhat ben expressid in [þe] Omitted in MS.; P.M.M., þe. secunde partie of þe book callid 'þe rewle of cristen religioun', and þe book of diuine office', in þe seruice or office of P.M.M. inserts þe. palme sundaie weke; His ordynaunce þat Jesus schulde so moche louȝe and meke him silf in man∣kynde His ordinance that Christ, though Man, should at the same time be God; þat he wolde be callid, and verrily be, oure weifere, oure techer, oure exaumpler, oure raunsumner, oure raun∣sum, oure tresoure, oure ioie, oure counforte, oure hope in þis lijf, oure fadir, oure broþir, oure spouse, oure goostly foode of mete and drynke, oure aduoket in heuene, oure protectour and defender in erþe aȝens alle oure enemyes, ȝeuer of alle gracis and goodis in erþe, ȝeuer of al glorye in heuene, not wiþstonding P.M.M runs: not withstondyng he was and is in his manhode king, &c. he, being in his manhode, was and is, in sensible execucioun, king P.M.M runs: not withstondyng he was and is in his manhode king, &c. of hevene, lorde of al P.M.M. omits al. þe worlde and emperoure of helle, bi merit of his holi lijf and passioun; His ordinaunce þat we mowe preie to him and to His ordinance that prayer to Him, to angels, and to saints, should be heard; aungelis and to seintis for us silf and for oure neiȝboris, and be herd; His ordinaunce þat alle aungelis in heuene and alle holi soulis passid and alle holi cristen in erþe mowe preie
for vs and be herd, as it is | recording P.M.M., according. to oure profite and His ordinance that angels, holy men de∣parted this life, and holy men on earth, should pray for us, and be heard; to P.M.M. omits to. oure nede and to his worschip; His ordinaunce þat ech cristen man schal fare þe bettir for ech of hise freendis sake, þat is to seie, ech cristen man schal þe more be sparid, þe more goodis receyue, for eche of hise freendis sake, þouȝ þilk freende preie not actualy þerfore, And þat more or lasse aftir His ordinance that every Christian shall fare the better for his Christian friends' sake; þat þis cristen man is more or lasse in þe freendschip of þis now seid freende, And aftir þat more or lasse god loueþ þilk freende for his good lyuing; And so, siþen alle cristen men being in charite ben to gedir eche oþeris freendis, it muste nedis folewe þat god haþ ordeined ech trewe cristen man forto fare þe bettir for ech oþir cristen mannys good lijf and good dedis; His ordinaunce þat holi scripture of þe oolde His ordinance of the teaching of Scripture. testament and of þe newe schulde enforme and remembre vs and so mynystre to vs oure P.M.M. inserts hool. seiþ ful trewli, dewli P.M.M. omits dewli. and deuoutely.

How mercyful, how desirosely, how piteuosely, how How merciful God is in giving to us all these gracious bene∣fits! graciousely, how louyngli and how myȝtly god wrouȝte and dide to hise peple in tyme of þe oolde testament and to hise peple of þe newe testament, and how he wole do gloriosely to hem boþe in an oþir lijf aftir þis lijf! And þus moche, o my sone, as for graciose benefetis, into tyme þou come into 'þe reule of cristen religioun'.

DIV3.HEAD: [xvje chapitre]
DIV3.P: [G]Loriose benefetis of god, þat is to seie, Joies of heven, III. Glorious benefits of God: ben so greet and so merueilose þat þei mowe not of vs be spokun, seen, herd, or þouȝt, as þei ben in her vtterist good∣nes and felicite. Neuerþelees, in suche maner as her knowyng mowe falle into mannys witte, þei mowe be dis∣cryuyd in þis maner:
Of gloriose benefetis, þat is to seie, of benefetis to be There are two degrees of glorious bene∣fits: ȝouun in heuene, summe ben princypal ioies, and summe ben secundarie ioyes.

Principal Joye stondiþ in cleer and immediat siȝt of þe
godhede, in hiȝe wel willing and swete loue to it, and in | (a) Principal joys. nyȝ, at þe next ioyning to it, and Omitted in P.M.M. in sure holding of it.

Of secundarye ioyes, summe ben vttirli supernatural, þat (b) Secondary joys, which are either (1) Supernatural or (2) Natural. is to seie, aboue kynde, And þese ben not al P.M.M. omits al. flowyng bi comyng and goyng, bi encresing and decresing; And summe ben natural wiþynne þe boondis of kynde, and P.M.M. substitutes: and þese ben. of þese manye ben P.M.M. substitutes: and þese ben. flowyng, comyng and goyng, now encresid, P.M.M. inserts and. now decresid.
Of supernatural ioies, summe ben of þe body, and Omitted in P.M.M. summe (1) Supernatural joys are: (a) Of the body. (b) Of the soul. ben P.M.M. omits ben. of þe soule.

Supernatural ioies in þe bodies side ben þese: passing fairnes, passing helþe, passing strengþe, passing swiftnes, (a) Supernatural joys of the body. passing fredom, passing sensual delectacioun þoruȝ al oure inwarde and outwarde sensitive wittis, in P.M.M. omits in . . . chapitre. þe maner tauȝt in þe ije partie of 'cristen religioun', þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. tretice, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre, P.M.M. omits in . . . chapitre. euerlestyngnes of lijf and of alle þese ioies and benefetis now seid.

Supernatural ioies in þe soulis side ben þese: passing (b) Supernatural joys of the soul. wisdom, passing frendschip having, passing power, passing worschip, passing pees and accorde, passing gladnes, and ful sikirnes neuer to leese vttirly eny of þese P.M.M. inserts ioies. now afore seid, neiþir of hem which now schulen be seid.

Accidental ioies natural in heuene, þat is to seie, suche (2) Natural joys rehearsed. þat bi oure natural powers mowe þere be geten and be aȝen lost, ben þese: Leernyng and cleer kunnyng getyng vpon sutel trouþis being in creaturis þo[r]uȝ MS. þouȝ; P.M.M., þoruȝ. alle maner sciencis, passing fer þe maner and þe P.M.M. omits þe. degree of kunnyng which may be geten in þis lijf, and þat wiþ greet delectacioun folewing þerupon in þe wil; ful Hole in P.M.M. greet and Omitted in P.M.M. sensual delite geting naturali in summe of þe outward wittis: as in siȝt of moost faire þingis, in heering of moost After moost, MS. has faire þingis, crossed through. myry þingis, and touching of moost louyd þingis, and in þe ymaginacioun and mynde
þerto answering; fful greet honoure, worschip, ouerte, fame, fauoure and glorye, which oþire P.M.M., oure. sauid aungelis and seyntis schulen ȝeve to vs; | ffull greet familiarite, or homelynes getyng, wiþ worþi persoonys and wiþ alle louyd persoonys: as for to talke wiþ hem, se hem, heere hem, biclippe hem, and abide wiþ hem; Also ful greet gladnes for ascapyng of dampnacioun and of peynes in helle; Also þe gladnes vpon goddis riȝtwisnes executid vpon dampned aungels and dampned men, And ful greet gladnes for P.M.M., of. oure owne salua∣cioun and oure blisse, and for þe blisse of eche saued aungel and saued man. And þus moche as for goddis gloriose benefetis in heuene.

More of þis mater, whiche ben goddis benefetis to man, Where further teaching on God's benefits may be found. may be seen in þe first partie of 'cristen religioun', P.M.M. inserts: þe ije treti, and in þe ije partie of cristen religioun. þe ije, iije, iiije, ve and þe P.M.M. omits þe. vje treticis, and in 'þe book of dyuyne office' in manye a wher. MS. awher; P.M.M., a wher.

Now, Cf. henceforward, P.M.M., fols. 53a, l. 17, to 54b, l. 4. sone, forto heere of goddis punysschingis, boþe of THE THIRD MATTER: GOD'S PUNISH∣MENTS. Of these there are two kinds: þo which ben holde P.M.M. omits holde . . . be. and seide to be P.M.M. omits holde . . . be. purgyng and amending synne, And also of þo which not so amendys maken for synne, þou schalte wite þat summe of hise punysschyngis ben maad in þis lijf, summe in þe lijf to come.

Of þo punysschyngis which schulen be in þis lijf, summe (1) Punishments in this life: ben peynes to þe body: as hungir, þirst, heet, ccold, sijknes, (a) Of the body. traueyl, murmur, MS. murmur; P.M.M., murþir, which makes better sense in this context. mayme, deeþ, and such oþire; summe ben (b) Of the soul. peynes to þe soule: as ben sorewe, hevynes, feer, wanhope, vilonye, schame, vnworþines, ignoraunce, leudenes, folye, diffame, and suche oþire; And summe ben goddis wiþdraw∣ingis (c) Through the withdrawal of God's grace, &c. of his grace and of his helpe and his loue and of his goostly diffence and forþeraunce, wherbi a man fallith from synne into synne, and so fro myscheef into myscheef.

Of þo punyschingis which schulen be in þe lijf to come, (2) Punishments in the life to come. summe is losse of alle þe P.M.M. omits þe. passing ioyes of heuene afore in þis chapitre rehercid, See Notes. and of ech of hem; summe is passing
greet sorewe making or suffring for losse of alle þese same seide ioies, and of ech of hem; summe is ful vttirly dispeire of eny lassing or releeue, but ful certeynte of alle þese now seid, and aftir | to be seid, peynes, wiþ her euerlastyng contynuaunce; summe is passing greet sensual peyne: as in seyng passing horrible þingis, in heering of Omitted in P.M.M. passing gastful noisis, in smelling moost loþid P.M.M., loþli. stinchis, in taasting moost squaymose taastis, in touching, and suffri[ng] MS. suffrid, clearly through anticipa∣tion of touchid; P.M.M. suffring. to be touchid, of moost peynful and moost greuouse þingis to þe touche; Summe is in abiding wiþ moost looþid and moost hatid cumpanye; Summe is in feer for ymaginacioun and mynde vpon þe chaunging of peynes to come.

More of þis mater, which ben punysschingis for oure Where further teaching on God's punish ments may be found. synnes, may be seen in þe first partie of 'cristen religioun', þe ije tretye, and in þe ije partye, þe vj tretye, and in 'þe book of dyuyne office', in preiers assigned for þursdaye to alle seintis, and in þe preiers assigned to ech special seynt. P.M.M. adds: and in oþir bokis of my writing.

Sone, þe knowyng of þi silf and of ech of þi neiȝboris, as Knowledge of oneself is knowledge of one's wretched∣nesses (the Fifth Matter) and of one's wicked∣nesses (the Sixth Matter), and of the remedies against both (the Seventh Matter). it is perteining to þin entent and purpos, is knowing which oure natural wrecchidnessis ben, which oure wickidnessis or synnes ben; and þanne aftir, if þou knowe which ben þe remedyes aȝens hem booþe, y truste þin entent is sumwhat geten and into þee receivid.

ffirst, oure natural w[r]ecchidnessis MS. wecchidnessis; P.M.M., wrechid∣nessis. ben not ellis þan pronytees and redynessis and inclinaciouns inclynyng vs to loue þis lijf for it silf, and to not chaunge it for þilk THE FIFTH MATTER: OUR NATURAL WRETCHED∣NESSES. which is bettir; þouȝ al þis lijf be foule, peynful, careful, perilose, dredeful, laboriose, vnrestful, ful of [vn]kunnyng, MS. kunnyng; P.M.M., vnkunnyng, which is more likely to be the right read∣ing.
