DIV2.HEAD: [ije partie]
DIV2.P: Here bigynneþ þe secunde party of þis book.

DIV3.HEAD: Capitulum primum.
DIV3.P:
[G]Ramercy, fadir, gentil fadir, louyng fadir, and ful Where in the First Part are taught the Twelve Articles of the Creed; the Seven Deadly Sins; the Five Wits; the Seven Works of Mercy; Faith, Hope, and Charity; the Four Cardinal Virtues; the Seven Gifts of the Holy Ghost; the Sacraments; and the Ten Command∣ments? profitable fadir, and y beseche god þat for ȝoure to me so riche and preciose teching deliuered in þe first afore going party of þis book, wiþ him and wiþ hise aungelis in heuene ȝe be richely rewardid. But now, fadir, to ȝoure reuerence I presente þis demaunde: If it so be as ȝe seien, þat þe loor of þis afore going first party be not oonly good and profit∣able, but also it is so ful and so sufficient as ȝe it to be pre∣tenden, where in þis seid afore going party is þe doctryne of þe xij articles of oure bileeue; where entriþ in to þis afore going first party þe leernyng of þe vij deedly synnes, or of þe vij heed synnys; where is bicome þe teching vpon þe weel vsing and keping of þe v wittis; where is þe scole of þe vij werkis of mercy, bodili and goostly; where in þis afore going first party ben feiþ, hope and charite; where renneþ þe chare of þe iiij cardinal vertues; where schulen be founde in þis same seid first party þe vij ȝiftis of þe holy goost; where in þis first seid party ben tauȝt þe sacramentis of god and þe sacramentis of holi churche; and where in þis seid first party is þe preching of þe x commaundementis? which doctrines, scolis and prechingis ben so famose, and so moche apprisid and sett bi of clerkis and of þe lay partye, þat þer is vnneþis eny holden for a cristen man but if þei
knowlech þat þei ben his not oonly good reule, but his sufficient, ful and hool and his oon only reule, to make al his vertuose conuersacioun aftir þe leding of hem. and ȝitt After ȝitt, the MS. has so crossed through, and of overwritten. of þese vij vij, so MS.; presumably an error for ix. so famose soortis, distincciouns or particiouns, fadir, ȝe make not mensioun of oon.

O, my sone, what article of þe crede or bileeue hast þou The TWELVE ARTICLES OF THE CREED have been taught already. which is not a treuþe falling vpon god him silf, or vpon summe of hise | benefetis, or summe of hise punysschingis, or vpon summe of hise lawis, or remedies aȝens oure wrecchid∣nessis and wickidnessis? And þerfore if þou biholde weel þoruȝ þis afore going first party, þou schalt fynde in him alle þi xij articles of þe comune crede, and manye mo articles which ben as moche to be bileeued as þi xij ben.

þe first article of þe comune crede, which article is þis: The First Article has been taught in Pt. I, chaps. xiv and xv. 'y bileeue into god þe fadir, maker of heuene and of erþe,' þou schalt fynde in þe xiiije and xv chapitris of þe first party afore going. ffor whi in þe xiiije chapitre it is tauȝt þat god is þre persoonys, fadir, sone and holi goost; and ȝitt þat þerwith he is not but oon and þe same substaunce in alle þre persoonys. Also in þe bigynnyng of þe xv chapitre, where benefetis vndirgraciose or louȝer þan graciose ben tauȝt, it is seid þat god maad heuene and erþe and alle her contentis. and how manye mo articlis of bileeue touch∣ing þe godhede, and touching his benefete in making creaturis, ben tauȝt in þe seid xiiij and xve chapitris, which articlis ben as necessary to be bileeuid MS. bileeuid it is liȝt to turne; it . . . turne being crossed through. as þis seid first article of þe comune crede is to be bileeuid, it is liȝt to turne þidir and to se.

Alle þe oþire xj articles of þe comune crede, which ben The other eleven Articles have been taught in Pt. I, chaps. xiv-xvi. þese: 'And y bileeue into Jesus crist, his oon bigeten sone, oure lorde; Which was conceyued of þe holy goost, and born of mary, þe maide; Which Jesus suffrid vndir pounce pilate, was crucified, was deed and biried
Pecock omits the Article of the Descent into Hell, as is noted in the margin in a later hand: omittit descendit ad inferna. This was one of the chief accusations brought against him.
See Notes.; and rose in þe iije daie
to lijf, stiȝed vp into heuene, sittiþ at þe riȝt side of þe fadir; fro whens he is to come for to deeme quyk and deede; I be∣leeue into þe holy goost See Notes.; and y bileeue his holy vniuersal or general chirche to be; y bileeue þe comunyng of seintis or of holy men to be See Notes.; y bileeue forȝeuenes of synne | to be; I bileeue þe aȝenrising of deed men, þat is to seie, to be or to come; and I beleeue euerlasting lijf to be or to come.' Alle þese þou schalt fynde eeuen, or welnyȝ bi rewe, in þe xv chapitre, among graciose benefetis þere rehercid, whanne it is seid þere þus: 'In which ordinaunce þe ije persoone took fleisch and blood', etcetera; except þe article of þe holy goost, which article is tretid afore in þe bigynnyng of þe xiiij chapitre of þe first party, as is now afore seid; and except þe article of euerlasting lijf, which is abrood sprad in þe xvj chapitre of þe first party. And how many mo articles of trew and necessary bileeue þan ben þese now rehercid of þe comune crede, þou schalt fynde in þese same now seid xiiij, xv and xvj chapitris, and in oþire chapitres of þe first party afore going, y committe to þe jugement of þin owne wijsdom.

ffadir, was not þe comune crede maad bi þe apostlis? And Did not the Apostles make the Creed, and are not the Articles of their Creed sufficient for the Christian? if it so were, whi schulde apostlis make and delyuere to vs pilk crede, but if þei, in þilk making and deliueraunce of þilk crede, meneden and entendiden þat oonly þo articlis y-sett forþ in þe same crede were sufficient to vs to be bileeued as feip?

Sone, wheþir þe apostlis maad þe comune crede, or no, Whether the Apostles made the Creed or no, will be dis∣cussed in the Book of Feith. schal not be seid here, but it schal be tretid in 'þe book of þe book of underlined in MS. feip See Notes.. but þis y dare wel seie and avowe: þe crede of þe apostlis ben þe al hool noumbre of alle þo articlis to be bileeuid which ben conteynyd wiþynne þe writing of þe new The New Testa∣ment is the Apostles' Creed. testament, fro þe bigynnyng of þe newe testament into þe eende of þe newe testament, And þerfore þe ful and hool crede of þe apostlis is moche lengir þan ben þe xiiij, xv and xvj chapitris of þe first party of þis present book.

As for þe vij heed synnys, what ben þei oþire þan vij vicis
contrarye to vij vertues comaundid in þe tablis of goddis The SEVEN DEADLY SINS are seven vices contrary to seven virtues contained in the Four Tables. lawe? Which vij vertues, and manye mo | vertues bisides hem, þou schalt fynde withynne þe seid iiij tablis. id iiij tablis underlined in MS. And þerfore þe teching of þe same vij synnys, with teching of manye mo synnys bisidis hem, þou schalt fynde in þe same iiij tablis. Lo, mekenes, which is contrarye to pride, þou (1) PRIDE is the vice contrary to Meekness; schalt fynde in þe iiije table, The loop of the e of table almost erased in MS. in þe ixe chapitre of þe first party afore goyng; And charite, or wel willing to oure (2) ENVY and neiȝbore, contrarie to envye and contrarye to wraþþe, þou (3) WRATH contrary to Charity; schalt fynde comprehendid and conteynyd vndir þe name of 'riȝtwisnes', and þat in þe same now seid chapitre; Temper∣aunce (4) GLUTTONY contrary to Temperance; aȝens glotonye, and continence aȝens leccherye, gladnes aȝens inpacience Impatience is not one of the Seven Deadly Sins: it is one of the 'manye mo synnys bisidis hem' to be found in the Four Tables, being a branch of one of the deadly seven. Chauncer ranks it as a branch of Pride (Parson's Tale). In the Ancren Riwle it is the Eighth Whelp of Pride (see Morton's ed., p. 198). In other places it is accounted a branch of Wrath and Sloth. The categories of the Seven Deadly Sins and their branches often overlap. For full treatment, see Pub. Mod. Lang. Assoc. Amer., vol. xxx, no. 21, Chaucer and the Seven Deadly Sins, by John Livingston Lowes., largenes and sum membre of (5) LECHERY contrary to Continence; riȝtwisnes aȝens couetise (auarice) and douȝtynes aȝens slouȝþe, þou schalt fynde in þe iij table, in þe vje, vije, [and] MS. vje, vije, viije and ixe; but the ixe chapter deals with the moral virtues of the Fourth Table. (6) AVARICE or COVETOUSNESS contrary to Largeness (Liberality) and Righteousness; viije MS. vje, vije, viije and ixe; but the ixe chapter deals with the moral virtues of the Fourth Table. chapitris of þe same first partye. And weel þou knowist bi þi philosophie þat a vice MS. avice. is neuer sufficientli knowun but þoruȝ þe knowing of þe vertu contrarie to þe (7) SLOTH contrary to Doughtness. same vice; or not so wel knowen but if þe contrarie vertu be bifore knowe. And þerfore in bettir maner ben þese vij synnys and manye mo knowen þoruȝ þe afore MS. a fore. going first partye, þan þei ben knowun oonly þoruȝ þe comoun rekenyng of þe vij deedly synnys.

As to slouþe, I schal teche here as y am now avisid, and Further teach∣ing as to Sloth: (1) Sloth may be merely a passion, and connected as circumstance with either a moral virtue or a moral vice. as now to me seemeþ. And if I schal here aftir in oþire wise leerne, I schal here aftir in oþire wise teche. Certis, in lijk maner as angir in a man is a passioun, and is noon moral vice, and ȝitt bi occasioun of him may rise a willing of yuel to an oþire man, which is a moral vice comounly
callid 'wraþþe'; And lijk as sorynes or heuynes in a man for þat anoþire man haþ good, is a passioun, and is not a moral vice, þouȝ bi occasioun of it þere may rise a willing þat þe oþire man lak þilk good, whiche willing is a moral vice callid 'envie'; so in a man oft is an | hevynes, loþe∣sumnes, or sorynes to do what resoun biddiþ to be doon, and þis hevynes, loþesumnes, sorynes or werynes is a passioun in þe sensual party, to which may answere anoþir lijk passioun in þe ouerer appetite, which is þe wil; and neuer neiþir of þese ij passiouns is a moral vice, þouȝ þei mowe be occasiouns þat þere rise in a man a willing to leeue and forbere what resoun biddiþ to be doon, and þat for eese or for squaymosenesse of peyne. and þan ferþir þus: if eny of þese passiouns now seid be clepid 'slouþe', forsoþe, þilk slouþe is no moral vice or synne, but it is natural and in∣different to moral vertu and moral vice, and may be a cir∣cumstaunce þat moral vertu be þe grettir and þe bettir.

And aȝenward, if þe seid willing to leeue and forbere, or a (2) As Doughti∣ness is con∣nected with every moral virtue See above, p. 59., so Sloth, as a moral vice and the con∣trary of Doughtiness, is connected with every moral vice, and is not a special moral vice, but a general vice opposed privatively to several virtues. nylling to do, what resoun biddiþ to be doon, be clepid 'slouþe', certis, þilk slouþe in his generalte is not oon specialist moral vice, fforwhi he is general moral vice con∣trarye or stonding aȝens manye special moral vertues. and so, in a lijk maner, ech oþire moral vice is priving moral vertu, þouȝ he be not ech moral vice priuyng, or being con∣trarie to, al moral vertu. See below, Pt. II, chap xvi. Cf. Folewer, Pt. I. chaps. xv and xvi. And þerfore þis slouþe is noon special vice to be noumbrid with pride, envie, wraþþe, glotonye and leccherie. And ȝitt ferþir to seie, if þe seid forbering, rising bi occasioun of excellent loþesumnes, heuy∣nes, sorynes, or werynes to fulfille þe doom of resoun or of god, and so circumstancionatid with þis excellence, be callid 'slouþe', þan þilk slouþe is vice contrarye to douȝtynes; and ȝitt he is not oon specialist moral vice, but it conteyneþ an aggregat of manye diuers special moral vicis, as douȝtines is not oon specialist moral vertu, but it conteineþ manye special moral vertues.

ffadir, it is good ȝe be waar in þis seing, ffor whi if þis be
trewe, it semeþ þat þe beest of which it is spokun, apocalipse, Does not this teaching on Sloth rob the Beast of the Apocalypse of one of his seven heads? xiije chapitre, Rev. xiii. 1. schal leese oon of hise vij heedis, ffor bi þilk vij heedis men vndirstonden | vij deedly synnys.

Sone, þilk beest schal haue alle hise vij heedis, not wiþ∣stonding eny þing which I haue ȝitt seid. And if þere be The Beast of the Apocalypse shall yet have his seven heads. no strenger argument aȝens me þan which mai be take bi such a moral vndirstonding or an allegorie or an an[a]gogie MS. anogogie. of holi scripture, my seiyng wole stonde wel ynouȝ. and ferþir forto seie, if in dyuynite were no strenger groundis forto holde þerbi þingis to be trewe þan ben mystyk conceitis takun bi holy scripture, as ben tropologies, allegories and anagogies, dyuynite were a symple and an vnsure faculte, as schal appere in þe book callid 'þe iust apprising of holi scripture', where also þou maist se into what effectis such mystyk sensis or vndirstondingis of holi scripture serven and weren founde. But no more of such mater here.

ffadir, a greet famose scole doctoure, Cf. the 'ful famose doctouris book' of the Folewer, fol. 45b. in a ful famose and Pecock's doc∣trine concern∣ing Sloth is right, notwith∣standing that a famous doctor holds a con∣trary opinion. moche apprisid book, þoruȝoute an hool article, bi disputing of manye questiouns, writiþ and techiþ aȝens þis what ȝe han here tauȝt of slouþe.

Sone, þouȝ I schulde haue noon oþire grounde [þan] Omitted in MS. þat which may be take of þe same article þere tretid bi þe seid doctoure, and of oþire articles þere nyȝ bi, y had no nede forto seche ferþir to conclude aȝens his holding þere, and for to iustifie what I holde now here.

What is more to be seid anentis allegeaunce of doctouris, Where allegi∣ance to doctors is discussed. whanne þei ben maad, þou schalt fynde in þe book callid 'þe iust apprising of doctouris', writen in latyn. þerfore no more MS. nomore. þerof here.

As for þe good reule and wel spending MS. welspending. of þe v outward Where the FIVE OUTWARD WITS and the FIVE INWARD WITS have been treated. wittis and of þe v inwarde wittis, and of speking, lauȝyng, pleiyng, goyng and in oþire wise moving, awaite þou what is seid of hem in þe first chapitre of þe first partye, where is toolde what is wil, etcetera, and what is seide in þe vje, vije and viije chapitris of þe first partye, where ben tretid þe
vertu of clennes and þe vertu of honeste and þe vertu of douȝtines; and I trowe þou schalt seie þat her | good vsis and wel spending ben þere sufficientli tauȝt and tretid.

ffer þirmore, if þou waite in þe ixe chapitre of þe first Where the SEVEN BODILY WORKS OF MERCY and the SEVEN GHOSTLY WORKS OF MERCY have been treated. partye, and marke þe viije poynt of þe iiije table, p. 67. which poynt is largenes, and þe iije poynt of þe iiije table, which is riȝtwisnes, pp. 62-4. þou schalt fynde þere þe comune vij bodili werkis of mercy and þe comune vij [goostli] MS. bodily. werkis of mercy, For enumeration, see Notes. and mo þan þilk twies vij.

how feiþ, hope and charite ben conteined withynne þe Where FAITH, HOPE, and CHARITY have been treated. afore MS. a fore. seide iiij tablis may be seen esili. fforwhi feiþ is a knowing of þingis and trouþis denouncid, affeermed, reuelid and schewid to vs fro god and bi god, what god is, and what FAITH in the First Point of the First Table. oþire þingis ben longing to god, and þat for as moche as þilk knowing may not be had of vs bi natural power oonly, without such denouncing and certifying from aboue. and siþen in þe first poynt of þe first table, in þe iiije chapitre of þe afore going first party, namelich if to þilk iiije chapitre be ioyned and couplid þe xiiije, xve and MS. and v, the v being crossed through obliquely and underdotted. xvj chapitris of þe same first party, is tretid of al maner leernyng, knowing and remembring what god is, and what hise benefetis and punys∣schingis ben, and so forþ of oþire þingis longing toward god, open it is þat feiþ is conteyned withynne þilk first poynt of þe first table.

Also if hope be no þing ellis þan feiþ of oonly þingis to HOPE is (1) A species of Faith. come, not present, as it is ful likly, and as it is holden of ful worþi doctouris and clerkis, riȝt as feiþ in his generalte is a knowing of þingis passid and of þingis present and of þingis to come, þanne is hope not ellis þan a spice and a party of feiþ. and þerfore hope must nedis be conteyned where þat ful, hool feiþ in his generalte is conteyned, and specialy þanne he is tauȝt in þe xvj chapitre of þe first party, wherynne it is spokun of blissis to come.

And if hope be a passioun of þe MS. ″wil ′þe, with the marks of transposition. wil, MS. ″wil ′þe, with the marks of transposition. as loue and drede
and oþire suche ben, as summe oþire clerkis holden, þanne Or (2) a passion, when it is included under the First Point of the Second Table. is hope conteyned in þe first poynt of þe secunde table, with purtenauncis to loue or charite þere re∣hercid and noumbrid.

And, siþen charite, as he is a general freendli loue, is not ellis þanne an habit or a dede of freendly louyng to god, or CHARITY is love towards God, ourselves and our neigh∣bour, and so has been taught already in the Four Tables. a wel willing to god aboue alle þingis, and to alle oþire resonable and sauable creaturis in god and for god, as moche as þei ben worþy bi doom of resoun to falle vndir such a loue or welwilling, or as moche as þei availen forto helpe into þe loue and seruice of god; and alle special welwillingis and beneuolencis which a man may haue anentis god, anentis him silf, and anentis hise neiȝboris ben sufficiently conteyned withynne þe iiij tablis; it folewiþ þat charite is sufficiently conteyned in þe iiij tablis.

DIV3.HEAD: [ije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [H]ow The o of [H]ow is small in manu∣script. þe iiij cardinal vertues, þat is to seie, prudence, The FOUR CARDINAL VIRTUES have been taught already in the Four Tables: temperaunce, strengþe and riȝtwisnes, ben loggid in þe iiij seid tablis, may in þis wise be seen.

In þe first poynt of þe first table is conteyned al maner kunnyng and knowing of god and of godli þingis: as which (1) PRUDENCE in the First Point of the First Table; ben hise benefetis, hise punysschingis, hise seruicis or lawis, and so forþ of oþire; and þat wheþir þilk kunnyng or knowing be had in natural liȝt of resoun, or bi reuelacioun from aboue. And siþen prudence is not ellis þan a knowing of summe such now seid þingis in liȝt of natural resoun, it muste nedis be þat prudence is conteynyd in þe first poynt of þe first table, euen as feiþ is þer conteynyd.

Temperaunce, as it is clepid a 'cardynal vertu', is no þing (2) TEMPERANCE in that it includes the Second, Third, Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Points of the Third Table; ellis þan a vertu comprehending þe ije, iije, iiije, ve and vje poyntis of þe iije table ysette afore MS. a fore. in þe vje, vije and viije chapitris of þe afore goyng first party: which poyntis ben fleischlihode, worldlihode, clennes, honeste and pacience. The pacien of pacience partly faded in MS.

Goostly strengþe, as it is a cardinal vertu, is not ellis (3) GHOSTLY STRENGTH in that it is the same as Doughtiness, the Seventh Point of the Third Table; þanne þe vije poynt of þe iije table, which poynt is callid 'douȝtines'.

And riȝtwisnes, as it is a cardinal vertu, in þe largyst maner in which he may be take, is not ellis þan þe compre∣hensioun or þe to gider gadering of alle þe moral vertues of (4) RIGHTEOUS∣NESS (or JUSTICE) in the wide sense, in that it includes all the moral virtues of the Second and Fourth Tables, unless we except goostli∣hode, the First Point of each. þe | iiije table, and of alle þe moral vertues of þe ije table, but if we except þe first poynt of þe iiije table and þe first poynt of þe ije table, or a vertu oonly comoun to hem boþe. ffor whi siþen þe office of riȝtwisnes, as it is a cardinal vertu, is forto þat a man bi it ȝilde to euery oþire persoone what euer þing is longing of him to þilk oþire persoone forto be paied or ȝouun, and siþen bi alle þe now seid moral vertues of þe ije table and of þe iiije table þis office is paied, but if in of euereiþir table þe first poynt be exceptid; it folewiþ þat riȝtwisnes, as it is a cardinal vertu, is withynne þe markis of þe iiij tablis, as is now seid.

And if riȝtwisnes, as it is a cardinal vertu, mai not be If Righteous∣ness may not be taken in so wide a sense, then it is the more certain that the Four Cardinal Virtues do not contain all God's law. take so largely as is now seid, þanne it is bi so moche þe more open þat þo iiij cardinal vertues conteynen not alle moral vertues of goddis lawe.

And þouȝ it were so, as it is not so, þat þese iiij cardinal vertues schulde sufficiently conteyne alle moral vertues of goddis service, and þerwiþ also þei conteynen an intellectual Disadvantages of the Four Cardinal Virtues. vertu or knowingal vertu, which is prudence, Cf. the Son's question immediately below, and the answer thereto. forto be dresser and reuler of alle þe moral vertues; ȝitt it is not expedient and profitable to stonde and attende into her noumbre of iiij oonly as for oure sufficient hool reule of goostly vertuose gouernaunce, bi cause þat þis noumbre of Four is too small a number to clearly com∣prehend all the moral laws of God. iiij is to narowe and to litil forto se in it fruytfully, esily and redily euery poynt of oure moral gouernaunce, whanne we schulen haue nede to wirche hem. And þerfore it is necessarye to resolue moral vertues into a widder noumbre, so þat þilk nowmbre be not ouer large, but compendiose, and in a meene bitwixe to schort and to long, as is þe noumbre of xxxj poyntis expressid and noumbrid in þe seid iiij tablis.

ffadir, it myȝt seeme to manye heerers of al þis declaracioun Is not to live leernyngly, the First Point of the First Table, an intellectual vpon feiþ and prudence þat þe first poynt of þe first table were not a moral vertu, but þat it were an intellec∣tual or
a knowingal vertu; ffor whi it is seid comounly of þe wysist þewysist joined in manuscript, but merely because cramped at the end of the line. doctouris þat feiþ and prudence ben intellectual or knowingal or knowyngal virtue rather than a moral? vertues, And now in þis p[re]sent MS. psent, the contraction mark for er being omitted. chapitre of þis present secunde party, ȝe setten feiþ and prudence in þe first poynt of þe first table; wherfore it wolde seeme þat þe first poynt of þe first table were an intellectual or a knowingal vertu, as feiþ and prudence ben.

Sone, myn answere herto is þis: ech poynt of þe first, ije, The virtues of the Four Tables are intellectual materially as well as moral formally. iije and iiije table afore sett in þe first party of þis book, is a moral vertu or a moral vertuose dede; and in special now to seie, þe first poynt of þe first table is a moral vertu or his moral vertuose dede. ffor whi þe first poynt of þe first table is a bisynes and an occupacioun, or a disposicioun or habit in þe wil, to gete knowing of þe vij maters þere rehercid into þe resoun; And þat wheþir þilk knowing be geten bi natural liȝt or bi reuelacioun in holy scripture. And siþen such a bisynes and an occupacioun or disposicioun or habit is not ellis þan drawen oute of þe wil, or comaundid of þe wil to oþire powers to be doon, aftir þe doom of resoun, it folewiþ nedis þat þe first seid poynt of þe first table is a moral vertu or his moral vertuose dede. Neuerþeles, þouȝ it be a moral vertu formali, ȝitt it may conteyne in sum maner withynne him intellectual vertues materialy, þat is to seie, as aboute whos geting laboureþ þis seid moral vertu, as aboute dedis comaundid to be bi hem gete. And so feiþ and prudence and also craft mowe be conteynyd in þis now seid maner, and ben so conteynyd withynne þe first poynt of þe first table materialy, wiþ þis þat þei ben also intellectual vertues formaly; And wiþ þis þat þei mowe be lijk materialy in þe iiije table, whanne we wirche hem to oure neiȝboris at þe next; notwiþstonding þat þe same seid first poynt be a moral vertu.
lijk obieccioun and like þerto answere may be maad vpon þe vij oþire poyntis of þe first table, bicause | þat þe dedis of preising, preiyng, þanking, worshiping and sacramentyng, ben dedis of resoun.

ffadir, ouer þis which ȝe han tauȝt now wel, þat þe
besynes in wil, witt and werk to leerne and remembre þe Since the learning of the Seven Matters is the First Point of the First Table, the learning of any craft or pro∣fession, in so far as it is a benefit of God (i. e. the Second Matter), is included in the First Point of the First Table. vij maters is þe first poynt of þe first table, y aske where, in þis so of ȝou tauȝt, is includid, conteynyd and closid þat bisynes in wil, witt and werk to leerne eny craft, as mason∣rye, carpentrye, or eny such oþire, is also a vertu in þe first poynt of þe first table? The syntax is somewhat confused: the sense seems to be: 'y aske where . . . (it) is includid . . . þat (conj.) bisynes . . . is also a vertu', &c.

Sone, answer herto is þis: þe besynes wiþynneforþ in þe wil, and þanne aftir in þe witt and in outwarde werke, to fynde, leerne and to remembre eny craft, for þat it is a meene into eny oþire wel knowun vertu and seruice of god, is a vertu in þe first poynt of þe first table; And so, vndir and wiþ þilk entent and circumstaunce of eende with which þilk bisynes is a good moral vertu, and withoute which he is noon good moral vertu, he is in þe first poynt of þe first table, fforwhi þe bysines to leerne or to remembre eny of þe vij maters is in þe first poynt of þe first table. but so it is þat ech leeful and necessarye craft of a comounte, which is for þe profite of þe comounte, and which þe comounte may not wel lack withoute hurte into sum oþire seruice of god þerbi þe bettir to be doon, is a benefete of god; And so ech oþire state of þe vij parties of a comounte bifore in þe first partye of þis book, in þe xij chapitre, rehercid, is also a benefete of god. wherfore folewiþ þat þe besynes to fynde, leerne and remembre eny such craft, or eny oþire facultee wherbi is maad enye of þe seid necessarie parties of a rewme or of a greet comunalte, is in þe first poynt of þe first table.

and also aftirward, whanne þe craft is founden or The practice of the craft or profession belongs to the same Point of the same Table as the virtue willing it. leerned or remembrid of a man, þanne his bisynes without∣forþ in werke to execute þilk craft, þat is to seie, to putte it into vse and werk of it, longiþ to þe same table and to þe poynt of þe same table in which þe seid | inward bisynes or willing longith, And þat sumwhile to þe ije table, and oþire while to þe iije table, and oþire while to þe iiije table, and oþire while to þe first table, as is liȝt to se; fforwhi þe outwarde werk haþ no moral goodnes save which he haþ of
þe inward willing and chesing bi which he is willid and chosun to be doon. And þerfore, siþen con and þe same or at þe ful lijk goodnes is in hem boþe, þat is to seie, which is in þe inward willing, as is tauȝt and provid in þe v trety, in þe first party of 'cristen religioun'; it folewiþ þat in what euer gendre or spice of moral vertu þe inward willing is, þe oþire of hem tweine is; And þerfore folewiþ ferþir þat in what euer table and poynt of þe table inward willing is, þe oþire of hem tweyn is. And þus moche, sone, is ynouȝ here to þin asking.

More doctryne seruyng for þe clering of þi two now last Where further teaching on this subject may be found. askid questiouns, þou maist se in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe first trety, and in 'þe filling of þe iiij tablis', þe first partye, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre.

ffadir, crist seiþ, mathew, xxije chaptire vv. 37-8. þat 'forto loue How can Christ's teach∣ing and Pecock's teach∣ing as to the first command∣ment be recon∣ciled? god is þe first comaundement in þe lawe', and ȝe seien here þat bisynes to leerne is þe first comaundement in þe lawe. After lawe, MS. has: and ȝe seien here, crossed through and underdotted. if it be so as ȝe seie, how mai it be trewe þat forto love god is þe first comaundement in þe lawe? how stondith goddis seiyng and ȝoure seiyng to gedir?

Sone, a comaundement may be first in dignyte and in To love God is the first com∣mandment in the sense of its being the noblest and best. worþines and in goodnes, þouȝ he be not first in weie of geting, and þouȝ he haue sum oþire comaundement bifore him to be hadde as a meene toward him; and in þis wise forto loue god is þe first comaundement as in dignitee and good∣nes, Learning to know the Seven Matters is the first com∣mandment in the sense of its being the first means towards attain∣ing the love of God. for he is worþiest and best of alle oþire comaundementis. And ȝitt summe oþire comaundementis ben meenys leding towards him, and þerfore going bifore him in weie of geting: as ben besynes to leerne, bisynes to preise, to preie, to worschip and to sacramente. And | amonge þese comaunde∣mentis being meenys into þe getyng of loue, bisynes to leerne is þe first. And so in þis now last seid maner, bisynes to leerne is þe first comaundement of þe lawe; and in þe oþire bifore seid maner, forto loue god is þe first comaunde∣ment of þe lawe. And so my seiyng stondiþ wel ynouȝ with þe seiyng of crist.

Also, sone, it is not to lete passe vndeclarid þat þere ben One must dis∣tinguish between the two kinds of love: ij maners of loue: Oone loue is a disposicioun or habit or his dede proceding oute of þe wil, which is a welwilling to sum persoone: þat is to seie, in willing to him sum good. (1) Love or charity, which is a moral virtue. and þis is charite, and it is a moral vertu.

Anoþire loue þere is which is a passioun, or a mouyng of (2) Love which is a passion, and an appur∣tenance of the First Point of the Second Table. þe wil toward an oþire persoone to good; and it is not a moral vertu, neiþir a moral vertuose dede; for it is not a disposicioun or habit or his dede of þe wil chosun of purpos bi doom of resoun, but it is a moving or a bering of oure wil toward anoþire þing in weie of oonyng vs to þe oþir þing; and it slippiþ into þe wil naturaly, aftir con∣sideraciouns had in resoun, bisidis al choice of þe wil, and bisidis þe doom of resoun made þat it so schulde slippe yn; and þerfore it is a passioun or a suffring, and it ouȝte be sette and noumbrid with þe purtenauncis of þe first poynt of þe secunde table, afore in þe ve chapitre of þe afore goyng first partie. and if þis passioun of loue moue not þe wil aȝens resoun, it is good, and it is a profitable pricke to stire forþ þe wil into good choisis of good inward and outward dedis; and if it move þe wil aȝens þe doom of resoun, þan it ouȝte to be refreyned and not folewid. and so it is to be seid of oþire passiouns: as is angre, drede, schame, sorewe, and so forþ MS. soforþ. of oþire.

DIV3.HEAD: [iije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, I haue herd oft tymes moche curiosite and Teaching is requested on the SEVEN GIFTS OF THE HOLY GHOST. moche diuersite of wittis spende aboute þe vij pointis which ben comounly callid 'þe vij ȝiftis of þe holy goost', which ben writen in ysaie, xje chapitre v. 2., where it is seid þus, þat vpon crist schulde | rest 'þe spirit of wisdom, and of vndir∣stonding, þe spirit of counseil, and of strengþe, þe spirit of kunnyng, and of pitee Cf. below, p. 116, ll. 8-12., þe spirit of drede of god'. And fewe treters of hem accorden to gider. And summe wolen þat þese vij ȝiftis conteynen alle vertues of goddis lawe, and þat þei maken an hool sufficient reule for alle oure moral gouernauncis. neuerþeles, what is ȝoure feeling, seie ȝe to me, o wise fadir.

Sone, leue þou me. it myȝt seeme þat moche of her such These SEVEN GIFTS do not contain all the virtues of God's law, but only some. seid bisynes aboute þe seid vij ȝiftis of god is not but vanyte and feynyd curiosite; fforwhi what euer tretyng, affermyng, or holding, not being historial or cronical, which is not groundid in resoun or reuelacioun maad to vs bi scripture, or in oþire surely and certeinly or probabily had reuelacioun from god, is not but feyned þing and vanite. but so it is þat þei mowe not ground in resoun, neiþir in enye oþire partye of scripture, neiþir in þilk same partye where þese vij ben writen, neiþir owȝwhere ellis in holy scripture, þat þese vij conteynen alle vertues of goddis lawis, and þat þei ben suche in alle degrees, as is seid of hem bi manye famose treters of hem. Wherfore it myȝt seeme þat suche teching is forgid, feynyd and veyn curiosite, difficultyng, harding and derking goddis lawe more þan it is derke in it silf, and traueyling and troubling mennys wittis with birþen which is not MS. not þe. necessarye, and þerbi letting mennys wittis to attende into profitable and necessary þingis. And þerfore it myȝt seeme to be seid þus: þat þese vij ȝiftis of god ben a gadering MS. agadering. to gider of summe intellectual vertues and of summe moral vertues, which, in as moche as þei ben ȝouun bi prouidence of god, þei ben ȝiftis of god, as ben oþire vertues; and in as moche as þei ben getun bi oure laboure, rennyng with þe worching and purveiyng of god, þei ben callid oure vertues. and if þei, or eny of hem, be at eny tyme fully ȝouun into | vs fro god, withoute oure owne laboure þerto helping, þanne þei ben oonly pure ȝiftis of god. And in lijk maner it is of alle oþire maner of vertues: as ben meke∣nes, charite, sobirnes, and such oþire. And in lijk maner it is of alle oþire maners of þingis: as ben helþe, fairnes, gold, siluer, and alle oþire þingis.

What is wisdom, what is intellect, and what is counseil (1) WISDOM, (which is prudence), and what is science, and what is (2) INTELLECT, (3) COUNSEL (or PRUDENCE), and knowingal or intellectual vertu, is declarid sumwhat aftir in þe book callid 'þe folewer to þe donet'. Pt. I, chaps. x-xii. and þei ben born (4) KNOWLEDGE are contained in living leernyngly, the in and conteynyd wiþynne þe first poynt of þe first table,
as maters wherupon laboriþ þe first poynt of þe first table; First Point of the First Table. or bettir forto seie þus: þei ben in þe first poynt of þe first table as disposiciouns, habitis, or her dedis, comaundid to be bi þe first poynt of þe first table.

What is þe vertu of goostly strengþe is seid afore MS. a fore. in þe (5) GHOSTLY STRENGTH (or Douȝtynes) has been already ex∣plained. viij chapitre of þe afore goyng first partye; for it is not ellis þan douȝtynes.

What is þe vertu of pitee, it is seid þere in þe ix (6) PITY, as a virtue, has been already ex∣plained under Largenes; as a passion, under Routh. chapitre, in þe vertu of largenes See above, p. 67.; or if þis pitee be þe passioun of [r]ouþe MS. ȝouþe., it is to be placid þere in þe v chapitre, among þe purtenauncis to þe first membre of þe ije table See above, p. 37..

Drede, which is a passioun, and þat wheþir he be sonely (7) DREAD, as a passion, has been already explained. In its wide sense of fearing to offend God, and desiring to obey God, it is not a special moral virtue, but contains many moral virtues. drede or seruile drede, is in þe place now last allegid See above, p. 37.. And if þis ȝift of drede to god be callid þe nylling to offend god or resoun, or be callid þe willing forto obeie god or MS. orto. resoun, as occasionyd and circu[m]stauncid circustauncid. bi þe now seid passioun of soneli drede, certis, þilk drede to god so callid is not oon specialist moral vertu, but he conteyneþ manye special moral vertues being sparclid abrood in alle þe iiij tablis; Euen as, if willing forto conforme or obeie to god or to resoun, as occasionyd and circumstauncid bi passional loue to god, be callid 'loue to god', þilk loue to god | is not oon specialist moral vertu, but he conteyneþ many special moral vertues sprad into alle þe tablis.

And so alle þese vij ȝiftis ben placid and conteyned Hence all these SEVEN GIFTS are contained within the Four Tables. wiþynne þe iiij seid tablis in cleer vndirstonding, and wiþ as moche making of hem as nede is to make of hem.

ffor, certis, I can not wite whi þese techers which writen Isaiah did not intend them to embrace all the moral virtues. and techen so curiosely of þese vij ȝiftis ben movid þerto bi eny euidence saue bi þis: þat þei fynden in þe prophete ysaie, þe xj chapitre, þat þe prophete makiþ þere mencioun how þat þese vij See above, p. 114. weren in crist. and, certis, þis is a feble euidence, þat þerfore þese vij schulde comprehende and conteyne alle vertues and alle oure goostli gouernauncis;
ffor whi þe same prophete ysaie, in [þe vij] MS. xj chapitre. But the reference is to Isaiah vii. 15. chapitre, makiþ mensioun how þat crist schulde ete buttir and hony, and he makiþ þere no mensioun of eny oþire mete which crist schulde ete; and ȝitt if eny man wolde make him so curiose þat þerfore butter and hony comprehendid and conteyned alle metis which crist ete, and alle þe metis which we ouȝte to ete, he were to moche curiose and to moch ful of vanite. and lijk skile, as it myȝt seeme, is in þis present purpos. þerfore, o my sone, it seemeþ þou maist seie as for moost likely to be trewe, and as for moost esily to holde, and with leest derking of goddis lawe, þat þese vij ȝiftis and manye mo weren in crist; þouȝ in þe seid xj chapitre v. 2. of ysaie be not mensioun maad of mo ȝiftis þan of þese vij; riȝt as crist eete manye mo metis þan buttir and honye, þouȝ in þe seid [vij] MS. xj chapitre. But the reference is to Isaiah vii. 15. chapitre of ysaie be not maad mensioun of eny mo metis þan of þese ij.

As for sacramentis of cristis ordinaunce in þe newe lawe, THE SACRA∣MENTS have been already taught in the Eighth Point of the First Table. it is open þat þei ben conteyned in þe viij poynt of þe first table, in þe iiije chapitre of þe bifore going first party. Also þere þou maist leerne sumwhat of hem, and more whanne þerto schal be couplid and ioyned þe 'bokis of sacramentis' MS. sacramentis tis; tis being crossed through and underdotted., in which 'bokis of [sacramentis Omitted in MS.] ech suche sacrament schal be tretid in special, bi cause þat of hem nediþ to be maad lengir processe þan is according | to þis present book.

And as for obeisaunce to cursing maad of preestis, and to Obedience to the priest's rebukes and the need for absolu∣tion have been already taught in the Second Point of the Fourth Table. absolucioun to be mekely askid of preestys, and to be in to vs of hem receivid, and as for cursing and assoiling which preestis doon to her suggettis or parischens, þou maist s[e] MS. so. generali hem to be conteyned in þe ije poynt of þe iiije table, which is forto lyue anentis curatis or prelatis of þe churche attendauntly and obeisauntly.

And how euer þese now seid sacramentis of þe new lawe Moses' tables do not sufficiently teach the Sacra∣ments, and the duty of the priest to rebuke sin and to grant absolution. and þe seid cursingis and assoilingis and þe seid obeisauncis
in þe new lawe mowe be conueniently tauȝt bi vertu of þe wordis writen in moyses tablis Contempt for Moses' Tables was one of the accusations brought against Pecock. See Babington's Introd. to Rep, p. lvi, footnote., it is ouer hard me to se; and so I weene it is to ech oþire man to [s]e MS. be., which is not lad more bi affeccioun þan bi resoun or feiþ; ffor whi þan For the Jews do not keep the Sacraments. þe iewis, to whom þe ten comaundementis of moyses tablis weren ȝouun, ouȝten forto haue feelid hem silf to be bounden in þe same now seid sacramentis, which is fals. And if eny And the words of the Ten Commandments signified the same to the Jews as to us. man feyne, as summe doon, þat þo x comaundementis writen in moyses tablis signifien and betoken to vs cristen men ferþir and fullier þan þei diden to þe Jewis, certis, þis may not be seid, þat þis ferþir and larger signifiyng schulde rise to vs bi vertu of þe wordis writen in moyses tablis; ffor whi þese wordis signified in oon maner to hem and to vs, bi cause þei were not, neiþir ȝitt ben not, equyuoca[l] MS. equyuoca., þat is to seie, wordis of manye significaciouns, as clerkis in latyn and in ebrewe and greke wel knowun. neiþir it may And the deeds signified by those words are the same now as then. be so seid þat þo x comaundementis writen in moyses tablis bitoken ferþir, fullier MS. fullier oroþe wise; oroþe wise being crossed through., or oþire wise to vs þan to þe iewis, for þat þe dedis or þingis signified bi þe wordis of þo x comaundementis schulden figure eny newe dedis to be doon in þe new lawe; ffor whi alle þe dedis vocaly bi strengþe of þo wordis signified, bi wordis writen in þo x comaunde∣mentis, ben pure moral ech oon, and not cerymonial, neiþir iudicial, except þe dede of þe iije The Anglican Fourth. Pecock, in numbering the Ten Commandments, follows the reckoning of St. Augustine (and the Roman Catholic Church), under which the First and Second Commandments of Origen (and the Anglican Church) are combined as one, and the Tenth divided into two. See p. 157 and Notes thereon. commaundement, which was halewing of þe satirdaie; wherfore There seems to be some slight omission here. Perhaps some 'poyntis of þe newe lawe' have been cited. Cf. below, p. 119, l. 2. The sense seems to be: 'Therefore the words written in Moses Tables were not ordained to signify any observances bind∣ing only for Christians, and not for Jews.' ...

| þo dedis weren not ordeined to signifie. And þerfore, forto so seie or answere seemeþ to be not but feyned chaffare, ffor whi not foundid in eny grounde of scripture or of resoun,
but being aȝens þe grounde of resoun. And namelich how þese now seid poyntis of þe newe lawe See above, p. 118, note 6. mowe openli, redili, liȝtli and currauntli, and þerfore profitabili, be representid to vs and remembrid of vs, bi beholding of þo ten comaundementis writen in moyses tablis, is aȝens skile and resoun to be; and þat for causis and skilis aftir in þis ije party, þe [ixe] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre, to be rehercid.

DIV3.HEAD: [iiije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [A]s Small s in MS. for þe ten comaundementis of moyses tablis, writen The TEN COM∣MANDMENTS are contained in Pecock's Four Tables. exodi, xx chapitre vv. 2-17., and rehercid eftsoonys wel nyȝ worde bi worde, Deutronomij, þe v chapitre, forto se wheþir þei ben conteyned in þe iiij seid tablis tauȝt afore in þe first party of þis book, y wole first reherce þe hool text of þe first The Anglican First and Second. comaundement, writen, exodi, þe xx chapitre, and deutro∣nomij, ve chapitre, which text is þis: 'The lorde god spake The FIRST The Anglican First and Second. COMMANDMENT has been taught already in the Donet. alle þese wordis: "I am þe lorde þi god, þat ledde þee out of þe londe of egypt, and brouȝte þee oute of þe house of þraldom. þou schalt not haue alien goddis bifore me. þou schalt not make to þee a grauen þing, neyþer eny liknes of þing þat is in heuene aboue, ne in erþe bineþe, ne of hem þat ben in watris bineþe þe erþe. þou schalt not loute hem, ne worschip hem, for I am þe lord þi god, a strong gelose louer, visiting þe wickidnes [of fadris] Omitted in MS. Cf. below, p. 120, 1. 23. into children, into þe iije and iiije generacioun of hem þat haten me; and I do mercy into þousindis of hem þat louen me and kepen myn heestis" '. þus moche as for þe first The Anglican First and Second. comaundement.

Of þis comaundement, þilk party which is þat 'þou schalt haue oon god and no mo', þou maist se tauȝt in þe xiiij chapitre of þe afore going first party, where it is seid þat þer is not but oon god, maker and keper and reuler of alle þingis; fadir, | sone and holy goost; and þat þere is not, neiþir may be, eny mo goddis þan he aloone. and oute of þis folewiþ pleynli ynouȝ to ech mannys resoun þe secunde party of þe same first The Anglican First and Second. comaundement, which secunde party is þis: þat 'þou schalt not make eny grauen
ymage or eny oþire creature to be þi god'. fforwhi þan þou haddist mo goddis þan oon, or ellis an oþer þan him which is verry god. And also out of þe same folewiþ pleynli þat þou schalt not ȝeue eny godly worschip to an ymage for it silf, Cf. the teaching on Images with that of Rep., Pt. II. or to eny oþir creature; fforwhi þan schuldist þou make þilk ymage or þilk creature to be to þee þi god, ffor as moch as godly worschip ouȝte not to be ȝouun to eny þing, name∣lich for it silf, saue oonly to a god.

And so al þe substaunce of þe first The Anglican First and Second. comaundement in Part of the First The Anglican First and Second. DIV3.P: [F]Adir, for as moche as in þe ije party of þis first The Anglican First and Second. Might it not be argued that God in the First The Anglican First and Second. Com∣mandment forbids images altogether? comaundement, where it is seid þus: 'þou schalt not make to þee a grauen þing', etcetera, manye men ben aboute ful sturdily for to grounde þat god forbediþ þere alle ymagis to be, þerfore y desire to heere and knowe more of ȝoure feeling þerupon.

Sone, as y seid in þe next chapitre bifore p. 121, ll. 21-23., y may not Images are allowable, so long as they are not worshipped as gods, as may be proved from Scripture. trowe þat, in þis xx chapitre of exodi, god wolde forbede to be doon MS. do on. þilk same þing which aftirward, in þe xxv chapitre vv. 18-19. of exodi, he bade moyses to do. And þerfore, siþen in þe xxv chapitre vv. 18-19. of exodi, god bade to moyses forto make in þe tabernacle ij ymagis of aungels, of cherubyn, I can not wite þat it schulde be goddis entent in þe xx chapitre of exodi forto forbede vtterly alle ymagis to be maad. And þerfore þe entent of god must nedis be here forto forbede ymagis to be maad as for goddis to þe peple. wherto accordiþ ful wel what god seid to þe peple in þe same chapitre, exodi, xx chapitre, aftir he had spokun þe x comaundementis of þe
tablis, where he seiþ þus: 'ȝe schulen not make to ȝou goddis of siluer, neiþir goddis of gold ȝe schulen make to ȝou'. Lo, sone, it seemeþ þat bi þese now last seid wordis, god wolde expowne þe oþire wordis afore in þe same chapitre writen, how þei ouȝten | to be vndirstonde, whanne he seid þus: 'þou schalt not make to þee a grauen þing', etcetera. And in lijk maner god expowneþ and declariþ þe same wordis, how þei ouȝten be vndirstonden, whanne in þe xxxiiije chapitre v. 17. of exodi, where moyses was bede to make þe newe tablis of stoon, god seid þus: 'ȝe schulen not make blowen goddis, or goddis molten bi founders craft', which musten nedis aftir al good vndirstonding be ymagis. Þe secunde resoun to þe same purpos is þis: Siþen god If God had wished to forbid images alto∣gether, He would have made a special commandment to that effect, and that one of the first, but He only forbids the use of images as gods. forbade þe peple to haue golden goddis and silueren goddis and ȝotten or blowen goddis, as in þis present chapitre alleged, and siþen þis forbode is an hiȝ forbode, and oon of þe hiȝest which myȝt be, and þe peple were ful redy and prone and moche enclyned and stirid to haue and to make to hem such blowen or ȝottid goddis, as schal be now anoon aftir schewid; it was resonable þat god schulde haue writen and placed þis now rehercid forbode withynne þe tablis as soone as eny oþir þere writen, and moche raþer þan summe oþire þere writen. but so it is þat þis now rehercid forbode kanne nouȝwhere be founde to be writun in þe tablis of moyses so accordauntly as is forto be writen and meened, whanne and where it is writen þere þus: 'þou schalt not make to þee a grauen þing', etcetera. wherfore þere, and in þese same wordis: 'þou schalt not make to þee a grauen þing', etcetera, is meened þis forbode: 'þou schalt not make to þee eny golden goddis or eny silueren goddis or eny blowen, molten or ȝottid goddis'. and a ful good cause was whi god schulde þis forbode The necessity of forbidding the Jews to use images as gods. make to þe Jewis, ffor whi in þo daies oþire peplis þan iewis maden to hem in þilk maner ymagis as for her verry goddis, as scripture witnessiþ in manye placis, And þe peple of Jewis were ful prone, prest and redy to suche now seid ydolatrie vsid in oþire naciouns, as also is open in manye placis of scripture, and in special is open in þe same now tretid storye. ffor whi whilis þe same peple dwellid aboute the mount of syna, and whilis moyses was in þe hille wiþ god to araie for þe tablis writing, þe peple constreyned aaron forto make to hem a calf of gold forto be taken of hem as her god; and which calf þei worschipiden as her god, as is open, exodi, xxxij chapitre, in two placis of þe chapitre. vv. 6 and 19.

This comaundement þou schalt fynde afore MS. a fore. in þe iiije chapitre of þe afore going first party, where it is tauȝt þat þou schalt reuerence, preise and worschip oure lorde god; fforwhi where euer it is comaundid a persoone to be reuerencid and worschipid, in þat same it is forboden him to be irreuerencid and vilonyed or vnworschipid. I, chap. iv. siþen for to swere in veyn bi god is to do irreuerence and vilonye to god and to his name, in as moche as in vs is, bicause whanne we sweren bi god in veyn, we bringen forþ
god or his name to be witnesse in a trifle and in a mater, in which mater it is aȝens | his reuerence him or his name to be brouȝt into witnesse, or we bringen forþ god or his name into witnesse, whanne no nede is to bryng forþ his name into witnesse, as þe vndirstonding and interpretacioun of ydil swering is comounly taken; þerfore folewiþ þat al ydil swering bi god, to vndirstonde þe sentence of swering in maner now seid, which is forto bring forþ god or his name into witnesse, is nedisly forboden in þe seid place of þe now seid iiij chapitre, in þe first afore going partye, And vndir It is forbidden also as against Righteousness and Truth. COMMANDMENT. þe xx chapitre, and deutronomij, v chapitre, is þis: 'Haue mynde to halewe þe vije daie of þe weke, which is þe satirdaie. Sixe daies þou schalt worche, and do þyne owne werkis. ffor in vj daies god maad heuene and erþe, þe se, and al þat is wiþynne hem. and he restid on þe vije daie, which is þe þe overwritten in MS. satirdaie, and he blissid þilk daie, and maad it holy from al servile werk. þou schalt kepe þese þi silf, þi sone and þi douȝtir, þi seruaunt and þyn hande mayde, þi werk beest, and þi gest which dwellith in þin house'.

Certis, sone, in þis iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement, aftir þe conseit Certain doctors consider that two points are therein to be observed: of manye doctouris, weren conteynyd ij þingis or ij poyntis or ij gouernauncis Cf. the refutation of this in Pt. II, chap. ix.: Oon is þat ech persoone now rehercid schulde forbere at sum whilis al seruile werk, þat is to seie, (1) Every person should set apart a special time for special ser∣vice to God. al worldly wynful werk; And þat þerbi in þilk whilis he attende to god in biþenking vpon god and goostly poyntis, in preising and preiyng to god and worschiping god, and do werkis þerto being | necessary, or meenys, and in leernyng of goostly profitable trouþis, or in aȝenstonding to alle mysful dedis, goostly or bodily, and such oþire.

þe ije is þat þis same now rehercid poynt or gouernaunce, (2) This special time should be the Saturday. þoruȝ al or sum of hise now seid parties, which gouernaunce in it silf is vnlimitid and vnassigned to eny special tyme, schulde be bisette and maad to be doon in þe vij daie of þe weke, which daie is clepid 'satirdaie'.

þe first of þese ij gouernauncis was, and is, moral in lawe The first point still holds for all Christians. of kynde, and þerfore it abidiþ euer from þe bigynnyng of þe worlde vnto þe eende, boþe to iewis and to cristen and to alle naciouns, and þat afore moyses lawe and aftir. and it was neuer reuokid, ne neuer schal be reuokid, for it is groundid in lawe of kynde, þat is to seie, in doom of pure resoun, and þerfore it schal neuer be reuokid. ffor what euer is pure resonable in oure gouernauncis, al þe while it so is, it is neuer to be reuokid.

þe ije now seid þoynt or gouernaunce was cerymonial to The second point applied only to the Jews. þe peple of iewis; and siþen al cerymonials and iudicials of þe iewis lawe ben ceesid and reuokid bi crist, as poul beriþ open witnesse in hise epistle to galathies, Especially chap. ii, vv. 16-21; chaps. iii and v. and in his secunde epistle to corinthies Especially chap. v, v. 17., þerfore þis ije now seid gouernaunce, wherof is maad þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in moyses tablis, haþ no place among cristen men; but þe first now seid gouernaunce oonly, haþ place among cristen men.

And so al þe moral lawe of kinde, and þerfore al þat is The first point has been already taught. perteyning to vs cristen men, conteynyd in þis iij The Anglican Fourth. com∣aundement of moyses tablis, þou maist haue and se afore in þe iiij chapitre of þe afore going first partie, where it is tauȝt þat þou schalt ȝeue at sumwhilis bisynes to leerne þe vij maters in þe bigynnyng of þe same iiij chapitre rehercid; And also where in þe same chapitre it is tauȝt þat at sum whilis þou schalt preise god, worschipe god and preie to god and þanke god; ioyned þerto what is seid þere in þe viij chapitre of þe vertu of douȝtines. And, ferþirmore, þat þou schalt kepe halidaies fruytfully and law∣fully ordeynid bi comune assent of þe churche, of which churche þou and ech oþire cristen man is a party, it is tauȝt þere in þe ix, xj and xij chapitris, where mensioun is maad of attendaunce of
preestis or curatis vpon her parischens, [and of parischens] and of parischens is an addition from the margin; mark of omission before anentis in text. anentis her curatis, and also of princis anentis her legis, and of legis anentis her princis; and also in þe ix chapitre, where mensioun is maad of accordingnes, which is þe v poynt of þe iiij table.

ffadir, is þis to be grauntid: þat as crist translatid, Is it right to say that Christ intended the Jewish Sabbath to correspond to the Christian Sunday? chaungid and turned þe oolde After oolde, MS. has preesthode, crossed through. lawe of þe Jewis into þe newe lawe of cristen men, and as he translatid, chaungid and turned þe oolde preesthode into þe newe preesthode (of which translaciouns, turningis and chaungis, seint poul makiþ mensioun, hebrews, vije chapitre); so crist translatid, chaungid and turned þe oold sabot daie of Jewis, which was þe vij daie of þe weke, þat is to seie, satirdaie, into þe newe sabot or newe halidaie of cristen men, þat is to seie, þe sundaie?

Sone, herto y answere þus: þer ouȝt no þing be It cannot be proved that Christ substi∣tuted the Christian Sunday for the Jews' Saturday, as a special time for special service to God. grauntid, or to MS. orto. be holden sadly and surely for treuþe aboute cristis dedis, saue oonli what is seen to be trewe bi doom of natural resoun, or bi witnesse of holy scripture, wherynne lieþ oure feiþ, or bi oolde storiyng and witnessing of hem þat weren in tyme of þe apostlis and heerers of þe apostlis, or but eny man canne depose, vndir perel of his soule, þat he is siker to haue it bi special vndoutable reuela∣cioun, wel and wijsely examyned of oold, expert, sadde and discreet men, laborid in such mater, lijk as poul had such reuelacioun in tyme of his conuersioun, and Johan, þe euaungelist, hadde suche in þe yle of pathmos. fforwhi oonly þese now seid poyntis ben groundis of al knowing and kunnyng in oure vndirstonding, which kunnyng schulde falle vpon cristis dedis; and þerfore alle oþire seiyngis of cristis dedis not groundid bi eny of þese groundis, owen to be seid and deemed fals, or at þe leest apocriphes | or feyned þingis, as suche þat we witen not fro whennes þei came, or whiþer þei wolen. Also ellis but if we schulde allowe for treuþis of cristis dedis oonly þo which bi þese now seide groundis comen to vs, we schulde haue so manye techingis
and opiniouns of cristis dedis þat we schulde wiþ hem be acumbrid and oppressid. And þerfore, siþen it is so þat neiþir bi resoun, neiþir bi scripture, neiþir bi story which þe disciplis and heerers of þe apostlis han writen, neiþir bi surest priuate reuelacioun, it is open þat crist maad enye suche positive lawe wherynne he translatid and chaungid þe sabot of þe iewis into oure cristen sabot, þat is to seie, þe halowing of þe satirdaie into þe halewing of þe sundaie, þerfore þere ouȝte no man holde it and graunte it aftir verry substancial wit, bi which a man ouȝte to reule him silf manly and substancialy.

And, ferþirmore, siþen no writing canne be had to bere Neither can it be proved that the Apos∣tles framed a law for the hallowing of the Sunday, though it was the custom in the time of the Apostles to hallow it. witnes þat þe apostlis ordeineden, bi lawe þerupon maad, eny such halidaie in þe sundaie to be kept wekely, þouȝ [I] Space left for reference in MS. See 1 Cor. xvi. 2. corinthies, [xvj] Space left for reference in MS. See 1 Cor. xvi. 2. chapitre, and actes, [xx] Space left for reference in MS. See Acts xx. 7. chapitre, mensioun be maad þat in ech weik suche a daie was kept holy, which is now clepid 'sunday', bi wilful deuout vse; And also, if þe apostlis hadden maad suche an ordinaunce or constitucioun, it had be putte among þe canouns or constituciouns whiche ben comounly named 'þe canouns of þe apostlis' raþir þan manye oþire þere expressid; wherfore wherfore is here used for þerfore. Cf. Rep. 356, 496, and Babington's glossary note., at þe leest, alle þo which trowen þat þo seide canouns were maad bi þe apostlis, schulden holde with me in þis present party, fforwhi it folewiþ lijk wise þat no man ouȝte holde þat, bi eny lawe þanne þerupon bi þe apostlis maad, þe peple were forto so fortoso apparently joined, but probably only crowded so as to get in halewe bounden. halewe bounden, but þat þei bi her It is probable that the people made this law of their own free will. good free wil and deuocioun ȝaue hem þerto. ffor þat þe peple in þo daies weren willi to do and holde suche gouer∣nauncis as were to her goostly profite, þouȝ to hem þerupon were no | boond y-maad, schal be schewid in oþire placis of my writingis. and evermore sentence is to be ȝouun for fredom, where open euidence is not had to ȝeue sentence for bondage, and so moche likely to be trewe þat þe contrarie is nouȝwhere nyȝ so likely to be trewe. and þerfore þis party is to be MS. beholde. holde MS. beholde., and not þe contrarie, into tyme
gretter euidence be gete for þe contrarye þan for þis, and ellis we synnen aȝens lawe of kinde. And so þus moche may be had in doom of resoun forto be likely trewe. And þerfore so moche a man may and ouȝte hoolde as for a likely trouþe or a likeli opinioun, þat, bi cause cristen peple wolde haue be ful reccheles to attende into preier and into mynde of goddis benefetis, if ne schulde haue be take into ech weke sum tyme whanue men schulde attende to preier and to meditacioun in comune to gider, þerfore, consenting and it wel suffring and allowing þe apostlis and oþire fadris in þo daies, bi doom of good pollitik resoun and profitable gouer∣naunce and good reule, þe peple chese of her owne deuocioun, withoute comaunding of þe prelatis in þo daies, to be taken to hem oon daie in þe weke, at þe leest, euen as bi lijk doom of good pollicye þei chese wiþ fre deuocioun, withoute boonde of positive lawe, placis and housis or templis whidir men schulde come forto þerynne to gider in comune to preie and biþenke in goddis benefetis and to heere preichingis and to talke of god; and þat for as moche as ellis, withoute suche a comune fre consent and apoyntment maad of þe peple to gider, þe peple wolde haue be ouer reccheles forto haue come to gider for heering of goddis worde to be prechid, or for þe oþire office now seid. And þus þe peple did, for þat þe peple hadde þerupon so greet resouns þat suche daies and placis schulde be hadde for her owne profite.

And raþir þe sundaie was chosen þan eny oþire daie of þe The Sunday was chosen because it was the day of Christ's resurrection. weke to þis seid office, as it is | likely in resoun, for þat crist roos fro deeþ to lijf þe sundaie. bi which rising was stablid al þe newe lawe and alle þe benefetis of crist to vs, as seynt poul writiþ, Romans, iiije chapitre v. 25., þat 'crist was taken for oure synnys, and roos for oure iustifijng'. And Ia corinthies, xve chapitre v. 14., poul seiþ þus: 'Soþeli, if crist roos not, oure preching is veyn, oure seiþ is veyn'. And, certis, more þan þis is, kanne not be groundable in resoun as for halewing of þe sundaie. And þerupon we haue no scripture, but oonly þat suche daies and placis were in þe tyme of þe apostlis, as is now bisore allegid; wherfore upon
þe sundaies halowing in þe oolde daies of cristen churche, we ouȝte to holde noon oþir opynyoun þan þis now afore seid. And for lijk skile is, þat peple schulde not be reccheles and vnkynde to considre deuoutly þe benefete of cristis resurrexioun, in tyme of þe apostlis and prelatis, in þo daies, þe peple bi her fre wil and deuocioun halewiden þe daie of cristis resurrexioun, þe apostlis and prelatis it we[l] MS. we. allowing. of which mater is long storiyng in a book y∣callid 'ecclesiastica historia'. By Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea (b. 267, d. 338). The Historia Ecclesiastica reaches to the year 324. Cf. Book of Faith, pp. 297-8.

And in lijk maner, and for lijk skile, in þe bigynnyng of The special hallowing of the Sunday is no more a com∣mandment of God than the hallowing of Whitsunday, Ascension Day, &c. þe chirche was halowid þe daie of cristis birþe, and summe oþire longyng to þe benefetis which crist did to vs, or for vs: as his ascencioun daie, witsundaie, and suche oþire. And þus it is open þat grettir grounde ne oþire grounde can be had for halewing of þe sundaie þan for halewing of eche oþire daie now seid; and so, if þou seie þat þe halewing of þe sundaie is comaundement of god, þou must folewingly seie and holde þat þe halewing of eche oþire daie now rehercid is comaundement of god and positive lawe of crist, which no man holdiþ.
More of þis mater schal be sette wiþ open proof to þis Where further teaching on the hallowing of the Sunday may be found. purpos in 'þe filling of þe iiij tablis', þe iiije party.

The text of þe iiije The Anglican Fifth. comaundement in moyses tablis is THE FOURTH The Anglican Fifth. COMMANDMENT has been already taught. þis: 'worschip þou þi fadir | and þi modir, þat þou be of long lijf vpon þe londe which þe lord þi god wole ȝeue to þee'. Soþeli, þis comaundement is pleinli tauȝt afore MS. a fore. in þe ixe, xje and xije chapitris of þe afore going first party, where is tauȝt þe attendaunce of a childe to his fadir and modir. þis þat was sette þerto, 'þat þou be of long lijf,' etcetera, was no comaundement; but it was a bihetyng or a prouoking or tolling forto kepe þis comaundement. Neuerþelees, where in þis foorme of þe x comaundementis is tauȝt how þe fadir and þe modir schulde bere hem anentis þe childe, is not open,
neiþir how þe scole maistir to his scoler, þe prelate to his parischen, þe prince toward his legi.

The text of þe ve, vje, vije, viije, ixe and xe The Sixth to the Tenth according to the Anglican reckoning, in which Pecock's Ninth and Tenth are combined as one. See above, p. 118, note 6, and Notes to p. 157. comaunde∣mentis The FIFTH to the TENTH The Sixth to the Tenth according to the Anglican reckoning, in which Pecock's Ninth and Tenth are combined as one. See above, p. 118, note 6, and Notes to p. 157. COMMANDMENTS have been taught already in the Third Point of the Fourth Table, the living riȝtfulli to our neighbour. in moyses tablis is þis: 'þou schalt not slee. þou schalt not take a mannys wijf in auoutrye. þou schalt not do þeeft. þou schalt not bere fals witnessing aȝens þi neiȝbore. þou schalt not coueite þi neiȝboris house, lond, rent, ne noon of hise goodis with wrong. þou schalt not desire withynneforþ in þin herte or wil þi neiȝboris wijf, ne his seruaunt, ne his maide, ne his oxe, ne his asse, ne eny þing þat is his, þou schalt not coueit it wrongfully.' Alle þese vj Five according to the Anglican reckon∣ing. comaundementis þou schalt fynde afore in þe first afore goyng party, þe ix chapitre, where mensioun is maad of þe ije membre of þe iije poynt in þe iiije table, which poynt is callid 'riȝtwisnes'; ffor whi where euer it be comaundid vs to be iust and riȝtful anentis oure neiȝboris, in þis same it is forboden vs forto be vniust or vnriȝtful anentis þe same neiȝboris. and siþen in þe secunde membre of þe iij poynt in þe iiije table, in þe now seid ixe chapitre of þe first party, we be comaundid forto be iust and riȝtful anentis oure neiȝboris; it folewiþ þat þerynne ben includid and inclosid þe now afore rehercid ve, vje, vije, viije, ixe and xe The Sixth to the Tenth according to the Anglican reckoning, in which Pecock's Ninth and Tenth are combined as one. See above, p. 118, note 6, and Notes to p. 157. forbodis of moyses tablis, siþen þei ben not oþire þan forbodis of oure vniustnes, of oure vnriȝtnes anentis oure neiȝboris.

and | wheþir eny mo comaundementis of god þan ben The Four Tables help to explain the Ten Com∣mandments. þese x now rehercid, ben conteyned withynne þe processe of þe afore seid iiij tablis, or no, y reporte me to alle reders in hem, which reders in þe louȝest degree ben able to be clepid 'leerned men'. Neuerþelees, if eny clerk or lay man kanne se so fer in þese x comaundementis þat he wole nedis make þe foorme þerof to be his ful reule of al þat god biddiþ him to do, and of al þat god forbediþ him to do, and þat bi fer∣fet
reducciouns, or into hoom bringing, of þingis being oute or aroume, I wole not werne him. ȝitt he may not seie but þat þe foorme of þe iiij tablis, and þe explaiyng of hem maad here bifore in þe first party and in þe oþire my writingis, schal do good to him; forwhi it schal opene abrood þe foorme of þe seid x comaundementis, þat he schal þe broder and þe wijder se in his foorme of þe x comaundementis bi þe foorme of þe seid iiij tablis þan he schulde se and knowe, if he had not þis foorme of iiij tablis, neiþir eny oþir lijk to it. Be he þerfore as curteis to me as I am to him, þat is to Pecock requests toleration of his arguments against Moses' Tables, in the same way as he tolerates those who believe in the adequacy of the Ten Com∣mandments. seie, as I weerne him not forto holde him in þe seid maner to hise x comaundementis, so weerne he not me forto argue in chapitris next folewing aȝens þe comoun pretencioun had of hem. And be he not boold forto vse symonye and oþire vicis for as moche as he can not se hem expressely, neiþir consequently, bi weie of formal folewing of argument, forbodid in hem; and make he sufficient answer to þe argumentis and skilis which I haue maad, and schal make, aȝens hem; and þanne he and I schulen not be at bate, but we wel schulen be freendis.

and at þe first schewe he to me skile herof: Siþen it is Just as the Ten Commandments cannot pretend to include all God's law for the Jews, so they cannot pretend to include all God's law for Christians. so þat god in þe tyme of þe iewis, to whom he ȝaf þis x comaundementis, ȝaf not hem as for a foorme of alle hise comaundementis to hem, as is open ynouȝ bi manye dosyns of comaundementis; wherbi schulen we take in þe oolde testament, or þe newe, þat | he ȝaue to cristen men þilk x comaundementis forto be alle þe preceptis and forbodis which he ȝeueþ to cristen men? siþen, as it seemeþ, for lijk skile, þilk x comaundementis ouȝte not be seid forto be alle preceptis and prohibiciouns maad to us cristen men, as þei ouȝten not be seid þat þei were alle preceptis and prohibi∣ciouns maad to þe Jewis; and þat After þat, MS. has as, crossed through and underdotted., for as moche as bi greet semyng, manye preceptis and prohibiciouns maad to þe Jewis were wiþoute hem i. e. outside them, not contained in them., so bi lijk seemyng manye preceptis and prohibiciouns maad to cristen men ben wiþoute hem i. e. outside them, not contained in them..

DIV3.HEAD: [vije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Erþirmore, sone, siþen fro þe bigynnyng of þe iiije The Ten Com∣mandments do not comprise all God's law. chapitre in þis secund partye hidirto, I haue schewid how þe x comaundementis of moyses tablis ben conteynyd euidently and openli in þe iiij tablis tauȝt bifore in þe first party, y schal now schewe þat þe x comaundementis in moyses tablis conteynen not sufficiently into oure profitable doctryne and oure remembring alle þe comaundementis of goddis lawe. þouȝ it be open ynouȝ bi what I haue provid bifore toward þe eende of þe iiije chapitre, ȝitt for more pleynes I schal eftsoone schewe þe same. and þus I bigynne.

Oute of þe forbeding of þe gretter yuel, folewiþ neuer þe The forbidding of the lesser evil does not follow from the forbidding of the greater. forbeding of þe lasse yuel, bi eny argument which is worþ a MS arisch. risch MS arisch., as clerkis liȝtli knowen. And þerfore in þe for∣beding of þe gretter yuel is not includid þe forbode of þe lasse yuel; þouȝ al oute fro þe forbode of þe lasse yuel may But the forbid∣ding of the greater evil follows from the forbidding of the lesser. sufficientli folewe þe forbode of þe more yuel; and so in þe forbode of þe lasse yuel is includid þe forbode of þe grettir yuel, as is seid bifore in þe next chapitre See above, p. 127.. and ellis þe Hence forswear∣ing is forbidden by the Second The Anglican Third. Commandment. seid susteyners of moyses tablis in þe seid large contynence, mowe not holde þat fals swering is forboden bi þe ij The Anglican Third. comaundement in moyses tablis, neiþer þat open raveyn is And ravine is forbidden by the Seventh.The Anglican Eighth. forbode bi þis comaundement The Anglican Eighth. of þe ije table: 'þou | schalt do no þeft', as seynt austyn seiþ. and þan forþ þus: Siþen But maiming or beating is not forbidden by the Fifth, The Anglican Sixth. and fornication is not forbidden by the Sixth. The Anglican Seventh. manslauȝt is grettir yuel þan is mayme or beting or hurting a þis side manslauȝt, And auoutrye is grettir yuel þan symple fornicacioun, And in þe ve The Anglican Sixth. comaundement afore rehercid in moyses tablis is forboden oonli manslauȝt, And in þe vj The Anglican Seventh. is forboden oonly avoutrye, as latyn clerkis knowen wel ynouȝ, and as it is open bi cristis rehercel of þe same vje The Anglican Seventh. comaunde∣ment, mathew, xixe chapitre v. 18., where crist reherciþ þe same vj The Anglican Seventh. comaundement vndir þese wordis: 'þou schalt not do avoutrye', as is rehercid aftir pleynlier, bi fuller processe,
þere in þe next chapitre folewing; how may enye man having an ynche of resoun and of clergye, feele and seie þat in þe seide ve The Anglican Sixth. and vje The Anglican Seventh. comaundementis of moyses tablis ben includid þe forbodis of maymyng, beting, hurtyng, and of symple fornicacioun? Certis, if clerkis wole seie þus, þat Otherwise the commandment of the Church not to eat meat on the Friday would mean that other things less delicate than meat were not to be eaten on the Friday. bi vertu or strengþe of þis comau dement: 'þou schalt do noon avoutrye', þei ouȝten take and vndirstonde þat it is forboden to hem forto do symple fornicacioun; and bi vertu and strengþe of þis comaundement: 'þou schalt not slee', þei ouȝten take and vndirstonde þat it is forboden to hem forte mayme, hurte and bete; y wolde wite whi wole not þei folewingly þerof seie þus: þat bi vertu and strengþe of þis comaundement of þe chirche, 'þou schalt ete no fleisch in þe fridaie', þei ouȝte take and vndirstonde þat it is in þat forboden to hem forto ete MS. ete fleisch; fleisch being under∣dotted to denote deletion. in þe fridaie MS. fridaie and al. al MS. fridaie and al. oþire etable þing being lasse delicate þan is fleisch; And if þe Or, if a com∣mandment were made that wine should not be drunk on the Friday, it would follow that other things less delicate than wine were not to be drunk on the Friday. churche wolde make þis comaundement forto forbede wyne to be drunken in þe fridaie, or if þe goostli fadir of þese seid clerkis wolde enioyne to hem þat þei schulden in oon fridaie forbere þe drinking of wyne, þei owȝten take and vndirstonde þat, bi vertu of þilk comaundement, it were forboden to hem forto drinke ale or MS. or sidre; sidre being crossed through. sydir or whey or eny oþire drynkeable þing of lasse delicacye þan is wyne? | siþen noon oþire grounde þei haue for hem whi in þe forbode of avoutrie is vndirstonde and conteynyd þe forbode of syngle fornycacioun, and in þe forbode of manslauȝter is vndirstonde and conteynyd þe forbode of hurting, but if it were þis: þat in eche forbode in which is forboden a dede, for it haþ with∣ynne it silf a certeyn grounde for which it is forboden, is includid, conteynyd and vndirstonde þe forbode of eche oþire dede hauyng sumwhat of þe same grounde, þouȝ it be lasse þan in þe oþire dede forboden for þe same grounde. And soþeli so it is in þe dedis of myn argument, þat delicacie of etyng is grettir in fleisch þan in fysch, for which delicacie fleisch is forboden to be eten in fridaies. wherfore, if þe
seid comoun talking and þe comoun declaring vpon þe forbode of auoutrye and of manslauȝter were trewe, it must nedis folewe what I haue þerof now dryuen oute and con∣cludid, Namelich siþen to do auoutrye and to do manslauȝter were not yuel, ne were þat god or resoun forbediþ hem, no more MS. nomore. þan to ete fleisch in þe fridaie were not yuel, ne were þat þe churche forbediþ it.

Also I argue þus: god forbediþ glotenye, as is open bi Gluttony is not forbidden in the Ten Command∣ments. luke, xxje chapitre v. 34., whanne he seiþ: 'Take ȝe hede þat ȝoure hertis be not maad heuy with ouer moche mete and ouer moche drynke'. and where is þis forbode amonge þe x comaundementis of moyses tablis? If þou wolte seie þat it is in þe first, þanne y seie aȝenward whi is þis glotenye forbode more þere þan is forboden þere avoutrye or fals witnesse bering? And if þese ij now rehercid forbodis of avoutrye and of fals witnessing ben in þe first comaunde∣ment, whi ben not þei stillid and vnsett forþ expressely, as is þe forbode of glotenye stillid and vnsett forþ expressely, in þe foorme of þe x comaundementis?

Also god biddiþ a preest to preche and teche þe peple, as The priest's preaching and teaching is not bidden in the Ten Command∣ments. is open, mathew, þe last chapitre Chap. xxviii, v. 19., where | crist seiþ þus: 'go ȝe and teche ȝe alle peplis, baptising hem'; and of þis teching to which preestis ben bounden, mensioun is open þoruȝ poulis epistle to tymothe. Especially 1 Timothy ii. 4. Neuerþelees, where in þe foorme of þe x comaundementis þis comaundement haþ place, I se not; but if þou wolte seie þat þere whanne it is seid: 'þou schalt worschip þi fadir and modir'. Certis, it seemeþ þat it were ful inconuenient forto so seie, fforwhi þilk wordis pretenden oonly þe foorme wherbi þe neþerer schulde reule him toward þe ouerer; and not wherbi þe ouerer schulde reule him toward his neþerer.

Also, siþen a mannys children and a mannys seruauntis Neither are any of the relation∣ships of the superior to the inferior. and a mannys parischens ben not to him fadir and modir, how in þilk wordis, 'worschip þou þi fadir and modir', schulde conuenientli be tauȝt þat a man ouȝte reule, dresse and teche his childe, his seruaunt, his parischen?

Also god comaundiþ vs to bileeue, as may be taken of þat Belief in the mysteries of the Trinity and in Christ's birth, death, and ascension, is not taught in the Ten Command∣ments. þat is writen, mark, þe last chapitre v. 16.: 'he þat schal bileeue and schal be baptisid schal be saaf; he þat schal not bileeue schal be dampned'; and more pleynli, Ia Johannis, iije chapitre v. 23.: 'þis is þe comaundement of him, þat we bileeue in þe name of Jesus crist, þe sone of him, and þat we loue oon þe oþire, as god ȝaue to vs comau[n]dement' MS. comaudement.. wherto wel accordiþ poul, hebrews, xje chapitre v. 6.: 'It is impossible to pleese god with∣oute bileeue'. and þis bileeue can be seid to be noon oþire þan what crist and hise apostlis techen vs in her holi writingis. wherfore folewiþ þat we ben bounden, and to vs is comaundid, forto bileeue þat holy writt groundiþ to vs. And so þerfore we ben bounden, and to vs is comaundid, to bileeue þat he is oon in substaunce, and iij in persoonys, which persoonys ben fadir, sone and holi goost; and þat þe fadir bigetiþ þe sone, and he bringiþ forþ þe holi goost; fforwhi al þis is reuelid, opened and tauȝt vs bi holi scripture, as is open in þe first party of 'cristen | religioun', in þe first trety, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre. And þis comaundement is not tauȝt in moyses tablis, neiþir we myȝt leerne þis com∣aundement in moyses tablis, if al oþire scripture were not. wherfore not alle comaundementis of god ben tauȝt in moyses tablis. Also ful vnseemely and vntreuli it is to seie þat þerynne is eny þing tauȝt, wherynne þe same þing may not be leerned. In lijk maner I myȝt argue þus: god comaundiþ vs to bileeue his sones incarnacioun of a mayde, his passioun, deeþ, resurreccioun, ascencioun, oure owne resurreccioun and þe laste doom, as may be taken of scripture, Ia Johannis, iije chapitre, in þe eende, v. 23. And Ia Johannis, iiije chapitre, in þe bigynnyng vv. 2-3., and bi þe proof which is maad in þe next argument now afore going, and bi þat þat schal be seid in 'þe filling of þe iiij tablis', þe ije partie, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre.

Also he comaundiþ vs to be baptisid, as is open of þe laste The Sacraments of Baptism and the Eucharist are not bidden in the Ten Com∣mandments. chapitre of mathew v. 19., and of þe iije chapitre of Johan v. 5.; And
to be housilid, as may be taken of Johan, þe vj chapitre v. 53., of mathew, xxvj chapitre vv. 26-8., of poul, Ia corinthies, xje chapitre vv. 23-5..

Also he comaundiþ vs for to make repentaunce for oure Neither is re∣pentance bidden. synnys, if we haue eny synnes doon; as may be taken of mathew, þe iiije chapitre v. 17., and mark, þe vje chapitre v. 12., of luke, þe iije chapitre vv. 3-8., and þe xiije chapitre v. 5. in þe bigynnyng, and dedis of þe apostlis, ije chapitre, toward þe eende v. 38.. fforwhi if god comaundiþ vs to bileeue in þe name of crist Jesus, þe sone of him, and forto l[i]ue MS. loue. to gider in charite, as it is open, Ia Johannis, iije chapitre v. 23., forsoþe, bi lijk skile it is to be vndirstonde, in placis now allegid, þat god com∣aundiþ vs to be baptisid and to be houslid and to repente for oure synnys.
