And noon of alle þese comaun lementis ben tauȝt, or mow Hence it follows that the Ten Commandments do not include all God's law. be leerned, bi strengþe of moyses tablis; fforwhi þanne þe Jewis myȝt haue leerned hem bi moyses tablis, and koude hem | bi strengþe of þe wordis in moyses tablis; Also folewiþ þat þese seid comaundementis myȝt be tauȝt and leerned bi moyses tablis, þouȝ alle oþire writingis were not, which is openly fals. wherfore nedis folewiþ þat not alle goddis comaundementis ben tauȝt and sett in moyses tablis, but if a man wole forge and feyne þat þei alle ben in moyses tablis, riȝt in lijk maner as he myȝt forge and feyne alle goddis comaundementis to be ȝouun to vs, and tauȝt to vs, in þe first verse of þe sawtir, or in þe first worde of þe sawtir, as prechers ben woned to wrynge oute of a worde alle maters whiche to hem liken, bi wrasting of sillablis and of lettris, and bi hookis and crokis of lettris, which conteynyng is litil worþ, and vnable to make þerbi eny sufficient doctryne to be receyuid of þe peple, ffor it is withoute proof, and þerfore wiþoute foundement and grounde.

Perauenture summe men wolen fle into þis hole fro þe Some may assert that what the doctors say is included in the Ten Command∣ments is in∣cluded by God. face of þese profis, and wolen seie þus: 'what euer holy doctouris writen to be includid in eny of þe x seid comaunde∣mentis, is þerynne includid bi entent and purpos of god'.

Sone, oute of þis hole such a seier may be drawe þus: But no doctor can produce proof, either of reason or of revelation, that God intended the Ten Com∣mandments to comprise all His laws. Sumwhere þese holi doctouris musten haue þis what þei so bi þee seien; and so nedis þei muste fynde and haue it bi laboure in her natural resoun, or þei muste receyue and haue it bi godli reuelacioun maad to hem þerupon. but so it is þat þou maist not seie and holde þat bi þe first now rehercid weie; fforwhi þan þe seid doctouris founden and hadden þilk seiyngis bi mocioun and strengþe of þe wordis in which þo x comaundementis ben writen, and þat is vntrewe; ffor∣whi þanne so schulde ech oþire witti man fynde and se þe same, and nameliche þan no witty man myȝte fynde and se and prove vndoutabily þe contrarye: þat is to seie, þat þo wordis, bi her dew litteral representyng, signifien nouȝwher nyȝ ech comaundement of god, as it is bifore sufficientli and vnsoilably pro∣vid. Neiþir þou maist seie and holde þat bi þe secunde weie now here rehercid; fforwhi þerto þou hast noon euidencis of resoun, or of scripture, or of þe same doctouris affeermyng, þat thei hadden bi reuelacioun her exposiciouns vpon þe seid x clausulis. and þerfore to seie and holde were a feyned opynyoun, bi cause it lackiþ suffi∣cient grounde to make him worþi to be trowid and holde. and also here aȝens it is myȝtli at þe fulle prouid in 'þe book of apprising doctouris'. See Notes. wherfore nedis folewiþ þat þis fugitive answere may not stonde, And nameliche whilis MS. whilis while. And the doctors disagree among themselves. holi doctouris in her expownyngis vpon þe seid x comaunde∣mentis not accorden, but discorden; and ȝitt discoord and contrariete vpon oon and þe same þing is not reuelid fro god, for þan falshede and vntrouþe weren reuelid and tauȝt of god.

Also þus: what euer eny doctour, or eny multitude of If an antecedent is true, its con sequent is true; but the conse∣quent arising from the ante∣cedent that the Ten Command∣ments contain all God's laws is not true; therefore the antecedent cannot be true. doctouris, holden and graunten, or what euer holi chirche holdiþ and grauntiþ, ȝhe, what euer aungel or god holdiþ or grauntiþ, it muste be seid nedis þat he holdiþ and grauntiþ al þat folewiþ formali þerof. Now þan lete þe chirche of god graunte al þat folewiþ oute of þe antecedent aȝens which I argue here, and I wole al redy graunte þe same antecedent. And, certis, ellis it may not be seid þat þe
chirche or god byndiþ me forto graunte and holde þilk antecedent.

DIV3.HEAD: [viije chapitre]
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, ful strong ben ȝoure profis for ȝoure party and It would seem folly to reduce all God's laws to the Ten Com∣mandments. for ȝoure entent; and ful strongli þei proceden aȝens newe doctouris and newe maistris, which ben movid, as to me it seemeþ, bi curiosite and bi no nede of resoun, forto reduce and bring alle goddis comaundementis into þese seid x.

Sone, soþeli bicause þat nede and resoun dryuen hem not It is folly to insist that the Ten Com∣mandments comprise all the laws of God. þerto, but curiosite oonly, or, if I schulde seie þe sooþe, not verrie curiosite, but bluntnes and boistosenes, or, at þe leest, moche vncircumspeccioun and vnattendaunce; þerfore hem | silf in þis mater þei biwamblen MS. bi wamblen. so rudely and so vnredili, as þouȝ þei hadden forȝete hem silf to biholde into her clergye. And, if it be weel aspied, þei in her owne declara∣ciouns and in her owne defencis hem silf ouer þrowen, which aspiaunce y committe to hiȝer consideracioun þan is pertynent to þis symple present book.

Neuerþelees, as here, I procede þus: þouȝ it were so þat Even if, for the sake of argu∣ment, the Ten Commandments are admitted to contain all God's laws, they do not teach them clearly, sufficiently, fully, and compendiously. alle goddis comaundementis were includid in þe seid foorme of þe x comaundementis (as no man can schewe þat þei ben); certis, ȝit it muste be seid and feelid þat þei so ben þere includid MS. includid and. in an hid, priuy, schort maner oonli; lijk as if a man wolde seie þat alle goddis comaundementis ben includid in þe MS. tweyne þe. tweyne MS. tweyne þe. first versis of þe sawtir, or in þe first worde of þe sawtir, bi wrestyng of lettris and of sillablis, or in sum oþire derk maner, not esili and liȝtli to be bi∣holden.

þanne y argue þus: þouȝ it be grauntid þat alle goddis If the Ten Com∣mandments were a clear and sufficient framework of God's laws, men not knowing God's laws would thereby learn and remember them easily. comaundementis ben includid and conteyned in þe comoun seid foorme of þe x comaundementis, in sum maner of conteynyng, if þilk including and conteynyng be not such in cleernes and in openes þat þerbi and þerynne men not knowing þe comaundementis of god sufficientli, [mow mow ... sufficientli, an addition from the margin. Omission mark in text after previous sufficientli. lerne knowe þerbi þe comaundementis of god sufficientli], mow ... sufficientli, an addition from the margin. Omission mark in text after previous sufficientli. and se
þerbi a grounde þat þei ben comaundementis of god, and þerbi and þerynne sufficientli se, recorde and remembre alle þe comaundementis of god, and reporte to oþire and to hem silf alle þe comaundementis of god; what availiþ to hem þilk priuei, close, now seid conteynyng and including of alle goddis comaundementis in þe seid comoun foorme of x comaundementis? or ellis, if men hadde leerned sufficientli And in the Ten Commandments God's laws would be seen and remem∣bered easily by those who had learned them elsewhere. alle comaundementis of god ouȝwher ellis þan in þe seid comoun foorme of þe x comaundementis, if þe seid foorme of þe x comaundementis wolde not serve to hem forto þerbi and þerynne sufficientli se, recorde and remembre to hem silf, and sufficientli reporte to hem silf and to oþire | þe hool summe of goddis comaundementis so fulli ouȝwher ellis of hem leerned, no greet avail and profyte schal hang vpon þe seid comoun foorme of þe x comaundementis, þat we schulde sette so moche bi it as we doon, and so moche preise it and write it and attende to it aboue alle oþire techingis of goddis comaundementis, as is open ynouȝ to ech mannys witt. but so it is, y dare wel seie, and ech man may haue But from the Ten Command∣ments, God's laws cannot be learnt, or easily seen and remembered. þe same in experience, if he wole, þat þe seid comoun foorme of þe x comaundementis is not suche þat þerbi and þerynne men not knowing goddis comaundementis mowe leerne suffi∣cientli alle goddis comaundementis, and se þerbi a grounde þat þei ben alle goddis comaundementis; neiþir þerbi and þerynne sufficientli se and remembre and recorde alle goddis comaundementis, and þat wheþir þei haue leerned afore sufficientli owȝwhere goddis comaundementis, or no. Wherfore folewiþ nedis þat þe seid comune foorme of x comaunde∣mentis is not of eny greet price or worþe forto so moche be sette bi as forto helpe vs into þe sufficient knowing and sufficient remembring of alle goddis comaundementis. and From the Four Tables, God's laws can be learned much better. at þe leest and ferþest folewiþ þis: þat þilk seid comoun foorme of x comaundementis is nouȝwhere nyȝ so moche to be sett bi, nouȝwhere nyȝ so moche to be desirid, to be kunned, to be had, to be leerned, to be attendid to, as þe foorme afore tauȝt in þe first party of þis book, from þe bi∣gynnyng of þe iiije chapitre into þe eende of þe ixe chapitre.

þat bi, and in, þe seid foorme of x comaundementis in It has been proved that all God's laws cannot be learned easily from the Com∣mandments by men not before knowing God's laws. moyses tablis, men not bifore knowing alle goddis comaunde∣mentis
mowe not leerne sufficientli alle goddis comaunde∣mentis, and bi þilk foorme se a grounde þat þei ben alle goddis comaundementis, y may prove þus: If bi and in þe seid foorme, þis leernyng and seing myȝt be had, certis, þanne, þouȝ noon oþire writing | were of eny goddis com∣aundementis saue þe seid foerme of x comaundementis, ȝitt men bifore not knowing alle goddis comaundementis, myȝten and schulden se hem alle þere in þilk foorme, ȝhe, and se in and bi þilk foorme þat ech of hem is goddis comaundement. but, certis, þis is openli vntrewe, as experience and assaie may þerof be iuge. wherfore it is vntrewe þat bi and in þe seid foorme of x comaundementis, men not bifore knowing alle goddis comaundementis, mowe leerne sufficientli alle goddis comaundementis, and se bi and in þilk foorme a foundement and grounde þat, and whi, ech of hem is a com∣aundement of god.

Also þat þis be trewe which is afore seid, takun and put And it has been proved that all God's laws can∣not be easily seen and re∣membered by the Ten Com∣mandments. in þis nowe afore going argument, þat þe seide comoun foorme of þe x comaundementis is noon such foorme þat þerbi and þerynne we mowe se, recorde, remembre and reporte suffi∣cientli as is nedeful to alle cristen men, þe hool summe of goddis comaundementis, may be provid in þis wise: No foorme is sufficient to vs and to alle cristen þat þerynne we mowe se and recorde, remembre and reporte, sufficientli, as oure nede and profit askiþ, þe hool summe of goddis com∣aundementis, which foorme schewiþ not forþ þe hool summe of goddis comaundementis cleerly and pleynli and openli and liȝtli and esily, wiþoute ouer greet laboure and deluyng and digging into it, and in vndirmynyng it derkely and laborously. fforwhi how may I se with my bodili iȝe cleerly and sufficientli eny þingis in eny foorme, or in eny þing, which foorme or þing schewiþ not to my bodili iȝe cleerli and sufficientli MS. sufficientli enye þingis; enye þingis being crossed through. þe same þingis? as how schulde I se in a myrrour enye þingis openli and sufficientli MS. sufficientli wherfore in þe same wise; wherfore ... wise being crossed through., if þilk mirrour schewid not þe same þingis openli and sufficientli? Wher∣fore in þe same wise, how schulde I with my resonable iȝe
se enyȝe þingis openli and sufficientli þere wherein MS. where in. þe same þingis ben not schewid openli and sufficientli? but so it is no man | may seie, if he wole assaie, þat þe seid comoun foorme of þe x comaundementis schewiþ forþ to vs and to alle cristen cleerly, pleynli, openli and liȝtli and esili, withoute ouer greet laboure in deluyng and diggyng derkely and laborosely, þe hool summe of goddis comaundementis tauȝt afore in þe first party of þis book, from þe bigynnyng of þe iiije chapitre into þe eende of þe ixe chapitre. wherfore nedis folewiþ þat þe seid comoun foorme of þe x comaunde∣mentis is not such foorme þat þerbi and þerynne we mowe se, recorde, remembre and reporte sufficientli to vs silf and to oþire, as nede or oure profite askiþ, þe hool summe of goddis comaundementis.

And who so wole, who so nyle, at þe ferþest it folewiþ þat From the Four Tables God's laws can be much more easily seen and remembered. nouȝwhere nyȝe þe seid foorme availith to þe seid purpos as þe vj seid chapitris doon of þe first party of þis book. And þanne, wherto schulde þe sufficient be lefte, and þe vnsuffi∣cient be taken, nameli in a purpos so necessarye?

DIV3.HEAD: [ixe chapitre]
DIV3.P:
[F]Adir, I consent wel to þe proof of ȝoure argumentis, The Son assents to the above teaching on the inadequacy of the Ten Com∣mandments to comprise all God's laws clearly and sufficiently. as I must nedis consent; and I wondre how moche newe techers pretenden þat in þe comoun foorme of þe x com∣aundementis ben sufficientli as for oure leernyng and remem∣bring and reporting conteyned alle goddis comaundementis, Siþen, if alle oþire scripturis schulde ceese, it were impos∣sible a man to come bi þe leernyng of alle goddis comaunde∣mentis þoruȝ þilk x wordis of moyses tablis; And þouȝ he were leerned of alle goddis comaundementis ouȝwhere ellis þan in þilk x wordis, ȝitt it were not esy, neiþir conuenient, forto reporte alle goddis comaundementis bi hem; ȝhe, it were a ful nyȝe meene to make him forȝete þe moost deel of goddis comaundementis, if he schulde make his greet atten∣daunce into þe seid x wordis as to be a myrrour in which he schulde profitabli se, recorde, remembre and reporte to him silf and to oþire þat goddis comaundementis be not for∣ȝeten,
| but euer wel kunnen, siþen þe seid foorme of þo x wordis is not to þis purpos so sufficient MS. vnsufficient; vn being underdotted. a foorme, as ȝe han now wel bifore proued. And bi so moche þe raþir he schulde forȝete þe more deel of goddis comaundementis, bi how moche þe more attendaunce he schulde ȝeue into consideracioun of so insufficient a foorme as is þe recording, remembring, seyng and reportyng of þese seid x wordis; fforwhi þere is no meene which schulde sunner make a man falle from suffi∣cient leernyng, remembring, seing, or reportyng of eny certeyn þingis, þan is forto leene to a meene as for a sufficient schewer of þe same þingis, which meene not so sufficientli schewiþ; And þerfore perauenture þe greet apprising of þe comune seid foorme of þe x comaundementis myȝt be bi sleiȝt of oure enemye; And perauenture it is a cause whi goddis comaundementis ben so yuel kunne of þe peple as þei ben; And þerfore I myȝt wondre how euer mowe MS. "þese 'mowe, with the marks of transposition. þese MS. "þese 'mowe, with the marks of transposition. techers diffame god, þat he schulde ordeyne so vnp[ro]fitable MS. vnpfitable. and so vnsufficient a MS. afoorme. foorme MS. afoorme. to be oure sufficient foorme forto in it leerne, knowe, remembre and reporte hise comaundementis, as þei seien þat god it so ordeyned.

Sone, I perceyue wel, bi al þat þou now hast reducid and Even if to the Ten Command∣ments be added the teaching of the Seven Deadly Sins, &c., this does not comprise all God's law. concludid and dryuen forþ oute of myn now afore arguyng, þat þou vndirstondist wel al þe piþe of myn arguyng; and þerfore I am riȝt glad. Wherfore I schal sette forþ MS. setteforþ. to þe same afore proued purpos þese skilis now folewing: If summe men pretenden þat þe foorme of þe x comaundementis is sufficient doctryne for alle goddis comaundementis, as þei seien þat it is, whi hangen þei aboute þe same foorme of x comaundementis suche lose gibilettis as ben þe teching of vij deedli synnes, þe teching of v wittis, þe teching of vij mercyful werkis, and oþire mo afore in þis pre∣sent ije partye, in þe bigynnyng of þe first chapitre, y-rehercid? as þouȝ þe foorme of þe x comaundementis were not in it silf sufficient; or ellis if þei wolen seie þat þe foorme of þe x comaunde∣mentis is not sufficient for teching, leernyng, remembring and reporting of alle goddis comaundementis, but þilk
foorme of þe x comaundementis, with þe foorme of þe vij deedly synnys, and her vij contrarye vertues, and with þe foorme of þe v wittis keping, and wiþ þe foorme of þe vij bodili and vij goostli werkis of mercy fulfilling, is sufficient doctryne at þe fulle for alle goddis comaundementis and for al oure vertuose reuling, certis, aȝens þis seiyng proceden alle þe same profis and argumentis which ben afore maad in þis ije party, in þe iije and in þe iiije and vij chapitris, as mai liȝtli to þe ensercher be seen. And so þei muste nedis be compellid for to sette ferþer to alle Þese now seid pacchis þe articlis of bileeue, and Þerynne hem to bryng in þe vse of þe sacramentis. And also, whanne alle þese schulen be þrowe to gider into heepe, for to make of hem an hool suffi∣cient foorme of leernyng, remembring and reportyng vpon goddis comaundementis, þis heepe schal not conteyne alle þe vertues of goddis lawe; fforwhi where in þis heepe is Examples of virtues not included. conteynyd þat a man ouȝte forbere vnmesurable or wantowne or vncomely lauȝyng, or vncomely or vnhonest setting of his body, or ouer heuy chere and countenaunce, or ouer liȝt chere and countenaunce, which bi resoun schulden not bisett a prelate or a reuler? or where in þis heep is conteyned þat a man schulde not be ouer myry and ioieful, and ouer∣moche sportyng? and so of oþire poyntis touchid bifore in þe first partye, in þe iije table, þoruȝ oute al þe iiije and ve poyntis of þe iije table, and her spicis and braunchis.

Also | þis heepe schal be as long in noumbre of poyntis The Four Tables teach all God's law, and that much more shortly and conveniently than the Ten Command∣ments, the Seven Deadly Sins, &c. as is þe foorme of þe iiij tablis in þe first party of þis book y-tauȝt, fro þe bigynnyng of þe iiije chapitre into þe eende of þe ixe chapitre, or, certis, moche lengir. And þerwiþ al it schal be oute of cours, of ioynt, and oute of liþþ, oute of ordre, and oute of dewe processe to gider clumprid, þat it schal neuer serue to teche, to leerne and to remembre and to reporte so fair and so esili and so profitabli as schal þerto serve þe foorme of þe iiij seid tablis aftir þat þilk foorme be had a MS. awhile. while MS. awhile. in haunt and vse of remembring. And ȝitt þanne þerof folewiþ ferþir, bi her owne knowleching, þat þe foorme of þe x comaundementis is not in it silf sufficient, forwhi not wiþoute þe seid loose gibilettis þerto sette, forto teche,
leerne or remembre goddis comaundementis, which is as now in þis present chapitre oure principal purpos to prove.

fferþirmore, if it be wel arguid aȝens so greet meynteners The Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment is not binding to Christians. and so greet glorifiers of moyses tablis, as þat þei so ben is afore rehercid, þei mowe not avoide, assoile or ascape MS. a scape. but þat þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of þo tablis is not to be holden, neþir to be kept, of cristen men; ȝhe, þat þilk iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement is forboden bi cristis lawe Alongside iije comaundement is for∣boden bi cristis lawe is written in the margin, in a later hand, falsum dicit. to be holden and kept of cristen men. And so her noumbre of x comaunde∣mentis, wole þei, nyle þei, is dockid bi oon, and sette into þe nou[m]bre MS. noubre. of ix.

And þat þis be trewe may be provid bi manye weies. Proofs that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is no longer binding: ffirst þus: A comaundement, as it is in þis present purpos forto speke of comaundement, is þe hool dede or werke bede to be doon, in þat þat it falliþ or abidiþ vndir þe dede of (1) A com∣mandment is the whole deed or work bidden, and the whole deed bidden in the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment is to hallow the Saturday. bidding or comaunding, as is open ynouȝ to se. Also þe iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of þe x in moyses tablis was forto halowe in eche weke þe satirdaie, as ech man must nedis graunte. þan herupon I argue þus: Al what was bede in þe iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of þe seid tablis was forto in eche weke To hallow the Saturday is no longer binding. halowe þe satirdaie. but so it is þat forto | in eche weke halewe þe satirdaie is ceesid, and bindiþ not. Wherfore al Therefore the whole Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment is no longer binding. what was bede in þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis is ceesid, and bindiþ not.

Also þus: no þing was bede in þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of (2) Nothing was bidden in the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment save to hallow the Saturday. moyses tablis, saue forto in eche weke, or in eny weke, halowe þe satirdaie, in þilk meenyng as for þe satirdaie silf. [but to halewe þe satirdaie] but . . . satirdaie, an addition from the margin; omission mark before is in text. is ceesid and bindiþ not. To hallow the Saturday is no longer binding. Wherfore no þing in þe seid iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement abidiþ and bindiþ. Therefore nothing in the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is now binding.

Soþeli, in euereiþir of þese ij argumentis, if þe first premisse be trewe, þo ij argumentis concluden and proven her conclusiouns. and þat in euereiþir of hem þe first The first premises of these two arguments are true; therefore the conclusions are true. premysse is trewe, I prove þus: If eny oþir þing was beden in þe seid iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement þan halewing of þe satirdaie
in a certeyne foorme and maner and þing making and perteyn∣yng nedisli þerto, þilk þing couþe be toolde and assigned; but For nothing other than the hallowing of the Saturday can be pointed out as bidden in the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment. no man canne it assigne, and seie what it is or was, bi eny witnessing of holi scripture. Wherfore no such þing is or was.

Also in lijk maner was þilke iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement ȝouun forto in eche weke halewe þe satirdaie, how þat comaunde∣ment was ȝouun forto in eche ȝeere halowe þe first daie of And the hal∣lowing of the Saturday is the only thing bidden in the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment, as the hallowing of a certain day is the only thing bidden in other command∣ments of hallowing. þe vije monþe, And how was ȝouun comaundement forto halewe þe x daie of þe same monþe, And how was ȝouun anoþir comaundement forto halewe þe xve daie of þe same vije MS. ″monþe ′vije, with the marks of transposition. monþe, MS. ″monþe ′vije, with the marks of transposition. as apperiþ to se for maundement of þe satirdaie, exodi, xxe chapitre, vv. 8-11. And for þe iij MS. iije. oþire now rehercid maundementis of halewing to be maad ȝeerli in þe vije monþe, leuiticus, xxiije chapitre vv. 24 ff.; except þat þe halewing of þe satirdaie was in his degree gretter, as apperiþ in þe text, exodi, xvje chapitre, v. 23. for þat þe satirdaie þei schulden halowe so moche þat þei schulden not diȝte eny mete in seeþing or roosting it bi fier, which makiþ no diuersite in þis present purpos. but so it is þat þe now rehercid comaundement forto in eche ȝeere halowe þe first daie of þe vije monþe, had no more in him but þis halowing of þilk daie | to be doon in eche ȝeere, with purtenauncis withoute which þilk halowing so bede myȝt not be doon. Wherefore neiþir þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis had eny more or oþire þan þe halowing of þe satirdaie to be doon in eche weke, with hise purtenauncis withoute which þilk halowing so bede myȝt not be doon, And þerfore whos bidding makiþ not a newe or a dyuers bidding fro þe principal bidding, but falliþ vndir þe principal bidding. Wherfore, siþen þilk oon Therefore the commandment to hallow the Saturday is no longer binding in any respect. þing, which is þe seid halowing of þe satirdaie, is ceesid, al is ceesid and bindiþ not which was in þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaunde∣ment; euen as, for þat al is ceesid which was in þe oþire seid comaundement of halowing þe first daie of þe vije monþe, al þilk comaundement is ceesid, and bindiþ not.

Confirmacioun herto is þis: If it myȝt be seid and holde The old com∣mandment to hallow the Saturday is no more binding than the old commandments to hallow the fifteenth day of the seventh month, &c. þat þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in moyses tablis now is
and bindiþ, folewiþ to be seid and holde þat ech comaunde∣ment in þe lawe of moyses forto halowe eny daie ȝeerli in eny monþe of þe ȝeere, abidiþ now and bindiþ. ȝhe, and bi lijk skile ech comaundement in þe lawe of moyses forto fast ȝeerly in certey[n] MS. certey. daies of þe monþe abidiþ now and bindiþ, which is tauȝt to be vntrewe bi poul in his epistle to galathies, Especially chap. ii, vv. 16-21; chaps. iii and v. and which is aȝens oure catholik feiþ.

The iije argument into þis present principal purpos is þis: (3) The whole of a simple thing (i. e. of a thing formed of one thing only) ceases, if that thing of which it is formed ceases. Whanne euer eny þing is symple and sengle, not maad of a resonable soule, þat is to seie, not compowned and maad of dyuers parties, if eny of þo þingis in it ceesiþ, al þe hool þing ceesiþ. but so it is þat þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in moyses tablis is symple and sengle, þat is to seie, not com∣powned And the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment is formed of one thing only, viz. the hallow∣ing of the Saturday. and maad of manye or of suche seid dyuers parties, but being oon symple þing in it silf. and ȝitt sumwhat is to be seid þat ceesiþ of þe iije The Anglican Fourth. seid comaunde∣ment, as no man may seie þerto nay. Wherfore folewiþ þat alle alle, overwritten. þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. And something of the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment, viz. the hallow∣ing of the Saturday, has ceased. comaundement ceesiþ, siþen he haþ no partye which schulde ceese while his oþire party abidiþ.

Certis, if þe ije premisse of þis argument be trewe, þis Therefore, since the hallowing of the Saturday has ceased, the whole of the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment has ceased. argument proviþ vndoutabli þe entent into which he con∣cludiþ. And þat þilk now seid ije premysse is trewe, y proue þus: If þe þing of þilk seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comau[n]dement MS. comaudement. in moyses tablis were maad of manye or of dyuers þingis or of dyuers parties, þei couþen and myȝten be assigned and seid which The second premise of this argument is true, and there∣fore the con∣clusion is true. þei ben or were. but, certis, no þing can be seid which was in þilk iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement oþire þan halewing of þe satirdaie. and al þilk halewing of þe satirdaie is not but oon hool þing, For nothing other than the hallowing of the Saturday forms the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment. not maad of enye oþire partye which is oþir þan halewing of þe satirdaie; no more MS. nomore. þan eny of þe oþire bifore rehercid comaundementis of halewing oþire daies in the ȝeere was maad of eny partie oþire þan þe halewing of þilk daie in þe And the hallow∣ing of the Saturday is one simple thing. ȝeere. Wherfore þe seid ije premysse is trewe. and herwiþ is trewe þat al þilke halewing of þe satirdaie is eendid, passid and ceesid. Wherfore alle þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in
moyses tablis is eendid, passid and ceesid. Or ellis I may Therefore the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment has ceased. argue þus: if þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in moyses tablis abidiþ in al, or in sum partie, þilke comaundement was maad of sum partye being a dede which was oþire þan þe halewing If the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment had not ceased, some part other than the hallowing of the Saturday would still exist. of þe satirdaie, or dede perteynyng into it, which party now abidiþ. but so it is þat þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement had noon suche party. Wherfore noon suche party of him now abidiþ.

Also into proof of þe ije premisse I may argue þus: No But no such other part exists. þing is maad of a general and of his special sett to þilk Further proof that the second premise of the third argument is true: general; fforwhi no þing is more of hem boþe so sett to gider þan is þe same symple and syngle special, withoute eny composicioun of him and | of his seid general, as of ij parties. A thing made of its general and its special is the same as a thing made of its special.

As if I seie in latyn þus, 'animal homo,' in þat MS. þat þat; the second þat being underdotted to denote deletion. I seie no more MS. nomore. þan if I seid þus, 'homo.' If I seie 'a quyck body man,' I seie no more MS. nomore. þan if I seid 'a man.' 'Colour whiȝtnes' is no more MS. nomore. or oþire þan is 'whiȝtnes'; 'beest asse' is no more MS. nomore. or oþer þan is 'asse'; 'moving rennyng' is not ellis þan 'rennyng', and is not maad of moving and of rennyng, as of ij parties, and þat for as moche as moving is general to rennyng, and rennyng is special to moving. And whanne þe special is sette to his general, þe special drawiþ and streineþ þe general fro his generalte into þe specialte of þe drawer, and makiþ þe general as þere to be noon oþire þan þe same special drawer is, As logiciens knowen wel, and as resoun in þe now putte ensaumplis wel schewiþ. This first premysse in þis wise maad, y sette þerto þe ije ije, overwritten. The Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment made of its general (i. e. the hallowing of any day) and its special (i. e. the hallowing of the Saturday) is the same as the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment made of its special. premisse þus: but so it is þat if in þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comau[n]dement MS. comaudement. of moyses tablis, eny ij þingis being dedis of halowing couþen be assigned to be comaundid, þei schulden not be oþire þan þis special (þat is to seie, forto halewe þe satirdaie, with his pertynent dedis making it) and þis MS. þis is. his general (forto halewe a daie in þe weke, or forto halewe a daie or a tyme). Wher∣fore of þese tweyne, þat is to seie, of þis now seid general and of þis also spokun special sette to him, is no more, MS. nomore. neiþir oþire had, þan is þilke same special in it silf. And
þan ferþir: siþen þilk special, which is halewing of þe Therefore, since the hallowing of the Saturday has ceased, the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment has ceased. satirdaie, or to be doon in þe satirdaie, is fully eendid and. ceesid, al þilk iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement is fully eendid and ceesid.

And herbi is inproued wel þe seiyng of manye greet and This rule of the general and its special proves the fallacy of doctors, when they argue that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment is partly law of nature, and partly cere∣monial law. famose writers in þis mater: þat þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement was sumwhat of lawe of kinde, and sumwhat positive cery∣monial. ffor whi þerynne þei musten meene þat oon partye of þilk iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement was of lawe of kinde, and þe | oþire partye was positive cerymonial. And, certis, þilk partye which was lawe of kynde was not but a general such as is now here rehercid, to whom þe positive cerymonial was a special, which was þe halewing to be doon in þe satirdaie. Wherfore þei musten graunte þat of þe general and of his special putte to him was maad þe iije þing dyuers from þe special, which is vntrewe, and now bifore inprovid. Redili, bi lijk skile, alle þo doctouris and alle þat folewen hem schulden holde þat alle þe comaundementis of halewing daies in þe ȝeere, and alle þe comaundementis of fastyngis, and alle þe comaundementis of preesthode, ȝouun in þe lawe of iewis, ȝhe, and alle þe comaundementis of cerymonies þanne ȝouun, abiden now in tyme of þe new testament. fforwhi in eche of þilk comaundementis we mowe fynde sum general being of lawe of kinde, to which general is sett his special positive or cerymonial. And ȝitt ferþir: if þe iije The Anglican Fourth. seid comaundement abidiþ noon oþir wise þan abidiþ eny oþir comaundement in moyses lawe of halowing, or of fasting, or of eny oþir iudicial or cerymonye doing, forsoþe, it is ynouȝ for þe purpos which I entende vpon þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaunde∣ment, þat forto speke in verry trewe speche, wiþoute figura∣tive speche, and wiþoute vnpropre speche, þilke iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement is not and bindiþ not; ȝhe, not abidiþ or byndiþ, as bi vertu of goddis comaundement bifore maad, more þan þe comaundement for to ete þe pascal lombe, and þe comaundement forto halewe þe first daie of þe vije monþe, and þe comaundement forto not were a clooþ maad of lynne and of wolle, and þe comaundement forto not eere londe wiþ an hors and asse couplid to gider, abiden now and binden.

If eny man wole blundre ferþir in þis mater, as summe If only the thing signified by the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment remains the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment itself does not remain. doon, forto seie and holde þat þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis abidiþ now in þe þing and dede signified bi þilk comaun∣dement, Certis, if he meene and seie þat þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement abidiþ noon oþir wise þan in þe þing which was signified bi it, he grauntiþ myn entent. fforwhi he in so seiyng meeneþ þat oonli þe þing which was signified bi þe comaundement abidiþ, And if oonli þerof þe þing signified abidiþ, certis, þe maundement abidiþ not After not, the MS. has forwhi aȝen∣warde if þe maundement abidiþ · not; forwhi ... not being underdotted to denote deletion.; forwhi aȝenward, if þe maundement abode, it were trewe þat not oonly þe þing signified abode.

Also no þing abidiþ as for þe abiding of anoþer þing, but And the thing signified by the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is neither the whole thing, nor any part of the thing commanded by the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment. if þe oþire þing be it fully, or a party of it. but so it is þat þe þing signified is not þe hool þing comaundid in moyses tablis, neiþir is eny party of it, as is open ynouȝ. Wherfore folewiþ þat MS. þat as. bi þe abiding of þe þing signified, neiþir abidiþ þe hool þing which was comaundid, neiþir eny party of it comaundid. And forto graunte þis is forto graunte þat Therefore the abiding of the thing signified by the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment does not mean that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment itself remains. treuli and verrily and formali to speke, þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaunde∣ment is not, and þat to it we ben not bounde. fforsoþe, if we schulden graunte and holde þat noes schip is now and abidiþ, in propir maner of speche, for þat þe þing which noes schip signified abidiþ now and is, we were wondirly auisid. The fact that the thing signified by the Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment may remain, does not mean that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment re∣mains; any more than Noah's ship remains, because the thing signified by it remains. And þerfore I aske of þee: whi grauntist þou not, wiþoute significative speche, which is not to oure present purpos, þat noes schip is, siþen þe þing signified bi it is? þou mayst not ȝeue oþer cause þan þis: for þat þe þing signified bi noes schip is not þe hool schip in it silf and in his being, neiþir is eny partye of it. Wherfore bi lijk skile, siþen þe þing or dede signified bi þe halewing of þe satirdaie is not þilke halewing in it silf, or in his being, neiþir is þe maunde∣ment þerof, neiþir is eny party of þilke halowing or of þilke maundement, þou ouȝtist feele and holde þat þe seid halowing of þe satirdaie, as it was comaundid, is not, neiþir þe comaundement þerof is; | þouȝ þe þing which was signified þerbi be now and is.

DIV3.HEAD: [xe chapitre].
DIV3.P: [F]Erþirmore, þouȝ it were trewe þat þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. Even if it be granted, for the sake of argu∣ment, that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment has two parts, one natural law, and one ceremonial law, yet the whole Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment has ceased, and is no longer binding. comaundement in moyses tablis had two parties, oon moral in lawe of kynde, and anoþir positive cerymonial, which is now bifore proued to be vntrew Pt. II, chap. ix, p. 152. Cf. what is said on this subject in Pt. II, chap. vi, pp. 128 ff.; ȝitt I schal proue þat þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement is not now, neiþir byndiþ now, ȝhe, þat þilke iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement is reuokid, ȝhe, and forbode to cristen men, aftir teching of seynt poul in his epistle to galathies. Especially chaps. ii. 16-21, iii, v.

And herto I argue þus: No þing, namelich not hauyng A thing made of two parts lasts no longer as a whole than one of those two parts. lijf, which is maad of two parties to gider had and abiding, dureþ lengir tyme þan his boþe parties duren with him; but whanne euer eny of þo ij parties ceesiþ to be, þe hool þing of hem booþ maad ceesiþ to be: as, siþen an house is maad E. g. a house, made of walls and roof, lasts no longer as a house than the walls or the roof. of þe wallis and of þe roof, it may not be seid þat þe house duryþ lenger þan whilis with him booþ þe wallis and þe roof duren. And also soone as þe roof, which is oon party of þe house, abiding þe wallis, is takun aweie, so soone it is to be seid þat þilk house dureth no lengir. but so it is þat þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement in moyses tablis was maad of ij The Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment, even if it had two parts, would last no longer than one of those parts. parties, The hypothesis that it is made of two parts has been proved untenable. See above, l. 5, and note 2. afore rehercid in þe vj chapitre of þe ij party; of which ij parties þe oon is reuokid bi cristis lawe, ȝhe, and forboden to cristen men bi cristis lawe, as it is þere afore in þe seid vj chapitre allegid. Wherfore nedis folewiþ þat it is to be seid þat þilke iije The Anglican Fourth. hool comaundement of moyses tablis is not now; but þilk hool comaundement in his ful hoolnes is reuokid, ȝhe, and forboden. þis purpos may be confermed For the one part is not the whole thing made of two parts. also þus: It is neuer to be seid þat þe oonli party of a þing is þe same þing; as it is not to be seid þat þe roof only, being withoute þe wallis, is an house, or þat þe wallis oonly, And one part of the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is not the whole Third The Anglican Fourth. Commandment. E.g. the roof or the walls is not the house. being withoute þe roof, is an house. But so it is þat now, in þe tyme of þe new lawe to cristen men, abidiþ | oonly þe first party wherof þe iij The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis
was maad; and þat withoute þe secunde party, which is reuokid and brouȝt to nouȝt. Wherfore it is not to be seid þat þis first seid party is þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis. and so no man on lyue may avoide or asoile but þat þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis is not, And [þat] MS. þan. The hallowing of the Saturday is no more binding now than the laws of the Jew∣ish priesthood. it is not now to vs in charge, no more þan is now to vs in charge þe preesthode or dekenhode of þe Jewis lawe. and so folewiþ þat þe glorifying of þilk tablis is lassid and dymynuschid more þan þe glorifiers in her speking know∣lechen. Certis, bi þis opinioun ȝens which I argue here, euen as þe keping of þe sabot daie in þe oolde lawe had withynne him a þing of lawe of kinde and anoþir þing posi∣tive cerimonyal, as is in þe vj chapitre bifore schewid pp. 128 ff. See also Part II, chap. ix, p. 152., so þe preesthode of þe oolde lawe had wiþynne him suche ij þingis. ffor whi þat þere schulde be preest forto teche and exorte þe lawe ȝouun fro god, which euer þilk lawe were, or hapened to be, ȝouun fro god, doom of resoun and þerfore lawe of kynde wole, as wel as þat men at sum while take leiser forto be contemplative, and forto preise and preie. and þat þe preestis schulden be in þis wise, or in þilk wise, araied, or in þis wise, or þilk wise, haue her bodily suste∣naunce, was pure positive and cerymonial. Wherfore, siþen þe first party of preesthode, which is moral in lawe of kynde, abidiþ now þe same in þe newe lawe as it was in þe oolde lawe, þou muste nedis graunte þat þe precept of god vpon þe oolde preesthode in þe oolde lawe abidiþ now in þe newe lawe, if þou graunte þat þe precept of god vpon þe sabot in þe oolde lawe abidiþ now in þe newe lawe. And if þou muste nedis graunte þat þe precept of god vpon þe oolde preesthode is not now, for so it is seid, ad hebreos, þe vije chapitre, v. 12. where | it is seid in sentence þus: þat 'nedis muste þe oolde lawe be translatid and chaungid', siþen or whilis þe oolde preesthode is translatid and chaungid', þou must nedis folewingli seie and graunte þat þe precept of god vpon þe oolde sabot is not now. And þan ferþir þus: þe Therefore the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment on the hallowing of the Sabbath is no longer bind∣ing. precept of god vpon þe oolde sabot is not now, and þe pre∣cept
of god vpon þe oolde sabot is not ellis þan þe iije The Anglican Fourth. precept conteyned in moyses tablis; it folewiþ nedis þat þe iije The Anglican Fourth. precept conteyned in moyses tablis is not now.

In lijk maner may ful strong argument be maad þat þe If the hallowing of the Saturday is still binding, then the old ceremonial laws for praying and fasting are still binding. precept of god in þe oolde lawe, þat men schulden preie in such a certeyn MS. certeyn a. cerymonial maner, and þat þei schulden faste in certeyn cerimonial maners, abiden ȝitt in þe newe lawe, if it is to be grauntid þat þe oolde precept of halowing tyme in a certeyn cerimonial maner abidiþ now.

Also ferþer þus: siþen þe iije The Anglican Fourth. precept of moyses tablis If we do not hal∣low the Saturday, we do not keep the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment, how∣ever well we may hallow the Sunday. lymytith and byndith into a certeyn special daie to be wekely halowid, which is þe satirdaie, it folewiþ nedis þat þilk iije The Anglican Fourth. precept is not kept of vs, but if we halowe wekely þe satir∣daie, how euer weel we halowe þe sundaie in stide of it.

Now alle suche men whiche dare not truste to doom of St. Augustine teaches that the Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is not binding for Christians, though they should take heed of what it signi∣fles. resoun, where þat resoun haþ place, þouȝ þei se it as cleerly bi resoun as þei seen what is white or blacke wiþ her iȝen, I remitte into þe writing and witnessing of seynt Austyn, which is sette in þe comoun glose, The Glossa Ordinaria of Walafrid Strabo (d. 849), expounding the Scriptures, and commonly accompanying copies of the Vulgate. exodi, xxxiiij chapitre, v. 21. where he seiþ pleynly þat þis comaundement of moyses tablis, which is of þe halidaie, is not comaundement to cristen men, þouȝ alle þe oþire ix be comaundementis to cristen men; but cristen men schulde take hede to þe þing which þilk comaundement maad to þe Jewis bitokeneþ mystily, þat is forto haue mynde of þe euerlastyng blisse to come, and to be had of cristen men in heuen.

And redili, if aftir seynt Austyn þere, þe seid comaunde∣ment, The Third The Anglican Fourth. Com∣mandment is forbidden to Christian men. | which ȝe rekene here to be þe iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement of moyses tablis, is eendid and ceesid wiþ þe state of Jewis, and is not bede to cristen men (And open it is to clerkis þat alle þo comaundementis ȝouun to Jewis, which ceesen with þe ceesing of Jewis state, ben forboden to cristen men, as is open, actis, xv chapitre, vv. 24-9. And bi poul in his epistle to gala∣thies) Especially chaps. ii. 16-21, iii, v.; it folewiþ þat not oonly þe seid iije The Anglican Fourth. comaundement
ceesiþ, and is no comaundement to cristen men, but also þat it is forboden to cristen men.

Manye oþire fantastik fyndingis and feynyngis ben ren∣nyng It is false to assert that in the First Table of Moses were the first three The first four of the Anglican reckon∣ing. com∣mandments, dealing with our duty towards God; and in the Second Table of Moses were the other seven The last six of the Anglican reckoning. dealing with our duty towards our neighbour. vpon þese tablis, of whiche summe ben good to be rehercid into þe abatyng and discumfityng of her ouer moche glorifiers. þe comune holding of suche newe seid glorifiers is þat þilk tablis weren so disposid þat in þe first of hem weren writen þe MS. þre þe. þre MS. þre þe. first The first four of the Anglican reckon∣ing. comaundementis, and in þe ije table weren writen þe vij The last six of the Anglican reckoning. oþire; as þat þese two tablis weren so wiseli disposid bi god him silf þat in þe first of hem schulde be conteynyd þo comaundementis which dressen vs toward god immediatly, and in þe ije table schulde be conteynyd þo comaundementis which dressen vs toward oure neiȝbore immediatli. And ȝitt, whanne al þis is seid, and so solempnely prechid, writen and denouncid, þe contrarye is founden trewe bi experience. ffor þe same Moses distinctly says there were five command∣ments in each table. two tablis of stoon which moyses had in þe mount of synay, haue ben openli and certeynli seen and redde þat of þo x comaundementis v weren in þe first table writen, and v weren in þe ij table writen, as reherciþ þe maistir of stories Petrus Comestor (d. 1178), author of the Historia Scholastica, dealing with sacred history from the Creation down to the events recorded in the Acts—'unde per excellentiam Magister historiae scholasticae appellatus est.' See Migne, Patrologiae Cursus Completus, tom. 198,—Historia scholastica eruditissimi viri Magistri Petri Comestoris, pp. 1051-2. vpon þe xx chapitre of exodi. Also þilk same comaundement Doctors disagree as to whether what Pecock terms the 'first' commandment is one or two; and as to whether what Pecock terms the 'ninth' and 'tenth' com∣mandments are one or two. which aftir austyn is not but oon and þe first comaunde∣ment, origene seiþ and holdiþ þat it is tweyn; and þilk tweyn last comaundementis which austyn seiþ to be tweyn, origene seiþ to be oon. Neuerþeles Josophus, a ful worþy, witty and myȝty Jewe, lyuyng in | þe tyme of crist and of þe distroiyng of Jerusalem, writiþ þat he sawe þe boþe tablis, and þat v comaundementis weren in þe oon, and v in þe oþire, And þat þilk tweyn last which we rekenen for tweyn, weren not but oon; and þilk which we rekenen as for oon and þe first, was tweyne. See Notes; also p. 118, note 5.

Also if þei bere god on honde þat bi greet avise and greet
wisdom he so wiseli disposid, as þei seien, þe ij tablis, þat in If one table deals with our duty towards God, and the other table with our duty towards our neighbour, there is no pro∣vision for our duty towards ourselves. þe first ben þo comaundementis which rewlen vs toward god immediatly, and in þe secunde table ben þo comaunde∣mentis which rewlen vs toward oure neiȝbore immediatly, where is þe wijse disposicioun of god þat in þese ij tablis ben comaundementis rewling a man toward him silf immedi∣atly? siþen ful greet hardnes bifalliþ to a man forto reule him silf dewly to him silf aȝens glotonye, leccherye, veyn glorye and inpacience, See above, p. 105, note 3. And god biddiþ vs ful eernestly to avoide glotenye MS. glotonye, seemingly altered to glotenye., veyn glorye and inpacience, as he biddiþ vs to auoide fals witnesse and coueiting of oure neiȝboris good. Or ellis if þou seie þat þe comaundementis forbeding glotenye, veynglorye, inpacience, ben conteyned in þe seid ij tablis, þanne folewiþ þe contrarye to her owne seingis; fforwhi þanne folewiþ þat þe first table serueþ not oonly forto dresse vs toward god immediatly, and þe secunde serviþ not oonly forto dresse vs towarde oure neiȝboris immediatly; fforwhi boþe of hem, or oon of hem, seruyþ also to rewle vs toward vs silf immediatly. And so bi skile of þilk ij dressingis, god myȝt not be movid resonabli and sufficiently to make oonly two tablis.

And so, sone, þou maist se þat manye þingis ben feynid aboute þe x comaundementis of moyses tablis, which ben not trewe, or at þe leest which ben lacking her groundingis; and alle þat lacken her groundingis ouȝten to be taken as feynyngis and wilful forgingis.

DIV3.HEAD: [xje chapitre]
DIV3.P: | [B]Ut, o fadir, oon þing I wolde wite in þis mater: ffor Why did God] give the Ten Commandments to the Jews, if they are in∣sufficient? what entent ȝaue god to þe iewis þilk foorme of x comaunde∣mentis in moyses tablis, siþen it is so þat þilk foorme is not sufficient doctryne of alle hise comaundementis, neiþir suffi∣cient reportacioun and sufficient remembraunce of alle hise comaundementis, þouȝ þei be ouȝwhere ellis fully leerned?

Sone, I myȝt aske of þee aȝenwarde whi þe apostlis, or One might ask also why the Apostles made the Creed, if its doctrine is in∣sufficient. ellis whi prelatis of þe chirche aftir þe tyme of þe apostlis, foormeden þe comoun crede of articlis of bileeue and bitoken
it to þe peple, siþen þilk foorme of articlis is not sufficient doctryne of alle articlis and poyntis of þe feiþ, which boþe symple men and bettir leerned men ben bounden openly to bileeue? Certis, sone, loke what answere þou schuldist ȝeue to myn now moued questioun to þee, and a MS. alijk. lijk MS. alijk. answere ouȝte be ȝouun to þi questioun now mouid to me and askid of me.

Neuerþeles, for þilk answere to þese boþe questiouns to When nourish∣ment has been long withheld, the stomach must be accus∣tomed to it gradually. Similarly the eyes must be accustomed gradually to the light. gidere, I may procede and seie þus: A wombe which haþ be long tyme fro mete may not sodeinly be replenischid, withoute greet hurte and vnbroking of þe mete so receiuid; iȝen which han ben long tyme in derknes mowe not sodeinli come to greet and moche liȝt, withoute greet hurte of þe same iȝen; and þerfore þei must be fed wiþ litil in þe bigynnyng, til þei bi þilk litil be customed and ablid to receyue þe Christ shows the importance of adapting the teaching to the taught. grettir; as crist schewiþ and techiþ of his newe callid to him apostlis and disciplis ful fair, ful curteisely and resonabli, mathew, ix chapitre, v. 15. and luke, v chapitre, v. 34. where crist bi hise newe disciplis seid þus: 'wheþir þe sones of þe spowse mowe morne how long þe spouse is wiþ hem? soþeli, daies schulen come whanne þe spouse schal be takun aweie fro hem, and þan þei schulen faste.' And sumwhat aftir MS. ″þere ′aftir, with the marks of transposition. þere MS. ″þere ′aftir, with the marks of transposition. þus Matt. ix. 17; Luke v. 37.: 'neiþir men putten newe wyne into oolde botels, ellis þe botels ben broken and þe wyne [is sched].'
There is a gap here. A new gathering, of six leaves only, instead of the usual ten, begins at this point, and probably the two outer double leaves are missing. The catchword, 'is sched', fol. 76b, does not correspond with the first words of fol. 77a. The numbers after the 'signature' letter are cut off, so unfortunately give no help here. The sense does not run on consecu∣tively, and the matter is different. Before the gap, the Father is speaking of Christ's adaptation of the teaching to the taught. After the gap, the Son is advising the Father not to cast his pearls before swine.
For collation of MS. and discussion of gaps, see Introd., Section I, a.

| and experiencis which I haue had in oþire maters þan is The Son advises the Father not to cast his pearls before swine. þis. it were good ȝou forto in þis mater be stille, namelich for, as it seemeþ, crist meened and counseilide suche dis∣crecioun to be had, mathew, vij chapitre, v. 6. whanne he seid þus: 'Nil ȝe ȝeue holy þing to houndis, neiþir caste ȝe ȝoure margaritis bifore swyn, leest perauenture þei diffoulen hem wiþ her feete, and þe houndis be turned, and al to tere you.'

O, sone, if I haue bi strengþe of resoun noon oþire hope To God all things are possible, and, with His help. Pecock hopes to turn the people from their slavish adher∣ence to old and insufficient teaching. þan þat þe peple were aȝens þis purposed mater so obstynat and so vnouercomable and vnaȝendressabli hardid as þou in þyn arguyng pretendist, I wolde and ouȝte in þis mater to holde me stylle and cloose. but, for as moche as bi certeyn evidencis I haue hope of þe bettir side and of þe gracioser lott, þerfore I am movid þus, if þe peple be so vndisposid þat þei louen so vndiscreetly her oold wones and derknessis more þan liȝt; ȝitt if þei be not vnrecouerabli dressable, þouȝ to so redresse happily longiþ sum labour, it is þe more nede forto labore þat þei come from þens oute, in happis þat god wole sette to his honde and worche in hem what is not in my power to wirche; ffor whi crist seiþ, luk, xviij chapitre v. 27.: 'what is impossible anentis men is possible anentis god'; and mark, in þe x chapitre v. 27.: 'Alle þingis ben possible at god'; And also poule seiþ, ad Romanos, ix chapitre, v. 16. þat 'helþe or saluacioun is not of a MS. awiller. willer, MS. awiller. neiþir of a renner, but of god a rewer, or of mercy a doer'. And þerfore my part and deel I ouȝte to wirche, and what longiþ to me in þis mater I wole do, whilis in me restiþ þis seid hope. And al þe remenaunt I schal bitake and commytte to god, þat he þerynne do as his lust is. But þis dare I wel seie: who euer wole holde þe contrarye of þis party, which party in þis present purpos I holde, aftir þat he haþ herd and conceyued þe euidencis making for my party, and wole not avowe and warante forto assoile þe euidencis which I haue brouȝt forþ | for my party, he may not excuse him but þat he is in þat obstynat to resoun, to liȝt, and to trouþe, and more froward þan longiþ to eny resonable cristen man to be, and þat he loueþ more derkenes þan liȝt. And þerfore asoile he cleerly
þe seid euidencis þat I may consente to him; or ellis if he may not hem cleerli assoile, consente he to me, or ellis knowleche he him silf to be such as he is.

fferþirmore, o my sone, I may not leeue vnconsiderid and And to explain to them how the Four Tables com∣prise all God's laws. vntobeþouȝtvpon MS. vnto be þouȝt vpon. how worschipful, how fair, how honest and according it were to alle cristen peple, namelich to clerkis, and speciali to clerkis of dyuynite, forto haue and knowe a ful foorme at þe leest vpon alle þe biddingis and forbodis of god to man, and endentid MS. ententid, altered to endentid. bitwixe god and man; And if a fuller foorme be had of hem vpon alle þe vij maters named bifore in þe iiije chapitre of þe bifore going first party, in which vij maters is comprehendid oure cristen religioun, bi whos keping cristen men schulen be trewe cristen and trewe seruauntis of god, and schulen enherite perpetualy þe kingdom of heuen, moche more according honest[e] MS. honest. and fairenes is þerbi had to þe seid cristen men, and specialy to alle in dyuynite leerned men; And ellis contrary inhoneste, schame and reprove may be dradde forto be dewe to hem. wherfore, or þe fynding of þis foorme of iiij tablis, ȝhe, þe fynding and þe tracyng of þis foorme of vij maters, as it is ladde forþ in my writingis, muste be founde, had and allowid of cristen clerkis, namelich of dyuyne clerkis, or summe oþire foorme like to þis, or bettir þan þis is, nameliche for greet wittid and leerned lay men, or at þe leest for clerkis of dyuynite. and ellis I can not witte but þat þe scole of dyuynite schal ligge lengir in an inconuenient, of which it were biseemyng þat it schulde be cleene and free; and | moche swete deuocioun and ful moche honest occupacioun and fair laboure of mennys wittis aboute god, hise benefetis, and hise lawis, schal be lette falle and lost; and þo same wittis schulen be bisette aboute fleischly and worldly occupaciouns more þan nede askiþ, and þerbi schulen be brouȝte forþ manye nedis aboute þe worlde, which ellis schulde not growe into suche nedis, as I touche in oþire writingis.

DIV3.HEAD: [xije chapitre] The numbering of this chapter should probably be xii. Cf. below, p. 164, note 2, and p. 171, note 2.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, bi weie of leernyng I myȝte argue aȝens ȝou þus: If the Ten Com∣mandments are insufficient, why did Christ com∣mand the rich man, if he de∣sired eternal life, to obey them? It is writen, mathew, xixe chapitre vv. 16-19., and in luk, xviije chapitre vv. 18-20., þat 'oon ryche prynce came to Jesu, and seid to him: 'Good maistir, what schal I do þat I haue euerlastyng lijf?' And Jesus answerid þus: 'If þou wolte entre to lijf, kepe þou þe comaundementis'. he seid to Jesus þus: 'which comaundementis?' And Jesus seid: 'þou schalt not do mansleyng. þou schalt not do avoutry. þou schalt not do þeft. þou schalt not seie fals witnessing. worschip þou þi fadir and þi modir. and þou schalt loue þi neiȝbore as þi silf.' and lijk sentence of þe same story is luk, xviij chapitre. vv. 18-20. Now I argue þus: þis man which came to Jesus askid of Jesus a sufficient foorme of lyuing, and a sufficient foorme of alle goddis comaundementis, as is open ynouȝ; fforwhi noon gouernaunce bringiþ a man to heuen saue þilk gouer∣naunce which is sufficient. And Jesus remyttid and sent þis man oonli into þe foorme of þe x comaundementis tauȝt in moyses tablis. wherfore folewiþ þat Jesus answerid not þis man sufficientli to þis mannys entent, and so Jesus deludid or disceyuid þis man so asking; or ellis þe foorme of moyses tablis into which Jesus sente þis MS. senteþis. man was sufficient foorme for þis mannys entent, which entent was to haue a sufficient reule of lyuing, which reule may not be sufficient, withoute sufficient doctrine of alle goddis comaundementis.

Sone, forto answere herto, I denye | and seie nay to it Christ bade the rich man keep all God's com∣mandments, not simply those of Moses' tables. what þou seist, þat Jesus sente þis man into moyses tablis oonly, whan he seid to him þus: 'If þou wolte entre into lijf, kepe þou þe comaundementis'; fforwhi Jesus sente him into euery where where goddis comaundementis weren writen. and siþen goddis comaundementis weren writen at þat tyme in manye oþire placis of þe lawe in þilk tyme rennyng þan in moyses tablis, and manye mo and oþire comaundementis weren in oþire placis of þe lawe writen þan in moyses tablis,
þerfore crist sente þilk man into alle þe writingis of goddis lawe which at þilk tyme weren writen. And þouȝ crist rehercid to him summe of moyses tablis oonli, ȝitt it folewiþ not þerof þat crist vndirstode þat þilke man schulde go to moyses tablis oonli; no more MS. nomore. þan folewiþ, See Notes. if crist had rehercid oonly to him summe certeyn comaundementis oute of moyses tablis oonly, and not eny of hem which ben in moyses tablis, but in deutronomij, þe vj chapitre vv. 5, 13-18. (as he did, mathew, xxij chapitre vv. 37-40., and mark, xij chapitre vv. 28-33., to anoþir man, a techer of þe lawe, lijk questioun asking) it folewiþ not See Notes. þat þis man ouȝte not go into moyses tablis, but oonli into þilk placis examplid and rehercid of crist. And so, my sone, is pleyn solucioun to þin argument.

Lo, sone, how to þilk man, a techer of þe lawe, asking, Christ bade the lawyer keep cer∣tain command∣ments other than those of Moses' law. mathew, xxij chapitre vv. 37-40., and mark, xije chapitre vv. 28-33., which was þe greet comaundement, and which was þe first comaunde∣ment of goddis lawe, crist answerid not bi eny þing sett and founden in moyses tablis, but bi oon þing which is writun, deutronomij, vj chapitre v. 5., and bi anoþir þing which is writen in lawe of kynde in þe tablis of mannys herte, as may be seen to þe reders in þe placis now seid, mathew, xxij chapitre vv. 37-40., and mark, xij chapitre vv. 28-33.. fforwhi þe answere of crist in þe placis now allegid, mathew, xxij chapitre vv. 37-40., and mark, xij chapitre vv. 28-33., to þe man asking of crist, 'which is þe greet comaundement in þe lawe?', was þis: 'þou schalt loue þi lorde god of al þin herte, of al þi soule, and in al þy mynde. þis is þe grettist and first comaundement. þe secunde, for∣soþe, is lijk | to þis: þou schalt loue þi neiȝbore as þi silf. In þese ij comaundementis, al lawe hangiþ and prophetis.' Certis, sone, neuerneiþir of of repeated in MS. þese ij comaundementis is in moyses tablis, as is open bi þe skile maad afore in þe iiije chapitre of þis secunde party. And marke þou weel also, sone, þat þis doctoure of lawe, temptyng and asking crist, askid not þus: 'which is þe greet comaundement in moyses tablis?' but: 'which is þe greet comaundement in þe lawe?', þat is to seie, in þe hool lawe, which was at þilk tyme
writen, and of whiche he was a doctoure; And þerfore crist, answering to him, answerid not bi moyses tablis, but bi þe hool lawe in þilk tyme writen. ffor crist answerid bi what was writun in deutronomij, vje chapitre v. 5., as to þe greet and first comaundement, and ellis he had not answerid euen and riȝtli, and metely to þe questioun. and he puttid to what was writun in lawe of resoun in þe tablis of oure herte, and in oure lawe of kinde, as to þe secunde maundement.

how may þan eny man seie þat god entendid bi ȝeuing of God cannot therefore have intended the Ten Command∣ments to com∣prise all His law. moyses tablis to ȝeue þe hool ful sufficient teching, leernyng, remembring and reportyng of hise comaundementis?

DIV3.HEAD: [xiije chapitre] There is a correct reference to this chapter and its matter, p. 16, l. 35. For numbering of chapters after chap. xiii, see Introd., Section I, A, where the question of gaps is discussed.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, anoþir argument I make aȝens al ȝoure doctrine, Does not Christ teach that Chari∣ty comprises all the command∣ments of God? which argument is þis: Crist seid, mathew, xxije chapitre v. 40., þat 'in þo ij comaundementis', þat is to seie, in comaunde∣mentis of loue to god and of loue to oure neiȝboure, 'hangen al þe lawe and prophetis'; And so who euer fulfilliþ and kepiþ charite, which is þe now seid ij comaundementis, he fulfilliþ and kepiþ treuli al þe lawe of god. Wherfore it folewiþ þat teching, leernyng and remembring of charite, or of þese two now seid comaundementis, is sufficient for al teching, leerning and remembring of goddis lawe to parfitly fulfille it, wiþoute eny teching of eny oþire moral vertues or pointis or moral vertuose dedis, so long afore tauȝt in þe iiij seid tablis. And so þe teching of alle oþire moral vertues If so, the teach∣ing of all other moral virtues is vain. or pointis | or moral vertuose dedis is waast and in veyn.

Also seint poul, Ia corinthies, xiij chapitre vv. 4-8., Noumbriþ xvj condiciouns or propirtees of charite, seiyng þus: 'Charite And does not St. Paul, by his rehearsal of the sixteen proper∣ties of Charity, teach that Chari∣ty includes all the necessary moral virtues? is pacient. it is benyngne. charite envieþ not. it doiþ not wickidly. it is not blowen. it is not coueitose. it sekiþ not þo þingis þat ben his owen. it is not stirid to wraþe. it þenkiþ not yuel. it ioieþ not on wickidnes; but ioieþ to gider to trouþe. it suffriþ alle þingis. it bileeueþ alle
þingis. it hopiþ alle þingis. it susteyneþ alle þingis. charite falleþ neuer doun, wheþir prophecies schulen be voidid, eiþir langagis schulen ceese, eiþir science schal be distroied.' þus moche seiþ poul þere. And if charite be so myȝty þat he haþ þese now rehercid xvj condiciouns, bi which her contrarie vicis ben excludid, bi lijk skile he haþ wiþ þese manye mo good MS. "condiciouns 'good, the oblique dashes denoting transposition. condiciouns MS. "condiciouns 'good, the oblique dashes denoting transposition., ȝhe, and alle þo good condiciouns bi which eny moral vices in þe worlde mowe be excludid. wherfore it seemeþ þat þe leernyng and knowing of charite aloone is sufficient leerning of þe lawe of god, and þe hauing of charite is sufficient hauyng of þe lawe of god, and þe fulfilling of charite is þe sufficient fulfilling of þe lawe of god. And so þe leerning of alle oþire moral vertues or pointis or moral vertuose dedis, bi iiij long tablis, and bi long treticis and bokis þerupon writen, is in waast and in veyn.

Sone, how euer it be of þe mater of þin argument, wherupon Christ command∣ed other moral virtues besides Charity; there∣fore Charity does not comprise all the command∣monts of God. soone aftir I schal make processe, ȝitt now þat þin argument bindiþ not, and þat it procediþ not in his proof, may liȝtli be schewid. ffor whi if bi cause in charite hangiþ al þe lawe keping and alle þe moral vertues, with alle moral vertuose dedis, þerfore myn afore maad teching and treting of oþire moral vertues in special, and her propre foormes wiþ moral vertuose dedis, schulde be waast and in veyn, bi þe same skile it schulde folewe þus, bi cause þat in charite hangiþ al þe lawe keping and alle moral vertues, with alle | moral vertuose dedis, þerfore cristis teching and treting of oþire moral vertues in special and in her propre foormes, or of oþire moral vertuose dedis, whanne he seid, mathew, xix chapitre vv. 18-19., 'þou schalt do no mansleyng, þou schalt do noon avoutrie, þou schalt do no þeft, þou schalt seie no fals wit∣nessing, þou schalt worschip þi fadir and þi modir', was waast and in veyn. but þis wolte þou not graunte of cristis doctrine maad vpon oþire moral vertues in special, or vpon moral vertuose dedis which ben not charite, þouȝ þei hangen in charite and comen oute of charite. wherfore bi lijk skile
þou ouȝtist not graunte of my doctrine maad vpon alle oþire moral vertues in special, wiþ alle oþire moral vertu[ose] MS. vertues. dedis, þat it is waast and in veyn, þouȝ alle þilke vertues and oþire moral vertuose dedis bi me so in special tauȝte hangen in charite, and oute of charite þei comen, riȝt as þe moral vertues or moral vertuose dedis which crist tauȝt in special vndir charite hangen in charite and oute of charite þei comen. so is schewid þat þin argument concludiþ not, and prouiþ not þi purpos.

Also, sone, I may schewe how þat oute of cristis wordis, Did not Christ mean that on the two command∣ments of Charity all the moral virtues of the law and the prophets are de∣pendent? mathew, xxij chapitre, v. 40. now allegid for þin entent, folewiþ euen þe contrarye of þin entent. fforwhi what me[n]ed MS. meved. crist whanne he seid so: 'in þese ij comaundementis of charite hangiþ alle lawe and prophetis'? me[n]ede MS. meuede. not he þus: þat in þilk two comaundementis of charite hangen alle þe moral vertues or poyntis or moral vertuose dedis of þe lawe and alle þe moral techingis of profetis?
Ȝhis, fadir, I may not seie þerto nay; for I can not wite Apparently He did so mean. what ellis crist schulde þerto meene.

Sone, þan I argue þus: If in charite hangen alle moral Therefore these moral virtues dependent on Charity are worthy to be taught by Pecock, as they were certainly taught by the prophets. vertues or pointis or moral vertuose dedis of þe lawe and alle þe moral techingis of profetis, it folewiþ þat þe profetis tauȝten þo pointis or moral vertuose dedis which hangen in cha∣rite, and comen forþ from charite, bisidis þat þei tauȝten also charite. And if þe profetis tauȝten þe seid moral vertuose dedis or pointis of þe lawe hanging in charite, bisidis þat þei tauȝten þe same charite, and ȝitt þei were not þerfore blamed, but commendid, whi schulde I be blamed if I [teche] Omitted in MS. Omission mark in text after I, and a cross in the margin. þe pointis and moral vertuose dedis of þe iiij tablis, for þat þei hangen in charite, or þouȝ þat þei hangen in charite?

Also I may argue þus: If in charite hange alle þe oþire moral vertuose dedis, pointis and moral vertues of þe lawe, And the moral virtuous deeds and the moral virtues depen∣dent on Charity are not Charity itself. þei ben different fro charite, bicause no þing hangiþ of him silf neiþir comeþ oute fro him silf. and þan I aske þis: wheþir þese moral vertuose dedis or pointis and moral Therefore no man should be blamed for teach∣ing the moral virtuous deeds and moral vir∣tues dependent on Charity. vertues ben worþi and necessarye to be writun, tauȝt or
leerned, or no? If þei be so worþi and necessarye to be writun, tauȝt and leerned, whi schulde eny man be blamed to write hem, to teche hem and leerne hem? fforwhi for writing, teching and leerning of necessarie þingis, a man ouȝte be preisid, allowid, rewardid and commendid. And if þese moral vertuose dedis, pointis and vertues so hanging in charite ben not necessarye and worþi to be writun, tauȝt and leerned, what commendacioun maad crist of charite forto seie þat in charite hangen alle þese vertues and pointis and moral vertuose dedis? Certis, noon oþire þan þis commen∣dacioun, þat in charite hangen þo þingis which ben not worþ to be writun, leerned or seen. And so, sone, þou maist see þat þe same wordis of crist which þou tokist to founde þi party, founden þe contrarye of þi partye. And so þou and alle oþire of þi opinioun ben ouer þrowen wiþ ȝoure owne swenge.

Neuerþeles, for cleer declaracioun of þin argumentis mater, Christ did not assert that Charity com∣prised all moral virtues and all moral virtuous deeds, or all the teaching of the law and the prophets. for as moche as manye men stumblen þeryn, and han þis wrong opinioun which þou were now aboute to prove, þat charite of which crist spekiþ is al moral vertu and al þe lawe of god in propre maner of speking, and þat bi occasioun y-takun to hem of cristis wordis now afore | leggid, mathew, xxij chapitre v. 40., it is of þe and of alle such men to be takun hede and to be vndirstonden þat crist seid not þus: 'charite is alle moral vertues and alle moral vertuose dedis,' or þat 'charite is al þe lawe and al þe teching of profetis,' for þanne he had seid a speche which is wrong. And þat þis is For if so, it would follow that Charity is each moral vir∣tue and each moral virtuous deed naturally or morally. trewe I proue þus: If charite schulde be alle moral vertues and alle maner of moral vertuose dedis, and eche of hem formaly and in propre maner of speche, þis muste be trewe in þis maner: þat charite is naturali, þat is to seie, in gendre of kynde, eche of hem propirly; or ellis þat charite is moraly, þat is to seie, in gendre of moralte or of maners, eche of hem propirly.

þe first of þese ij maners may not be seid and holde; Charity is not each moral vir∣tuous deed na∣turally. For moral virtuous outward bodily deeds (both means and exe∣cutions) are not Charity, because Charity is an in∣ward spiritual deed of well-willing. fforwhi whanne I ete or drynk or write or walke or sleepe for goddis sake, þese ben moral vertuose dedis and dedis of
þe lawe and techingis of profetis, and ȝitt noon of þese dedis is loue to god, ffor whi þe loue or charite which I haue to god is a goostli dede sitting withynne forþ in my wil and in my soule, And þese now seid vertuose dedis ben bodili dedis, appering and sitting withoute forþ in my body and in my membris, and eting and drynking sittiþ in my mouþe and teeþ, writing in my honde and fyngris, and walking in my leggis; wherfore þere may no witty man seie þan þat þei ben charite or loue in it silf naturaly and propirly. þis argu∣ment procediþ vpon ech dede which is meene into þe inwarde willing which is charite, and vpon eche dede which is execucioun of þe inwarde willing being charite. and open it is þat noon of þese ben in hem silf naturali, formaly and propirli charite, as noon of hem is so withynforþ a willing MS. awilling. of good, which is charite and loue.

Also, not oonly þese now seid sensible dedis being execu∣ciouns, And nillings of evil to God, our∣selves, and our neighbour, and forbearings of evil to God, our∣selves, and our neighbour, are moral virtuous deeds, but not Charity. and oþire sensible dedis being meenys into þe inward inuisible and insensible charite, ben moral vertuose dedis; but also nyllingis of yuelis, with whiche | we nyllen yuel to god, to vs silf and to oure neiȝboris, ben moral vertuose dedis or dedis of vertu; and forberingis of yuel outward doingis to god, to vs silf and to oure neiȝboris, and also forberingis So MS. See Notes. of noon willingis So MS. See Notes. of þe same yuelis to god, to vs silf and to oure neiȝboris, ben moral vertuose dedis or dedis of vertu; and ȝitt noon of þese is naturaly, formaly and propirli charite, fforwhi noon of þese is so a willing MS. awilling. of good to god, to vs silf or to MS. orto. oure neiȝboris. wherfore nouȝwhere nyȝ alle moral vertuose dedis or dedis of vertu ben charite or charitees naturaly or formaly, and in verri propre maner of speche.

þat þe secunde maner of seiyng may not be holde, y proue Nor is Charity each moral vir∣tuous deed morally. For no outward bodily moral virtuous deed—either in its means or its execution—is morally Charity, unless it has the same moral vir∣tue as Charity. þus: Siþen it is so þat charite is a loue MS. aloue. or a willing of good to god or to MS. orto. sum oþire persoone for god, accordingli to doom of resoun or of feiþ, noon of þese oþire now bifore spokun vertuose dedis, which ben þese meenys into loue, and execuciouns of loue, and nyllingis of yuel to a persoone, and meenys into þo nyllingis and execuciouns of þo nyllingis,
may be morali charite or loue or willing of good to a persoone, but if it were trewe þat eche of þo dedis, as þei ben dedis of moral vertu, han þe same moral goodnes which haþ þe loue or þe charite or þe willing of good comaunding þese oþire dedis to be do; and so but if it were trewe þat þei han noon And unless it has no other moral virtue than has Charity. And unless the same accordance to Reason or Faith is in the outward deed as in the inward willing. oþire moral vertuosenes but þe same which þe seid willing or loue haþ; And þat for as moche as moral goodnes and moral vertuosenes is not ellis þan accordaunce of a dede to þe doom of resoun or of feiþ, and þat oon and þe same accordaunce schulde be in þe inner willing and in þe outwarde dede comaundid to be bi þilk willing.

and þouȝ þis were trewe, ȝitt þe oþer seid þing schulde But it is not true that all outward moral virtuous deeds have the same moral vir∣tue as Charity, or no other moral virtue than has Chari∣ty; even if it were true that they have the same accord∣ance to Reason or Faith. not be trewe: þat noon of þo dedis were eny oþire moral vertu þan is loue or charite or þe seid willing of good, and þat ech of hem is þe same moral vertu and þe same vertu in kinde of moralte with þe seid loue or charite. fforwhi þouȝ þe same | whitnes were to gider in a stoon and in a stok, ȝitt it were not trewe þat þis white stoon is þis white stok. And so in lijk maner in þis case, þis out∣warde dede of my drynking according to þe doom of resoun or of feiþ and for god, is not þe inwarde dede of loue or of charite or of willing good to my silf according to þe doom of resoun or of feiþ, for god; þouȝ oon and þe same in noumbre moral goodnes were in þe seid outward and in þe seid inwarde dedis.

But more forto seie in þis mater: It is not oon and þe And the outward deed cannot have the same accordance to Reason or Faith as the inward deed; though it may have a like accordance. same accordingnes to þe doom of resoun or of feiþ which is in þe outwarde dede, and which is in þe inward dede comaunding þe outwarde dede to be doon; ȝhe, it is im∣possible bi kinde þat eny oon and þe same accordingnes in noumbre schulde be in eny ij dedis except myracle. but it muste nedis be þat in euery ij dedis according to þe doom of resoun, be ij accordingnessis, And þat how manye dedis according be, so manye accordingnessis be, and þat eche of þo dedis haue his owne propre accordingnes; þouȝ, certis, þo accordingnessis ben euen lijk, as þe boþe whitnessis of ij eggys ben euen lijk, but þei ben not oon and þe same whitnes. And þerfore for þis skile, ouer þe oþire skile here Therefore it is again proved false that an outward moral virtuous deed commanded by Charity is Chari∣ty; though it is true that the outward deed and Charity have a like moral virtuous∣ness. bifore sett, it is not trewe þat ech oþir outwarde dede of moral vertu, as
as he is a dede MS. adede. of moral vertu and a poynt of goddis lawe and seruice, is morali charite or loue or willing of good to a persoone; þouȝ eche such oþire outward dede of moral vertu be euen lijk moraly vertuose to charite, which comaundiþ him to be, and haþ euen lijk moral goodnes and euen lijk moral vertuosenes to þe moral goodnes and ver∣tuosenes of charite, How euer it be herof þat þo moral good∣nessis ben lijk greet in moralte, or no, which questioun I decide not here | now. Riȝt as in a caas a white stoon and a white MS. awhite. stok ben euen lijk white bodies, and han euen lijk whitnessis, but ȝitt þe white stok is not þe white stoon, and þat for þe stok is not þe stoon, þouȝ it were so þat oon and þe same whitnes were in boþe of hem, but, certis, also, þe whitnes of þe stok is not oon and þe same whitnes which is in þe stoon, but it is anoþer whitnes al and euen lijk—bi case And euen so it is in þis present purpos.

Neuerþeles, þouȝ þe outward execuciouns of þe moral Moral virtuous deeds of inward choosing and willing are 'charities' or 'loves', but not moral virtues, because they are not habits. vertues being wiþynforþ willingis or chesingis, and þouȝ þe outward dedis being meenys into hem be not loues or charitees formali, naturali or morali, as is now bifore proued, ȝitt ech of þo moral vertuose dedis which withynforþ be willingis and chesingis, ben loues and charitees formaly, naturaly, and moraly, þouȝ þei ben not vertues, for þat þei ben not habitis or disposiciouns into habitis; ffor whi bi ech of hem þe willer williþ to sum persoone; þat is to seie, to god or to MS. orto. him silf or to his neiȝbore, sum þing according in kinde to þilk same persoone; wherfore þe same willer, in þat [he] Omitted in MS. williþ good to þe same persoone, he in þat loueþ þe same persoone. And so ech poynt of þe ije, iije and iiije tablis writen in þe first partye of þis book, as þilk point is a vertu, or ellis a vertuose dede in þe wil withynneforþ, is a loue and a charite formaly and naturaly and moraly, þouȝ þis be not trewe of alle dedis of moral vertu which executen him, neiþir of alle dedis of moral vertu withynforþ or wiþouteforþ which ben meenys into him.

But what þerfore seid crist? certis, he seid þat in charite, All moral viru∣ous deeds depend upon Charity, because no deed is a moral virtu∣ous deed unless it is done for love. or in loue to god and to oure neiȝbore, hangen alle dedis of
moral vertu. and þis seiyng is trewe, ffor whi no dede now rehercid, neiþir eny oþir dede, is a moral vertuose dede, or a After a, MS. has moral, crossed through. dede of moral vertu, or a morali vertuose dede, but if it be doon for god finaly and endely, þat is to seie, for his sake, and for loue afore had to god, Also loue y-had toward eny persoone.
There is a gap here, in which probably chap. xiii ended, and chap. xiiii began. A new gathering begins at this point, but there is, of course, no catchword on fol. 82b, the last existing leaf of the previous gathering.
The sense does not run on consecutively, and the subject is changed. Probably the missing passage dealt, in part at least, with presumptuous and ignorant interpretation of the Scriptures in the native tongue.
For collation of MS. and discussion of gaps, see Introd., Section I, A.

DIV3.HEAD: [xiiije chapitre]?
