DIV3.P: | fro presumpcioun, and schulen be so clerid in her witt Concerning the reading of the Bible in the native tongue. þat her reding þanne in þe englisch bible schal not hurte hem silf neiþir eny oþir man.

DIV3.HEAD: [xv chapitre] On the numbering of chapters, see above, p. 171, note 2.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, how schal I fele in þis? If I se or heere, taast, Is there any sin in the sinful de∣sires engendered by the outward and inward bodily Wits? smelle, or touche wiþoute forþ, or ymagyne or biþenke with∣ynne forþ, eny þing, and þerwith anoon þere is gendrid in me a liking or a delectacioun which tysiþ and drawiþ me towarde a dede contrarye and aȝens sum poynt of þe iiij tablis, do I so soone synne, or breke I so soone þerynne þe comaundement of god?

Nai, sone, not so. ffor riȝt as resoun and wil ben þo Sin begins with the consenting of Reason and Free Will to sin∣ful desire, and not with the actual sinful de∣sires engendered by the Wits. powers of man bi which he is different from a beest, and bi which he is aboue a beest, and þerfore bi which oonly he is verri man, as is bifore seid in þe first partye of þis book, þe first chapitre, so resoun and wil ben oonly þo powers of man bi whos werkis wrouȝt in hem and bi hem in oþire powers, a man plesiþ god and displesiþ god, serviþ god and offendiþ god, And bi þe werke of noon oþire power in man, saue for as moche as þe oþire powers ben so comaundid to worche bi þe wil comaunding to hem so to do. and þanne þe moral goodnes of þilk vertu, and þe malice of þilk syne so wrouȝt, sittiþ placid and is MS. his. receivid, propirly to seie MS. seie or., princi∣paly and first in þe wil, and not principaly and first in þe siȝt or in þe heering or in þe ymaginacioun or mynde, or in her appetitis so wirching at þe comaundement of þe wil, neiþer in þe likingis of hem, neiþir in þe bodily membris, as in þe iȝe, þe honde, tung or foot; as herof large doctrine is ȝouun in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', in þe more book, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. tretice, and in 'þe folewer to þe donet'. Pt. I, chap. xxv.

And þerfore, sone, leerne þou þat synne is gendrid in The stages by which sin is en∣gendered: a man bi þis processe: þyne iȝe seeþ, or þe eere heeriþ, or þe ymaginacioun ymagineþ, or resoun biþenkiþ and vndir∣stondip
a þing; vpon which siȝt, heering, ymagynyng, bi∣þenking (1) A sinful de∣sire in the lower appetites is pro∣duced by some outward or in∣ward temptation to the Wits or to Reason. Neither this temptation nor this desire is sin. or vndirston∣ding, anoon a lust to an vnleeful dede floweþ into þe appetite of þe same power so worching. Certis, if þis worching in eny of þese seid powers and [þis] MS. þus. lust be not afore chosen of þe wil avisidly, þat is to seie, bi avisement and deliberacioun bifore had in þe resoun þat it be in þis now seid wise wrouȝt and lustid, þis worching is not synne, neiþir þe seid lust and delite folewing vpon MS. vpoon, the second o being under∣dotted to denote deletion. þe same worching is MS. is not; not being crossed through and underdotted. synne. ffor it is callid þe 'first moving', and it comeþ not ȝitt to resoun and to wil; but it holdiþ him silf bineþe ȝitt in þe bestial partye of man, þat is to seie, bineþe resoun and wil, and in þilke powers oonly in which beestis and we accorden, and þerfore it is no synne.

þanne ferþir, aftir þis, happili resoun haþ a sodeyn blusch (2) A sinful de∣sire is produced in the Will, which is a pas∣sion, and not a sin. of knowing þerof, but ȝitt wiþoute avising and wiþoute iuge∣ment wheþir it ouȝt to be do, or no. And þerwiþ happily smytiþ in a lust and a a overwritten. delectacioun in þe wil, which is not ellis þan a passioun or a moving of þe wil, and not a choice of þe wil, and þerfore not a dede of þe wil, which dede is clepid 'willing' or 'nylling', 'chesing' or 'refusing'. and, certis, al þis while ȝitt is not synne doon, namelich synne of þe ije maner, wherof it is spokun in þis same ije partye, in þe ije partye of þe xixe A correct reference only if chap. xix is rightly so numbered in the margin, and if a chapter heading is missing in Pt. II. See above, p. 171, note 2, and Introd., Sec∣tion I, A, for discussion of gaps. chapitre.

Aftir al þis, resoun takiþ consideracioun in avising wheþir (3) The wilful choice of sin, after Reason has pronounced it sin. This is sin. þe dede wherto þis lust in þe louȝer appetitis and þe lust in þe wil drawen, is to be do, or no, and wheþir it is aȝens goddis lawe, or no. and aftir þat resoun haþ ȝouun doom bi deliberacioun and avisement þat þilke dede [is] From the margin; MS. it, overdotted, and the is in the margin correspondingly overdotted. not to be doon, or is aȝens goddis lawe, if þanne þe wil chesiþ it to be doon, and þat bi a dede or a worching of þe wil, which dede is clepid a 'willing', MS. awilling. þanne first is brouȝt forþ synne, and þat in þe wil. ffor þilk seid willing or chesing in þe wil,
born vpon þe seid vnleful outwarde dede or in∣warde dede to be doon, is þe synne. And þanne, if þe wil comaunde to þe tung to speke þe same answering to þe same willing, or to þe honde to touche answeringli to þe same willing, or to MS. orto. bete answeringli to þe same willing, ȝitt noon of þe outwarde dedis were, or schulde be, synful in hem silf, if ne were þe synfulnes which sittiþ in þe seid willing sitting in þe wil.

and, eer þan suche avisement be had vpon þe dede inwarde A second sin committed dur∣ing some sin which hinders the judgement of Reason is sin, even though Reason has not been in a condi∣tion to judge and consent to this second sin. or outward doable, wheþir it be good or badde, and eer þat þe sentence be ȝouun in resoun þat it is badde, and eer þat þe wil chesiþ it, not wiþstonding þe seid iugement of resoun deemeþ it to be not doon, is not synne ydoon of man; in lasse þan þe man, aȝens ful avisement bifore had, dooþ a þing. which wole lette him to haue resonable auising aboute þe ije dede in tyme whanne þilke dede profriþ him silf to be doon, and al þis þe man in þe same while wel knowiþ—as it fariþ with þilk man þat wole wityngly make him silf drunke, witing wel þat þilk drunkenes wole lette him to haue deliberacioun and avisement þat leccherye is aȝens resoun and goddis wil, whanne þilk dede of leccherye wole profre him silf to þe same man to be doon whanne he schal be drunke. Certis, in þis case, þouȝ he do leccherie in his drunkenes, withoute such avisement as is now seid þat þe dede of leccherye is aȝens goddis lawe, and þat for it is not as for þanne in his drunkenes or madnes forto so avise and considere, þe same dede of leccherye schal be to him synne; And þat bi vertu of þilk avising in resoun bi which he kuewe bifore þat, if he made him drunke, he schulde putte him in suche plite þat he schulde lese þe vse of his resoun whanne he schulde haue nede to it. And as I hope, sone, bi þis processe of þe wel leernyd, and bi þi good witt sett þerto forto iuge in | casis aftir lijk iugement which is seid in caasis of þis same processe, þou schalt deeme in alle casis whanne synne is doon, and whanne not.

To þe sentence of þis afore going processe ben to be referrid The teaching of Scripture on the processes by which sin is en∣gendered. and to be brouȝte þe wordis of James in his epistle, þe first chapitre, vv. 14-15. þat þo wordis ben deuly vndirstonden, whanne he
seiþ þere þus: 'Ech man is temptid, drawen and stirid of his owne coueiting or lust. aftirward lust, whanne it haþ conceiuid, bringiþ forþ synne. but synne, whanne it is fulfillid, gendriþ deeþ.' And also answeringli to þe sentence of þe same processe, is to be vndirstonde what is seid in moyses tablis, exodi, xxti chapitre v. 17., whanne it is seid þus: 'þou schalt not coueit þi neiȝboris wijf, not his house', etcetera; And also what is seid, mathew, ve chapitre v. 28., þus: 'Euery man þat seeþ a womman' (þat is to seie, a wijf) 'forto coueit hir, he haþ now do avoutrie bi hir in his herte'; þouȝ, my sone, þis last text may in oþir wise be vndir∣stonde, as schal be tauȝt in 'þe filling of þe iiij tablis', þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. party, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre.

ffadir, I myȝt trowe þat þe cause whi men leenen so moche Is the slavish adherence to the Ten Command∣ments due to the fact that they are God's own words? to þe foorme of moyses tablis is for þat þe wordis and pointis þerynne writen ben goddis owne wordis, And men ben redier to receyue goddis owne wordis, þouȝ þei ben not ful, al and hool reule, þanne mannys wordis, þouȝ in hem be ful, al and hool reule. And also perauenture, fadir, bi cause ȝoure And is the pre∣judice against the Four Tables due to their grounds in Scripture not having been fully alleged? That the Ten Commandments are God's own words cannot be the reason for slavish adher∣ence to them, because there is the same slavish adherence to the Seven Deadly Sins, &c., which are not God's own words. teching of þe iiij tablis, wiþ al her purtenauncis; in þe first afore going party of þis book, ben not allegid in holi scrip∣ture, þerfore happily þei schulen be þe lasse sett bi.

O sone, if þe cause which þou hast now assigned were þe verry cause whi peple so avidiosely and plesauntly knytten hem to þe foorme of moyses tablis, certis, þanne wolde not þe peple knytte hem so hertily, feruently and auydiosely to þe comoun tradicioun of þe vij deedly synnes, See above, pp. 104-7. of v wittis, The five outward and the five inward bodily Wits. See Pt. I, chaps. i, vi-viii. of vij bodi∣ly werkis of mercy, and of vij goostly werkis of mercy, Cf. above, pp. 62-4, 67, 108. as þe peple now doon; ffor whi þese now last rehercid foormes ben not wordis of goddis mouþe neiþir wordis of holi scripture, excepte þis, þat a foorme of vj bodili werkis of mercy, withoute þe vije, is rehercid bi crist, mathew, xxv chapitre vv. 35-6, 42-3. See Notes to p. 108, 11, 7-9., And ȝitt þe peple receyuen alle þese now rehercid After rehercid, MS. has foomes, crossed through. foormes as tendirly as þei doon þe foorme of
moyses tablis. And þerfore, sone, þou assignest þy cause amys. but þe verry cause is þe vsage and custom of such The true cause is the long stand∣ing of the Ten Commandments, the Seven Dead∣ly Sins, &c. If the Four Tables were taught for some time, the people would adhere to them equally. attendaunce into which þe peple is brouȝt and lad þoruȝ long tyme bi her prechers and techers. And þerfore herof folewiþ þat if þoruȝ eny notable tyme þe peple schulen be brouȝt into vsage and custom bi her prechers and curatouris forto attende into þe doctryne of þe bifore tauȝt iiij tablis, þei schulen cleeue and leene to þe foorme of þe iiij tablis as moche or more þan þei cleeuen and leenen now to þe foorme of moyses tablis, and to þe oþire foormes ioyned þerto of þe vij deedly synnes, of vij werkis of mercy, of v wittis, and so forþ of oþire spokun bifore in þis present secunde party.

And as for þat þou dredist leest þe peple wole sett not bi, The foundation of the Four Tables in Holy Scripture does not come within the scope of the Donet. or wole sett þe lasse bi, al þe afore going teching of þe iiij tablis of goddis lawe in þe afore going first party, bi cause it is not þere toolde forþ and alleggid how and where her pointis and parties ben groundid in holi scripture, I answere in þis wise: whanne I purposid to make þis present litil book, I purposid to make no more þan þat which is now þe first party of þis book, for þat it schulde be a schort Either of Pt. I. profitable compendi of alle þe vij maters, whereupon rennen in lengþe þe two large parties of þe more book y-callid 'þe reule of cristen religioun,' with manye oþire bokis knytte to him, for þat men schulden haue haue repeated in MS. þe verry trewe knowing of alle þe moost party of substancial | pointis of þilk greet large bokis, and for þat þei schulde have þe more sauoure and þe esier laboure to vndirstonde þe seid greet bokis, whanne þei schulde come to leerne hem. And, sone, aftir Or of Pt. II. þe eende of þis seid first partye, I was moved forto make ferþer þis which is MS. "now 'is, with the marks signi∣fying transposition. now MS. "now 'is, with the marks signi∣fying transposition. þis present ije partye, for a defen∣sorye and an excusatorye and sumwhat a declaratorye See Notes. of þe oþir first seid party. And aftir al þis I was movid ferþir for goode causis to make þe book which is now 'þe folewer to þe donet'. And so it myȝt not stonde wiþ myn entent to make allegeaunce and accordaunce of scripture to so manye pointis as I haue schortli and compendioseli in þe
first partye of þis book afore rehercid, no more MS. nomore. þan it mai stonde to gider forto be greet and litil, longe and schort, diffuse and compendiose. And þerfore, þouȝ I brynge not a greet book into a tretice, þe see into a cuppe, or a moun∣teyn into an ynche, alle men muste holde me excusid.

who so wole se not oonly how ech poynt of þe seid iiij Where the foun∣dation of the Four Tables in Holy Scripture is taught. tablis is witnessid in holi scripture, but also þat ful moche holy scripture spekiþ of hem, boþe in þe oolde testament and in þe newe, namelich aftir litteral vndirstonding of scripture, bi cause þat mystik vndirstondingis maken noon profis or eny sufficient witnessing of eny poynt, go he into þe book clepid 'þe witnessing of þe iiij tablis'. And ȝitt, for as moche as þe seid book, clepid 'þe witnessing of þe iiij tablis', muste be ful longe, and, perauenture, ouer costiose to pore men, þerfore an oþir lasse compendiose book, clepid 'þe prouoker', [or] or, a correction from the margin: MS. of, overdotted; the or on the margin being correspondingly overdotted. 'þe forþ caller of cristen men', is maad into þe esement of pore men, wherynne ech poynt of þe iiij seid tablis of goddis lawe schal be bi scripture at þe leest oonys y-wit∣nessid in general; and anoþir book is maad, clepid 'þe book of leernyng', in which is witnessid bi holy scrip∣ture in greet lengþe þe first poynt of þe first table. and þus moche as for treting of moyses tablis.

DIV3.HEAD: [xvje chapitre] On the numbering of chapters, see above, p. 171, note 2.
DIV3.P:
[F]Adir, siþen amonge comaundementis of god summe Why are God's forbiddings not taught in the Four Tables of Part I? ben biddingis or preceptis, as þese: 'þou schalt loue god aboue al þing; þou schalt loue þi neiȝbore as þi silf; þou schalt worschip þi fadir and modir'; and summe ben forbodis or prohibiciouns, as þese: 'þou schalt slee no man; þou schalt not stele; þou schalt not bere fals witnesse', whi techen ȝe not in þe iiij tablis bi ȝou bifore in þe first party of þis book displaied, comaundis of goddis forbodis conteynyd in moyses tablis, as ȝe techen þere comaundis of goddis biddingis conteynyd in moyses tablis? It myȝt seeme to
summe men þerfore þat ȝe techen not in þo tablis alle goddis comaundementis conteynyd in moyses tablis.

Sone, if al it were trewe [whiche] whiche, an addition from the margin; mark of omission in text before haþ. haþ be holden and If the teaching of the Church is true, that every vice is the con∣trary of a virtue, then God's for∣biddings are sufficiently taught in the Four Tables in that His biddings are there suffici∣ently taught. writen fro eldist daies of þe chirche hidirto of moral vice and synne, whi al moral vice is yuel, and wherof al moral vice takiþ his yuelnes, And þat al moral vice so takiþ of moral vertu contrarye, I myȝte to þi douȝt answere þus: þere is no forbode in þe worlde [ne] Omitted in MS., which is slightly ough at this point. eny comaundement [of] of, a correction from the margin: MS. or, with superior stroke and dot, the of of the margin having corresponding superior stroke and dot. forbode, saaf bi strengþe of a bidding contrarye which bifore is a comaundement, and oute of which bidding þilk forbode haþ al wherbi and wherfore he is a forbode, and in which bidding is conteynyd al wherbi and wherfore þilk forbode is worþi to be a comaundement of forbode; and if þilk bidding were not afore, MS. a fore. þilk forbode is [not] not, an addition reconstructed from the n of the margin, the ot being cut away. Superior stroke and dash is in text, and superior stroke over n on margin. worþi to be a comaunde∣ment of forbode; and if þilk bidding were not afore, þilk forbode hadde not eny þing or cause in him silf whi he ouȝte be a comaundement of forbode. And þerfore herof folewiþ þat if I teche in þe iiij seid tablis alle goddis biddingis, and ech of hise biddingis, certis, þanne I teche in hem alle hise forbodis or | hise forbedyngis, ȝhe, and ech of hise forbedingis, bettir þan if I tauȝt eny of hise forbedingis bi him silf, wiþoute þe teching of þe bidding oute of which bidding þilk forbeding comeþ and takiþ his strengþe of forbeding. and so in Examples of for∣biddings taught through bid∣dings. þis þat I teche withynne þo iiij tablis þat oon god is and no mo, MS. nomo. and þat I ouȝte loue him with al myn herte aboue alle creaturis, I teche also þat I ouȝte not haue alien goddis; ȝhe, bettir [þan] MS. þat. If I tauȝt þis bi him silf, 'þou schalt not haue alien goddis', wiþoute þe oþir affirmative bidding now afore seid of hauyng oon god oonly, þat is to seie, being withoute eny mo goddis; And in þis þat I teche, 'whanne euer eny man schal bere witnesse, he schal bere trewe witnesse', I teche þat he schal not bere fals witnesse; ȝhe, and bettir þan if I schulde
teche þus, 'þou schalt bere no fals witnesse', withoute þe affirmative bidding now bifore seid of trewe witnesse beryng; And in þis þat I teche þus, 'Ech man schal suffre his neiȝ∣bore to haue and reioice his owne bodily and worldly goodis pesibily', I teche þat no man schal sle his neiȝbore, or mayme or hurte hise neiȝboris body, and þat no man schal coveite or schal take hise neiȝboris wijf, seruaunt, beest, or eny oþir of his worldli or bodili goodis; ȝhe, and bettir þan if I schulde teche þe now seid forbedingis withoute þe now seid affirmative bidding, to suffre eche man to haue al his owne good pesibily. and so bi lijk skile it is to be feelid of alle oþire goddis forbedingis, þat þei ben bettir tauȝt in affirmative biddingis þan if þei ben tauȝt in her owne foormes of forbedingis oonly, and þat þei ben sufficientli tauȝt in þe seid biddingis oute of which biddingis þe forbedingis comen and taken her strengþe of forbeding. And bi þis answere, sone, is þi questioun assoilid.

Neuerþelees, þat my now maad answere be trewe and not Otherwise it would follow that God did not forbid our dishonouring our parents, and did not for∣bid the Jews to break their Sabbath laws. feyned, I schal assaie to proue bi ij skilis: Oon is bi mark taking of goddis teching, | and þat in þis wise: if myn answere now maad were not trewe, it wolde folewe þat god forbade not in þe tablis of moyses a man to disworschipe his fadir and modir, and also þat god forbade not to þe iewis in þe tablis of moyses hem to breke her sabot day, but if it be seid þat in þis bidding þat a man schulde worschipe his fadir and modir, god forbade a man to disworschip his fadir and modir, And in þis bidding þat þe Jewe schulde kepe his sabot daie, god forbade to þe iewe him to breke his sabot daie. And if al þis be grauntid, þan is myn answere now bifore sette, wel þerbi confeermed.

Þe ije skile, and seemyng to be moche strenger, is þis: þer If the teaching of the Church is true, there is no just forbidding unless it forbid a moral vice or moral vicious deed. is no forbode iust and worþi to be a forbode, MS. aforbode. but if it renne vpon a moral vice or a moral viciose dede forboden bi þilk forbode. now so it is þat þere is no moral vice or moral viciose dede, neiþir knoweable to be suche, saue for þat he is contrarye or repugnaunt to a moral vertu or a moral And there is no moral vice or moral vicious deed, known as such, unless be∣fore there is a moral virtue or moral virtuous deed, known as such, to which that moral vice, or moral vicious deed, is contrary, through lacking the whole matter of the moral vir∣tue or moral virtuous deed, or the whole number of cir∣cumstances. vertuose dede, and knowen to be a moral MS. amoral. vertu or a moral
vertuose dede; and, for þat it is a moral vertu or and, crossed through, and or over∣written. a moral vertuose dede, þerfore and þerbi oonli þe oþire dede or dis∣posicioun haþ þat he is a moral vice or viciose. And so, erst and bifore sum disposicioun or his dede muste be a moral vertu or moral vertuose, eer to him þe contrary or þe repug∣naunt disposicioun or dede be a moral vice or morali viciose; and þerfore, erst and bifore sum dede or disposicioun must be knowun to be a moral vertu or morali vertuose, eer to him þe repugnaunt be knowen to be a moral vice or morali viciose; fforwhi þere is no dede or disposicioun a vice saue oonly for defaute or lacking of þe hool dewe mater, or of þe hool noumbre of circumstauncis wherbi, if þei were had, he schulde be a moral vertu or morali vertuose [dede], Superior stroke and dot to denote some omission before as in text, and correspond∣ing superior stroke and dot, and also a cross, in margin. as schal appere in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun' in latyn, whos processe muste nedis be cleer∣li knowun eer what is now seid here be cleerly knowun, þouȝ it be neuerþelasse trew in it silf. And eche man mai wel wite þat þe defaute or lackyng of eny circumstaunce; is not but aftir in kynde to þe hauing of þilk circumstaunce; neiþir þilk lacking is knowable saue bi þe knowing of þe hauing of þe same circumstaunce. as Examples. pouerte mai not be knowun what it is, and þerfore mai not be tauȝt or leerned what it is, but if ricchenes or ricchete be bifore knowun and be bifore tauȝt or leerned what it is; neþir blindenes may be knowun what it is, and þerfore mai not be tauȝt or leerned what it is, but if siȝtnes or siȝte MS. siȝtite. be bifore knowun, tauȝt or leerned what he is. wherfore folewiþ þat þere is no vice assignable but eer and bifore to him þere is a moral vertu assignable, bi lacking of whos circumstaunce þis vice is in it silf a vice, and is knowable to be a vice.

and þanne ferþir þus: how euer tymeli eny such moral And, therefore, with the bidding of a moral vir∣tue, follows the forbidding of a moral vice. vertu be, so tymeli is groundable vpon him [a biddyng] a biddyng, a correction from the margin; MS. abiding, with superior stroke and dot; the abiddyng of the margin with corresponding superior stroke and dot. þat he be kept. wherfore eer and bifore eny suche forbeding of a moral vice be, and eer þan eny moral vice be, goiþ a bidding MS. abidding. of a moral vertu to whom þilk vice is contrarye
or repugnaunt, And in which and bi which bidding knowun, þe forbeding of þilk vice is knoweable, And withoute which bidding knowun, þilk forbeding of þe vice is not knowun. And if al þis be trewe, þan folewith sufficientli and openly ynouȝ þat in þe bidding of a moral vertu is sufficientli in∣cludid þe forbeding of þe repugnaunt to him moral vice; ȝhe, and bettir þan if þe vice were forboden bi it silf, withoute þe bidding of þe vertu to which þe same vice is repugnaunt or contrarye. More treting of þis mater, wheþir ech negative trewþe hangiþ vpon affirmative trewþe or affirmative trewþis, must be deferrid for his hard∣nes into 'þe book of making of creaturis in general' or into 'þe book of questyouns' in latyn.

Also þoruȝ oute þis present chapitre and in manye oþire It must be noted that, so far, vice 'contrary' to virtue has been used in a wide sense, to signify not only vice logically con∣trary to virtue, but also vice op∣posed privative∣ly and contra∣dictorily to vir∣tue. placis of After of, MS. has w, crossed through. my writingis, whanne I speke of 'contrariete' bitwix vice and vertu, I vndirstonde not in streitist and proprist maner of contrariete, but in general or in large maner, as what euer þing is aȝenstonding anoþir þing, wheþir it be bi streitly takun contrariete, or bi priuacioun of it, or bi contradiccioun to it, in þat and so be callid 'contrarie' to it. See Notes; also above, p. 106. Cf. Folewer, Pt. I, chaps. xv and xvi.

Lo, sone, þis is þe answere which myȝt be ȝouun to þi The aforesaid teaching of the Church is true only as regards vice opposed privatively to virtue, which is known to be vice through former know∣ledge of the virtue. doute mouid in þe bigynnyng of þis present chapitre, if þe groundis of þis answere which ben rehercid þoruȝ þis present chapitre, which han be holde fro tyme of greet antiquite hidirto moche solemply, MS. solempnely; ne being crossed through and underdotted. weren trewe. But, certis, þei ben not trewe, as schal appere in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun' to be maad in latyn. ffor þouȝ moral vice or synne which stondiþ aȝens moral vertu priuativeli, as bi priuing or forbering þe dede of vertu in it silf, or bi priuyng þe dewe mater wherupon goiþ þe dede of vertu, or bi priuyng eny notable circumstaunce of þe vertu, is such þat he takiþ his malice in a biholdyng to þilk vertu aȝens which he so stondiþ priuatively, and þerfore is knowun to be suche a vice bi biholding into þilk vertu; ȝitt þis [is] is, an addition from the margin, the is there having superior stroke and dot corre∣sponding to superior stroke and dot de∣noting omission before not in text. not like trewe of
vice and synne which stondiþ aȝens vertu in pure contrariete, Vice strictly con∣trary to virtue is, on its own principles, ad∣judged to be vice by Reason, without regard to its contrary virtue. as for þat he is a disposicioun or habit mere contrarye to þe disposicioun or habit of vertu, or for þat he goiþ vpon mater contrarye to þe mater of þe vertu, or for þat he takiþ a notable circumstaunce contrarye to þe notable circumstaunce of þe vertu; ffor whi ech such vice haþ his malice in him silf bi biholding into þe doom of resoun, as for þat resoun is demyng him forto be a willing of natural yuel to sum per∣soone, or sum execucioun of such a willing, MS. awilling. or a dede being | meene into such willing; Euen as þe contrarye vertu is good and haþ his goodnes in him silf bi a biholding into þe doom of resoun, as for þat resoun deemeþ it to be a willing of natural good to a persoone, or an execucioun of such a willing, or a dede being meene into such a willing; And like wise of viciose nyllingis being contrarye to vertuose nyllingis. Wher∣fore suche moral vicis being meere contrarye to moral vertues mowe be knowe bi her owne pryncipalis and groundis, wiþ∣oute dependence into þe knowing of þe contrarye vertues, and withoute a biholding MS. abiholding. into þe moral vertues to which þei ben contrarye; lijk as þei ben moral vicis in her owne affirmative being, bi her owne principlis and groundis of being, withoute biholding into þe moral vertues to which þo vicis ben contrarye, as to be dependent in being fro þo vertues.

So þanne, my sone, I leue þe answer which I haue made Hence a previous knowledge of moral virtues helps one to know the vices strictly contrary to them. And a previous know∣ledge of moral virtues is neces∣sary before one can know the vices opposed privatively to them. in þis present chapitre to þi doute, and I answere þus: who euer schal knowe moral vertues fulli or sufficientli, he is in a weie wherbi he schal soone aftir, if he wole, knowe þe moral vicis which stonden aȝens þe vertues contrariosely, and þat liȝtly and esily, bi what he schal se soone aftir in þe doom of resoun. And so þe knowing of moral vertues is good weie into þe knowing of þe moral vicis being to hem contrarye. And þat þe knowing of moral vertues is þe weie bi which oonli, and bi noon oþir weie, ben knowun þe moral vicis which stonden aȝens moral vertues priuativeli, is open ynouȝ bi philosophie. wherfore it is trewe þat vicis forboden mowe be knowe wel aftir þat her MS. "contrarye, her, with the marks signifying transposition. contrarye MS. "contrarye, her' with the marks signifying transposition. vertues beden be
knowe, and þat þe knowing of þo vertues schulen be occa∣siouns into þe soone to be had knowing of þo vicis forboden. And þis is ynouȝ for answer here. Certis, if þe groundis which ben rehercid in þis present chapitre schulden be vndir∣stonde oonly of suche vicis being priuatively aȝens moral vertues, þo groundes | were trewe. but þanne þei were ouer narowe and scant forto ȝeue a sufficientli large answer into al þi douȝt, which goiþ and passiþ vpon moral vicis contrarye to moral vertues as vpon moral vicis priuatively stonding aȝens moral vertues. But þan if eny man wole aske whi bifore þis last answer I wolde putte þe oþir former answer, which I deeme now to be vnsufficient, It myȝt seeme þat bettir it had be forto haue lete bi þilk first answer vn∣spokun, siþen he is vntrewe or vnsufficient. herto I answere and seie þat herfor I puttid forþ þe former answer: þat men schulden be warned þat he and his groundis ben not trewe of al maner moral vicis, þouȝ of long tyme passid þei han be holden for so trewe. What is more to be seid in þis mater I hope schal be write in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun' in latyn.

DIV3.HEAD: [xvije chapitre] On the numbering of chapters, see above, p. 171, note 2.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, siþen ȝe take vpon ȝou forto teche in þe biddingis Where in the Four Tables are forswearing and vain swearing forbidden? of þe iiij tablis ech of cristis forbedingis, I After I, MS. has aus, crossed through. aske of ȝou where and in which point wiþynne þe iiij tablis ȝe techen þe for∣bode of forswering and þe forbode of ydil swering?
Sone, for cleer answer to þis questioun, þou schalt vndir∣stonde In answer to this question three truths must be under∣stood: iij trouþis:

Oon is þat ech lawe of god which is to be kept and fulfillid of vs, is an habit or a disposicioun, or his dede of willing or (1) Every law of God (i. e. every moral virtue) is a habit or dis∣position, or a deed of willing or refusing, or a deed commanded by this willing or refusing, or a means towards this willing and refusing. of refusing, or a dede comaundid to be bi willing or refusing; þouȝ herwiþ it be trewe þat summe moral vertues and her dedis ben meenys into such seid willing or refusyng, siþen þo meenys ben bifore comaundid to be bi a willing MS. awilling. and a chesing in þe wil. fforwhi ech lawe of god to be kept and fulfillid of vs is a moraly good gouernaunce, And ech moraly
good gouernaunce is suche as now is rehercid; and þerfore eche lawe of god which is to be kept of vs is an habit or disposicioun, or his dede, or a worching or a gouernaunce. And mor[e] MS. mor. proof | herof schal be sett aftir in 'þe folewer to þe donet'. Pt. I, chap. xv.

Neuerþeles, sone, þou schalt herwiþ vndirstonde þat in my How the terms 'deed', 'leaving undone', &c., should be taken. writingis ful oft and moche, for schortnes of speche, I com∣prehende and conteyne withynne þe significacioun of þis worde 'dede' boþe doyng and suffring, and also refusyng of a doing or of a suffring; And also bi þis worde 'leeuyng vndo', or 'cecing', or 'vndoyng', or 'forbering', I vndir∣stonde alwey, or welnyȝ alwey, or at þe leest moche oft, a dede of þe wil which is a nylling or a refusyng, and not a noon MS. anoon. worching of þe wil oonly. and þis I wole þat þou not forȝete for eny þing.

þe ije trouþe is þis: eer þan eny habit, disposicioun, or (2) Every law of God (i. e. every moral virtue) must lack undue matter, and must have every circumstance that Reason deems it should have. his dede be a lawe of god or a moral vertu or moral vertuose, he muste lacke vndewe mater, and [muste have] muste have, an addition from the margin; muste having the superior stroke and dot corresponding to superior stroke and dot denoting omission before ech in text. ech circumstaunce which resoun wole deeme þat he haue; and ellis he is not a moral vertu or moral vertuose, and þerfore not a lawe of god and of vs to be kept, as schal be tauȝt aftir in 'þe folewer to þe donet', Pt. I, chap. xvi. and also in 'þe lasse book of cristen religioun', þe iiije trety. which circum∣stauncis ben avisosnes, eend, maner, tyme, place, oþe, vowe, helpis, and oþire such. and þei ben clepid 'circumstauncis' These 'circum∣stances' are so called because they may change while the deed remains the same. of þe dede for þat þei mowe be chaungid aboute þe dede, and ȝitt þe dede stonding þe same in him silf and in his kinde or nature vnchaungid, as schal be tauȝt aftir in 'þe folewer to þe donet', Pt. I, chap. xvi. And in þe oþire book alleggid, and in 'þe more book of cristen religioun', þe first party, þe iij trety.

The iij trouþe is þis: þe circumstaunce of a dede is not (3) The circum∣stance of a deed is not the deed itself. þe dede to whom he is sett; As, if I ȝeue an almes in money, or if I fast, with ful avisement for þis eende þat god loue me, and in þis fridaie, and in þis hospital, and wiþ vowe forto so do, or wiþ ooþe þat I wil so do, þis avisosnes is not
þe dede of fasting, neiþir is þe almes ȝeuing; neiþir þe loue of god is þe dede of fastyng or of almes ȝeuing; neiþer þe tyme neiþer | þe Before þe, MS. has þer, crossed through and underdotted. place is þe dede of fastyng [or] or, an addition from the margin, with usual superior stroke and dot; the corre∣sponding stroke and dot appearing before of in text. of almes ȝeuing; neiþer þe ooþe neiþer þe vowe which I sette to þe deede [of] of, a correction from the margin; MS. or, with usual superior stroke and dot. biheest or promysse, þat I schal so faste or ȝeue almes, is þe dede of biheest or of of, overwritten. promysse. ffor whi þe dede of þe bihest myȝt be maad stonde and be fulfillid, þouȝ þe ooþe or vowe were not sett þerto. And þerfore, siþen þe promysse, which is a dede, and þe ooþ or vowe mowe be departid, þei ben not þe oon and þe same þing.

Now, sone, if ech lawe of god is an habit, disposicioun, or Since the law of God is a habit or disposition, or deed with its circumstances, therefore where the deed is found in the Four Ta∣bles, there will also be found the circumstances. his dede bisette aboute resonabli with circumstauncis, and no þing ellis is a lawe of god þan an habit, disposicioun, or his After his, MS. has a, underdotted. dede bisette wiþ circumstauncis resonabli, and þerfore noon such circumstaunce, in as moche as it is a circumstaunce, is eny lawe of god, it muste folewe þat where euer withynne þe iiij tablis it is to be spokun of eny dede which is goddis lawe, and as he is of goddis lawe, þer it is to be spokun of þe circumstaunce which may bi resoun be sette to þe same dede, and also nouȝwher ellis [it] it, an addition from the margin, with usual superior stroke and dot; the corre∣sponding stroke and dot appearing in text before is. is to be spokun of such a circumstaunce withynne þe iiij tablis in þat þat he is a circumstaunce, saue where it is to speke of such a dede to which þilk circumstaunce is bi resoun setteable as of it a circumstaunce.

And, ferþirmore, siþen an ooþ and a vowe MS. avowe. ben not goddis Oaths and vows are circum∣stances to some deeds which are God's laws, viz. deeds of affirm∣ing, denying and promising. Therefore oaths and vows are treated in the Tables with these deeds of affirming, deny∣ing and promis∣ing. lawis, for þei ben neiþir good neiþir badde, but þei ben circumstauncis settable to summe dedis being goddis lawis, þat is to seie, to affermyngis and denyingis being goddis lawis, and to bihetingis being goddis lawis; þerfore folewiþ þat forto speke of ooþis and of vowis haþ no place in þe tablis of goddis lawe, saue oonli where it is to speke of affermyngis or denyingis or bihetingis maad to god or to man, and to which affermyngis or denyingis or biheetingis,
ooþe and vowe mowe bi doom of resoun be sett as circum∣stauncis of þe same affermyngis, denyingis, or bihetingis. And þerfore, siþen | to speke of such affeermyngis and Hence oaths and vows are treated along with Truth and Righteousness in the Four Tables. denyingis haþ no place withynne þe iiij tablis, saue in þe ve poynt of þe ij table, which is clepid 'trouþe to god', and in þe vje poynt of þe iiije table, which is clepid 'treuþe to neiȝbore', And siþen to speke of suche bihetingis or pro∣myssis haþ no place withynne þe iiij tablis, saue in þe iije point of þe ij table, which is riȝtwisnes to god, and in þe iije point of þe iiije table, which is riȝtwisnes to neiȝbore, it folewiþ þat nouȝwhere withynne þe iiij tablis it is to speke of ooþis and vowis, saue in þe now seid pointis of þe ije table and of þe iiije table; and ȝitt not þere saue as of circum∣stauncis settable sumtyme bi resoun to summe seid dedis of þo now seid pointis, þouȝ oute of þe iiij seid tablis speche and treting mowe be maad of þe seid circumstauncis bi hem silf for good causis.

þat ooþis and vowis ben not dedis being goddis lawis, Proof that oaths and vows are circumstances of a deed, and not the deed itself; and therefore are only to be treated in the Four Tables with the deed itself. neiþir ben dedis being aȝens goddis lawis, for þei ben not good neiþir badde, but ben circumstauncis to oþire dedis good or badde morali, I proue þus: If I seie þus, 'bi god', 'bi mary', 'bi seint Jame', [with]oute The with of withoute is an addition from the margin, the usual superior stroke and dot marking the omission. more, þese seiyngis ben neiþir morali good neiþir morali badde; And þerfore þo seiyngis ben not dedis being goddis lawis, neiþir being aȝens goddis lawis. And if I seie þus: 'I hard masse ȝistir∣day', 'I was in þe chirche ȝistirdaie', 'I schal heere masse to morewe', 'I schal faste in þe next frydaie comyng', in so seiyng I seie and I affeerme and I bihete dedis being goddis lawis, which ben neiþir ooþis neiþir vowis, but ben affeer∣myngis and biheestis. wherfore folewiþ nedis þat if I ioyne þe seiyngis of þe first now rehercid maner to þe seiyngis of þe ije now rehercid maner, forto seie þus: 'Bi god, I hard masse ȝistirdaie', 'bi mary, I was in þe chirche ȝistirdaie', 'bi god, I schal heere masse to morewe', 'bi seint Jame, I schal faste on fridaye next comyng', þese spechis hoolid and maad of þe ij seid maners | schulen not be ooþis, but þei schulen be affeermyngis and promissis circumstauncid wiþ
ooþis, þat is to seie, to whom ooþis ben sette. And in lijk maner it is to be seid, if vowis ben sette to affeermyngis or denyingis or to promyssis, þe hool dedis of affeermyngis or denyingis, of bihetingis and of þe vowis þerto sette, schulen be affeermyngis or denyingis or bihetingis circumstauncid with vowis þerto sette, þat is to seie, to whom vowis ben sette; euen riȝt as If I wolde holde vp a torche or a candel into testimonye whilis I affeermed or bihiȝt, lijk as Jacob rerid vp a stoon into title See above, p. 124, note 2. whilis he promisid to god. And so is schewid sumwhat, as for þis place, þat ooþis and vowis, propirli to speke of ooþis and of vowis, ben not lawis of god, neiþir aȝens lawis of god, but þei ben circumstauncis of lawis of god and of disposiciouns and of habitis and of her dedis, being vicis or viciose contrary to þe lawis of god. And þerfore of hem it is not to trete withynne þe tablis of lawis, saue wiþ þe dedis to whom ooþis and vowis ben se[t]table MS. sectable: tt frequently looks like ct in the MS., but here ct seems actually written. as circumstauncis; and þat is in þe iije and ve point of þe ije table, and in þe iije and vje poynt of þe iiije table.

Neuerþeles, þouȝ ooþis and vowis ouȝten be clepid noon Sometimes, however, the terms 'oath' and 'vow' are loosely used for the deed of affirming, deny∣ing, or promis∣ing, with the circumstances of that deed. Pecock often uses the terms in this loose sense. oþire þingis þanne suche circumstauncis now bifore spokun, ȝitt, for as moche as oft it is woned in holi scripture and oute of holi scripture forto clepe an 'ooþ', in an vnpropir maner of speche, þe al hool dede of affeermyng or denying or bi∣heeting, with þerto ioyned þe seid circumstaunce of ooþ, and also forto clepe a 'vowe', in vnpropir maner of speche, al þe hool dede of bihetyng, with þerto ioyned þe seid circum∣staunce of propirli taken vowe; þerfore to þe same vnpropir spekingis I wole in my writingis boþe here and in oþire placis oft me confoorme. And þanne folewingli I seie þat al Hence it follows that all lawful oaths and vows are allowed, and all unlawful oaths and vows are forbidden, in the Points of the Tables deal∣ing with Truth and Righteous∣ness. leeful ooþis and vowis takun in þis maner, ben allowid in þe iije and ve poynt of þe ije table, | and in þe iije and vje poynt of þe iiije table, And folewingli herto þat alle suche vnleeful ooþis and vowis ben forboden bi þe same now seid pointis, and alle ydil ooþis and vowis ben disalowid bi þe same now seid pointis. what is propirli a vowe MS. avowe. is tauȝt in 'þe filling of þe iiij tablis', in þe first party, where it is seid þat he is not þe dede of biheest to whom þe vowe is sette.

DIV3.HEAD: [xviije chapitre] On the numbering of chapters, see above, p. 171, note 2.
DIV3.P: [N]Euerþeles, sone, þou must herwith vndirstonde þat of Some circum∣stances are necessary to every virtuous deed. These are treated under one head in the Folewer, Pt. I, chap. xvi. þe seid circumstauncis longing to make dedis to be morali vertuose and morali good, summe ben of suche kinde þat bi doom of resoun þei muste be hadde to eche moral vertuose dede, and ellis he is not a moral vertuose dede: as ben avisidnes, eend, tyme, maner, place, and summe oþire. And siþen forto trete eche of þese circumstauncis in ech poynt of þe iiij tablis were ouer long and ouer oft to be spokun, þerfore of alle suche circumstauncis it is tretid vndir oon and at oonys in 'þe folewer to þe donet', in þat þat it is seid þere in þe [xvje] chapitre þat no moral vertu mai be withoute hem, but eche moral vertu muste nedis haue hem, in what euer poynt of þe iiij tablis he be assigned to be sett. And þilk teching and treting of hem alle to gedir is sufficient ynouȝ þere for to be sette for alle þe iiij tablis, þat it is no nede to trete eny of hem in þe iiij tablis singulerly to eche vertu.

Summe oþire circumstauncis longing to make dedis to be Some circum∣stances are necessary only to certain moral deeds under cer∣tain conditions. Oaths and vows are such circum∣stances. As before said, they are treated in connexion with Truth and Righteousness. morali vertuose and morali good ben of suche kinde þat bi doom of resoun þei ben not nedis to be had at eche moral vertuose dede, but at summe oonli, as at affeermingis or denyingis, or at bihetingis; and ȝitt not at eche affeermyng or denying, but [at] at, a correction on the margin: MS. a; the usual superior stroke and dot marking error. summe affeermyng and denying oonly, wiþ summe certeyn circumstauncis aboute goon and bisette, And at summe bihetingis oonly, with summe oþire circum∣stauncis aboute goon and bisette. of which secunde now seid principal soort of circumstauncis ben | ooþis and vowis. and þerfore it longiþ forto trete of ooþis and of vowis with∣ynne þe iiij tablis, where it longiþ to trete of affeermyngis and denyingis and of bihetingis, to whom ooþis and vowis ben settable circumstauncis, if sparing þerof be not maad for loue of schortnes, or for sum oþire good cause; and þat is
in þe iije and ve pointis of þe ij table, and in þe iije and vje pointis of þe iiije table.

Aftir al þis in þe bifore going maner tauȝt and declarid, Forswearing in promises to∣wards God is forbidden in connexion with Righteousness, the Third Point of the Second Table. forto now come doun into þe specialist foorme of answer to þi questioun, o my sone, movid in þe bigynnyng of þe next bifore going chapitre, I seie þus: In þe iije point of þe ij table, which is riȝtwisnes to god, it is seid and meenyd þat if and whanne eny man wole or schal bihete to god, þat he perfoorme it in fulfilling. And þerfore in þat same it is tauȝt sufficientli þat who euer wole or schal bihete to god, wiþ ooþe or vowe, or withoute ooþe or vowe, þat he perfoorme þe dede bihiȝt. And so þerynne MS. soþerynne. it is eftsoone sufficientli tauȝte þat no man euer breke his vertuose bihest maad to god, swoorn or vowid, or not swoorn neiþir vowid, ffor þanne he were not iust to god, but vniust to him. and so in þat is tauȝt þe forbeding of false promissorye ooþis or of forswering to god, and of fals vowing to god, aftir þe bifore seid comune maner of vnpropre speche vpon ooþis and vowis See above, p. 187., which vnpropre speche y now folewe. ffor, propirli to speke of ooþ and vowe, neiþir ooþ neiþir vowe is trewe or fals, neiþir makiþ formaly a þing trewe or fals, or bindiþ or vnbindiþ and freeþ; but sum tyme ooþ, sum tyme vowe, is ioyned to a speche or to a signe occupiyng þe stide of speche, which is trewe or fals, as it is bifore proued; And sum tyme ooþe, sum tyme vowe, is ioyned to a speche pro∣myssory which bifore was binding, MS. bindding, the first d underdotted. and which, bi setting MS. bisetting. to of þe ooþe or of þe vowe, is þe more binding.

And ferþirmore, | siþen bifore in þe iije poynt of þe ij Vain swearing in promises towards God is forbidden in connexion with Righteousness, the Third Point of the Second Table. table it is tauȝt, or at þe leest it is conuenient and according þere to be tauȝt, or in sum oþire writing of lijk nature to it, þat if and whanne euer a man wole or schal bihete, wiþ ooþe or vowe to god, þat he so bihete for þat he wolde be þerbi þe more remembrid and stirid to fulfille what he bihetiþ, whilis resoun wole þat he so be þe more remembrid and stirid to fulfille þe same bihest; þerfore in þilk same doctryne is sufficientli tauȝt þe forbeding of bihetingis maad to god wiþ ooþe or vowe, whanne resoun seeþ not nede in þe biheter
þat eny suche remembring or stiring meene be sette to þe biheting. And in þis ben forboden ydil ooþis and vowis, which sum man MS. summan. perauenture wolde make to god. And ferþirmore, siþen in þe same seid iije poynt it is tauȝt, or it is techeable, þat noon bihetingis be maad with ooþe or vowe to god, saue whanne it is nede or profitable or honest þat þilk mater be bihestid to god, for ellis þilk biheest lackiþ a circumstaunce which resoun in his doom requiriþ to be at þilk promys; þerfore in þat is sufficientli tauȝt þe forbode of eche biheest maad with ooþe or with vowe to god vpon maters not profitable and honest to be to god bihestid: as ben Japis, triflis, and veyn þingis, or liȝt, not chargeable þingis, or foul þingis.

þat it is aȝens resoun a man or eny pure creature forto All oaths and vows in affirm∣ing or denying to God are need∣less and un∣reasonable. affeerme or to denye eny þing to god, doon or present, wiþ ooþ or vowe, is open y-nouȝ; fforwhi þilk ooþ þerto sett schal not make god bileeue þerbi þe more þe affermer, bi cause þat god openli knowiþ bi him silf, withoute þe affermer, wheþir þe affermer seie trewe, or noo. And þat it is aȝens resoun a man to sette a vowe to an affermyng or denying maad to god vpon a þing passid or present, or vpon a þing vntrewe or vnhonest, or litil and triflose, or wiþoute nede to so set∣te, is open ynouȝ also to eche mannys resoun bi lijk skile.

Certis, to eche witty persoon reding þe processe now maad Forswearing and vain swear∣ing towards our neighbour are forbidden in connexion with Righteousness and Truth, the Third and Sixth Points of the Fourth Table. vpon it what is seid to be tauȝt in þe iije and ve pointis of þe ij table, it schal be liȝt and esy forto se and knowe þerbi how þat a mannys fals swering and his fals vowing in biheting or in affermyng to his neiȝbore, is forboden bi it what is to be tauȝt in þe iije point and in þe vje point of þe iiije table; and how þat a mannys ydil swering or vowing to his neiȝbore is forboden bi it þat is sette bifore in þe iije and vje poynt of þe iiije table. And also more forbeding þan þis now seid aboute ooþis and vowis of a man to god and to his neiȝbore mai liȝtli be knowun bi it what is seid al redi and expresseli in þe first parti of þis present book in þe now spokun tablis, and in her now spokun pointis. And þerfore
of lenger talking þer aboute here, what for schortnes, and what lest I sette þe reders þerof into werynes, I wole absteyne and forbere.

DIV3.HEAD: [xixe chapitre]. Numbered xix in margin; a correct numbering only if in Pt. II there is a chapter heading missing. See p. 171, note 2, also Introd., Section I, A, for collation of MS., gaps, and numbering of chapters.
DIV3.P: [F]Adir, I haue mynde how afore in þe ije chapitre of þe Are all the moral virtues of the Four Tables com∣mandments of God, or are some only counsels? afore going first party of þis book, pp. 15-16. ȝe tauȝte þat summe moral vertues ben comaundementis of resoun or of feiþ, and summe ben counseilis of resoun; but ȝitt it is vnknowen to me wheþir ȝe feelen þat alle þe pointis or membris þere afore tretid þoruȝ þe iiij tablis be moral vertues of comaundement, or no; ffor to MS. fforto. my symple witt it seemeþ þat summe moral It seems that Reason does not order certain moral virtuous deeds of the Four Tables to be done in a very high de∣gree, but it seems that they may be left undone in this high degree, for a lower degree will serve. Therefore in this high degree they are coun∣sels, not com∣mandments. vertuose dedis in eche of þese iiij tablis ben dedis oonli of counseil; ffor whi I may preise god, worschip god, and preie to god in so hiȝe degree of laboure in vndirstonding and in affeccioun and in lengþe of tyme þat resoun iugiþ not it so to be doon þat it may not be left vndoon; but resoun iugiþ þat, þouȝ it may be so doon as for þe bettir good, ȝitt lasse of it, or a louȝer degree of it, may be doon and be sufficient. wherfore bi ȝoure owne teching in þe seid ij chapitre pp. 15-16., whe∣re ȝe discriuen what is a comaundement and what is a counseil, þese dedis in suche now seid degrees and circumstauncis ben oonli dedis of counseil, and not of comaundement; and in For example, certain degrees of Cleanness, Honesty, &c. lijk wise mowe be assigned summe degrees or summe circum∣stauncis in þe vertues of clennes, of honeste, of pacience, of douȝtynes, of mekenes, of largenes, and of attendaunce; in which degrees or circumstauncis þese now seid vertues ben not vndir precept and comaundement, bi cause þat neiþir resoun neiþir feiþ iugiþ hem to be so doon þat þei mowe not be left vndoon, or þat her contraries mowe not be doon.

Sone, I graunte wel þat þe pointis conteynyd in þe iiij It is true that the moral virtues of the Four Tables are sometimes com∣mandments, sometimes only counsels. seid tablis, in þo maners, degrees and circumstauncis in which þei ben oftist to be doon, and of mede to be doon, ben comaundementis; Neuerþeles, summe of hem, and, as it
seemeþ to me now, eche of hem, may in suche degree of heiȝt, maner and circumstaunce be chosun bi doom of resoun þat it is not in þilk degree, maner and circumstaunce a precept or a comaundement, but oonli counseil. And in lijk maner þe counseilis rehercid afore in þe ije chapitre of þe first partye, See pp. 15-16. þouȝ þei be oonli counseilis in þilke maners and circumstauncis in which þei oftist fallen to be chosun aftir doom of resoun, ȝitt in suche maner eche of hem may be circumstancionat þat, wiþ þilk circumstaunce, it is a precept or a comaundement. of which maner of circu[m]stanciona∣cioun MS. circustancionacioun. ensaumple is sette forþ in 'þe more reule of cristen religioun', þe first party, þe iije trety, þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. chapitre. And þanne chastite, vndir þilke circumstauncis whanne it is The three great counsels—Chas∣tity, Voluntary Poverty, and Obedience—may sometimes be commandments. Their positions in this case in the Four Tables. a precept, it is in þe iiije point of þe iije table; voluntary pouerte, whanne it is a precept, it is in þe ve point of þe iije table; And obedience of oon man to anoþir, whanne it is a precept, it is in þe ije point of þe iiije table, and is a spice of attendaunce; euen riȝt as bi sum consideracioun | þei ben in þe same tablis and pointis whanne þei ben counseilis. See p. 15.

Neuerþeles, bi cause þe pointis of þese iiij tablis ben in The difference between a com∣mandment and counsel ex∣plained. þe oftir side preceptis, and in þe seelder side counseilis (except in eche of þe iij laste tablis þe laste point, which is larges, and except þe vij point of þe iij table, which is douȝtines); and aȝenwarde chastite, wilful pouerte and obedience, and summe oþire moral vertues afore in þe ije chapitre of þe afore going first partye rehercid, See p. 15. ben in þe oftir side cheseable as counseilis, and ful seelden þei fallen to be chosen as preceptis; þerfore resoun wole þat al þe afore seid pointis of þe iiij tablis (except summe now bifore exceptid) See above, ll. 23-5. schulde be callid 'preceptis' or 'comaunde∣mentis', and alle þe oþire now afore seid schulde be clepid 'counseilis'.

ffadir, is ech comaundement of god so streiȝtli bynding Is a man damned for wilfully breaking any commandment of God? þat, if a man do wittingli and willingli aȝens it in maner
and circumstancionacioun in which it is a comaundement of god, þat þilk man þerfore is dampnable?

Certis, sone, moche þing is to be seid and tauȝt aboute þe Where the full doctrine of deadly sin and venial sin is to be found. doing aweie of deedli synne, and aboute þe doing aweie of venial synne, and aboute þe difference bitwixe venial synne and deedly synne, which doctryne haþ no place to be seid in þis book here, but þerof speche and treting schal be maad in 'Þe book of cristen religioun', in þe first party, þe ije tretice, and bittir in 'þe book of penaunce' in latyn.

Neuerþelees, forto sumwhat seie here vndir myn oft maad Even for the slightest sin a man must make amends, or be forgiven by God, before he can enter into Heaven. protestaciouns, take þou þis: In lasse þan þilk gylt drawen bi breking of eny leest comaundement of god, or bi doing aȝens eny moral vertu, be forȝouun of god, or be doon aweie bi sufficient amendis for it maad to god, þilk man so agilting MS. a gilting. is to be dampned fro his blys, or ellis he is to be taried and lettid fro his blis; fforwhi no suche synne, be it neuer so litil, may be receiued into | heuen, And but if þe seid synne of þilke man were to be forȝouun, or in þe now seid maner be doon aweie, ellis he schulde entre into heuen with synne. and so herof it folewiþ þat for ech kinde of moral synne doon to god, þe doer is dampnable, in lasse þan it be to him forȝouun, or in lasse þanne he make þerfore to god a sufficient amendis; or ellis he is tariable and lettable fro heuen into tyme þilke synne be forȝouun, or into tyme þat amendis sufficient be þerfore maad.

And forto se þe bettir þis to be trewe, into tyme þou As there are degrees of sin, so there are degrees of punishment. schalt rede in þe oþire bokis now bifore named, Lo, ij en∣saumplis: þou seest þat a fadir biddiþ his childe forto in eche werke daie go to scole; and also he biddiþ him make no maner of lesing, be it neuer so litil; and he biddiþ to þe same childe þat he be no þefe; he biddiþ also þat þe childe schal slee no man, and namelich not his owne fadir, or his modir, or his briþeren. Lo, eche of þese pointis ben comaunde∣mentis or biddingis of þe fadir to þe childe, fforwhi ellis þei were oonli counseilis of þe fadir, And þanne folewiþ þat, þouȝ þe childe schulde breke hem, he schulde neiþir lasse neiþir more trespace anentis his fadir, which is vntrewe. and ȝitt bitwixe þese comaundementis or biddingis is a greet difference in gretnesse or litilnesse, and in lasse or more charging in
þe fadir so bidding; fforwhi if þe childe breke þe first now A father will voluntarily for∣give a child for a slight offence, and will punish him only slight∣ly. seid comaundement, or þe ije, oonys or twies, or oftir, or how euer oft he do so, þe fadir wole not forsake þe childe and putte him oute of his grace, housholde and heritage bi iugement; But he wole soone forȝeue it, wiþoute eny special þerfore requirid to be doon prouocacioun into mercy, or requirid amendis or satisfaccioun, and þat for biholding to oþire good gouernauncis of þe childe, or for biholding into his owne gentilnes and loue toward þe childe. And at | sum while for þat þe childe schulde be afeerde MS a feerde. to do so eftsoones, þe fadir wole chastise þe same seid MS. ″childe ′seid, with the marks of transposition. childe MS. ″childe ′seid, with the marks of transposition. bi sum [sm]al MS. final, certainly with an f at the beginning, but with signs of the stroke over the i having been erased, as if to alter in to m. peyne, according to þe quantite of þe trespase, not wiþstonding þe fadir haþ forȝouun þe trespace and kepiþ þe same childe in his oolde bifor had title and cleym to his eritage, so þat him nediþ no newe graunte. but, certis, if þe childe trespase But for a grave offence the child may be dis∣owned and dis∣inherited, unless he make suffici∣ent amends for his sin, or earnestly strive to obtain his father's mercy. aȝens þe iije or þe iiij now seid his fadris comaundementis, no wondre it were þouȝ þe fadir putte bi jugement þe childe so trespasing oute of housholde and oute of eritage, and not to haue þe title of riȝt of þe newe, but if þe sone so tres∣pasing schulde bere him silf douȝtili in vse of prouocative meenys to bowe his fadir into mercy, or but if he schulde make to him a ful iust aȝen quyting amendis.

we seen also þat an housholder, a fadir of meyne, biddiþ A master will only tempo∣rarily punish a servant for a slight offence. to his man 'do þis' and 'do þat', in manye vnnumerable tymes. of which þingis so to be doon, summe ben liȝtli chargid of þe bidder, and summe ben more chargid and at a greet force y-sette. And ȝitt alle ben hise biddingis, ffor∣whi we mowe not seie þat alle þo ben hise counseilingis, and þat for cause now sumwhat bifore sette. And ȝitt þis bidder bi resoun ouȝte not bi so stirid þat for eche trespace of his seruaunt y-doon aȝens eny of hise seid biddingis, he forsake his seruaunt, and wiþdrawe al his good maistirschipe, re∣warding and avauncing from þe seruaunt; not wiþstonding þat he muste abide and tarye ȝitt a while MS. awhile. into tyme he it for∣ȝeue, or but if he receyue for it a sufficient amendis. fforwhi ellis freendschip and indignacioun or enemyte toward þe same persoone schulden stonde to gedir in þis fadir of hous∣holde
which may not be, for þei ben contraries. but resoun wole þat þis fadir of housholde biholde into his owne curteis manhode, and into his loue which he schulde haue to his meyne, and to þe oþire | good gouernauncis which in oþire sidis his meyne paien to him, and þerbi be moued þat he forȝeue suche smale defautis anoon as þei ben doon; þouȝ at sum tyme he rebuke þe trespacers, and perauenture smyten hem softly in wey of venging, þat is to seie, forto agaste hem and oþire, it seyng to [not] not, an addition from the margin; the usual superior stroke and dot marking the omission. in lijk maner trespace eftsoone.

And euen so it is in þis purpos bitwix god and vs in hise In the same way God will volun∣tarily forgive a small sin. A somewhat greater sin He will slightly punish. For a deadly sin a man will be eternally damned, unless he earnestly strive to obtain God's mercy. comaundementis breking, þat summe of oure smale trespacis god wole forȝeue for his greet loue and gentilnes. And for summe oþire of oure smale trespacis being sumwhat grettir, god wole take a temperal vengeaunce or punyschment, forto make þis trespacer and oþire þe bettir be waar, not wiþ∣stonding þe synne þerbi is not forȝouun but bi goddis greet loue. And for summe oþire grettir synnys, which we callen 'deedli synnes', god wole assigne and juge vs into dampna∣cioun fro heuen, neuer to haue riȝt þerto aȝen withoute a newe ȝift and a newe restoryng; and ȝitt neiþir to haue it so bi a newe graunte, in lasse þan we prouoke him into mercy bi meenys afore tauȝt in þe xviij chapitre of þe first party of þis present book.

ffadir, I can not se MS. seie; the ie being crossed through. whi þe iiije counseil schulde not bi Is not partial or total abstinence in eating meat a moral virtue of counsel? sett to þese iij counseilis Viz. Chastity, Voluntary Poverty, and Obedience of one man to another, the three great Evangelical Counsels. See pp. 15, 192, and Pt. I, chap. vi. now afore tretid. fforwhi, if forber∣ing of woor[l]dly MS. woordly, with a dot after the r to mark the omission of the l. goodis in sum quantite and in sum maner, or ellis vtterly, for propirte, whanne to þe forberer is excludid greet occasioun of synnyng in coueitise, is a vertuose dede and a counseil, bi lijk skile forbering of sopers in sum quantite and in sum maner, or ellis vttirli for al and euer, or forbering of fleisch for euer, whanne to þe forberer or absteyner is excludid ful greet occasioun of leccherye and of manye wijlde recchelesnessis, þouȝ þerbi bifalle sum feblenes in þe body, or schortyng of his bodili lijf, is as a greet
vertuose dede, siþen euer eiþir dede is according to þe doom of resoun, | and bi euer eiþir dede is excludid an occasioun of synne, and grettir occasioun of synnys is not þerto knytt and anexid. And þerfore folewiþ as wel oon to be a vertu or or a, overwritten. a or a, overwritten. vertuose dede as þe oþire. And siþen resoun, which allowiþ boþe hem to be doon, deemeþ not þat þei must nedis be doon, folewiþ þat boþe ben counseilis, And namely þat, if oon of hem be a counseil, so wel is a counseil þe oþire. In And are not partial or total abstaining from certain sports and abstaining from the com∣pany of women moral virtues of counsel? lijk maner I myȝt argue þat forbering of certein sportis and myrþis of þe iȝe or of þe eere for a certeyne tyme or for euer schulde be a vertu and a counseil to hem which receyuen þerbi a greet lett fro synne; and also forbering of certeyn cumpanyes, namelich of wommen. And so manye mo coun∣seilis myȝt be noumbrid þan þese þree. And so to haue þese iij as for þe hool noumbre of counseilis seemeþ to procede bi insufficient in þis mater consideracioun.

Sone, þi resoun proueþ þi party wel, and þerfore aȝens þi It is true that there are many more moral vir∣tues of counsel than Chastity, Voluntary Poverty, and Obedience of one man to another. party as in þis I wole not seie, but I wole it graunte; And not oonli for þi skilis now maad, but also for þat I haue in mynde wel how in mathew, þe v chapitre, vv. 21 ff. in þilk place where it is seid þus: 'ȝe han herd þat it was seid to oolde men, "þou schalt not sle",' etcetera, and from þens into þe eende of þe same chapitre, crist techiþ diuers vertuose gouernauncis which ben not of þe streit comaundementis, and þerfore þei ben oonli counseilis. And þerof sumwhat is seid in general in 'þe book of cristen religioun', in þe first party, þe iij tretice, and in 'þe book of counseilis'.

DIV3.HEAD: [xxe chapitre]. See above, p. 171, note 2, and p. 191, note 1.
DIV3.P:
[F]Adir, for as moche as ȝe han maad þe first party of þis Will it not be said that the Fourth Matter, 'God's law', is sufficient for the Christian, with∣out the know∣ledge of the other six Matters? book and also ȝoure 'greet book of cristen religioun' forto renne vpon þese vij maters, þat is to seie: what god is in his owne dignitees and nobiltees, which ben hise benefetis, which ben hise punyschingis, which is | his lawe and seruice þoruȝ which he lokiþ to be serued of vs, which ben oure natural wrecchidnessis, which ben oure synful wickidnessis, and which ben remedies aȝens booþe oure natural wrecchid∣nessis
and aȝens oure synful wickidnessis; and ȝe haue maad þe ij partye of þis present book forto defende and to magnifie and sumwhat declare þe first party of þis same book; I trowe verrily þat manye men schulen detract and bacbyt ȝoure present litil book, and ȝitt moche more ȝoure grettir book, 'þe reule of cristen religioun', seiyng in þis wise: þat it sufficiþ to euery cristen lyuer for to knowe þe lawe or seruice of god into þis eende, þat he þerbi lyue holili, goostli, or sufficientli, fforwhi þerbi he schal knowe alle moral vertues of goddis comaundementis and alle vicis and synnys con∣trarye. And þese now seid vertues ben alle þat a man owith to worche, do and folewe; And þese now seid contrarye vicis and synnys ben alle þo þingis which a man owiþ to forbere, eschewe and flee. And more is þere not to be doon in a cristyn mannys good lyuing þan bowing from yuel and worching good, which is not ellis þan moral vertu, as is open in þis book afore. and al þis is in oon of þese vij maters of þese ij bookis, þat is to seie, in þe iiije mater, which is þis: which or what is goddis lawe. Wherfore it nediþ not a cristen lyuer to knowe þe oþire vj maters now afore rehercid, as forto make his good lijf to hange þerupon. And bi so moche I mai þe bettir trowe þat such as is now seid doom and jugement schal be ȝouun vpon ȝoure ij now seid bokis, bi how moche I haue herd such motryng long eer and bifore þis present daie, in which ben not ȝitt vtterli maad neiþer vtterli pupplischid ȝoure now seid ij bokis. See Introd., Section I, B.
Sone, for answer herto þou schalt vndirston∣de þat 'þe The term 'law of God' may be taken in three ways: lawe of god' is takun in iij maners:

In oon maner 'þe lawe of god' is takun as it comprehendiþ and conteynyth al þing what euer god comaundiþ to be doon, (1) Equivalent to the 'Fourth Matter', but not including the command to learn the Seven Matters. except þe bisynes to gete knowing. And in þis maner I take 'þe lawe of god' as oft as I noumbre it to be oon of þe seid vij maters, And it is þe iiije mater amonge þe seid vij. Certis, 'þe lawe of god' takun in þis maner is not sufficient To know the 'law of God' in this sense is not sufficient. to vs þat we neden not to knowe more þan þis lawe as for knowing of oure goostli helþe; fforwhi þis now seid lawe muste be kept and fulfillid, and it mai not be kept and ful∣filled
wiþoute þe knowing of þe þe overwritten in MS. vj oþire maters, as wel as not withoute þe knowing of it silf, as aftir in þis same present chapitre schal openly be proued. Wherfore folewiþ þat þe knowing of þis lawe in þe first maner y-takun [is] is, a correction on the margin; MS. it; the usual superior stroke and dot marking the error. not so ynouȝ and sufficient þat we neden not to knowe more for oure goostli helþe.

In þe ije maner 'þe lawe of god' is takun as it compre∣hendiþ (2) Equivalent to all God's commandments, including the command to learn the Seven Matters, and therefore in∣cluding the 'law of God' in the first sense. and conteynyth al þing, what euer god biddiþ to be doon, wheþir it be bisynes to leerne and knowe, or to loue, or eny oþire dede comaundid bi þe wil to be doon. And siþen god comaundiþ not oonly þe lawe now seid in þe first maner taken forto be kept and doon, but also he comaundiþ þe knowingis of alle þe vij seid maters to be doon, kept and had, as aftir in þis same present chapitre schal also openly be schewid; þerfore 'þe lawe of god' in þe ije MS. first, crossed through, and ije overwritten. maner taken After taken, the MS. has: and þe bisynes to gete, crossed through. comprehendiþ and conteyneþ 'þe lawe of god' in þe first maner taken, and þe bisynesse to gete þe knowingis of alle þe vij seid maters and of eche of hem. And in þis ije maner I schal vndirstonde and take 'þe lawe of god' as oft as I schal speke of it bi it silf, not noumbring it wiþ þe vj oþire seid maters.

In | þe iij maner 'þe lawe of god' is takun as it compre∣hendiþ (3) Equivalent to all God's commandments and counsels, and so including the 'law of God' taken in the second sense. and conteineþ al þat god biddiþ to be doon, and al þat god counseiliþ to be doon. and so 'þe lawe of god' takun in þe iije maner conteineþ generali al þe lawe in þe ije maner takun, and ouer it þe counseilis of god. which dedis þo ben þat god counseiliþ oonly, and how þei ben diuers from þe dedis which god biddiþ to be doon, þou maist sumwhat se, se, overwritten. o my sone, afore in þe first party of þis book, þe ije chapitre, and bifore in þis ije party of þis book, þe xix See above, p. 173, note 5. chapitre.

Now, sone, bi þis maad distinccioun and declaracioun of Why it is not sufficient to know only the 'law of God' in the first sense. þe iij maners of goddis lawe, þou maist esili wite how þou schalt answere to such arguers, which, as þou seist, þou hast
herd. fforwhi if [bi] bi, an addition from the margin. Mark of omission in text before her. her now afore MS. "maad 'afore, with the oblique marks denoting transposition. maad MS. "maad 'afore, with the oblique marks denoting transposition. arguyng [þei] þei, a correction on the margin; MS. þe; the usual superior stroke and dot denoting error. vndirstonden of follows in the text, but with the o underdotted to denote deletion. 'þe lawe of god' in þe first maner takun, it is fals and it is to be denyed þat it sufficiþ to euery cristen lyuer forto knowe þis lawe or þis service of god into þis eende þat he lyue þerbi holily or goostly sufficientli; And it is fals and to be denyed þat bi þis lawe schulen be knowen alle vertues of goddis comaundementis and alle vicis contrary. ffor whi god comaundiþ þe knowing or þe bisynes to gete þe knowing vpon þe first, ije, iije, ve, vje and vije seid maters, as schal be proued anoon here aftir. And þis bisynes to gete þe knowingis of þe seid vij maters is not includid and con∣teynid in þis seid lawe taken aftir þe first seid maner. Wherfore more knowing is necessarye to vs þan is þe know∣ing of þis now seid lawe takun in þe first seid maner, which lawe is þe iiije mater of þe vij.

And if þese arguers in her arguyng vndirstonden 'þe If the term 'law of God' is taken in the second or third senses, it is sufficient for a Christian to know only 'God's law'; but then this is a different thing from knowing only the 'Fourth Matter'. lawe' takun in þe ije maner or in þe iije maner, þan it is trewe þat þis lawe sufficiþ to euery cristen lyuer þat bi it he lyue go∣ostli at þe fulle, And it is to be grauntid þat bi þis lawe eche moral vertu comaundid bi god is in it con∣teyned and includid. But, certis, þan it is to be denyed þat þis lawe is þe iiije mater of þe seid vij maters, fforwhi þis lawe comprehendiþ, conteyneþ and includiþ þe seid iiije mater; And ouer it þis same lawe comprehendiþ, conteyneþ and includiþ þe bisynes to gete þe knowingis of þe iiije mater and of þe oþire vj maters. And þerfore þis lawe includiþ in sum manere The ma of manere overwritten. þe same iiije mater and þe oþire vj maters, and so is her argument assoilid.

þat 'þe lawe of god', takun in þe first maner, mai not be To know the 'law of God' in the first sense is insufficient; for it is impossible to fulfil the law of God unless we know that law, i. e. the Fourth Matter. kept and fulfillid wiþoute knowing of it silf, þat is to seie, not wiþoute knowing of þe same seid iiij mater, namelich meritorily, þankeabli and rewardabli, it nediþ not to make þerto eny proof: it is so open ynouȝ in it silf. ffor how
myȝt a lawe be kept and fulfillid meritorily, but if it were knowun?

but þat 'þe lawe of god', takun in þe first maner, mai And it is im∣possible to fulfil the law of God, unless we know the other six Matters. not be kept and fulfillid withoute knowing of þe first, ije, iije, ve, vje and vije maters, I mai prove in þis wise: Lo, sone, þese ben pointis of goddis lawe and seruice takun in þe first maner: forto loue god aboue al oþir þing, to preise god, to worschip god, to such repentaunce and penaunce do þat we falle not into hise punyschingis of þis worlde and of helle. No man mai herto seie nay, as schal be openli proued and groundid in 'þe book of repentaunce' or 'of penaunce' in latyn. but so it is þat no man mai fulfille þese now seid pointis, but if he afore knowe god, how worþi he is, which ben hise louyng greet benefetis, and which ben hise hard punyschingis. whe[r]fore MS. whefore. nedis it folewiþ who so wole kepe goddis lawe and his seruice, taken in þe first maner, he muste nedis knowe þat god | is reuerend, hiȝe, digne, good and worþy to be reuerencid, worschipid and louyd, boþe for him silf and for hise benefetis, and þat hise punyschingis mowe not be ascapid but if we do in þis lijf repentaunce and penaunce for oure synnys. fferþirmore, how schal a man drede and aȝenstonde his natural wrecchidnessis [but yf he bifore knewe his natural wrecchidnessis] but . . . wrecchidnessis, a correction on the margin; stroke and dot after the previous wrecchidnessis in text, and corre∣sponding stroke and dot over but in margin.; how schulde a man repente him of hise synnys but if he knowe his synnys; how schulde a man sette remedies aȝens hise wrecchidnessis and aȝens hise wickidnessis but if he bifore knewe þe same remedies? And ȝitt þese iij now rehercid gouernauncis ben dedis and gouernauncis of goddis seruice and of goddis lawe, bi as moche as bi þe moral vertu of clennes a man aȝenstondiþ þe natural pronitee, redynes, or wrecchidnes which wolde drawe him into glotenye and leccherye, and bi þe moral vertu of benyngnite a man aȝen stondyth his natural redynes or wrecchidnes which wolde drawe him and tempte him into wraþþe and enuye, and bi mekenes a man aȝenstondiþ his owne natural wrecchidnes drawing him towarde pride; And so forþ of eche moral
vertu in goddis lawe. Wherfore nedis folewiþ þat if a man schal kepe sufficientli goddis seruice and his lawe, he muste knowe whiche ben hise wrecchidnessis, and which ben hise wickidnessis, and which ben remedies aȝens hem boþe. how schulde a man haue greet longing desire into heuenward, how schulde he be strong and hard to suffre greet peynes in contynewaunce for heuen, and ȝitt knowe not þat þere is an heuen, or knowe not what heuen is, or what ioies ben in heuen? How schulde a man drede and fle peynes of helle, and ȝitt no þing knowe of hem? how schulde a man be stirid to loue god aboue a man him silf but if he knewe god∣dis worþines to be fer aboue mannys worþines? And þerfore I wondre how for schame eny man knowleching him silf in louȝest degree a clerk, schulde so iuge, deeme and affeerme, preche and publysch, in maner now afore MS. a fore. rehercid, þat it is no nede þat þe peple leerne and knowe [ouȝte] ouȝte, a correction from the margin; MS. oute. of þe first, ije, iije, ve, vje and vije maters.

þat god comaundiþ þe bisynessis to gete þe knowingis of Proof that God commands the knowledge of the Seven Mat∣ters, and so commands more deeds than are included in the 'law of God' taken in the first sense. þe seid vij maters, and so þat þerynne he comaundiþ in sum wise þe knowingis of þe seid vij maters, and so þat þerbi he comaundiþ mo dedis þan ben includid in 'þe lawe of god', takun in þe first maner, may be schewid þus: god biddiþ to be knowen and kept al þe lawe in þe first maner takun, as no man wole seie nai þerto. Wherfore god biddiþ alle þo oure dedis and gouernauncis to be had and doon, wiþoute which dedis and gouernauncis þe seid lawe [beden] beden, a correction on the margin; MS. bidden; the usual superior stroke and dot marking the correction. mai not be kept; riȝt as, if I bidde a man speke, in þat I muste nedis bidde him breþi, And if I bidde a man ride on myn erande, in þat nedis I bidde him lepe vpon þe hors. And þan ferþir þus: but so it is þat þe lawe in þe first maner beden may not be kept and fulfillid withoute þe knowingis of þe oþire vj seid maters, as now bifore in þis same present chapitre it is openli schewid, and not wiþoute knowing of þe iiije mater of þe vij, as is open ynouȝ. wherfore folewiþ þat god biddiþ þe bisynessis forto geete þe knowingis of þe seid vij maters. and herbi it folewiþ ferþir, which was my
purpos to proue, þat þerynne he biddiþ þe knowingis of þe same vij maters, ouer þat þat he biddiþ þe lawe taken in þe first maner to be kept and fulfillid in werke, which is þe iiije mater of þe vij.

And þan ferþir þus: how moche euer god biddiþ to be All that God commands or counsels is His 'law'. doon, or counseiliþ or [ordeyniþ] ordeyniþ, a correction on the margin; MS. denyiþ; the usual superior stroke and dot marking the correction. Before the following ordeyniþ, MS. has denyiþ, crossed through. to be doon, so moche is his lawe. And god biddiþ or ordeyniþ or counseiliþ to be doon al þat is | seid in þe ije maner and in þe iije maner of taking goddis lawe. whe[r]fore MS. whefore. folewiþ þat al þilk þing, which þing boþe in þe ije maner and also in þe iije maner is taken and assigned bi me to be clepid 'goddis lawe', is ful worþi to be so clepid 'goddis lawe'. And þus moche, sone, is ynouȝ for answer and declaracioun to þe mater of þin argument. mo obiecciouns aȝens þe conceit of þe iiij tablis of goddis lawe, with answeris to þe same obiecciouns, schulen be sette in 'þe folewer' to þis present book, See Folewer, Pt. II. which þerfore I clepe 'þe folewer to þe donet'.

DIV3.HEAD: [xxje chapitre] See above, p. 171, note 2, and p. 191, note 1.
DIV3.P:
[Ȝ]itt Small i in MS., fadir, for as moche as bifore in þe [iiije] MS. iije. chapitre The Son desires to learn a form of praising and praying. of þe first party of þis book, ȝe tauȝt þat we ouȝte at sum while preise god, and also þat we ouȝte at sum while preie to god, and to me now remembring vpon þilk now rehercid teching, it seemeþ þat, if þere were diuisid a certeyn foorme of preising and anoþer certeyn foorme of preying, it were a redy þing to eche man whanne he schulde schape him to preise and to preie, And it were a greet eese to him bi þat it schulde be to him forto boþe to gyder fynde or make his foorme of preising and of preiyng, and forto þerwiþ at oonys to vse þe same foorme of preising and of preiyng deuoutely, bi cause þe laboure of fynding is in þe resoun, and þe laboure of deuocioun is in þe 'wil, And whilis a man labouriþ strongli in þe resoun, bi so moche he schal þe lasse laboure in þe wil, And so folewingli þe swetnes of deuocioun in þe wil muste be bi so moche þe lasse, riȝt as, whilis a man
Ȝeueþ greet attent to seing wiþ hise bodili iȝen, bi so moche Þe whilis he schal þe worse heere or smelle or taast delec∣tabili; wherfore Here, as frequently, wherfore is equiva∣lent to 'therefore'. Cf. above, p. 131, l. 20., good fadir, I preie ȝoure gentilnes, dresse Ȝe me in þese two now touchid desirid foormes, þat is to seie, of preising and of preiyng, and as | for þis tyme I schal aske no more. MS. nomore.

Sone, þi schewid now desiris to haue sette forþ a foorme The Father assents to the justice of this demand. of preising and anoþir foorme to be sette for[þ] MS for. lent to 'therefore'. Cf. above, p. 131, l. 20. of preiyng ben resonable, and þerfore aȝens hem I wole not be.

As forto assigne to þe a foorme of preising, siþen preising Where forms of praising may be found. a persoone is not ellis þan a a, overwritten. declaring of a persoonys dignitee bi wordis þerof in speking, as is tauȝt in þe first party of 'þe reule of cristen religioun', in þe vije trety, And siþen so it is þat al þilk 'book of cristen religioun', þoruȝ alle hise ij parties, goiþ vpon goddis dignitees and goddis worþinessis and goodnessis, and þat in ful faire and swete and deuoute maner, þou nedist not haue a fairer, a fruytfuller, a deuouter foorme to preise god þerbi, þat is to seie, if þou wolte preise him bi rehercels of doctryne and of cleer knowing vpon goddis worþinessis and dignitees and goodnessis, þan is forto rede bi worde withouteforþ in þe seid book, 'þe reule of cristen religioun', þoruȝ eny of hise ij partyes. Neuerþeles, þe ije partye wole serue herto more deuoutly þan þe first partye.
