And, if it lijke þee to preise god with rehercels of not so cleer doctryne vpon goddis dignitees, worþinessis and goodnessis, but bi wordis of hiȝe swetnes and greet enhaunc∣ing goddis worþynes and goodnes, withoute such at þe clerist doctryne, þou nedist noon bettir, fairer or swetter foorme fynde þan þou maist haue in þe first party and in þe iije party of þe book y-callid 'dyuyne office for alle þe tymes of þe ȝeere'; And þat wheþir þou wolte preise god in him silf, or in hise seintis, or in hise oþire benefetis. And þus moche as for assignyng to þe foormes of preising.

Now as for foormes of preiyng, I seie þus: þou maist There are three forms of pray∣ing: (1) The Pater noster. preie in þre maners of foormes: ffor whi þou maist, if þou wolte, preie in þe foorme which crist tauȝt, mathew, þe vj
chapitre, vv. 9-13. and in luk, xj chapitre, vv. 2-4. wiþoute | eny setting þerto of eny oþire wordis, which foorme is callid in latyn 'Pater noster'; or ellis þou maist preie in þe same foorme, (2) The Pater noster with other words and processes joined thereto. with setting to of oþire wordis and oþire processis; or ellis, in þe iij maner, þou maist preie in foormes diuisid bi holy mennys laboure in oþire wordis þan is þe Pater noster, þouȝ (3) Other forms devised by holy men. þei ben not contrarye to þe sentence of þe pater noster, And þei asken þe same þingis which asken þe parties of þe pater noster, þouȝ in oþire maner wordis.

If þou wolte preie in þe first of þese iij maners, þan I wole Where the ex∣position of the Pater noster is set forth. þat þou take þin vndirstonding of þe pater noster þoruȝ eche of þe peticiouns, which vndirstonding is sette forþ in þe vij trety of þe first party of '[þ]e MS. re. reule of cristen religioun', and þat þou vse þe doctryne and þe sleiȝtis which ben tauȝte þerynne of rehercyng of eche peticioun, which sleiȝtis ben sumwhat exaumplid MS. exaumplis, altered to exaumplid. and practisid in þe fridaie office at euensong in þe exposicioun of þe pater noster. And if þat þou do so, y weene þilk foorme of preier schal seeme to þee, and schal verrily be to þee, ful preciose and ful swete and profitable; And perauenture it schal be to þee so ryche, so swete and so preciose þat þou schalt desire aftir noon oþire, for, certis, of alle þe exposiciouns and vndirstondingis which euer I siȝe vpon þe 'pater noster', þilk exposicioun and vndirstonding þere I-sett beriþ þe price.

If þou wolt preie in þe ije maner now seid, þan I wole þat Where exam∣ples of the second manner of praying will be found. þou go into 'þe book of dyuyne office', in þe first euensong of friday, ffor þere þou schalt fynde þe pater noster wel mengid wiþ oþire wordis, and wiþ doubling and trebling of peticioun. And þerwiþ al þou schalt preise god, and þou This form is also a form of praising. schalt þerbi be disposid to soone leerne and to kepe weel in delyuere and curraunt remembraunce and mynde þe seid fruytful exposicioun and vndirstonding of þe pater noster. And þerfore þe long and oft vse of þilk foorme þer y-sett in þe first euensong of friday is in manye weies | ful profitable as wel as for preiyng. Also for þis secunde maner of preiyng, þou maist go into þe book y-callid my 'manuel' See Notes. or ellis
myn 'encheridion', wherynne it is deuisid þe rialist foorme of preiyng with pater noster þat euer, as I trowe, was devisid—which 'encheridion' as to þe office of preiyng mai not at his euen worþ be apprisid neiþir preisid, neiþir be bouȝt wiþ siluer or golde or wiþ preciose stoonys.

If þou wolt preie in þe iije seid maner, þan þou maist go Where exam∣ples of the third manner of pray∣ing may be found. into al þe ije party of 'þe book of dyuine office', where is rubrisch sett afore in þis maner, 'Preiers for euensong', or in þis wise, 'Preiers for matyns'. And, as I weene, for þe now seid iije maner of preier, þou nedist neuer seche eny bettir, swettir, fairer or or, overwritten. deuouter þan þou schalt þere fynde, And þerwiþ al so long and so large and so copiose as þou schalt þere fynde. MS. fynnde, the second n being crossed through and underdotted. I seie not After not, MS. has nouȝ, crossed through. þat nouȝwhere ben oþire preiers so good, so swete, and so deuoute, seruing for þe iije maner of preiyng, ffor I wote weel þere mowe be maad manye twenty siþis better in alle degrees; but I seie þat, as for þe iije maner of preiyng, þou nedist neuer to seche eny bettir.

but, certis, sone, if þou wolte loke aftir forto haue bi þese The course to be followed in outward prais∣ing and prayer. Each clause of the form of praise or prayer must be well considered. It is the time spent, not the number of words said, that matters. seid maners of preising and of preiyng þe hiȝer auaile and effect for which preising and preier seruen and ben to be vsid, þou muste cast forto tarye vpon ech notable clausul in þe preisingis and in þe preiers a notable while, And not forto renne ouer swiftli as men doon in seiyng her sawtir or her matyns and euensong and oþire processis in þe chirche; And þat þou point to þee þi labour of preising and of preiyng forto dure aftir þe quantite of tyme, as forto endure oon hour or ij houris, þan aftir þe quantite of þi maters, or of writing which þou schalt rede or speke; And þat þou reck not how moche mater | þou ouer rede and speke, but how long tyme oon mater or fewe maters þou rollist vp and down in þin vndirstonding and in þin wil or affect, and how wel þou wrastlist wiþ hem in þin vndirstonding and in þin effect. ffor, soþeli, MS. fforsoþeli. it were bettir seie oonys wel þe preier clepid in latyn pater noster, wiþ suche a labour as is now spokun off þoruȝ a certeyn tyme, þan forto seie an hundrid rabbischly and rennyngli þoruȝ þe same tyme. fforwhi if þe availis
and þe effectis wherfore preising and preier weren ordeined schulde raþir and more plenteuously be getun bi a fewe wordis seid atretly MS. a tretly. and vndirstondingli, with þe answering þerto affeccioun, þan bi an hundrid wordis seid recchelesly and aloone noisingli, it must nedis of ech man be more chosen to seie in þe seid maner a fewe wordis in oon tyme þan in þe oþire maner how euer manye wordis in þe same or lijk tyme; but if a man be so lewid and rude þat he trowiþ For it is not the mere sound of the words that pleases God. god to be charmed, constreyned and drawen bi vertu of þe wordis, which vertu þe wordis schulde haue bi her sown, as it wolde seeme þe moost party of alle þe peple ffeeliþ. and Witchcraft is condemned for attributing more virtue to mere words than Reason allows. soþeli þis is not fer from wicchecraft. fforwhi what grounde haue we to condempne wicchecraft saue þis: þat þilk craft puttiþ vertu in wordis and countenauncis and dedis more þan bi resoun can þerynne be founde? Neuerþeles, preising Sometimes, however, long prayers, and even unintelli∣gible prayers, are to be ap∣proved. and preiyng maad bi manye wordis swiftly spokun and in long tyme during, ȝhe, and þouȝ in a langage not vndirstonde, I not condempne, but in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', in þe [ ] Space left in MS. for reference. treticis, I it approue, and þe fruyt and þe availe þerof I þere opene and schewe, which for rude men is good and allowable and profitable, ȝhe, and for þe more party of men lyuing.

Al∣so into þe seid hiȝer auaile þou muste holde þin vndir∣stonding The understand∣ing and the will must be con∣centrated on the praise or the prayer. and þin affect or wil coplid stifly to þe maters which þou redist, and þou schalt sett þese boþe now seid powers, vndirstonding and wil, into her feruent wirching aboute þe maters which þou redist; and so bi þis stif attending and occupiyng hem aboute þe maters of preising and of preiyng, þou schalt lete hem not wauer aboute oþire þingis and maters vnpertinent to þe maters of þi preising and preiyng. And but if þou kepe þese ij now seid gouernauncis, whilis þou redist þe seid preisingis and þe seid preiers, ellis þou schalt haue but litil of þe availe which þe reding of hem is ordeyned to bring forþ, And þou schalt spende tyme febily, and þou schalt spille and mys vse what myȝt be ful fruytfully vsid into a ful greet availe.

And forto þe bettir kepe þese ij now seid gouernauncis, it
is spedeful and profitable to þee, whanne þou wolte preise or A private place and a quiet time should be chosen for private praise and prayer. preie, þat þou chese to þee, if þou mowe, a secrete MS. asecrete. and priuey place, partles of noise and trouble of þe peple; And also þat þou chese to þee tyme of þe nyȝt, namelich aftir þi first sleepe, or eerliche in þe morowe, fer bifore þat þe peple risiþ. Soþeli, in such priuey place and in suche nyȝt tyme, þou schalt wynne more of þe affectis and availis wherto preising and preiyng weren ordeyned, and þat bi moche quantite, þan þou schalt wynne in placis of cumpanye, and þan þou schalt wynne in þe daie tyme, þouȝ þou be in placis priuyest. And This is the course to be followed in out∣ward praising and prayer. þus moche, my sone, is ynouȝ to þee for assignyng to þee special foormes of preising and of preier to be maad bi voice, or bi speche and noise of mouþe, to god, with þe vndirstonding þerof and þe affeccioun þerwith rennyng.

DIV3.HEAD: [xxije chapitre] See above, p. 171, note 2, and p. 191, note 1.
DIV3.P:
[F]Erþirmore, sone, if þou wolte vse preising and preier The course to be followed in in∣ward praising and prayer. | in meditacioun and biþeuking, þat is to seie, in inwarde speche in þin vndirstonding to god, without After without, MS. has warde, crossed through and underdotted. outwarde speche to be maad, namelich in continewaunce of eny long foorme, þou muste haue anoþir teching þan þis now ȝouun to þee After þee, MS. has now, crossed through. teching is. fforwhi þou muste kunne þe treuþis of þe vij The Seven Mat∣ters must be perfectly known from memory. seid maters whereupon rennyþ 'þe book of cristen religioun'; and þou muste kunne remembre þee vpon hem parfiȝtli and currauntli, and þat wiþoute eny biholding vpon a book to be maad þerfore, ellis wiþ a biholding vpon a schort pointing of hem in a papir leef, sumwhat aftir þe maner in which þei ben pointid in þe first party of þis present book. And whanne þou hast After hast, MS. has se, crossed through. þese conclusiouns and trouþis of þese vij seid A private place and a quiet time (preferably the middle of the night) must be chosen. maters in þe maner now seid, þanne þou muste chese to þee priuey place and priuey tyme, as is tauȝt bifore in þe next chapitre, and specialy þe nyȝt tyme, and moost special þe tyme aftir þi first sleep, whanne þi vndirstonding and þi wil or affeccioun and þyne oþire louȝer wittis and her appetitis ben more nakid þan in oþire tymes from alle maner of worldli þingis. þan next aftir þis, þou muste applye þin
vndirstonding and þyn wil into her werkis strongli vpon þe The understand∣ing and the will must be closely concentrated upon the matter in hand. maters which þou schalt biþenke, and þat þou be not in eny of hem to sluggy, vnquyke and heuy, as [is] MS. it. tauȝt bifore in þe next chapitre.

Next aftir þis þou must dispose þee bi suche a speche There must be a prayer of pre∣paration. inwarde to be doon to god, which oon I sett in 'þe book of diuine office' to be seid next bifore euensong, and next bifore matyns. whanne al þis is bifore araied and doon, þan in oon The First Mat∣ter should then be pondered. daie or in oon tyme of þi bisynes or of þi contemplacioun or of þi meditacioun to be doon, þou maist take þe first of þe vij seid maters, þat is to seie, what god is in him silf | and in hise dignitees and nobiltees, and how he is in hise persoonys, and biþenke þou now vpon oon trouþe þerof, now vpon anoþir, as þei ben vttrid in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe first trety, and in þe ije party of 'cristen religioun', þe first trety, with manye oþire ful swete pointis of trouþe which wolen falle into þi mynde with hem. but loke þat þou tarye in þe þouȝt of ech, and holde þou vndir to þis þouȝt þi wil, þat þe affeccioun according to þe þouȝt be gendrid in þe wil. And þat þe wil so gendre, applye þou þe wil to werk, and suffre þou not him to be ydil. And aftir þat þou haste taried in þis seid wise long Then the Fifth Matter. tyme vpon trouþis of þe first seid mater, wiþ gendring of affecciouns þerto answering in þe wil, þanne þou maist turne þee into þe þenking vpon þe v mater of þo seid vij, which ve mater is oure natural wrecchidnes; in which while þou schalt considre how vnworþi, how foule, how brotyl, vnsure a wrecche þou art, how perilose to trust to, how redy to be vnkinde and to be fals, wiþ settyng and appliyng þerto þi wil to gendre anentis þi silf indignacioun, loþynes, drede, haterede, and suche oþire to þe seide þouȝtis according affec∣ciouns. and þanne þou maist seie to god þus: 'O lord, Then should follow confession and repentance for our wicked∣ness, and so the Sixth Matter is considered. siþen þou art such as I haue now considerid and biþouȝt, and I am suche oon as I haue also now considerid and biþouȝt, how myȝt I be so boolde, so vnkinde, so cursid, so wood, forto offende þee, forto tarye þee into wraþþe, forto vnworschip þee, forto vnobeie to þee? And ȝitt not wiþ∣standing
al þis, certis, I haue synned and trespacid aȝens þee þus'. And þanne make þi confessioun and schrift to god in inward speche, wiþ gendring of affecciouns in wil þerto answering: as schame and sorewe for þi synne and drede toward god and desire forto not falle aȝen into synne. þis schrift þou maist make in þi mynde aftir þe foorme which is writen | in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe vj trety, and in 'þe book of dyuine office', in þe matyns of ffridaie seruice; or ellis þou maist make þis schrift aftir þe maner þat þou canst make remembraunce of þi synnis, fro þe tyme þou were a litil childe into þe same daie in which þou art at þis seid werke of meditacioun. Whanne al þis is do, and Then the Pater noster should be repeated, and its petitions well considered. eche kynde of þese iij labouris ben doon þoruȝ a notable tyme, þanne biseche þou god in þin inward speche þat þou schalt offende him no more MS. nomore., and þat þou schalt haue alle þe vertues contrarye to þi synnys and to alle synnys. And forto do so as now is seid, falle þou into þi preier y-callid in latyn Pater noster, and speke þou it to god in þe vndirstonding and in þe declaring which is maad þerupon in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe vij trety, and with sleiȝtis þere tauȝt, and as sumwhat it is exaumplid and practisid in þe friday seruice at euensong, in þe ije party of þe book clepid 'dyuine office'. And whanne þou hast contynued and oft rehercid and bi a notable tyme laborid in þis preier clepid in latyn pater noster, and þat boþe wiþ þi resoun to [se] MS. so. cleerly þe trouþis, and wiþ þi wil to gendre affecciouns, namely þe affecciouns of desire, þou muste make þerynne an eende as for þilk iorney in þe nyȝt.

or in þe morewtide, or in þe euentide in þe next nyȝt, or Another time, after the neces∣sary prepara∣tion, the Second Matter might be considered. in þe next morewtide daie or euentyde, þou maist chaunge þi course of meditacioun in þis wise: Aftir þi bifore seid disposingis and araiyngis, which þou schalt kepe at eche tyme þat þou bigynnist þi meditacioun, as þou bigannyst þi meditacioun at þe first of þe vij seid maters, so now þou schalt bigynne at þe ije of þo vij seid maters, þat is to seie, at þe benefetis of god which he dooþ toward alle men, and
þat as þei ben noumbrid, toolde and expowned in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe ije trety, and in þe ije party of 'cristen religioun', þe | ije, iije, iiije, ve and vje treticis, and as god wole sende and caste to into þi mynde whilis þou schalt be in þi laboure of biþenking. and, for as moche as As this Second Matter is long, it might be di∣vided so as to serve for three or four times of meditation. Then the Fifth Matter should be considered. þis ije mater of goddis benefetis is a ful long mater, þerfore þou maist departe it into iij or iiij or mo porciouns for iij or iiij day iourneys to be maad in meditacioun; but fro con∣sideracioun and þe biþenking of eche of þo porciouns assigned for oon daye or nyȝt, þou schalt falle into þe consideracioun of þe ve mater, sumwhat and in þe maner as þou feeldist from consideracioun of þe first mater into it. And þan from Then the Sixth Matter. þens þou schalt falle into consideracioun and meditacioun of þe vj mater, as þou didist bifore in þe first iorney of þi meditacioun, and from þens into þe preier clepid pater Then the Pater noster. noster, as þou didist in þe first now tauȝt iourney.

And so þou schalt chaunge at ech day, if þou wolt, þe Hence there is a special subject for meditation each day, though part of the ground is each day the same. hede of þi meditacioun, which schal be þe grettist portacioun of þi meditacioun. and al þe remenaunt of þi meditacioun schal be lijk and þe same in eche daie as for þe kyndes of maters wherupon þou schalt labour; þouȝ, wheþer þou wolte or not wolte, þou schalt make manye particuler and special chaungis in ech day dyuers from oþire, withynne þe boondis of oon and þe same general mater, and þat for quykenes which þi resoun and þi wil schulen gete to hem in tyme of þin in hem laboring.

Whanne þou hast bi diuers day iourneys or nyȝt iourneis Another day one may con∣sider God's special benefits to oneself. And then pro∣ceed as before. spende oute alle þe seid porciouns of goddis benefetis, þan þou maist in an oþir daye or nyȝt make þe heed or þe cours or substaunce of þi meditacioun vpon þe singuler benefetis of god which he haþ ȝouun to þee and to noon oþer; And þat as þou maist bryng hem to mynde which þei were, fro þe tyme whanne þou were bigete into þe hour in which þou laborist, and how greet þei were, and so | forþ of oþire circumstauncis. And whanne þe remembraunce of alle hem is maad, or of summe of hem is maad, þanne biþenke how wrecchidly and vnkyndly þou euer barest þee aȝens god, so greet a benefetoure to þee. And so aftir þi wrecchidnes sumwhat biþouȝt in a notable tyme, falle þou into schrift of
þi synnys, and aftirward into preier, as þou didist in þe first iourneye bifore tauȝt.

In anoþir iourney þou maist bigynne at goddis punysch∣ingis Another day the special subject may be God's punishments, i. e. the Third Matter. in helle, as þei ben tretid in þe ije partye of 'cristen religioun', þe vj trety, and sumwhat in þe first party, þe ije trety; and aftirward falle into þe silfe i. e. the Fifth Matter. mater, and from þens into þe vj mater, and eende þou in preier.

In an oþire tyme þou maist bigynne þi meditacioun in þe Or the special subject may be the Fourth Mat∣ter, i. e. God's law. iiije mater, which is þe lawe of god, as it is tretid in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe iije trety, and in þe ije party, þe vije trety; And considre how resonable it is, how cleer, how profitable, how fillable, how gentil, how rewardable. and from þens falle into consideracioun of þe ve mater, and so into þe vj mater, and last into preier.

Neuerþeles, sone, I wote wel þat þou schalt stertmele and It will probably be impossible to keep strictly to each Matter, but one should do so as far as one can. bi litil whilis menge þese maters to gider, wille þou, nylle þou, And þou schalt menge schort preiers soone aftir þat þou hast bigunne þi preisingis, and so aftir whilis þou schryvist þee, where aȝens I wole not be. but ȝitt, not wiþstonding þis mengyng which schal so bifalle for habundaunce of con∣sideraciouns and of affecciouns, I wole þat þou make þi cours to kepe þi seid foorme fro mater into mater, as it mai be kept with þe seid schort among mengyngis of preiers.

In anoþir tyme þou maist bigynne þi cours of meditacioun Another time the special sub∣ject may be the wretchednesses of the world and one's own in∣dividual wretch∣ednesses, i. e. the Fifth Matter. vpon þe wrecchidnessis of þis worlde, and þat as þei ben tretid in þe first party of 'cristen religioun', þe vj trety, or ellis as as, overwritten. þou maist gadere into þi mynde bi þin experience takun þerupon, or bi reding in stories | and cronicles gaderid of þee and to þee for þis purpos; and from þens falle into consideracioun of þin owne experte and knowun to þee wrecchidnessis, and from þens into þi schrift of synnys, and so into preier.

Þe remedies aȝens oure wrecchidnessis and oure wickid∣nessis The remedies against our wretchednesses and wicked∣nesses may be considered along with God's benefits, or along with His law. mowe be sette wiþ meditacioun of goddis benefetis, And summe with his lawe.

Þus moche is ynouȝ to þee, my sone, for vse of meditacioun, with alle þe oþire consideraciouns which god wole ȝeue to
þee whilis þou laborist þerynne—which consideraciouns þou Another day the considerations arising from these medita∣tions should be rehearsed. schalt not recchelesly forȝete, but poynt hem in a papir, and þo same reherce in anoþir daie iourney, with þe standerdis of þe seid 'book of cristen religioun', til god wole ȝeue to þee newe wiþ þe same standerdis. And þersore, þouȝ þou neuer desire to be more leernyd how þou schalt be a medita∣tive man or a contemplative man, in reule and in fixe foorme, in treuþe and in no falshede receyuing for treuþe, þan is now in þis present chapitre to þee assignyd, þou darist neuer recke, for þis present assygning and poynting maad to þee is for euer sufficient.

DIV3.HEAD: [xxiije chapitre] See above, p. 171, note 2, and p. 191, note 1.
DIV3.P:
[A]Nd ferþirmore, sone, þouȝ þis labour be straunge to One must not be discouraged if the labour of silent medita∣tion is hard at first, for the result is worth the pains taken. þee in þe bigynnyng, spaare þou not, breke not of, continue þou it, and it schal be liȝtir and liȝtir aftir þou hast had þerynne continuaunce. MS. contineuaunce, the first e under∣dotted. And þouȝ þou laboure and swete þerynne, I mai atteeme þee ful wel withoute birewing þat þou so doist, ffor whi I wote weel þe fruyte þerof is greet, and also þou schalt haue more ioie, delite and solace þerynne aftir þe bigynnyng þan schal be þi peyne of laboure forto entre, falle and to breke into it. fferþirmore, sone, witte Though silent praising and prayer is much more difficult than outward praising and prayer, its fruit is greater. þou wel þat no man mai be an excellent laborer in þis now tauȝt craft of meditacioun or contemplacioun, but if his heed be strong and hool, After hool, MS. has o crossed through. not sicke or litil sick, and but his mynde be stable to procede ordinatli from oon poynt of trouþe | into anoþir, and þat he mai holde his mynde vpon trouþe as long as nede is, til deepe affeccioun be gendrid þerupon in þe wil. and if a man be not in þis now seid wise temperid and disposid, it is good to him þat he ȝeue him to labour bi outward worde and speche to god, in reding vpon a book þe foormes of preisingis and of preiers which ben tauȝt in þe chapitre next bifore going, wiþ þe disposiciouns and gouer∣nauncis þere tauȝt—which gouernauncis he schulde kepe whilis he is reding, or vocaly withoute book speking. but certis, sone, loke how moche þe sunne whanne he apperiþ
moost cleer passiþ in briȝtnes, in hete, in counforte, and in profite þe moone; and likeli so moche or more þe labour of meditacioun tauȝt in þe next bifore going chapitre, treuli doon and daily continued, passiþ þe oþer vocal labour of preising and preiyng tauȝt in þe xxj See above, p. 173, note 5. bifore going chapitre; and þat in cleernes of siȝt in þe vndirstonding, in hete of affecciouns in þe wil gendring, in counforte and strengþe and stabilnes to do and to suffre for god in his lawe keping, and þerfore in mede at þe eende of þis lijf receiuyng. And, perauenture, weel toward like passage þe vocal foormes of preising and of preiyng tauȝt bifore in þe xxj See above, p. 173, note 5. chapitre, passen summe vocal foormes of preising and of preiyng, þouȝ þe oþire foormes be takun forþe into After into, the MS. has so, under∣dotted and crossed through. solempne vse and haunte of þe chirche. If þou wolte haue more to be seid vpon þis craft of meditacioun, go þou into þe vije trety of þe first party of 'cristen religioun', not wiþstonding See Notes. þat þou nedist not moche, aftir þis present doctryne here I-leernyd, as þerfore come þere. See Notes.

wel is him þat is to þis craft and laboure of meditacioun The advantages of meditation in strengthening a man to fight against sin. ordeynid and clepid, namelich if he be leerned sufficientli in eche poynt what is trewe and what [is] MS. it. not trewe, and if he make his meditacioun reulily, ordinatli, | bi rewe and in cours, as þe poyntis of maters in her processe and kinde liggen, þat he make not hise meditaciouns bi fals heedis and feynyd pointis in stede of trouþis, and lest he make his meditacioun startlyng, heedling, tumbling or reeling, and þerbi bryng not forþ þe ful availe of good affecciouns, which myȝt ellis be foorþ brouȝte, if þe meditacioun were wel reulid; which affecciouns wolen arme and strengþe and chere a man forto stonde as a giaunt aȝens temptaciouns, to not ouer deintyli apprise eny þing a þis side god, forto not ouer moche cherisch him silf and pampre his fleisch; withoute which affecciouns so to be gendrid bi such meditaciouns, ful hard schal be a mannys MS. amannys. batail aȝens synne to stonde, and
into hård werkis of vertu to be into þe eende douȝti and strong.

And þerfore wo is me þat þe goodnes of þis labour in It is much to be regretted that prayer and praising are so praising are so little practised. meditacioun is not knowun, and þat men ben so fer from þe assaie and þe vse of it; and more wo is to me þat þei ben vnlosabli lettid boþe from þe laboure of meditacioun tauȝt in þe next bifore going chapitre, and from þe laboure of vocal preising and preiyng bi þe foormes and in þe maners tauȝt in þe xxj See above, p. 173, note 5. chapitre bifore going. ffor neiþir in priuate religiouns neiþir oute of priuate religiouns, neiþir of preestis neiþir of layfe, is eny of þese two now seid laboris vsid and hauntid so mych as I wolde it were. not þat I wolde eche Proper time should be allow∣ed for medita∣tion, and the rest of the day given to labour. man and womman, or eny man and womman, to be occupied þoruȝ alle tymes of eche daie in such preising, preiyng or meditacioun, but if he were such a crepul and so feble in powers þat he couþe not or myȝt not do profitabli eny oþir þing. but my meenying is þat eche man and womman schulde in þe morewtide, or in þe nyȝt tyme bifore þe morew∣tide, take a sawli of þese seid occupaciouns, and in þe euen∣tide eftsoones; and in al þe remenaunt of þe daie | I wolde þat þei ȝaue hem to oþire vertuose occupaciouns: as summe to studie, summe to preching, summe to writing, summe to craft, summe to marchaundising for þe comoun profite, and so forþ of alle oþire leeful occupaciouns aftir þat men ben þerto bi goddis grace able, callid and assigned.

And, certis, þan bi vertu and strengþe of þese now seid Due time given to prayer and praise would enable the day's work to be the better perform∣ed, and sin to be the more easily resisted. bisynessis to be doon, first in þe morewtide, and aftir in þe euentide, þe doers and þe vsers of hem schulden be strengþid ful wel to aȝenstonde temptaciouns and synnys, with þe which þei schulden be assailid whilis þei schulen turne hem into þe seid worldli occupaciouns in þe same daie; and þei schulen be quykenid and strengþid to þe more douȝtili and perseuerauntli worche, do and suffre þoruȝ al þe daie in þe same worldli occupaciouns for god, and for his cause and his sake and his charite.
And here ynne I make an ende to þis present ij party The end of the Second Part. longyng to þe lawe of god.
